column8:
The game had a lot of potential when it first came out, and although it was quite buggy, you could see the direction it was going. Unfortunately, the game was abandoned, and all that's left is a buggy, shallow mess.

It is quite a shame as this was one of the DF-like games that all came out around the same time (Gnomoria is another one that comes to mind, which although also abandoned, is a lot more feature-complete than this). This isn't as bad as Spacebase DF-9 in terms of abandonment, but pretty close.

If you're interested in this game, rather look at Dwarf Fortress, Rimworld, Songs of Syx or Oxygen Not Included (depending on what part interested you the most), and you'll be much happier.

column8:
I loved this game, I still think of it sometimes fondly and wonder what could of been.

A very old early access game, abandoned, unfinished, but there was still a lot there for replay-ability for its time.

I kind of feel obligated to leave a kind review because I think the hate is a bit unwarranted. I think Banished was similarly sort of abandoned without much features besides a bare-bones city builder framework that today would be looked at as hollow and soulless, yet that game was lauded because it was seen as more casual for its time.

While I don't think the price is warranted anymore, if it were $1-3 or maybe $5 max then it would still represent a cheap game to have fun for a few hours or more if you get into it.

column8: Felt like posting a positive review just to combat the insanity of some of these negative reviews. This is a prime example of the brutal unfair nature of the Internet, which apparently hasn't got any better since the 10+ years this was released. There are literally reviews on this game spouting absolute trash like "i'm sure the original dev has died" and "they cut and ran with the money"... guys, do a 5 minute bit of research like some of us decent folk have and you'll see that one of the devs actually is still in the discussions as of this year actually explaining in detail what has happened. I've seen much more unpolished games asking for more money being given free passes on this platform yet this seems to be one of the dumping grounds for that sweet sweet negativity adrenaline rush. The people who are here now spewing trash are the same ones that drove the devs away in the first place. A good amount of you need to get off your high horse and grow up.

column8:
I love this game.  The mechanics are detailed and thought out.  There are lots of different ways to do things from food production to weapon/armor creation to building.  I would recommend giving it a try if you like city builders and citizen indirect management.

Its sad to me that most of the negative reviews are about it being abandoned and/or unfinished.  Those have no relevance on the game-play or mechanics that make it good or bad.  Unfortunately it didn't do well enough for the developer to keep working on it which is sad because it could be a great game once finished and polished.  Sure there are bugs and issues, some pretty big, but looking past that there are a lot of fun things about the game that were there from the beginning:

[list]
	[*]You control the townies by telling them what to build.  They build them in a semi random order determined by the game.  You can control the order of different categories of actions.  You can also group townies separately and assign them sub actions that they focus on, and ignore the rest.  You can totally mess up the production line and kill half of your town because they starve to death haha.  This also applies to soldiers which have various options on how to patrol or guard the barracks they are assigned to.
	[*]Various food production options with pros and cons.  Some affect happiness, some take a lot of space, some have a lot of steps to make, others are plain and quick.  I recently spent many hours going through the food mechanics and trying various options out to figure out which ones scale better or not.  It was fun to dive in and use a spreadsheet to track everything.
	[*]Numerous options for creating armor/weapons.  They do scale as you get more items from going further down in the dungeon.  Which makes exploring the dungeon essential to create better gear.  There are also vanity options which make the townies happier, which attract more townies.
	[*]There are heroes you can attract by meeting certain conditions in the game.  Some of them really make you think outside the box and set up something in a way you normally wouldn't do.  They explore the dungeon for you so you can go back and mine ores and stone.
	[*]The happiness mechanic is unique, haven't seen anything like it.  You have to plan out your build design to keep them happy so as they are working they stay happy.  Otherwise you run them into the ground and don't go anywhere.  There are decorations you have to place down fairly close together so the townies "see" them and gain happiness.
	[*]The monsters can come from the dungeon or from sieges (which you can turn on or off).  But it allows you to plan out your city with walls and funnel the enemies through a barracks to kill them.  There are also traps you can use, possibly in a maze design, to kill the monsters.  There are different difficulties of the sieges to try out.
	[*]There are several different kinds of maps with different resources available to you at the beginning.  Some are harder to start with than others so it makes it more challenging and fun to try different maps.  Every map is random so the replay is great.  
	[*]Lots of block types for building.  Having a roof overhead does make them happier.  Various themed or environmental building can be created.  Many of the initial pictures of the game show lots of these options.  You have to build temp blocks so the townies can get to all the locations to build more blocks.  Its possible to trap townies that will then starve to death if you don't rescue them.
[/list]

For me I am not that creative.  So I didn't explore all the various ways to create awesome looking buildings.  I dove into the mechanics to figure out how to grow the town faster and which food options were better and which weapons/armor to use at the beginning.  
Some of the map variants gave the better food options right at the beginning, others were generated with the enemies right in the way of the resources and so it made it challenging right from the start.

There is definitely replay-ability built into the game.  I still do pick it up from time to time to start a new map and see where it goes.

column8:
Easily one of the best abandoned "Mostly Negative" games still available to buy on Steam when it comes to sandbox city builder/colony simulators.

On the surface it might look like a typical drawn/pixel art city builder where you manage and instruct villagers to harvest resources, plant crops, raise animals, trade with wandering merchants, build structures, craft tools and weapons while trying not to starve to death or get wiped out by monsters that live on the surface and in the dungeon levels below.

The part that really captured my attention and held my interest was the mechanic that allows the player to construct a residence with certain attributes used to attract different types of wandering heroes who will stay in your town and defend it from threats (several different types with their own abilities and stats).  The longer you keep them happy the better chances you have of keeping them around, gearing them up and watching them faceroll your enemies.  The more heroes you attract, the better their chances of not getting killed off.  To spice things up a bit, these heroes are never under your direct control.

Overall, the farther these heroes and your guards clear the dungeons, the better the loot and resources you have access to but also the more dangerous the enemies and raids can become.  So it can be a delicate balance in terms of when to expand and when to "wall off" new areas.

It can be both a fun and frustrating experience trying to figure out how to best attract and keep the heroes as well as lay down the infrastructure to maximize their effectiveness.  In the end, it's a fairly satisfying experience.

[spoiler]Honestly, if someone remastered this game and "finished" it, it'd be an instant hit on Steam even by 2024 colony sim standards.  After all, despite it being more than 10 years ago, there still aren't any games I know of that have repeated this specific formula (i.e. a multi-level map/game world where the player is constructing a city or colony to attract autonomous AI NPCs that the player needs but can't directly control).[/spoiler]

column8:
This game has a lot of potential; I love the idea of the game. Create a town that attracts adventures; mine into the Earth to locate precious metals and uncover monsters and demons. The adventures that come to your town explore the depths of your mines. Dig to deep to fast and the harder the creatures get and they start to ascend upwards and if your adventures aren't up high enough the horde can over run your town and kill everyone.

You can definitely cheese the mechanics to give max villagers and gold farming; But to spend the time to create something that is functional and looks good too; that's the true challenge. Build ways to prevent the overrun of your town. Construct tunnels that aid the adventures and prevent the from being flanked. With a lot of planning you can make a pretty solid town and amazing ecosystem. 

Lastly you get what you put into it. It can be a very fun and enjoyable game.  I really wish the developers would continue working on this. This could be amazing with a few more tweaks. 

Their is a high learning curve at the start but if you stick with it you'll be rewarded.
I find it similar to Rimworld but with less control making it a bit more challenging.

column8:
It has so much potential, and realized none of it. It was actually a lot of fun with mods. Unfortunately, the dev team had no idea how to actually realize any of their ideas, they hard coded a lot of limitations into the game, and then tried desperately to sell the game to a third party. When the sale fell through, the devs dropped it like a hot potato and the modders followed shortly afterwards. There isn't a game on the market that scratches the itch this game did, but this one isn't worth your money even on a sale. 

Historical fact: This game is one of the reasons the 'Early access' concept was introduced to Steam, because everyone was so disappointed when they abandoned it that it actually made waves. That's actually kind of impressive, in a "Well, I wasted money" kind of way.
column9:
It has so much potential, and realized none of it. It was actually a lot of fun with mods. Unfortunately, the dev team had no idea how to actually realize any of their ideas, they hard coded a lot of limitations into the game, and then tried desperately to sell the game to a third party. When the sale fell through, the devs dropped it like a hot potato and the modders followed shortly afterwards. There isn't a game on the market that scratches the itch this game did, but this one isn't worth your money even on a sale. 

Historical fact: This game is one of the reasons the 'Early access' concept was introduced to Steam, because everyone was so disappointed when they abandoned it that it actually made waves. That's actually kind of impressive, in a "Well, I wasted money" kind of way.

column8:
This isn't a glowing review, but this game is very decent and worth a try if you're interested in this genre. It's a chill game that allows a player to watch their ants go about their jobs, while you read or do something else.

Not the best in the genre regarding:
1. User-friendliness
2. Depth of building options 
3. Variety of game possibilities, or possible directions a player can decide to go
4. Music
It makes up for it with:
1. Better graphics than many others in the genre
2. Sufficient depth of gameplay and buildings to stay busy quite a while
3. Decent building options and variety of tasks to create a unique and interesting town
4. A difficult challenge for players, even in normal biomes, to find satisfaction in successfully surviving

column8:
This game has been left in a very unfinished state for many MANY years, running on what is an obvious development build with debug commands still exposed to the player without any modification. Last updates to this were in May 2014 and it's maintainer (not the listed devs on the store page) have stated they have ceased development. 
The game itself was one of the first games to pass through Steam's Greenlight platform. It was already raising eyebrows then as it wasn't clear on the greenlight page (or in fact this store page) that the game was still in development and that customers were buying an unfinished product. 

On a more positive note, this was one of the prime examples of the glaring issues with Greenlight which led to the platform's closure and rework into Early Access. 

Do not pick this game up. The people involved do not deserve your money in the slightest.

Slow and steady gets the job done. Make sure you have steady food supply.

column8:
Easy carrot cake

if you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding carrot cake recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients

230ml vegetable oil, plus extra for the tin
100g natural yogurt
4 large eggs
1½ tsp vanilla extract
½ orange, zested
265g self-raising flour
335g light muscovado sugar
2½ tsp ground cinnamon
¼ fresh nutmeg, finely grated
265g carrots (about 3), grated
100g sultanas or raisins
100g walnuts or pecans, roughly chopped (optional)
For the icing
100g slightly salted butter, softened
300g icing sugar
100g soft cheese

Directions

STEP 1
Heat the oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Oil and line the base and sides of two 20cm cake tins with baking parchment. Whisk the oil, yogurt, eggs, vanilla and zest in a jug. Mix the flour, sugar, cinnamon and nutmeg with a good pinch of salt in a bowl. Squeeze any lumps of sugar through your fingers, shaking the bowl a few times to bring the lumps to the surface.

STEP 2
Add the wet ingredients to the dry, along with the carrots, raisins and half the nuts, if using. Mix well to combine, then divide between the tins.

STEP 3
Bake for 25-30 mins or until a skewer inserted into the centre of the cake comes out clean. If any wet mixture clings to the skewer, return to the oven for 5 mins, then check again. Leave to cool in the tins.

STEP 4
To make the icing, beat the butter and sugar together until smooth. Add half the soft cheese and beat again, then add the rest (adding it bit by bit prevents the icing from splitting). Remove the cakes from the tins and sandwich together with half the icing. Top with the remaining icing and scatter with the remaining walnuts. Will keep in the fridge for up to five days. Best eaten at room temperature.

Tip:
top this classic carrot cake with moreish icing and chopped walnuts or pecans. Serve as a sweet treat with a cup of tea any time of the day.

column8:
This was the first  "Steam Greenlight/Kickstarter-esque" game that really burned me. I believed if I bought the game that my money would go to a loving and caring developer that would make the game flourish over the long term, a-la Project Zomboid or Star Sector. (Zomboid did force me to buy it again once it came to steam but whatever). 

Long story short it received like 2 updates after I bought it and was then promptly abandoned. Never any reason. No communication. Don't even know if the developer is still alive. 

It's a sad story of what could have been an incredible game. Despite taking my money for false promises, I hope the developer is doing well. 

ONLY BUY THIS GAME FOR THE PURPOSES OF EXPLORING EARLY STEAM GREENLIGHT. IT IS ABANDONED.

column8:
既に開発が終わっているけど、よく纏まっていて、個人的にはとても好きなゲーム。
お気に入りのプレイスタイルは、潜るほど強くなる敵に対して、村人を強化して何階まで潜れるかチャレンジする事。
行商人から買えるレジェンダリー装備を集めて固めれば、村人でも勇者より強くできるので、強化した村人で挑む地下攻略はっけこう楽しいです。
column9:
Development has already finished, but it's well put together and I personally really like the game.
My favorite playstyle is to strengthen my villagers and challenge myself to see how many floors I can go down against enemies that get stronger the deeper I go.
If you collect and equip villagers with legendary equipment that you can buy from traveling merchants, even villagers can be stronger than the hero, so it's quite fun to tackle underground dungeons with strengthened villagers.

column8: why is deal still for sale on steam???    should be removed from the store

I was not around for the initial launch of this game so keep that in mind.  Towns was the first real attempt to make Dwarf Fortress, or I should say a Dwarf Fortress style game, more accessible to a wide audience.  In SOME ways it did achieve that, for instance adding some greater graphical interest while also somewhat streamlining crafting.  However the game is still rather clunky, in a sort of endearing way for those who like challenges.   However I must say that to be truly successful in Towns one must be at least competent in or excel with Dwarf Fortress already.  This is what leads me to my decision to not recommend buying this game for PLAYING it (This sentence will make sense later, work with me).  If you want the "Grognard" experience in a city/colony builder, just get Dwarf Fortress and watch Krugsmash on YouTube to learn it.  If you want to try the Colony/builder genre for the first time or to play it casually get something like Rimworld (HIGHLY RECOMMENDED) or Banished (Oldie but Goodie).  

NOW here is where that earlier sentence will make sense.  If you want to have a better understanding on Game development, and how some design decisions or implementations of ideas effect the overall quality, reception, and success of a game, DO buy this game. First check out the community tab to see what a player who is familiar with the games "Language" can achieve.  Then play the game and experience for yourself where the game trips itself up and prevents you from achieving the same level of success.  Did the desire for Isometric graphics get in the way of the "Vertical Slicing" the game uses to portray the third dimension?  Does the Game give enough positive and negative feedback to the player? Does the game explain failure sufficiently?  Does not committing to either a simplified set of mechanics or a hyper-detailed set ruin the game enjoyment?  Most importantly, how would YOU change things about this game in particular to better increase the user experience?
column9:
I was not around for the initial launch of this game so keep that in mind.  Towns was the first real attempt to make Dwarf Fortress, or I should say a Dwarf Fortress style game, more accessible to a wide audience.  In SOME ways it did achieve that, for instance adding some greater graphical interest while also somewhat streamlining crafting.  However the game is still rather clunky, in a sort of endearing way for those who like challenges.   However I must say that to be truly successful in Towns one must be at least competent in or excel with Dwarf Fortress already.  This is what leads me to my decision to not recommend buying this game for PLAYING it (This sentence will make sense later, work with me).  If you want the "Grognard" experience in a city/colony builder, just get Dwarf Fortress and watch Krugsmash on YouTube to learn it.  If you want to try the Colony/builder genre for the first time or to play it casually get something like Rimworld (HIGHLY RECOMMENDED) or Banished (Oldie but Goodie).  

NOW here is where that earlier sentence will make sense.  If you want to have a better understanding on Game development, and how some design decisions or implementations of ideas effect the overall quality, reception, and success of a game, DO buy this game. First check out the community tab to see what a player who is familiar with the games "Language" can achieve.  Then play the game and experience for yourself where the game trips itself up and prevents you from achieving the same level of success.  Did the desire for Isometric graphics get in the way of the "Vertical Slicing" the game uses to portray the third dimension?  Does the Game give enough positive and negative feedback to the player? column8: I'm not exactly breaking new ground in saying it's abandonware. In a pre-alpha state that never should have left Early Access if it ever was in it, this game prototype isn't worth any money. There have been games made for free on things like itch.io in more recent times that were better, and considerably better games if actual money is involved if you go looking.

column8:
[h1] Empty Town [/h1]

[b] What I Liked [/b]

Not much that I recall.

[b] What I Did Not Like [/b]

I didn't really get into it.

[b] Why I Stopped Playing [/b]

Couldn't get into it.  Plus read that the developer abandoned the game, so there is that.

[b] Disclaimer [/b]

I have been a gamer for over 30 years.  I tend to play mostly PC games.  I also bounce around between games A LOT.  I may purchase a $60 game and play it for 2 hours or spend $10 on a game and spend 50 hours on it.  Even if I played a game a short time, it does not mean it is bad.  It just means another game caught my attention.  I also complain about flaws in games a lot, even about the littlest of things.  Keep that in mind when reading my reviews.  If I do not have a complaint, then the game must be special!

column8:
Игру захейтили за баги и общую сырость, которые так и не будут исправлены, но несмотря на то, что прошло уже несколько лет с момента, когда я в последний раз в нее играла, я до сих пор вспоминаю эту игрушку, как довольно интересного представителя жанра, где кроме развития вашего города и его жителей, есть еще и приходящие герои, которыми напрямую управлять нельзя и они сами по себе занимаются своими делами.

Концепция непрямого управления (именно как в Majesty) довольно редкая механика, и таких игр раз два и обчелся, поэтому кому нравится такой жанр, я считаю, однозначно стоит попробовать поиграть. Просто надо быть готовым, что не все сразу будет понятно, и придется начинать заново несколько раз, прежде чем сможете справляться не только с балансом, но и тотальными багами (например, помню было что-то вроде бага, когда несмотря на наличие еды жители все-равно массово дохли от голода, но даже с этим багом можно было как-то справиться игровым путем). 

И все же, несмотря на сложность освоения, сырость и баги, игра смогла удержать мой интерес, судя по стиму, аж на 60 часов, которые точно не были скучными, а на такое способна далеко не каждая игра, поэтому рекомендую.
column9:
The game was criticized for its bugs and overall lack of polish that will never be fixed, but even though several years have passed since I last played it, I still remember it as a rather interesting example of the genre, where, in addition to developing your city and its inhabitants, you also have visiting heroes who can't be directly controlled and who go about their business on their own.

The concept of indirect control (like in Majesty) is a rather rare mechanic, and games like it are few and far between, so I think it's definitely worth a try for anyone who enjoys this genre. You just have to be prepared that not everything will be immediately clear, and you'll have to start over several times before you can master not only the balance but also the pervasive bugs (for example, I remember there was a bug where, despite having food, citizens still died en masse of starvation, but even this bug could be somehow overcome through gameplay).

And yet, despite the difficulty of mastering, the rawness and bugs, the game managed to hold my interest, judging by Steam, for as long as 60 hours, which were definitely not boring, and not every game is capable of this, so I recommend it.

Please buy yourself Rimworld or another similiar game and have fun. It is a great genre.

column8: Fun game, Incomplete, Wouldn't buy it unless you understand that. The development team abandoned game, Tried to hire a person to continue work for almost no pay. Sad cause game had potential but could be ALLOT better if the game had been finished. Buyer beware as it can be fun (over 1900 hours in game) but can also be frustrating when things break for no reason, priorities break for some random reason and the people do whatever they want (including doing tasks they are not set to do). Only buy IF you understand that your game at some point will probably break, or get so much lag it is no longer playable. Thumbs up cause fun, wish there was a neutral rating besides just yes and no.

column8:
This is the game that taught me never to trust Early Access and community funded game projects.

It was abandoned shortly after the hype died down and somehow the Devs thought it was the community's fault that they never finished this game. The fact that this half-finished -- no, less than half-finished piece of scamware is still for sale on Steam is mind-blowing to me.

column8:
Every now and then I'll come back to this game when I want a good chill building and management game. I've seen that it's not supported anymore, but I have yet to find a good 3D town building simulator that gives a similar experience. I've seen Rim World and such, but they don't generally feel the same to me.

That said, there is a bit of a learning curve to get everything working smoothly. Right off that bat, there is a need to get the automated crafting set up to keep your townies fed. This is done via the menu on the left of the screen. This works better if you've created job categories with specific tasks to allow your assigned townies to specialize. Once you get your auto crafting set up and your townies organized, it helps to know that there is a minimum level option in the townie menu to keep your townies from going too deep and getting into potentially fatal encounters. Once you've got the hang of those features, keeping townies alive and happier becomes a lot easier.

That said, it does need some modifications to make it more enjoyable. There are .xml files in the game folder that allow the game to be modified to some extent. By default, as you get down to lower levels of the dungeon, you'll see your townies slowing down because they are tired and ultimately starving to death as they wind their way through a labyrinth of passages despite being moments away from starvation. This can be alleviated by hand-editing an XML file to increase the time before they get tired or hungry, and can make the game significantly more enjoyable due to some issues with the townie AI, and for me is completely necessary to enjoy the game more. If you want more variability, the format is along the lines of 2000 + 1d200, where the 1d200 generates a random value between 0-200. So you can somewhat randomize your townies to get some winners and losers.

On an older computer, I have also noticed significant lag as my townie count got closer to 60. Bringing the game to a near crawl.

Overall, I would personally recommend getting the game if it's on sale as a relatively relaxed time killer.

This game actually had a lot going for it when released and is worth a try if you like the type. There wasn't early access back then. Would I like them to come back and do some updates. Sure. 
However, there is plenty of city building, some fighting, and even the chance to find old cities when you're digging that was a really nice feature.
It's not a new game with the latest features but it's worth some time if you need a breather from something else and like this type of game.

column8: I played this game a lot as a child. I really enjoyed it, after watching Sip's playthrough. But I could never get very far without having everyone die, and the mechanics being very broken. I don't recommend buying it at all, because it's just a broken city builder that you could get the same experience out of many other games. So sad it was abandoned with such promise.

This game is one of the very first I bought on steam. I did because it had an appealing idea behind it and I was unaware of the backlash the devs were facing through their buyers. 

Honestly I had a good time and invested quite a lot of said time into it. Eventually the appeal dies down when you have done everything that it has to offer. I would still recommend it if you find the idea of managing a town and indirectly influencing heroes to fight in a dungeon beneath the town itself appealing, then you should try it. It's not expensive.

This game is enjoyable for sure. It's a casual town management game with decent building and fun mechanics. That said, I cannot in good faith recommend that anyone purchase the game, because of its development.

This game is good, but could have been much better if not stuck in what should have been early access followed by abandonment. If you can find it for free, it's worth playing, I find it particularly captivating and enjoyable over other simulation games. Do not give more money to a developer who gave up on it though.

column8:
The problem with the game is not that it was abandoned. It is an early access game that was created before early access was a thing. The developer "didn't ran away", he was pressured to release the game and during his time, the idea of developing a game that is already playable wasn't very applicable. Early Access wasn't a thing, so the game was released as a full game when it wasn't finished yet due to pressure from backers and others.

The game itself is good. People complain about many things, but the game really doesn't has a functional gameplay, building, rpg elements and similar. The problem is, that it gets stale very quickly, due to the missing end game content. You can teach yourself how to play without a tutorial, even though it might be a bit tough at times.

Simply asked, do you enjoy building cities, create small communities with a side of small combat parts and managing a load of people? If yes, then this game is more than enough for you to buy. Otherwise, simply don't.

column8:
Simple. Playable on older, lesser laptops.

Minecraft type building in a management format. Similar to Rimworld, although less complex but, also in contrast, three dimensional allowing for multi-level buildings and sub terranean buildings.

The underlying motive in the game is to dig down and attract heroes(npc's) that will clear the dungeons below level by level, using your people for combat is also available as well.

More of a builder/design game than an rpg.

column8:
While the mechanics can be frustrating at times while you are learning the ins and outs of how the game works, the end result is a tough town simulation. You can gear your heroes or make your own military and explore deep into the depths of the world and try to get better gear and ore. All of this takes place while you try to regulate happiness with work load to get things down and get more people to join your town.

There are a lot of things to learn here and a good chunk of your questions are answered in the forums here on Steam. Others can be answered by watching shortish videos on YouTube. The main thing to learn is the building tree and what you need to make in order to build the things you want. 

I've dropped over 100 hours into Towns and while it may be an "unfinished" game, it's still solid enough of an entry to warrant picking up if you like the "building and maintaining your town" genre. There are a lot of negative reviews. A lot of them have less than an hour. This is not a simple game, while it does come off as such by the look. The reviews that are negative that have over 100 hours... I don't get that at all. 100 some-odd hours in a game for this price (although I love a good sale) is more than a thumbs up.

column8:
Игра шикарна для своего жанра!

ОБЗОР спустя 25 часов игры:

первый минус: житель может застрять в постройке или в подземелье и умереть от голода (при наличии еды на складе)... как исправить: ставим галочку АВТОСЕЙВ начала дня... и переигрываем день освобождая дорогу убирая блок или строя ступеньки из блоков в подземелье!

второй минус: жители любят закончить крышу и остаться на ней умирать от голода... решение: рядом строим леса (вровень с крышей) и он по ним спускается...

Если сделать упор на доспехи и оружие (железо и кости есть), то вся местная флора/фауна не страшна!!! (необходимости в заборах нету)))

хардкор как раз вот в чём: чтобы найти железо и уголь придётся всё перерыть!!! (...мне "повезло" на моей карте нашлось много железа, но угля вообще нет... и как крафтить его, так и не понятно)

ОБЗОР спустя 15 часов игры:

Игра интересна! Без разных сейвов (один перезаписывается), так что переиграть ошибку не получиться (разве что сохранять из папки)... За 15 часов меняешь стратегию развития несколько раз! На 10 час осталось только пятеро поселенцев (но поселение оставлять не хочется) И о Карл!!! Как я забыл про доспехи с оружием (здесь тебе не мирная ферма) ВСЕМ БРОНЮ И "СТВОЛЫ"))) ...понеслась!!! теперь счастье зашкаливает и бегут ко мне мои любимые новые поселенцы))) старые, закалённые в кулачных боях, вообще всех рвут в доспехах с оружием)))

ОБЗОР после 2 часов игры: 

Русификатор для последней версии можно найти в ВК (может позже руководство сделаю), переведено всё, кроме туториала... (может на поздней игре тоже, пока я в начале)
игра весит 25мб))) (пришлось поставить Яву, автоматически винда 10 поставила и работает)
Думаю игра пойдёт на любом ПК (наверно на калькуляторе тоже, ЛОЛ) 
Туториал очень подробный и понятный (придётся переводить, но оно того стоит)
Интерфейс очень удобный и наглядный (иконки ко всем действиям)

РАЗРАБОТЧИК ВЕРНИСЬ!!!

пс: на распродаже взял за 142руб., - это просто даром (уже 2 часа наиграл), кто меня за такие деньги будет 2-а часа развлекать???))) Я думаю наиграть часов 10 ещё и продолжить обзор!!!
column9:
The game is fantastic for its genre!

REVIEW after 25 hours of play:

First drawback: a villager can get stuck in a building or a dungeon and die of hunger (if there's food in the warehouse)... How to fix: check the AUTOSAVE box at the start of the day... and replay the day, clearing a path by removing a block or building steps from blocks into the dungeon!

Second drawback: villagers like to finish building a roof and end up dying of hunger... Solution: build scaffolding nearby (level with the roof) and let them climb down...

If you focus on armor and weapons (there's iron and bones), then all the local flora and fauna won't be a problem!!! (There's no need for fences)))

Hardcore is precisely this: to find iron and coal, you'll have to dig everything!!! (...I was "lucky" enough to find a lot of iron on my map, but no coal at all... and I still don't know how to craft it.)

REVIEW after 15 hours of play:

The game is fun! No multiple saves (one gets overwritten), so there's no way to replay the error (unless you save from a folder)... Over the course of 15 hours, you change your strategy several times! By the 10th hour, there are only five settlers left (but I don't want to abandon the settlement). And oh, Karl!!! How did I forget about armor and weapons (this isn't a peaceful farm). ARMOR AND GUN GUNS FOR EVERYONE))) ...here we go!!! Now my happiness is off the charts and my favorite new settlers are running towards me))) The old ones, seasoned in fistfights, are tearing everyone apart in armor and weapons)))

REVIEW after 2 hours of play:

The Russian translation for the latest version can be found on VK (maybe I'll make a guide later), everything is translated except the tutorial... (maybe in the late game too, while I'm at the beginning)
The game weighs 25 MB))) (I had to install Java, but Windows 10 installed it automatically and it works)
I think the game will run on any PC (probably on a calculator too, lol)
The tutorial is very detailed and clear (it will have to be translated, but it's worth it)
The interface is very user-friendly and intuitive (icons for all actions)

DEVELOPER, COME BACK!!!

P.S.: I got it on sale for 142 rubles - it's just a gift (I've already played it for 2 hours). Who would entertain me for 2 hours for that kind of money???))) I'm thinking of playing for another 10 hours and then continuing the review!!!

column8:
I've been waiting to put this review for years on the off chance the Dev came back and fulfilled all the wishes of the backers. Safe to say at this point he never will. When it was first added to early access there was not much like it on the market, no other game really had you controlling a population, building a city and generally just doing whatever you wanted. In the past few years this genre has been saturated with tons of games, some of which are even worth playing. Towns could have been one of the greatest, instead it will always be a reminder of when Steam Greenlight first stated and people didn't know better.

Other games I would recommend to get for the same kind of feeling would be Rimworld, and Stonehearth (for now)

column8:
It's good; It could have been great. Explores a hybrid genre that was not well developed--especially at the time--and ends up being very fun. I got my $15 worth.

Probably deserves more of a yes and no review, but Steam still doesn't give us the option. Why yes then?

-Everybody knows it is unfinished.
-Everybody knows it was abandoned.
-Everybody knows they said they were going to hire someone to finish it and it didn't work out.

And? I don't care. It's still fun. My only gripe is poor performance when your town (and the dungeon) gets very large, which limits how long a play-through can last. However, more recent hardware and Java versions have alleviated this to an extent.

It would be a wonderful apology to their fans if the owners just gave in and released the game code. Can't imagine they are getting a lot of sales at this point--might as well earn some goodwill.

If you like (or want to like) Dwarf Fortress but feel like relaxing with something more on the "winning is fun" side, Towns still might be worth a purchase.

column8:
ONLY ON SALE. Do not pay more than $5 USD. Not sure if this game even goes on sale anymore lol.

So this game has a sad development history, tl'dr version is after a long development time, it switched hands from dev teams, and everything fell apart. The game had great potential and went from being updated to a semi-limbo to completely dead. (Think Cubeworld levels of dead). Supposedly it was supposed to have been made open source, shame it never happened. Ultimately the devs internal issues cheated themselves over.

So why would I recommend it? Well, I've put 71 hours in over the years. I'm pretty sure the current build of the game was actually sabotaged by one of the last people who held it. There's major bugs with the food system and your village just starves to death if you aren't paying attention (which is easy to focus on anything but food).

The game is still playable, and there's still good fun to be had, even if it leaves you wanting more from a  game that no longer exists. Should the game ever go for $5 I'd say go for it. Otherwise avoid it, go play something like Gnomoria or dwarf fortress. This review likely comes from a deep nostalgia, admittedly. But at the same time, the game does have a good amount of content, and it's good fun just building stuff or waking up to a town full of ghosts and ghouls because literally everyone died for no reason.

column9: Well, after leaving it for a few years to see what else they offered me, I decided to start playing it and it has that difficulty that hooks you, it is not the typical game in which they tell you what you have to put at each moment, and I really appreciate the RPG point that they have given it. I would only add a co-op or online multiplayer mode to see who dominates the map or to see who manages to kill a boss first at level (for example) 200, or help each other to be able to defeat very difficult bosses. But although it does not have those modes, I have to say that an excellent job has been done.

column8:
While no longer under development, Towns is still an enjoyable game if you like to plan out a blocky city and indirectly control the populace, currency, food production, and current construction tasks of a small town occasionally besieged by monsters and placed directly above a dungeon.
In general it is rough and not very polished in both graphics and gameplay, and everything can very quickly become a tedious task without planning.
All I really do in the game is deforest the land, build a base in a mountain, try to make a decently sustainable town that's fully automated, then begin exploring the dungeon. I don't get much farther than that; I get bored of it too fast. But I'll come back to once a year and enjoy it nonetheless.
Seeing that the game has been abandoned and will never receive an update outside of potentially mods, it is only ever worth getting if it is on sale for $5 or less, and only if you really think you'll get a lot of fun time out of it like I have.

column8:
Six years ago, I purchased and played this game. I enjoyed it, but there were severe bugs. Villagers were suicidal in battle with the flee button not working. If you broke a block, the item on top of the block would dissapear without a trace. Then, I decided to stop playing until the game was actually finished. Which never happened.

Fast forward to 2019. Fortnite exists. Guess what? Fortnite has that exact same bug where if you break something, objects on top of it dissappear.
But Fortnite is one of the best games ever made, I mean, society told me so! So Towns is also good.

column8:
Alright, so I probably have more hours into this game than some who want to complain about it.  So maybe I'm biased.  This game was well worth the price, and yes, it is unfinished in various ways.  But I also come from an era in time, not so long ago in the 80s, where game development actually stopped at some point, and publishers had no real means to push updates.  So.  Call it Abandonware if you want.  I call it "meh, most of this stuff works".

Everything in this game takes some trial and error.  Part of the fun is coming up with a self-sufficient settlement that you can leave on full-speed overnight to see if some hole in your defenses and/or AI got your town wiped out.  Didn't send enough guards to patrol your graveyard?  Didn't have enough traps and choke points to slow down a massive army of ogres?  Accidentally broke that one brick holding an entire lake from flooding your mine?  Better luck next time.

There's a lot of little things to annoy pretty much anyone.  Storage zones take some configuring, items disappear if dropped on traps/items other squares with stuff in them already, farm zones can create a flood of unfed cows creating AI pathing CPU lag if you don't monitor it, your haulers will think they're invincible when they're anything but... 

That all said?  I really like this game.  I'm always looking for something new that does all of this stuff in a 'better / more complete' game.  And I've yet to find it.  Get this title on the cheap, build your walls early, and have some fun.  It is what it is.

The only thing that was at all good about this game was the Skootenbeeten. One funny critter name. That's it.

I played quite a bit because I got this back when it was still in development and kept trying to get it to work. Gameplay was punishingly slow so it ate up hours. (Finally got around to reviewing it when I saw it again going through old games.)

Do not buy this at any price. It had a cool concept and then completely failed to deliver. Dev ran away with the money and then supposedly hired another dev to finish it, who also ran away.

column8:
Also ich habe es schon Lage und auch ne lange Zeit gespielt.
Nach den Tutorials kann man sich an eine eigene Welt wagen und Block für Block ab zu bauen.
Allerdings ist die KI etwas seltsam.
Man hat keine direkte Kontrolle über die Bewohner.
Die gestalterischen Freiheiten halten sich in Grenzen.
Größere Bauwerke sehen zwar gut aus, erfüllen dann aber keinen Zweck mehr, da die Laufwege zu lang werden. Auch wird überschüssige Nahrung nicht optimal gelagert um längere Strecken zurück zu legen.
Es fehlt noch an vielen Ecken und Kanten an Verbesserungen. Leider wird hier nicht weiterentwickelt.
column9:
Well, I've played it for a while now.
After the tutorials, you can venture into your own world and mine block by block.
However, the AI ​​is a bit strange.
You don't have direct control over the inhabitants.
The design freedom is limited.
Larger buildings look good, but then they no longer serve a purpose, as the walking distances become too long. Excess food isn't stored optimally for traveling long distances.
There are still many areas where improvements are needed. Unfortunately, there's no further development here.

column8:
Towns is a fantastic game! While yes it has been abandoned and is missing several key features, you need to appreciate it for what its worth. Towns is a very unique game and gave me tons of hours of enjoyment that other city builder games lacked. From heroes exploring the dungeons deep beneath to your Town to Townies picking apples on grassy hills. Towns has been a fantastic game to play and while i don't recommend it now I definitely enjoyed it.
I first discovered Towns from Yogscast Sips's 2 playthroughs on the game. After putting in 80 hours i sorta 'left it on the shelf' for a few months (or years? I don't really remember). Then I found Vechs do a 30+ series on Towns where he tested and explored nearly every asepect of the game. This brought me back into the game to put in that big 200+ hours number next to my name. 
Definitely didn't regret the money I spent on it but now but with it 6 years old its probably not in your best interest to buy. But hey! It could still be fun, I grew very attached to my Townies, especially the guards that I would beef up and send them into the Dungeons to slaughter dozens of slimes and goblins to avenge a fallen Townie. Hope this reviews meant a something to you as either a fellow Towns player or a protential buyer. Best wishes, ~ Daark

column8:
Right.  So I think it is long past time I cast my voice here.  Towns is a sad tale of of two devs reaching high and discovering once more that the world is full of @$$holes.  They aimed for a simplified Dwarf Fortress when Dwarf Fortress and Gnomoria were really the only colony building games around.  They had a lot of goals and wanted to incorperate a lot of RPG Elements.

Saddly life happened to one of the devs and his wife was fighting off Cancer.  Things fell apart from there.  It certainly didn't help that the many, many, many, many Entitled pieces of shit, who are likely some of the most toxic people you will ever encounter in life, liked to drop such "Helpfull" messages such as "I DON"T CARE IF THE ***** HAS CANCER< FINISH MY GAME!"

This is a game that was Destroyed by the greenlight community.

If you want a simple city builder a few dozen features to it.  Towns is going to meet your needs and is well worth the price.  Note that I say simple city builder.  Please ignore most of the hate here, as many of the ones who complain loudest, are the ones who caused the game to die in the first place.

column8:
You want to be the hero that slays all the monsters and wins the day?
You want stunningly beautiful graphics?
You want an exciting plot?
You want a developer who cares about your whining and promises to do better?
Go look elsewhere.
What you get are eleven townies with silly names in a landscape of your choice that allow you to start building a thriving town where heroes want to stay to do your slaying for you. 
You can farm, cook, build and make armor and weapons while you get to decide where everything goes and how you want it to look. Meanwhile, you have to keep your guys from doing silly things and that's not always easy... 
There are some minor bugs and to me, the settlement gets boring once I can build pretty much everything, but hey! I start over some other day. Still lots of fun.
Check out the tutorials if you're lost, there are some great ones out there.

While not worth it, some games have been inspired by this game, not from looking at what is missing, but what is there to go off of. I can only wonder what some modders could have done with this game, or what the devs could have ended up with.

column8: This game is a great exercise is horrible game design.  It essentially exists to copy Dwarf Fortress, but makes a game that was famously overly complicated even more complicated in all the wrong places and that lacking in detail in the places that need it.  A tech tree that is stupidly needlessly long before you can build the most simple things, but then once you've done that there's nothing much else left.

column8: I've watched this game from its earliest stages of development and always hoped that it would be the next graphics based Dwarf Fortress, but when the developer abandoned the game, I've lost such hope. column8:
Towns is an attempt to remake Dwarf Fortress without understanding that people love DF because of all the thousands upon thousands of tiny details that are behind the characters.  DF has literal story arks for its characters, almost purely by accident.

Dwarf Fortress is a city builder / kingdom management game with a feature list 10 miles long.  That graphics are piss poor and the controls are a pain, but that's because the dev is constantly adding new things.  It's been around for 15 years, and the dev is only half way done with the game.  It's literally Feature Creep: The Game.

At best guess, Towns has maybe 5% of the features of Dwarf Fortress, with better yet still shit graphics, and a bad control scheme.  And Dwarf Fortress is free!

TLDR: Go play Dwarf Fortress, don't give this company your money.

column8:
It's a rare game where you can leave the game on idle while you do other things and come back to later, hell you might be surprised. They could have cleared the whole dungeon while you were gone, or be overrun by famine zombies from your own people because you forgot to tell them to bake the bread.

Could use a lot of interactive refinement, but it's an okay to good game for what it is. It's an interesting and new experience if you like the village builder simulations.

(Even though game is no longer in development, it's still okay)

column8:
This game is a flat scam, and I urge anyone thinking about buying this to reconsider.

I bought it based on screenshots which were literally not possible to achieve in the game without mods and editing. The product was extremely buggy and unpolished to the point of being unplayable in the long term, but it was still sold on Steam as a finished game. After many complaints, it was put into "Early Access" *after* many of us had bought it. Even then, Valve refused to issue a refund.

Development was later taken over by someone other than the original developer, but it seems to have been dropped again, since the last update was in 2014. And still the un-discounted price is a ridiculous €11.99 in Europe.

You would be better served burning your money than buying this game. The frustration and bitterness of playing this game represents a negative value to the life of any person buying it. If someone is forcing you to buy this game at gunpoint, you should do a serious cost/benefit analysis before pushing the buy button, because it still might not be worth it.

Worst game I ever bought.

column8: What was once a brialliant glimpse into what Dwarf Fortress could have evolved into has become a barren wasteland of abandonment. The developers have left this game high and dry, unfinished and unpolished. Imagine dwarf fortress, but 3d, with zoning and crafting. then imagine all those ideas never leaving alpha and being completely forgotten by those who created them. Then imagine dungeons being introduced and basically being the equivalent to putting mice in a maze full of mousetraps and hoping they dont go the wrong way. This game had SO MUCH going for it, but was deserted and now exists as a shadow of its potential.

column8:
Management building game that I really enjoyed, until I got frustrated with the fact that people wouldn't prioritize their needs enough to keep themselves alive, and hence I kept losing precious pops to self neglect. 

Can't really manage them directly so nothing I could do to keep them from suiciding like that. Still played it for 81 hours before I expanded to the point that it became a major problem. So I can't really say it's not worth the modest price. 

I did very much enjoy this game in the meantime, and forced me to do tons of planning and calculating to get my city (town I guess) how I wanted it to be. I only got frustrated and gave up because of how much I was enjoying it and the fact that it was torpedoing anotherwise very well balanced difficutly level for the game. It's possible that this has been taken care of in an update since I last played, and if anyone confirms that I'd be happy to go back for another look.

column8:
Es ist zwar schade, dass an diesem Spiel nicht weiter entwickelt wird und es noch den in oder anderen Bug gibt, aber trotzdem halte ich das nicht für einen Grund für eine Negativ-Bewertung.
Das Spiel ist schön simpel und das was es soll macht es relativ gut. Ich hatte hier viel Spaß und fang auch immer noch ab und zu gerne eine neue Karte an und probiere andere Spielweisen aus.

Man muss dazu sagen, dass das Spiel wohl nur als Anfäger schwierig ist, bis man weiß was zu tun ist. In etwa wie bei Banished. Der Survivalanteil ist da noch zu spüren^^
Ansonsten wird es mit laufender Tiefe des Dungeons immer schwieriger, so dass man sich später doch einiges einfallen lassen muss, damit die eigene Bevölkerung nicht abgeschlachtet wird. Da man aber selbst entscheiden kann, ob man weiter gaben will, kann man sich doch lange Zeit sehr gut auf das nächste Level vorbereiten und die Spielschwierigkeit ist damit auch für jeden selbst anpassbar.

Wer mal "Minecraft" (gibt natürlich sehr viele Unterschiede) als Strategie-Survival-Spiel ausprobieren möchte ist hier richtig. Vielleicht bis die anderen Early-Access-Titel endlich spielbar sind ;)
GL & HF
column9:
It's a shame that this game isn't being developed further and that there are still a few bugs, but I still don't think that's a reason for a negative rating.
The game is nice and simple and does what it's supposed to do relatively well. I had a lot of fun with it and still enjoy starting a new map every now and then and trying out different playstyles.

I have to say that the game is probably only difficult for beginners until you know what to do. Kind of like Banished. The survival element is still noticeable there.^^
Otherwise, it gets increasingly difficult as you delve deeper into the dungeon, so you'll have to come up with some ideas later on to avoid slaughtering your own population. However, since you can decide for yourself whether you want to continue playing, you can prepare yourself for the next level for a long time, and the difficulty is also adjustable for everyone.

If you want to try out "Minecraft" (there are, of course, many differences) as a strategy survival game, this is the right place for you. Maybe until the other Early Access titles are finally playable ;)
GL & HF

column8:
92 hours divided by ten bucks.  Win!

I enjoyed this.  Quite a lot.  I really don't understand the hate for people claiming this is 'unfinished'.  Yep, it is true that this project did not reach the full set of goals the original developer set out, but that doesn't change the fact that the game is pretty cool, and has plenty of play in it.  

Is it ground-breakingly different or new?  Not really.  Is it a totally different take on the genre?  Again, not really.  But it does fit the niche for building some buildings, farming some stuff, killing some mobs, and looting some treasures.  And while you are doing that, it is a pretty involved and good experience with just enough depth in it to make it feel like you are developing your community and bonding with the toons.

I reckon if there was no 'beta/greenlight/whatever' tag associated with this, and someone just marketed it as a 'lightweight town builder with dungeon elements' then I think people would shut the heck up about abandonware and realise it has easily enough weight in it to be released as a standalone indy-developed product that is really rather enjoyable.  Don't pay attention to the abandonware bitching.  Play it, and enjoy it for what it is.

column8:
I still play this game, 6 years on (9+ years now). It appeals to how I think.

It's tricky to get the hang of but once you understand the little bugs and how to play the game we've been left with, it's quite enjoyable.

The game is pretty much the same each time you start a new town, the difference is in how you play. I feel it's similar to Minecraft, in the sense that there really isn't that much to do, but you have the potential to play and build however you like.

I don't think it should be $15, given that it's been abandoned. But I've personally gotten way more than $15 of value out of Towns and will continue to do so.

2020 Update: Town++ mod adds some flavour to a game that hasn't changed for years. Makes some things easier, more user friendly but also some aspects harder. I still play from time to time. It's challenging in a soothing way (or soothing in a challenging way..)

column8:
D'accord, ce jeu est tombé dans l'oubli, n'a pas su atteindre sa version finale mais il reste malgré tout jouable pour les amateurs de construction sachant faire preuve d'imaginations.

Ainsi, nous pouvons créer de grandes villes ou simplement de petits villages, d'assigner nos citoyens à des tâches civiles ou militaires.

Le gros plus est les héros qui donne un aspect RPG même s'il est limité. Peut-être que les développeurs auraient souhaités renforcer ce système s'ils en avaient les moyens.

Le point noir est la répétivité une fois à court d'idées. La rejouabilité est une question de volonté.

Bref, un jeu qui a de bonnes idées mais n'ayant pas abouties. Dommage. Je ne regrette cependant pas son achat durant les promos.
column9:
Okay, this game has been forgotten and never reached its final version, but it's still playable for construction enthusiasts with a bit of imagination.

Thus, we can create large cities or simply small villages, and assign our citizens to civilian or military tasks.

The big plus is the heroes, which gives it an RPG feel, even if it's limited. Perhaps the developers would have liked to strengthen this system if they had the means.

The downside is the repetitiveness once you run out of ideas. Replayability is a matter of willpower.

In short, a game with good ideas but which didn't come to fruition. It's a shame. However, I don't regret buying it during the sale.

column8: Honestly, this is one of my favourite games. I haven't played it in a while, but relaxing and building up a town is a lot of fun for me. I really like the gameplay, and  the price for content is really good. People are upset they didn't get all the promised features from the devs, but we still get usually more than 50 hours of content for $17, and even less on a sale. If you like Dwarf Fortress (or maybe even the Sims), you'll probably like this game!

column8:
I like it. It is obviously the same type of game as Gnomoria, inspired by Dwarf Fortress. I don't care if it is considered "abandonware" by the community. Back in the day, you bought software as-is. Any updates after release were at the discretion of the dev, not at the demand of the end-user.

So, I think this is a fun little city builder game. I love that the point is to attract heroes to clear your dungeons for you. Meanwhile, you can outfit your whole town with armor and stone hammers to clear the dungeons more democratically.

Yes, the whole town can starve because your only baker got stuck on a roof when the scaffolding was removed. But that's part of the fun!

I recommend this to fans of similar games, who don't mind if their Steam friends see them playing something with negative reviews. There's too much self-concious peer pressure here. It's just a game!

column8:
Personally, I used to love the game. While it was a buggy featureless mess at the very start, frequent updates and gameplay improvements kept it fresh and interesting. It had great potential. 

However, I can not possibly recommend this game to anyone else. The game was abandoned, left in a buggy mess. Starvation or being slaughtered by enemies will spring upon you, all because a few villages bug out, ruining hours of work. If you can make it despite the bugs, you are met with a shocking lack of endgame content. 

Do not buy this, even at a sale.

column8:
This review is now for all of those that came in just to leave a negative review and scream: "Abandonded!" It's a long story, but this was posted by one of the devs:

The story is a liiiiiiiiiiittle bit more complicated than that -- unfortunately, most of the original explanations and discussion are lost (they were posted on the now-defunct Towns Community Forums on the original website, which was shut down and now redirects to the Steam store page)

A summary of some of those extra factors:

- at the time, Steam's Project: Greenlight was in its infancy, and wasn't well defined. "Early Access" didn't exist yet, although the concept was being thrown around -- many devs from the first few waves of Greenlight were under the impression that Greenlight itself was going to be set up to support the type of games that would become Early Access titles. Unfortunately, this wasn't what Valve ultimately went with; so for the first couple of years the games that got voted up through Greenlight were put under immense pressure to rush to a "minimum viable product" -- and Towns, as one of the titles in the first batch of Greenlight releases, was going into uncharted territory with a changing Steam marketplace.

- it's worth noting that in those days, Steam itself was very different -- you had to know someone at Valve to even start the discussions about getting onto the Steam platform, and games that did get released on Steam typically sold quite well. Back when Towns released into the Steam Store, there were less than 1000 titles available for purchase on Steam; a far cry from today! In those days, Valve had a reputation for being more hands-on, offering support with releases and with things like community management. So, where the Towns dev team expected to get a bit more support from the Greenlight program, they were unfortunately left to their own devices to handle the influx of new players (many of whom had no familiarity with the state of the game.)

- As part of celebrating the first wave of Greenlight releases, Towns was put into a much-advertised sale; it was quickly followed up with the Steam Summer Sale and then a third "best of the year" encore sale -- so while there were many many copies sold right after the game launched, the actual revenue was much lower than most people assumed. I remember outrageous figures like $3-4 million being thrown around, with no accounting for tax or Steam's cut or the fact that the devs had significant expenses to cover (e.g. the cost of all the legal services, accounting, and similar paperwork required to run a game studio; running the game website and forum; upgrading computers and software licenses)... that's all before anything the devs actually got to take home. I know that Supermalparit did eventually post a statement regarding the actual income Towns made from that first Steam Store check, and it was a little less than $1 million by the time it hit the studio accounts. It's also worth noting that Steam pays out revenue on a 3 monthly cycle, so the devs didn't even see any of that income during the sales -- it landed in their accounts months afterwards.

- On top of all that stuff on the business side of things (which, remember, Ben and Xavi had to handle all of that communications + paperwork + etc themselves; they didn't have a business developer or admin to take care of it), there was also a lot going on in their personal lives at the time. Xavi in particular is very private about that side of the story, so I'll respect that privacy, but suffice to say that he took on a whole full-time caring role for his wife and children during that period. Ben (Burningpet) similarly took some long-overdue time to focus on his family following the release of the game on Steam -- in effect, that milestone was the end of a years-long sprint; under the belief as previously discussed that Valve would step up to help handle things like monitoring and moderating the Steam community forum during this break. So, when that support didn't materialise, Xavi and Ben also had to take on the extra workload of trying to answer a deluge of questions, criticisms and in some cases outright accusations, while trying to juggle both the business side of game development, the actual game dev work, and looking after their families.

So, with all of that going on, the vitriol coming at them from certain loud corners of the Steam community had a much larger effect than it otherwise would -- not just emotionally; it also added extra (urgent) work that further delayed the other important stuff on the to-do list. And, in the most unfortunate irony of the whole story, that vitriol ended up having a direct negative impact on the game's marketability and made it much harder for the devs to get support to turn things around -- when they tried to bring on Moebius to help out with the dev work, the sheer amount of work required to repair the game's image (coupled with the fact that sales had dropped away to basically nothing since everyone had already bought a copy during the Steam sales) made Towns a commercially risky prospect and Moebius ultimately couldn't go through with the deal. I know that Moebius wasn't the only dev that Ben and Xavi approached to join the Towns team; I don't believe that any of the other attempts weren't even announced (there are a couple I know of because of conversations with Xavi after-the-fact, and one where I actually fielded an initial inquiry and helped get the person in contact with Xavi so they could discuss the idea) but ultimately the major hurdle in all cases was that there was no "runway" left -- any new dev would be jumping straight into the fire, and would need to make major additions and improvements immediately as well as fielding a whole new round of heat for stuff they had nothing to do with. And when that was the job description, without guarantee of future success and with an already strained budget... I can't blame any of those other devs for deciding it was too risky. 

Finally, it's worth noting that even after all this, Xavi and Ben returned to work on half a dozen more updates and bring in major features (water system, buried towns, new event mechanics, and a largely under-utilised 'gods' system which honestly could have been amazing when coupled with the events if only there had been an opportunity to flesh it out properly) -- of those features, the dynamic water system was the first time that any city-building game had attempted anything like that in decades, and the gods and events system (really it's 1 linked system with multiple facets) is still impressive compared to its modern comparisons. Messing around with the gods and events through mods, it allowed for some amazing possibilities -- re-shaping the map, changing up the whole game... one of the janky prototypes I created was "seasons" where it literally changed the grass terrain to snow terrain and then back again over the course of the year, as well as 'sprouting' new trees and plants in spring, and creating floods in summer. If the devs had been able to work on those systems the way that they envisioned, I am confident that Towns would rival its much later/more modern genre companions in terms of interactivity, dynamism and 'living world' feeling.

Yes, words do matter and the harsh words levelled at Towns did have a visible and lasting impact. But it's not [i]just[/i] the words that mattered here -- ultimately, there were pre-existing factors outside the devs' control. The harsh words served to make an already difficult situation even worse, and bump it from 'extremely difficult' to 'commercially untenable to continue.'
column9:
This review is now for all of those that came in just to leave a negative review and scream: "Abandonded!" It's a long story, but this was posted by one of the devs:

The story is a liiiiiiiiiiittle bit more complicated than that -- unfortunately, most of the original explanations and discussion are lost (they were posted on the now-defunct Towns Community Forums on the original website, which was shut down and now redirects to the Steam store page)

A summary of some of those extra factors:

- at the time, Steam's Project: Greenlight was in its infancy, and wasn't well defined. "Early Access" didn't exist yet, although the concept was being thrown around -- many devs from the first few waves of Greenlight were under the impression that Greenlight itself was going to be set up to support the type of games that would become Early Access titles. Unfortunately, this wasn't what Valve ultimately went with; so for the first couple of years the games that got voted up through Greenlight were put under immense pressure to rush to a "minimum viable product" -- and Towns, as one of the titles in the first batch of Greenlight releases, was going into uncharted territory with a changing Steam marketplace.

- it's worth noting that in those days, Steam itself was very different -- you had to know someone at Valve to even start the discussions about getting onto the Steam platform, and games that did get released on Steam typically sold quite well. Back when Towns released into the Steam Store, there were less than 1000 titles available for purchase on Steam; a far cry from today! In those days, Valve had a reputation for being more hands-on, offering support with releases and with things like community management. So, where the Towns dev team expected to get a bit more support from the Greenlight program, they were unfortunately left to their own devices to handle the influx of new players (many of whom had no familiarity with the state of the game.)

- As part of celebrating the first wave of Greenlight releases, Towns was put into a much-advertised sale; it was quickly followed up with the Steam Summer Sale and then a third "best of the year" encore sale -- so while there were many many copies sold right after the game launched, the actual revenue was much lower than most people assumed. I remember outrageous figures like $3-4 million being thrown around, with no accounting for tax or Steam's cut or the fact that the devs had significant expenses to cover (e.g. the cost of all the legal services, accounting, and similar paperwork required to run a game studio; running the game website and forum; upgrading computers and software licenses)... that's all before anything the devs actually got to take home. I know that Supermalparit did eventually post a statement regarding the actual income Towns made from that first Steam Store check, and it was a little less than $1 million by the time it hit the studio accounts. It's also worth noting that Steam pays out revenue on a 3 monthly cycle, so the devs didn't even see any of that income during the sales -- it landed in their accounts months afterwards.

- On top of all that stuff on the business side of things (which, remember, Ben and Xavi had to handle all of that communications + paperwork + etc themselves; they didn't have a business developer or admin to take care of it), there was also a lot going on in their personal lives at the time. Xavi in particular is very private about that side of the story, so I'll respect that privacy, but suffice to say that he took on a whole full-time caring role for his wife and children during that period. Ben (Burningpet) similarly took some long-overdue time to focus on his family following the release of the game on Steam -- in effect, that milestone was the end of a years-long sprint; under the belief as previously discussed that Valve would step up to help handle things like monitoring and moderating the Steam community forum during this break. So, when that support didn't materialise, Xavi and Ben also had to take on the extra workload of trying to answer a deluge of questions, criticisms and in some cases outright accusations, while trying to juggle both the business side of game development, the actual game dev work, and looking after their families.

So, with all of that going on, the vitriol coming at them from certain loud corners of the Steam community had a much larger effect than it otherwise would -- not just emotionally; it also added extra (urgent) work that further delayed the other important stuff on the to-do list. And, in the most unfortunate irony of the whole story, that vitriol ended up having a direct negative impact on the game's marketability and made it much harder for the devs to get support to turn things around -- when they tried to bring on Moebius to help out with the dev work, the sheer amount of work required to repair the game's image (coupled with the fact that sales had dropped away to basically nothing since everyone had already bought a copy during the Steam sales) made Towns a commercially risky prospect and Moebius ultimately couldn't go through with the deal. I know that Moebius wasn't the only dev that Ben and Xavi approached to join the Towns team; I don't believe that any of the other attempts weren't even announced (there are a couple I know of because of conversations with Xavi after-the-fact, and one where I actually fielded an initial inquiry and helped get the person in contact with Xavi so they could discuss the idea) but ultimately the major hurdle in all cases was that there was no "runway" left -- any new dev would be jumping straight into the fire, and would need to make major additions and improvements immediately as well as fielding a whole new round of heat for stuff they had nothing to do with. And when that was the job description, without guarantee of future success and with an already strained budget... I can't blame any of those other devs for deciding it was too risky. 

Finally, it's worth noting that even after all this, Xavi and Ben returned to work on half a dozen more updates and bring in major features (water system, buried towns, new event mechanics, and a largely under-utilised 'gods' system which honestly could have been amazing when coupled with the events if only there had been an opportunity to flesh it out properly) -- of those features, the dynamic water system was the first time that any city-building game had attempted anything like that in decades, and the gods and events system (really it's 1 linked system with multiple facets) is still impressive compared to its modern comparisons. Messing around with the gods and events through mods, it allowed for some amazing possibilities -- re-shaping the map, changing up the whole game... one of the janky prototypes I created was "seasons" where it literally changed the grass terrain to snow terrain and then back again over the course of the year, as well as 'sprouting' new trees and plants in spring, and creating floods in summer. If the devs had been able to work on those systems the way that they envisioned, I am confident that Towns would rival its much later/more modern genre companions in terms of interactivity, dynamism and 'living world' feeling.

Yes, words do matter and the harsh words levelled at Towns did have a visible and lasting impact. But it's not [i]just[/i] the words that mattered here -- ultimately, there were pre-existing factors outside the devs' control. The harsh words served to make an already difficult situation even worse, and bump it from 'extremely difficult' to 'commercially untenable to continue.'

column8:
This game had Potential.

More often than not for a game like this, you see it simply labled "It's S@$&!" and they walk away. But the truth is this game had potential, and sadly that potential never got off the ground.

I bought into this game during its early access state, sometime in alpha 13 I believe. During that time, I was big into Dwarf Forttress like games that had more graphics, and this game was amazing in that regard. A mixture of minecraft style view with dwarf fortress rouge-like hardness; the game was a shoo-in to take the market in my opinion.

Sometime after alpha 14, the game's dev simply stopped updating it all together. SInce then, the game has been abandoned.

I believe this game still has some potential as both a learning tool and a testimate; a testimate that such games are necessairy to bring hope and inovation to our industry. So please, don't review this game as being terrible becasue its incomplete, or unbalanced; review it as learning-game, one that was used to learn how to fail faster (make mistakes so you don't do it again), and how to make more awesome games.

column8:
Towns ist immer noch ein geniales Spiel. Es wird vermutlich nie mehr sein, als es jetzt gerade ist - okay. Aber deswegen das Spiel negativ zu bewerten ist Unsinn. Das Spiel selbst ist nicht perfekt (auch technisch gibt es Mängel), aber es macht verdammt viel Spaß es zu spielen. Daran messe ich dann auch ein Spiel, dass ist ja der Sinn des Ganzen - Unterhalten werden.
In der Hinsicht sind die negativen Reviews größtenteils kompletter Müll. Das Spiel ist super und ich habe für mein Geld ne Menge geboten bekommen. Die Spielmechaniken sind durchaus anspruchsvoll und bei Reviews unter 10h halte ich es persönlich für sehr unwahrscheinlich, dass man das Spiel dann tatsächlich bewerten kann.
Übrigens ist das Spiel kein "Early Access". Es wurde mittels Greenlight von Steam unterstützt, veröffentlicht und dann zwei Jahre betrieben.
column9:
Towns is still a brilliant game. It'll probably never be more than it is now - okay. But to rate the game negatively because of that is nonsense. The game itself isn't perfect (there are also technical flaws), but it's a hell of a lot of fun to play. That's how I measure a game; that's the whole point of the whole thing - to be entertained.
In that respect, the negative reviews are mostly complete garbage. The game is great, and I got a lot for my money. The game mechanics are quite challenging, and with reviews under 10 hours, I personally think it's very unlikely that you can actually rate the game.
By the way, the game isn't in "Early Access." It was supported, released, and then operated via Steam Greenlight for two years.

column8: I find it funny how some people who have gave the game a bad review have put hundereds of hours into the game, as if that isn't good enough. I really like this game, and it has a few bugs which will never get ironed out, but it is still playable. If you can get it on sale then I can't recomend it enough. If you want depth and more complexity then get dwarf fortress, it's free. And if you are willing to shell out large amounts of money as it rarely goes on sale, RimWorld is a nice mix of complexity and graphics. Still though, it's a fun game and for a low price you can get good entertainment from it.
