column8:
I bought this game years ago. And I liked it when it was coming out; it was like a simplified (and approachable) version of dwarf fortress; It was in early access at the time.

While I enjoyed the game at its core, they stopped updating ages ago. And it was never really completed. At the moment this game is not worth your money. 
As for personal experience, there were bugs and ultimately, I lost my biggest save after making some limited progress. it felt like a bad buy; I don’t recommend it.

column8:
I wouldn't go as far as to call Towns a scam - because it isn't. Everything that the store page says it does, it does do it. It is, even in it's current state, decent. Not excellent. Not awful. Just okay.

Your mileage might vary whether or not 'decent' is good enough for you.

For me, it isn't - and the game will never be any different, because there have been no updates for three years. Nor will there be any. It is, by all intents and purposed, abandoned.

column8:
leider extrem schlecht gemacht.
nur halb fertig 
es fuktioniert kaum etwas richtig in dem spiel.

die bewohner sterben schneller als man bauen und rohstoffe ranschaffen kann.
der rohstoff verbraucht insbesondere der nahrungs verbraucht ist viel zu hoch. 
man kann nicht zuweisen welche aufgaben ein npc machen soll nur einzelne sperren. 
keine wirklich ki. man muss jedem einzelnen jede aktionen zuweisen jedes mal.
sprich wenn einer nen bäume fälllen soll muss man jeden baum einzeln makieren. 
keiner leih automatismus beim rohstoff abbau.
bis jetzt konnte ich nicht raus finden wie man werkzeug und kleidung herstellt, oder roh stoffe wie flint stone oder eisen bekommen kann. die aber not wendig sind damit die leute nicht wie die fliegen von alleine sterben.

sind sie tot kommen keine neuen.
möbel wie betten bringen wohl garnichts und werden nicht benutzt, 
türen werden immer gleich plaziert und lassen sich nicht drehen.
und diese lieste lässt sich uneendlich weiter führen.

das spiel ist reine geld verschwendung und die macher sollten sich was schämen für so einen dreck geld zu verlangen.
column9:
Unfortunately, it's extremely poorly made.
Only half-finished.
Hardly anything in the game works properly.

The inhabitants die faster than you can build and acquire resources.
Resource consumption, especially food consumption, is far too high.

You can't assign which tasks an NPC should perform; you can only block certain ones.

No real AI. You have to assign each individual action each time.

In other words, if someone is supposed to chop down a tree, you have to mark each tree individually.

No automation for resource mining.

So far, I haven't been able to figure out how to craft tools and clothing, or get raw materials like flintstone or iron. These are necessary, though, so people don't just drop dead like flies.

Once they're dead, no new ones appear.

Furniture like beds is apparently useless and isn't used.

Doors are always placed in the same place and can't be turned.
And this list goes on indefinitely.

The game is a complete waste of money, and the makers should be ashamed of themselves for charging such crap.

column8:
This is what happens when a community turns on a developer. At the time of this writing, Towns has a Very Negative recent score, with most of the reviews saying it is unfinished, don't buy it. These reviews are not about what the game is, they are reviews about the disparity between what the game is and what those reviewers feel it should be.

Towns is a city builder that lets you do things (EDIT) [strike]no[/strike] few other city builders let you do. Enticing heroes (who are not citizens) with the quality of your town, then controlling their access to underground ruins to allow them to level up (while cleansing said ruins of enemies so your citizens can loot them). 

You can arm and armor your citizens to help in the fight, and/or defend the town as well. 

Try the demo. Decide if the cost of Towns is worth the 30+ hours enjoyment I feel anyone interested in city builders should reasonably get from it. I've gotten 70 so far, and still come back to it from time to time. It will never reach it's full potential, which is too bad, but the game is still fun to play.

column8:
I love this game. I find myself coming back to it every couple of months, and playing it for a couple hours. I truly was disheartened to learn it was abandoned.

It has such potential to be a fantastic game, and I find similar games just don't measure up to it.

I love it. I love how difficult it is, how it takes you a good couple playthroughs to understand what you need to do. Like the risks you have to take with your townies, and how easily your civ can crumble by one stupid move (or werepig).

I definitely would hit up Towns2 if the dev got around to it, and i wish they'd come back to this one.  

I wouldn't pay $16 for it, as it is abandoned. But i would pay maybe $10, becuase it STILL gives you several hours of fun, all things considered. Its not a completely unfinished game, it is just abandoned and has no future.

column8:
Towns is basically the original Early Access scam, from before Steam Early Access, and the first of many abandoned sandbox games on Steam.

Other than being the first major failed attempt at a graphical Dwarf Fortress, it's pretty much completely non-notable and permanently unfinished, with the last patch in September 2014.

column8:
Эта игра могла бы стать ответом Majesty. Всё необходимое для этого у неё, в общем-то, есть: куча горожан, которые занимаются своими делами, но выполняют поставленные приказы, куча разнообразных монстров, строительство помещений, которое делает тебя сильнее, инвентарь у каждого персонажа...

Замечу также, что ещё тут есть продуманная "цепная" экономика (для изготовления топора, например, нужно обработанное дерево и сталь, которые соединяются на станке. А для этого надо сначала нарубить дерева, добыть железную руду и переплавить её в сталь). Есть подземелье с монстрами (они не респаунятся, так что зачистка возможна - и часто необходима). Есть атаки рейдеров. Есть разные условия, чтобы к тебе приходили разные герои (например, герои-гномы приходят только в таверну, расположенную под землёй). Даже странствующие торговцы периодически наведываются.

В общем, тут много чего есть... но у автора случился нервный срыв буквально за пару месяцев до окончания производства. В итоге игру он бросил и не вернулся никогда, так что тут хватает глупых недоловленных багов и нет "склейки", которая бы сделала из песочницы нормальную игру: отсутствуют квесты, разные карты (ну, если не начинать игру с нуля, конечно) и нет сюжета.

Поэтому, как вы можете видеть, игра имеет крайне негативные обзоры. И зря. Если не ждать от неё невозможного, она довольно симпатична. Любителям повозиться с экономикой - рекомендую.
column9:
This game could be Majesty's answer. It basically has everything it needs: tons of townspeople who go about their business but follow orders, a variety of monsters, building structures that make you stronger, and an inventory for each character...

I'll also note that it has a well-thought-out "chain" economy (to craft an axe, for example, you need processed wood and steel, which are combined at a workbench. To do this, you first need to chop wood, mine iron ore, and smelt it into steel). There's a dungeon with monsters (they don't respawn, so clearing them is possible—and often necessary). There are raider attacks. There are different conditions for different heroes to come to you (for example, dwarven heroes only come to the tavern located underground). Even traveling merchants drop in periodically.

Overall, there's a lot going on here... but the author had a nervous breakdown literally a couple of months before production ended. He ended up abandoning the game and never came back, so there are plenty of silly, unresolved bugs and no "glue" to make a proper sandbox game: there are no quests, no different maps (well, unless you start from scratch, of course), and no story.

So, as you can see, the game has received extremely negative reviews. And that's a shame. If you don't expect the impossible, it's quite enjoyable. I recommend it to those who enjoy tinkering with the economy.

column8:
Yes this game has been abandoned. But what is there is still really fun. You can lose hours and hours in it. Sadly my hours played doesn't show the time sunk into the game before it hit Steam. 

I might call the game a Dwarf Fortress lite with Majesty hero mechanics. I love the production ordering system. The almost Minecrafty building system is cool. 

As an added bonus, the game works well on very old hardware. I can even play it fantastically on my GPD Win, so I have Towns in my pocket on the go.

column8:
I happen to think that this game is fairly good, despite many reviews on here. I haven't put an absurd amount of time into it, however the time I have put in, I enjoyed. 

There are a few quirks here and there, such as people who are building walls will sometimes stand on the wall while building, causing them to become stuck and eventually dying to starvation. While things like this aren't techincally bugs, they make the game difficult to play for long periods of time. 

The Hero system is fun and decently rewarding. Heroes will occasionally wander into unwanted areas and get themselves killed, again making long sittings of this game somewhat frustrating.

Overall, I do recommend this game. Maybe it isn't what it was promised to be, but it is still a fun game; albiet with some 'bugs' that aren't technically bugs.

column8: Ich spiele dieses Spiel schon seit einigen Jahren immer mal wieder. Mir persönlich macht es immer wieder Spaß, eine neue Siedlung hochzuziehen, Farmen anzulegen, Material zu sammeln, die Bewohner auszurüsten, Helden anzulocken und Höhlen zu buddeln, um Eisen, Kohle usw zu finden. Mir gefällt auch das Micromanagement - bestimmte Bewohner bestimmten Aufgaben zuzuweisen und so dafür zu sorgen, dass immer genug Nahrung da ist und Bau- und Buddeltrupps zur Verfügung stehen, um alle Minen zu graben. Sind die Bewohner glücklich, erscheinen neue Dörfler, vorausgesetzt, man hat genug Räume für sie hergerichtet. Ich habe auch gelesen, dass der bzw. die Entwickler aufgehört haben, das Spiel zu entwickeln, allerdings habe ich bisher noch keine fiesen Bugs und/ oder Abstürze bemerkt. Meiner Meinung nach ist das Spiel so absolut spielbar und macht irgendwie ein wenig süchtig. Ich habe bei meinem aktuellen Spiel ziemlich lange nach Kohle suchen müssen, damit ich ein Gebäude bauen kann, dass auf Eisen paltziert, automatisch Eisen auswirft. Aber bis ich die Kohle hatte, vergingen einige Grabungen und Dungeons :)
column9: I've been playing this game on and off for a few years now. Personally, I always enjoy building a new settlement, establishing farms, gathering materials, equipping the inhabitants, attracting heroes, and digging caves to find iron, coal, etc. I also enjoy the micromanagement—assigning specific inhabitants to specific tasks, ensuring there's always enough food and construction and digging crews available to dig all the mines. If the inhabitants are happy, new villagers appear, provided you've prepared enough rooms for them. I also read that the developer(s) have stopped developing the game, but I haven't noticed any nasty bugs and/or crashes yet. In my opinion, the game is perfectly playable and somewhat addictive. In my current game, I had to spend quite a long time searching for coal so I could build a building that, when placed on iron, automatically ejects iron. But it took a lot of digging and dungeon-building before I got the coal :)

column8: People, stop reviewing a game in a negative light for the sole reason of it being abandoned. It is childish! So ironic that I see so many reviews stating that they "loved this game early on" and then proceed with something around the lines of "but the developers abandoned it". The fact remains that even as it stands, in an abandoned state, it is still worth playing. I vote it up not because I want to prove a point, nor do I vote it up because I support the developers running off with my money. I vote it up because of the question the "Yes" or "No" asks, "Do you recommend this game?" That yes or no answer is a recommendation for the game, not the developers. This game is well deserving of at least trying it. I played it before it got on Steam for countless hours and enjoyed every second, and also experienced no "bugs" at all. So stop your fucking whining over something you can fix and move on.

column8:
I must say, it is incredibly disappointing to read all the negative reviews on this game. First we must realize a basic concept here... for $15 if you expect developers to work forever on a game, and never stop, you're expecting too much. 

Beyond that... it's a great game! I've played over 500 hours off and on for years, and is one of the few titles that I will pick up and play over and over again. 

Buggy: I believe most people are playing minimal time and doing stupid things (like queuing 1000 tasks to 10 townies and wondering why they aren't doing a specific task) then screaming "buggy buggy!" Because they can't admit that they suck at the game. 

Towns is a great game. I have 0 issues with how it is, as is. Perhaps it's because I don't suck, I know how to play the game, and even more importantly, learn how to overcome obstacles instead of cry like a baby to have someone patch and fix a games challenges so that it becomes easy (boring). 

Pull up your big-boy pants naysayers... Towns for $15... I would have paid $40 and still been happy. To current date (and I'm still playing!) that's $0.03 / hour. 

Keep in mind - NEVER had 1 crash, never had one broken save of any kind. In 500 hours I've yet to see a "bug". It does not frustrate me, and I don't expect more.

Towns is a great game to whittle away time, get off your high-horse baby-wagon naysayers and learn to play the game instead of cry broken because you can't manage a toon town.

column8:
Got this game back when it was still alpha, for very cheap. Knowing it was alpha, and browsing the forums, the game was a very fun experience. There were contests, and a bunch of good spirited discussion, etc. I definitely had my moneys worth of enjoyment from this game. 

Sadly, devs started delaying new updates, kept cutting out parts of the game that were promised, and eventually "settled" that the game was finished in the current state, which let me tell you, is not even close to what it should be. 

From that point the game left its "alpha status", apparently went through a very short beta period, and it released here on Steam (I only have little time with the game here on steam, because I played a lot of the standalone version). Like it was a full game or something...

The rest is history now, but in case you don't know, it goes something like this: The general public in steam find that the game is really lackluster for a full game, and complain. Devs promise to improve, despite insisting that the game is complete. At some point one of the devs simply disappears without warning. After some time, the guy reappears, saying that he had problems and he couldn't deal with the pressure the players put on him, or something of the sort... and promises to try and get back on the game again. Never heard of him since then...



The game as it stands still has a ton of balance issues, incomplete features, and despite that I really enjoyed my time with the game, I doubt anyone can really enjoy it as it is today. The promise of future improvements and the community is what made the game fun, other than that I admit that it was pretty mediocre. 

I advise that noone buys this game, if anything to keep their moral integrity and not fund half-baked abandoned projects. 
If you still wanna buy it, at least be aware of what it is.

Thanks for reading,
Jon_jon13, self proclaimed "watergineer".

column8:
If you actually sit down and play this game and look at the experience objectively, it's an excellent game. It's fun, it has interesting mechanics. There's building, industry and then later on exploring dungeons and so on. It's like a similified Dwarf Fortress. I was an early backer before this came to Steam and I've spent at least 30 hours playing the various builds of the game. I think it's just a really fun game. It's bug-free, lots of things to do, easy to learn. People refuse to judge this game objectively because the developer moved on to other projects; I think that's totally understandable. There's a huge amount of content to enjoy in this game, well worth the price.
It's sad to see the mob mentality, that players will instantly turn on a developer if they don't commit their entire lifespan to a small greenlight project. I think this is an unfair expectation. Reviews should simply look at the game objectively.

column8:
As many others have been stating, this game has long since been abandoned. I used to play this quite a while back, and while I did have fun and enjoy it at times, it lacks in quite a few things that could've been improved to be much better. The game has quite a few glitches and issues, and I think it's a shame what happened to it. It could've been a much better game than it is right now. It has some potential, but I'm disappointed that the makers have stopped entirely, and I wish that I hadn't spent the $15 on it that I spent. This game has become one of the only games I regret purchasing.

Likely the creators and developers do not have enough support, and things probably got too complicated. While I understand everyone and all developers have their own life and their own needs, I've seen so little effort into updating this game and bringing it back to life that it feels like the entire project is dead to them.

It's sad when this happens to games. I've played some wonderful indie games before, but I'm afraid this one is just going to still be dead as it's been for so long. I wouldn't advise purchasing it, and I'm sure there are much better games that could be found of similar gameplay types.

column8:
I've been playing this game for several years. I don't find it to be particularly buggy, but I'm really disappointed that the developer abandoned it. It really did have so much potential. I'd buy it again, on sale, if I didn't own it, but I wouldn't recommend it to anyone else who doesn't like janky city. I'm known for collecting and loving misfit games.

If you're looking for polished graphics or decent progression, this is not the game for you. If you're looking for a city builder that allows you to play in dungeons as well, this might be a decent bet if you can get it on sale.

If you just like city builders that are well-supported by the community, go for Banished or something instead.

column8:
This game was purchased for me a long time ago as a birthday present. Got a shitload of good hours out of this game, but it was abandoned by the developers and left in a painfully unfinished state. It basically went straight from Alpha to "Finished". They flip-flopped on actually abandoning it for a while - they hired a new guy to work on it, which failed within weeks of happening...twice. Then they talked about releasing a Towns 2, despite this game being unfinished. The last attempt at saying "yes, we still care about this" was in early 2015, when a dev's house was supposedly under construction, so he had no room/time/internet to release a new patch. Finally, they stopped talking altogether. Their forums are a ghost town. This was one of the unfortunate early failures of the Greenlight system.

Been a while since I've played it, but I just wanted to add my voice to the chorus of "holy shit don't buy this" that is already out there. The game you're getting is not worth a 15 dollar price tag.

column8:
Before you read any further: this game has been abandoned. Any flaws, problems or glitches will not be fixed. 

Towns might have been the first Early Access game I've ever bought and it made me skeptical and wary of all future Early Access titles. It has a great premise that is executed poorly and although you might have a bit of fun with it for a few hours, there is little here to recommend an indepth playthrough.

I don't mind isometric, retroish graphics but these are, more often than not, absolutely annoying to look at. Towns has gone for a sort of Populus/Simcity kind of look, all graphical tilesets and while I think some of it works, particularly outside of the Town in the woods and forest, it often just looks totally ugly. There's no definition or clear sense of layering; what lies in front of things and behind other things can be really hard to tell. When you do have a Town, it all runs together and looks like someone who just found out they can download Final Fantasy sprites and has mashed them all together. Certain textures really grate on the eyes, particularly the water texture which you see a lot of.

Controlling this game isn't much better as the inteface is awful.  I've played a lot of games with clunky interfaces and struggled my way through them but this might be one of the worst. Absolutely nothing about it works properly; you'll probably have to hit every key on the keyboard to figure out what does what and even then, attempting to divine the systems that control anything in this game is like trying to scry the future or turn lead into gold. 

Towns had a lot of potential for growth (with a bad launch, but hey, potential?) - I mean, running a town built over a dungeon and attracting heroes, managing the enemies that come out, building the town up with facilities for the adventurers? It sounds like a perfect blend of Recettear, Diablo and Dungeon Keeper. But this is not that; Towns is a shoddy, abandoned game with very little to recommend it. It usually comes on sale for 7.49, discounted down from 14.99. It is not worth playing at either price and the fact they want you to pay $15 dollars for an abandoned game is repulsive. You shouldn't be paying for abandonware - speak with your wallet and say no to Towns.

NOTE: Steam shows 0.1 hours on record but I know for a fact I played at least a day of this - it felt longer, honestly, but trust me you don't need a whole day to see the flaws in this one.
column9:
Before you read any further: this game has been abandoned. Any flaws, problems or glitches will not be fixed. 

Towns might have been the first Early Access game I've ever bought and it made me skeptical and wary of all future Early Access titles. It has a great premise that is executed poorly and although you might have a bit of fun with it for a few hours, there is little here to recommend an indepth playthrough.

I don't mind isometric, retroish graphics but these are, more often than not, absolutely annoying to look at. Towns has gone for a sort of Populus/Simcity kind of look, all graphical tilesets and while I think some of it works, particularly outside of the Town in the woods and forest, it often just looks totally ugly. There's no definition or clear sense of layering; what lies in front of things and behind other things can be really hard to tell. When you do have a Town, it all runs together and looks like someone who just found out they can download Final Fantasy sprites and has mashed them all together. Certain textures really grate on the eyes, particularly the water texture which you see a lot of.

Controlling this game isn't much better as the inteface is awful.  I've played a lot of games with clunky interfaces and struggled my way through them but this might be one of the worst. Absolutely nothing about it works properly; you'll probably have to hit every key on the keyboard to figure out what does what and even then, attempting to divine the systems that control anything in this game is like trying to scry the future or turn lead into gold. 

Towns had a lot of potential for growth (with a bad launch, but hey, potential?) - I mean, running a town built over a dungeon and attracting heroes, managing the enemies that come out, building the town up with facilities for the adventurers? It sounds like a perfect blend of Recettear, Diablo and Dungeon Keeper. But this is not that; Towns is a shoddy, abandoned game with very little to recommend it. It usually comes on sale for 7.49, discounted down from 14.99. It is not worth playing at either price and the fact they want you to pay $15 dollars for an abandoned game is repulsive. You shouldn't be paying for abandonware - speak with your wallet and say no to Towns.

NOTE: Steam shows 0.1 hours on record but I know for a fact I played at least a day of this - it felt longer, honestly, but trust me you don't need a whole day to see the flaws in this one.

column8: Towns is one of my favorite settlement building games, and I  have played over 200 hrs.  It's in depth and challenging but sadly ragged around the edges. The developer abandoned the game a couple of years ago so it will never get finished, but it is still playable, as long as you don't mind not having an end game. It's hard to pick up, difficult to master, but still very satisfying to build a working, living settlement.

column8:
Evidemment, il est impossible de conseiller ce jeu. Mais il faut voir plus loin que ça, et non pas seulement le fait qu'il a été abandonné, et que les développeurs sont ''partis avec notre argent.'' Non. Il y a une histoire derrière ce scandale, scandale qui sera d'ailleurs devenu avec le temps un cas d'école, du moins dans sa face externe: celle du jeu indépendant qui ne sera jamais abouti et dont les joueurs payants auront été floués et jamais remboursés.

Mais il faut se pencher sur l'histoire de Towns. Car Towns a été un pilier. Effectivement, il a été un cas d'école, mais pour beaucoup plus que ce qu'il a créé en surface.
Raconter tout cela en détails serait trop long, aussi j'exhorterai tous ceux qui liront cet avis à s'y pencher. Lisez des articles, apprenez ce qu'il s'est passé. Towns aura été pour moi une belle expérience d'une quelque dizaine d'heures, mais une expérience forte, parce que la musique, parce que le contexte, parce que son histoire en tant que jeu et qu'aventure vécue par les développeurs. 

Towns fait partie de l'histoire du jeu indépendant, au même titre que Braid, Super Meat Boy, Machinarium, et tous ceux qui pourraient nous venir en tête. Mais il en fait partie pour une raison différente: Towns n'a peut être pas été un succès colossal, hissant ses créateurs au statut de dieux intouchables, mais il a eu un rôle beaucoup plus important: celui d'explorateur, celui de pionnier. Le rôle malheureux de l'exemple à ne pas suivre, le ''rôle du con.'' Est ce que je regrette d'avoir acheté ce jeu aussi cher ? Je ne pense pas. Parce que Towns me laissera des souvenirs de joueurs indélébiles, parce que j'ai vécu son histoire en tant que joueur impliqué directement.

Je tiens tout de même à remercier les trois membres de l'équipe SMP, qui malgré tout ont fait de leur mieux et se sont malheureusement retrouvés enterrés sous le poids de la réalité. Gracias hombres. Os agradezco mucho por lo que habeis hecho.



Je propose en lien le billet le plus complet et le plus pertinent que j'ai pu trouver sur ''la chute de Towns'': c'est en anglais, mais ça vaut le coup: http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-05-09-the-fall-of-towns
column9:
Obviously, it's impossible to recommend this game. But we need to look beyond that, and not just at the fact that it was abandoned and that the developers "ran off with our money." No. There's a story behind this scandal, a scandal that will, over time, become a textbook case, at least on its surface: that of the indie game that was never completed and whose paying players were cheated and never reimbursed.

But we need to look at the story of Towns. Because Towns was a pillar. Indeed, it was a textbook case, but for much more than what it created on the surface.
Recounting all this in detail would take too long, so I urge everyone reading this review to look into it. Read articles, learn what happened. Towns was a wonderful experience for me, lasting about ten hours, but a powerful one, because of the music, the context, its story as a game and as an adventure experienced by the developers.

Towns is part of the history of independent gaming, just like Braid, Super Meat Boy, Machinarium, and any others that come to mind. But it's part of it for a different reason: Towns may not have been a colossal success, elevating its creators to the status of untouchable gods, but it played a much more important role: that of explorer, that of pioneer. The unfortunate role of the example not to be followed, the "role of the idiot." Do I regret having bought this game so expensively? I don't think so. Because Towns will leave me with indelible gaming memories, because I experienced its story as a directly involved player.

I would still like to thank the three members of the SMP team, who, despite everything, did their best and unfortunately found themselves buried under the weight of reality. Thank you, men. We thank you very much for what you have done.

I'm linking the most comprehensive and relevant post I could find on "the fall of Towns": it's in English, but it's worth it: http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-05-09-the-fall-of-towns

Was the first and last time I put any money on an early access game. Shame, as I said I like the idea behind the game, the graphics are cute but in the end.. there isn't enough there.

Oh and did I mention the dev just ran off without a word?

column8:
tl;dr - Game is abandoned and overpriced, but if you pick it up for $5 you get your money's worth and have a new game to spend some weekend afternoons playing.

Years ago, this game was fun. Nothing in this game hadn't been done before, but it brought a lot of things together in an enjoyable package, and new content was being brought out that added facets to the idea of managing a town catering to adventurers and trying to survive the dangers of a D&D world. Now, the game is exactly the same. That's the problem; the end of Towns' beta came purely because the dev wanted more sales for less work.

It's really too bad that the development of this game became something of a hot potato due to fewer sales than the original developer wanted. Towns was developing in an interesting direction, and at the end of the updates had started introducing some enjoyably complicated ways to use basic water channels to make tasks easier. However, it never got to a fully mature stage, instead slowly petering out with updates being smaller and much less often. Eventually, after everyone assumed the dev had already walked away, it was pawned off to make a little more money, to someone who promised new updates but never delivered.

A lot of people are saying not to buy this game because it has been abandoned, and at full price I back that up. But I enjoy it still from time to time, knowing full well what kind of game it is. Maybe you will too?

My recommendation to buy this game comes with the caveat that you should look more closely at what it is, maybe scan through the wiki, and see if you might enjoy it. You can always try it out for an hour, then refund it, you know? But for god's sake don't pay $15 dollars for this, $5 at most. Something to stick on the wishlist and pick up during a steam sale.

column8:
The Short of it:
This game has been abandoned, wait till a sale brings its price down if you want to try it.

The long of it:

Unfortunatly I can't recomend this game. I bought it when it was still young and worthwhile, full of proimise and hope, sadly it has been abandoned.
Don't get me wrong here, I love the concept, I love the style and I love how the game works, but its unfinished, buggy and in need of some serious love. Perhaps the developers would be willing to part with it and hand it to someone who would be better suited to... finishing it off with all the features that I recall seeing on a roadmap... somewhere a long time ago....
If theres anything I can say about the game its that its gotten buggier since I stopped playing it, perhaps thats just the age of my computer finally showing, but I don't think so.
Its still quite challanging in and of itself, but like most of my towns end up, it is very unfinished, "Hero" mode and one other mode not implimented, and a lot of things requiring some much needed... laquer.

If you are looking for a game that will play similarly to this one but has a more finished feel try Gnomoria or Banished. Hell even the currently WIP Hearthstone has a more finished and complete feel!

Keep an open mind that games are always subject to change, and that, if this game is lucky, it will be worked on again.

I'd only EVER recommend buying this on sale.  Pay full price ONLY if you're in love with the advertising materials.

It's pretty good.  Nice, new concept, but it's also half baked.

It's somewhat challenging to get your town stabilized.  I never really did figure out how to do that, so that I could experience the 'sieges', or the deeper bosses.  I only made it to somewhere like the 5th or 6th underground level.

Buyer beware.  This game is incomplete, but very playable.

column8:
So...where to begin. This game I remember seeing back in 2011 on YouTube and I thought it was pretty cool. Found it on Steam when I joined, bought it when it was on sale for like $5. At the time, it was still being worked on, albeit slowly, so I thought "why the heck not." 

Looking back now, this game had potential but was left to rot by the devs and since late 2014 has never received a lick of development. It's unfinished, unpolished, buggy and will probably never, ever see what it was to become. It has good features and has a lot to it despite being in its forever unfinished state. The A.I. has always had a mind of its own and is hard to deal with when trying to set up runners, farmers, builders, and traders at the same time. Not having even just one person assigned to just one tiny task could end up causing your settlement to crash without enemies even attacking, simply because someone wouldn't go and make flour so you can bake bread so your dedicated farmers could eat and go harvest more wheat to repeat the cycle. 

It's a challenge, but if you're looking for a basic time waster, this game is good for that. I can't recommend it, however, just because of the state it's been left in without further development. If it's on sale for cheap and you like a nice, casual city builder, you might look into it. But for full price, look elsewhere. This game is going nowhere and will forever be that way.

column8:
Died in infancy, a failed product of Early Access.  What killed it?  Literally Steam Early Access.  This game sold pretty solidly for a bit before that, but when it was dubbed as being "garbage" by a majority of steam, it seems the devs lost interst in further developing it, and moved on.

Sad, but true.  Other games seem to be following in it's foot-steps however, though less in the "Failed and Abandoned" way.  Stonehearth looks promising, as does Timber and Stone.

Edit 12/30/2018:  Was looking through my reviews.  Stonehearth AND Timber and Stone are pretty dead.  T&S is unfinished and won't get any further updates, and Stonehearth is "Finished" and the community seems to agree it never lived up to it's potential.

Town building games focused around creating buildings seem to be screwy thanks to the fickle customers and devs.

column8:
Going to put in a few words to defend this game. Everything people say is true - it's unfinished and abandoned, and I wouldn't pay $15 for it. However, if you can get it for like $5, and you like this sort of game, I'd say go for it.

I haven't played it since like 2 years ago, but I have to admit I liked it when I played it, despite its unfinished-ness and bugs. Like, there's Dwarf Fortress, then there's Gnomoria, which is DF-lite, and then there's Towns, which is Gnomoria-lite. Relatively easy to play and fun to build up your little town. Not too much micromanagement. Fun to zone out to.

column8:
Alright folks, the game doesn't deserve all the hate. Well, ummm, actually it does, but not to this extent. I originally bought the game at version 8 (now it's version 14e), so yeah, I'm amongst those who were "cheated" by early promises, and I will still give this game a thump up.

Why it does deserve the hate? Because it's clearly unfinished.
-Several in-game features are clunky, for example ordering your troops around: you can't simply say "go there", you can only place patrol points. So exploring the dungeons beneath the surface is like: right-click somewhere, place waypoint, wait until they get there, right-click on waypoint, remove waypoint, right-click somewhere else, place waypoint, wait until they get there, etc. Since there's no other option I can live with it, but I'm not lovin' it.
-Poor pathfinding. The townies may just ignore the roads, although they walk parallel with them only one square away.
-AI is lacking. The haulers tend to choose stuff to pick up far, far away, instead of that exact same thing they are standing on. And, please, don't go to sleep or eat when several dozens of spiders are besieging the town. Also, don't try to gather loot in the middle of the battlefield, because it's dangerous to your health.
-The variety of stuff to build is a bit underwhelming, although not always. For example you can build one type of wooden chair (not counting that one which needs gold besides wood), but at the same time there are like twenty stone wall styles. So building homes is not on Sims level.
I think these are the negatives worth mentioning, may update if I encounter something I haven't written here yet. Umm, okay, others may say the music is repetitive, but I don't mind, it's not horrible.

Why it does not deserve this much hate:
- Contrary to a lot of other reviews, I have not encountered _any_ bugs, at least not apparent ones. No memory leaks. No hangups, no slowdowns, no CTDs. I don't really get what others mean when they describe this game as "buggy as ****". There were a lot of them in earlier versions, but right now this is one of the most bug-free games I ever played.

I will not make a list about other pros, because they are subjective. I just leave here this: I still prefer Towns way over Gnomoria, and if it was a terrible game I wouldn't have come close to play it for 270 hours. Not many of my games can boast that much playtime.



Thus, I dare to say, if you like building towns from blocks, and if Towns is on sale, try it.

column8:
We made so much pie.

My people had 0 happiness at all times.

They all had beds, but we couldn't afford to house everyone, so we just built waist-high wooden walls around everyone's little tenements and called it good. 

We could barely afford to make clothing for everyone. What clothing we had was made of dead spiders and assorted bones. 

But we would never starve.

Because there was so much pie.

And that's all I have to say about this game.

column8:
I wanted to like this game when I got it. I really did. I was intimidated by Dwarf Fortress and thought that this would be an equally fun little world builder game.

No, it really is not.

This is Dwarf Fortress's half cousin he really wishes wasn't kinda in the family. The menus are much less deep that DF, but at the cost of having what feels like very few options. The UI is terrible in general, and I found that after playing this game for 27.6 hours, I still felt lost and slow doing everything. This isn't helped by a TERRIBLE camera angle, and the entire game just feels in general like a poorly made and thought through Dwarf Fortress.

If you want this game's experience, just get Dwarf Fortress and find some youtube tutorials. You'll thank me later, I promise.

column8:
Klar, es wurde aufgegeben und das schon mehrmals (dies ist glaube ich das dritte Mal), dennoch: Es macht Spaß und ist in seiner Art besonders. Nur weil die Entwicklung beendet wurde heißt es nicht, das Spiel sei schlecht (nun perfekt ist es auch nicht aber trotzdem gibt es Leute die kaufen EA oder Ubisoft Spiele).
Das Spiel wird immer schwieriger, Invasionen kommen oder Zombies infizieren eure Einwohner und ihr habt eine kleine Apocalypse. Goblin und Orks kommen zwischendurch mal und plündern eure Stadt. Es kann gehandelt werden etc.
Es gibt Helden welche ihr bei Laune halten müsst! Diese erkunden eigenständig "euer" Dungeon und leveln auf. Eure Wachen können sich währenddessen um lästige Invasoren kümmern und eure Dörfler sammeln unterdessen Loot ein!
Es ist ein komplexes Spiel, mit vielen Möglichkeiten und es macht halt wie gesagt Spaß (es gibt auch eine Demo....nur so nebenbei). 50% der negativen Reviews regen sich eh nur darüber auf, dass die Entwicklung abgebrochen wurde...am Schluss wurde extra Modding-Support eingefügt damit es nicht stirbt.
column9:
Sure, it's been abandoned several times (I think this is the third time), but it's still fun and special in its own way. Just because development has ended doesn't mean the game is bad (well, it's not perfect either, but there are still people who buy EA or Ubisoft games).
The game gets increasingly difficult; invasions come, or zombies infect your inhabitants, and you have a mini-apocalypse. Goblins and orcs appear from time to time and plunder your city. You can trade, etc.
There are heroes you have to keep happy! They explore "your" dungeon independently and level up. Your guards can take care of annoying invaders, while your villagers collect loot!
It's a complex game, with many possibilities, and, as I said, it's fun (there's also a demo...just by the way). 50% of the negative reviews are just complaining about the fact that development was canceled...in the end, extra modding support was added so it wouldn't die.

column8:
The game used to be really good. But then the devs changed one little thing, that ruined it for me entirely.
To get a higher population you used to need happiness. Happiness was achieved due to idleness (no work).
This made somehow sense and was somewhat easy to achieve (the rest of the game is time consuming enough, so that was fine). But now they changed that. Being overworked and being idle is decreasing happiness now... 
To maintain a mix between idleness and workload you have to insanely manage and switch work groups of citizens in a tedious, time consuming, boring and annoying way.

The game was fine, but now I can't recommend it anymore.

But not this game. Move along folks.

column8:
Love this game because 491 hours of gameplay said so. I don't know why people are saying there is only 7 hours gameplay in there. So not true.

Yes it's been halted due to being launched before steams beta program meaning the game stopped getting advertised and people stopped buying it but it's still a solid game with very few bugs.

I think half the problem is that people get frustrated with not knowing how to actually play. When did the world start needing tutorials to function in games? Just jump in and figure it out piece by piece.

It's a great game in my opinion and it's been well worth the money even if it doesn't have all the features we were promised

column8:
ก็เป็นเกมส์เล็กๆไฟล์เบาๆเสปกก็เบาๆแต่ไม่เบาสมอง(ปวดหัวสัด) กราฟฟิกพอรับใด้ แค่หมุนจอไม่ใด้  Ai ยืดหยุ่นพอสมควรและฮาดคอด้วย เจอมอนเตอร์หล่ะก็ใด้ตายกันไปข้างนึงเลยทีเดียว พี่แกเล่นสู้ไม่ถอยไม่สนสเตตัสด้วย  แบบว่ามือเปล่าก็สู้เว้ย เดินเฉียดเป็นโดน
แนวทางการเล่นก็ไม่มีอะไรน้อย แบบมีเยอะมาก  อธิบายแบบผ่านๆละกัน   ก็เลือกแมพตามใจชอบละกัน ถ้าไม่ชอบก็กด just quit ออกมาโดยไม่ต้องเชฟ แต่ถ้าคิดว่าใช่ก็ให้กดเชฟใว้ก่อนเลย ค่อยๆเลือกไปโหลดแมพไม่นาน   ใน2วันแรกคนของเราจะยังไม่หิวดังนั้นต้องรีบปลูกต้นแอปเปิลกับต้นข้าวใว้ก่อน แล้วต่อมาก็ให้ปลูกต้นสน(pine tree) เมนูคำสั่งปลูกพืชจะอยู่ปุ่มฟ้าด้านขวามือรูปต้นข้าว ควรกดเชฟใว้ด้วยเพราะการปลูกต้นpineนี้คนของเราจะออกไปหาต้นอ่อน(ต้นเป็นพุ่มเล็กๆ)ข้างนอกอาจมีตาย ให้กดหยุดเกมส์เพื่อหาดูต้นอ่อนว่าอยู่ใกล้มอนเตอร์หรือปล่าวหากมีให้คลิกขวาเพื่อทำลายชะคนของเราจะใด้ไม่ไปเก็บจากแถวนั้น  
....แนะนำ....ให้สร้างโชนตลาด(ไม่มีเงื่อนไขในการสร้าง)จะมีพ่อค้ามาขายของ(เสียงผิวปาก)อาจมีเหล็กมาขาย(ไม่ต้องชื้อมากใช้แค่ทำเครื่องมือพอ)  และให้สร้างtavern room กับสร้างtavern โชน(ไม่แน่ใจว่าต้องการArenaด้วยหรือปล่าว) จะมีheroสุ่มมาให้(เสียงกีต้าดัง)ดีกว่าแบ่งคนไปเป็นทหารแน่นอน(คราฟอาวุทธและชุดเกราะเผื่อให้เค้าด้วยแต่ส่วนใหญ่พี่เค้าจะหาเก็บจากมอนเตอร์เอง)  ข้อดีของhero คือเค้าจะตระเวนไล่เก็บมอนสเตอร์เอง ยิ่งมีชัก3-4คนนี่สบายเลย เลือดมีมากและฮิวเร็วมาก ส่วนข้อเสียคือเราไม่สามารถควบคุมเค้าใด้ เผลอๆบางทีโดนมอนเตอร์รุมยำเล่นหนีมาหาให้คนเราช่วยอีก(ชักศึกเข้าบ้าน)  การสร้างเตียงนอนถึงแม้นว่าจะวางอยู่นอกโชนห้องนอน(ผมคราฟใว้ขายแล้วก็กดลบโชนห้องนอนออก)ก็ยังถือว่าเป็นห้องนอนนะ 

การคราฟอาวุทธและชุด กดเมนูปุ่มแดงเพื่อคราฟ(ควรวางสต็อคไพล อาวุทธและชุดเกราะด้วยไม่งั้นคนจะไม่ทำ)เริ่มต้นก็ชุดไม้  อาวุทธหิน ชุดเหล็กนี่ผมแนะนำให้มองข้าม เพราะชุดหนังกับชุดขนแกะแหล่มกว่า แต่หากเลี้ยงสัตว์ใว้ (สร้างคอกสัตว์ สัตว์ทีเราเก็บเกียวจริงๆตือตัวที่วิ่งเพ่นพ่านรอบคอกสัตว์ คอกที่สร้างก็แค่บ้านเก็บพ่อพันธุ์แม่พันธุ์ ) แล้วสัตว์ตายเยอะกระดูกเกลื่อนแหล่มเลยคราฟอาวุทธกระดูกจะแรงกว่าอาวุทธหินและใกล้เคียงกับอาวุทธเหล็กมากๆ (ชุดกระดูกกันน้อยกว่าชุดหนังแต่ถ้ายังคราฟชุดหนังไม่ใด้ก็ให้ใช้ไปก่อน) แต่หากมีHeroหล่ะก็สบายครับ หินแมงมุมมีเกลื่อนแน่นอนให้คราฟดาบแมงมุมเลย(ใช้ทองแดง1หินแมงมุมม2)หรือไม่ก็หอกเขียว 


การสร้างบ้านอันนี้ต้องใจเย็นครับ ระวังคนเราติดอยู่บนหลังคาตายด้วยนะ การวางหลังคาควรวางบนกำแพงก่อนลากทีละแถวอย่ากดคลุมไม่งั้นมีหล่น(ลบยาก) หากไม่แน่ใจกดเชฟใว้ก่อนเลยครับ หากพลาดก็แค่ just quitออกแล้วโหลดใหม่

สุดท้ายนี้(ขี้เกียจพิมพ์ละ)จงทำจิตปล่อยวาง Ai ไม่ฉลาดมันคิดไม่ใด้ หมั่นกดหยุดเกมส์เพื่อตรวจสอบเกมส์หรือพักสมอง ...........................อย่าลืมอันนี้สำคัญ หมั่นเชฟบ่อยๆมันจะช่วยคุณใด้เยอะ
column9:
It's a small, light game with light specs, but not mind-boggling (it gives me a headache). The graphics are acceptable, except you can't rotate the screen. The AI ​​is quite flexible and hardcore. If you encounter a monster, you'll almost certainly die. The game is a no-brainer, regardless of status. It's like fighting barehanded, and anything close to it will kill you.
The gameplay is simple, but there's a lot to it. Let me explain briefly. Choose a map you like. If you don't like it, just quit without saving. If you think you're up to it, save first. Choose a map slowly and load it. It won't take long. During the first two days, your people won't be hungry, so plant apple trees and rice plants first. Then, plant pine trees. The crop menu is the blue button to the right of the rice plant. You should save because planting pine trees will kill your people outside if you go out to look for saplings (small bushes). Pause the game and check if there are any saplings near monsters. If there are, right-click to destroy them so your people don't have to harvest them.
....I recommend building a market zone (no requirements). There will be merchants selling goods (whistling sound). They might also sell metal (no need to buy much, just use it to make tools). Also, build a tavern room and a tavern zone (not sure if an arena is required). A random hero will be assigned (loud guitar sound). It's definitely better than dividing up your troops (craft weapons and armor for them, but they usually gather it from monsters themselves). The advantage of a hero is that they will roam around and hunt down monsters themselves. With 3-4 of them, it's easy. They have plenty of health and heal very quickly. The disadvantage is that you can't control them. Sometimes, they might get attacked by monsters and run away to ask for help (inviting enemies into your home). Creating a bed, even if it's outside the bedroom zone (I crafted it to sell and then deleted the bedroom zone), is still considered a bedroom.

To craft weapons and armor, press the red menu button to craft (you should place a stockpile in it). Weapons and armor (or else, people won't make them). Start with wooden armor. Stone armor. I recommend skipping steel armor, as leather and wool armor are better. However, if you raise animals (building animal pens, the animals you actually harvest are the ones that roam around the pens; the pens are just for breeding houses), and animals die and bones are everywhere, crafting bone armor is more powerful than stone armor and is very similar to steel armor. (Bone armor is less effective than leather armor, but if you can't craft leather armor yet, use that for now.) But if you have a hero, you're good to go. Spiderstone is abundant. Craft a spider sword (1 copper, 2 spiderstones) or a green spear.

Building a house requires patience. Be careful of people getting stuck on the roof. When placing the roof, place it on the wall first, dragging one row at a time. Don't press "Cover," or it will fall (it's hard to erase). If you're unsure, save it. If you make a mistake, just quit and reload.

Finally (I'm too lazy to type) let your mind go. AI is not smart, it can't think. Press pause often to check the game or rest your brain. ...........................Don't forget this is important. Save often, it will help you a lot.

column8:
Why the heck is this game still for sale Steam??  Boo on you Steam.  Boo.   We should bring you up on charges of human rights abuses.  The cowards gave up on it nearly 2 years ago, and you still leave it up here for them to get more out of the player community?   Need a downvote on Steam as well as this game!

So my review of the game.
Well it showed promise for the first 6 months.  Had fun with it and was patched pretty often.  You could see it starting to come together.

Then these two cowardly, piece of re-heated dead monkey lice they call Devs gave up.  Their names are Xavi Canal and Ben Palgi if you'd like to read more about the story.  So then they give the development over to some poor schmuk named Frankenberger.  He couldn't handle it solo as he was more of a fan than a true dev.  So when he quit in Sept. 2014 that's exactly where this game has been.  Exactly.  18 month ago.

So it sold 200K copies for $15-$20.  You do the math.  Someone got paid, and we got the shaft.

column8:
The game was rather crude back then. I found myself struggling to enjoy it. Back then, I would've recommended it if you're into sandbox games like this. After all, devs were working on it, slowly making it better.

....But I wouldn't recommend it at all anymore. It's abandoned, devs have completely stopped working on this, and it's definitely NOT worth 15 bucks for an unfinished, buggy, crude product. Another game that never makes it out of early access, just like fucking Day-Z. Don't bother.

column8:
I bought Towns, back when it was in alpha (pre-steam) and had great potential.

It's saddening to see that there have been no updates or even bug fixes. The developers have abandoned their dream - something that happens all too often. 

Don't buy. It's not worth $15. I thought it was too much when I paid $5 for it, but I thought it would be continued. I was wrong. This is a shining example of why you don't buy into these early access scams.

column8:
Неплохая игра, но ужасно глючная, недоработанная и, по всей видимости, заброшенная,
При населении около 100 человек или даже меньше, посленцы начинают дико тупить из-за чего скорость производства сильно падает и в итоге половина населения вымирает от голода не смотря на то, что куча полей с готовыми фруктами и овощами.
column9:
It's a decent game, but terribly buggy, unfinished, and apparently abandoned.
At a population of around 100 or even less, the survivors begin to lag horribly, causing production speed to plummet, and eventually half the population dies of starvation, despite having tons of fields of ripe fruits and vegetables.

column8: As it is this is not a game you want to spend more than $5 or less on. If you are looking to spend a long time building and making slow or no progress this is it. There are a few tricks to pick up that allows you to actually achieve some progress but due to the programming allowing your townies to starve because they have traveled to far, or gotten themselves stuck its still a slow and frustrating game. I keep hoping that the developers will adress some of these issues and still nothing. The food issue is the worst as you can do nothing to adjust for it, once you go into the ground mining and exploring your townies will die and fast. The values for food and sleep run down to swiftly, and outside of stopping your townies from digging completely you can not keep them from entering the depths where once you go ten levels down they die from starvation. Some of the tools are intriguing, and fun to play with as long as you refrain from going past -10 in digging. Once you come to terms with these drawbacks its a fun little game. Oh yea to clear out the monsters in the dungeons you do get heros yet they are completely random and you must account for them as being three population wise thats how hard they hit your food supply. There is so much potential in this game and it is sad to see it left so broken. If given an overall score for entertainment, novelty, and playability at best its a 3 out of 10.

column8:
Pro:
Finished and relatively bug free.
Ability to give units tasks (and thereby automate your "Town")
Dungeon crawling in addition to town/city building
Lots of crafting / building
Resource management

Con:
Devs abandoned the game
14.99 price tag is a bit steep (get it on sale)
Can be rough for beginners / learning curve


Because the game has been abandoned doesn't mean the game is horrible just no additional patches, content, etc for this game.

Personally, I enjoy this game.  It took a bit to figure out but there's a wiki because what game doesn't have a wiki these days ( http://towns.gamepedia.com/Towns_Wiki ).  You can get most/all the information you need to be able to play the game here as well as access to mods or where to get mods.

I like how you're able to relocate/make resource areas to where you want them.  In a lot of these games, generally they just regrow in an area that you've already harvested or you have to craft a special/specific building to harvest any additional resources.  In this game, you can take saplings/seeds/fruit/etc and create an area where you'd like them to grow.  Flowers, trees, etc will still grow in other areas but this allows you to have say 5x5 of trees (for lumber) that will continually regrow in that exact same plot (after being chopped down, a sapling will begin to grow in it's place and after a few minutes you'll have a fully grown tree... this applies to wheat, fruit, etc.).  This makes your villagers much more efficient at gathering and better for your resource management.  It is also significantly safer than traversing the area filled with random monsters like brownies, goblins, ghosts, etc.

The big downside of the game is that a lot of people feel it isn't "finished" or "unpolished" and the lack of further development.  However, the game is fully functional and the balance may be a little off but that's easily adjustable via the xml files or mods.  Also, game can be pretty brutal at times such as when you expand a bit too early or get raided by monsters and your villagers have no armor nor weapons at their disposal in addition to their piddly health pool.

If you like these kinds of games (city building/resource management) and don't mind that there won't be able more updates then buy the game but I'd recommend waiting until it's on sale.  Even if development has stopped, there's a lot of mods for the game which add content or change texture packs, etc.

column8:
A Cautionary tale of how easy it is to get duped in todays global community. People want to believe in indy developers, because some incredibly unique and interesting experiences sometimes come from unexpected places. Unfortunately, right from the start of this games release, you could tell it was not where it should be, despite peoples support and the developers initial passion. All of that interest trailed off into nothingness very quickly, and now all of the initial supporters are left with a scar in their libraries.

Dead project. Read other reviews for much better and complete alternatives.

column8:
住人に命令を出して眺めるのを楽しむゲームです。
やってみれば面白いです。一時は夢中になりました。
荒削りなドット絵のおじさん達がワキャワキャ働いている姿は
微塵もかわいくないのについ目を奪われます。
建材ブロックもそれなりにおしゃれだし、家具も多いです。
シージ(襲撃)や洞窟探索、雪地形や砂漠地形など楽しめる要素が
詰まってるので、決して手抜きのゲームではないです。
採掘のシステムなどもバランスは割といいと思います。

AIがいかんせん馬鹿なので、勝手に遠くまで採集に行って骨に
なってたり、食事抜きでその骨を回収しに行って骨になってたり
なかなか困らせてくれます。
あと洞窟内をわざわざ遠回りして行って骨になったりします。

建築は高さ制限があり、3階建てがやっとできるぐらいです。
(地下から建てればまた別ですが)
それがやっぱり惜しいです。高層建築はロマンですから。
それでも100時間は遊べました。wikiもあります。
前途なきゲームですが、セールなら買ってもいいと思います。
column9:
This is a game where you enjoy giving orders to residents and watching them.
It's fun once you try it, and I was hooked for a while.
The rough-hewn pixel art of old men working enthusiastically is not the least bit cute, but it's still captivating.
The building blocks are reasonably stylish, and there's a lot of furniture.
It's packed with fun elements like siege (raids), cave exploration, snowy terrain, and desert terrain, so it's by no means a sloppy game.
I also think the mining system is pretty well-balanced.

The AI ​​is pretty stupid, so it can be quite annoying, like traveling far away to gather forage and turning into bones, or skipping meals to collect those bones and turning into bones again.
It can also be quite annoying, like taking a detour through a cave and turning into bones.

There's a height limit for buildings, and you can only build three stories.
(It's a different story if you build from underground.)
That's a shame, after all. High-rise buildings are the dream.
But even so, I still managed to play for 100 hours. There's also a wiki.
It's a game with no future, but I think it's worth buying if it's on sale.

column8:
First off, this game is the embodiment of early access games gone wrong. It's terrible when developers don't deliver on every promise, because this game had a lot of potential.
That said, the game you see now is complete and wont see any future updates. It is very difficult and takes a long time to progress, which is good. There is definitely replay value as well. 
The one thing I hate most about this game is how the levels work when you're trying to build everything.

Tl;dr- It's good as-is,  but the developer is terrible, so buy it at a discount when you can.

column8:
One of the collective of Greenlight games that has been discontinued in its development.

The developers have backed away from it entirely, after having instilled new ones to take their place.

Though it has mods to take its replayability and value up a notch, it is not going anywhere beyond the most recent update.

The game itself offers an interesting idea, where you are given a group of individuals who've managed to get stranded in the middle of a wilderness where survival is bent upon preparation against attacks from waves native slime blobs, werebears, skeletons, goblin-like creatures, and other manners of mythical beings. Each of said creatures seems to inherently wish to destroy the little "Townies" that inhabit the locale.

Thus it is up to you to assign duties and crafts in order to farm, harvest, bake, mine, and provide a kind of economy of barter in order to sustain the townspeople from starving, or being slaughtered and eaten by local denizens.

After creating a working village, whether it be in a mountainside or under the ground, or whatever the case, townies can venture below, into the earth to unveil treasures from creatures, with or without the help of heroes attained from local taverns.

With certain mods, the game can be improved, but what with the care given to it, the modding community has very well moved on; it has been left aside and is a token of proof against the usefullness of buying games before their true completion.

Other games similar to this are Gnomoria, and Stonehearth, both of which brandish better Ai development and offer a team who is in love with the product they are creating.

I would only recommend trying this game if it were on sale at 80% off if you wish to give a town-simulator a try; but I personally would have preferred buying Gnomoria over this game.

column8:
I adore Towns. I know it's not the popular opinion here, but I have spent a happy 300+ hours building and exploring and fighting. It was well worth the $10 or so that I spent on it a few years ago. 

In Towns, you are in charge of an idiotic band of Townies who you instruct to gather resources, build buidlings, craft luxuries, cook food, and defend the town both as soldiers and civilains. In addition to keeping you populace well-fed and happy, you must defend against raiding bands of villians while delving deep into the dangerous underground to find more stone, iron, and gold. You can entice heroes to come and help you or instead swarm the monsters with well-armed townsfolk. The gameplay is heavy in resource management and building but has a satisfying amount of fighting and exploring. 

Why are the reviews so negative? This game long been public and under development, and that development stalled and then eventually halted. There are lists of features yet to be implemented and bugs to be fixed. Many believe that Towns is an unfinished game and are very angry about this. My interpretation is that the developers were just too ambitious about what to include and ended up with lots of great features that don't all function perfectly. I think it's finished, just not polished.  

So despite my positive review, buyer beware. Play a demo if you can. Think about what bugs get under your skin and what you are happy to ignore while exploring the game mechanics. Think about how many hours or what level of gameplay you need to shell out some cash. But I would buy this game again, even in its current state. But do not buy it expecting additional development - that ship has sailed.
column9:
I adore Towns. I know it's not the popular opinion here, but I have spent a happy 300+ hours building and exploring and fighting. It was well worth the $10 or so that I spent on it a few years ago. 

In Towns, you are in charge of an idiotic band of Townies who you instruct to gather resources, build buidlings, craft luxuries, cook food, and defend the town both as soldiers and civilains. In addition to keeping you populace well-fed and happy, you must defend against raiding bands of villians while delving deep into the dangerous underground to find more stone, iron, and gold. You can entice heroes to come and help you or instead swarm the monsters with well-armed townsfolk. The gameplay is heavy in resource management and building but has a satisfying amount of fighting and exploring. 

Why are the reviews so negative? This game long been public and under development, and that development stalled and then eventually halted. There are lists of features yet to be implemented and bugs to be fixed. Many believe that Towns is an unfinished game and are very angry about this. My interpretation is that the developers were just too ambitious about what to include and ended up with lots of great features that don't all function perfectly. I think it's finished, just not polished.  

So despite my positive review, buyer beware. Play a demo if you can. Think about what bugs get under your skin and what you are happy to ignore while exploring the game mechanics. Think about how many hours or what level of gameplay you need to shell out some cash. But I would buy this game again, even in its current state. But do not buy it expecting additional development - that ship has sailed.

column8:
Don't buy this game and never ever buy any Early Access game.

Calling this fraud was probably a little too strong.  The game is unfinished.  There is no real workable mature town.  You can start your town and you just get to a certain point where there is garbage all over the ground and even with a current gen processor and GPU your townies spend so much time trying to figure out how to do their next task they get tired and need to sleep or they don't eat and die.  It is very broken.  You can fudge hunger and sleep timers in the game files as a workaround to some degree, but cheating can't really be called a fix and your town will still end up with unused trash everywhere and the game will lag as it tries to deal with this.  Just don't buy it.  There is no accountability in early access and Steam does nothing to police bad games/developers so you end up with a lot of shovelware like this.  Avoid early access.

column8:
Overall the game is very fun at first but doesn't really have any long term replayability.  I bought it because I enjoyed similar games (mostly Gnomoria) and wanted to see what else was out there.  If you enjoy that style of game you'll get a few good play throughs on this (maybe 10-20 hours, even though I got 43 out of it) and they you will run out of things to do.  If that is enough entertainment for you to be worth the cost then you should buy it.

There are a lot of negative reviews about the game being broken.  It isn't.  There is a big difference between broken and not nearly as good as it could have been.  I don't usually review games but I didn't feel like this game deserved most of the comments being made in the negative reviews so I wanted to provide another point of view.

column8:
0/10

Do not buy Towns.  It has ripped off too many people.

Towns is a game about building a village for simulated RPG adventurers. Reading about all the features it had and all the downloads, I figured I would throw in my $5 and play. This is 2013 by the way. Unfortunately, the game was unplayable. With a glitchy interface and the inability to even pass the tutorial or even build one room.

A few months passed from August 2013 and Steam decides to release Green Light, I service indicating which games are incomplete but still up for purchase. To my surprise, Towns was lumped into the newly founded category. Basically, I bought a game I did not know was incomplete. The optimistic side of me thought that Towns would be complete some time in the future.

Fast forward a year to 2014 and I see news that Towns developers gave up on ever finishing the game. Meaning they simply took off with my money.

http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/217154/Alphafunded_Steam_game_Towns_abandoned_by_devs.php

Upon hearing the news, I was again disappointed. 

The following year, Steam released a refund policy. I was excited to read that they would allow refunds that were within 14 days with less than one hour of play time. Given that I have clocked a whopping, miserable 19 minutes on Towns, I figured I could do one last attempt.... DENIED.

So here I am, writing about how much I have been ripped off from buying the game Towns. It was $5 sure, but I didn't know it was incomplete at the time and Steam fails to acknowledge their mistake.

I hope this is the right forum to post to because quite frankly, I feel people should know the darker side that is Steam.

Moral of the story.

DO NOT BUY TOWNS

Development on this game stopped about a year ago when it was still unfinished. I don't understand why it is part of today's (Oct 12, 2015) weeklong sale. It is not a finished product and never will be. The last patch was over a year ago. 

Steam, you are doing your customers a disfavor by still selling this. It is failures such as this product that are turning players away from funding and purchasing Early Access games. It certainly turned me off and I won't make that mistake again. 

Steam, please remove this game from sale.

column8:
I had previously written a positive review for this game having bought it in 2012 or so. It was a game with some potential, like an RTS version of Minecraft where instead of playing as a single character, you are managing an entire town, complete with heroes etc.

The game was very much imperfect, but as an early access game at the time it was worth a shout. Here we are 3 years later and the verdict is very different. I could go on with basically the same stuff that the other reviews have said, but TLDR:

The devs abandoned the game. It is buggy and incomplete. The devs have censored basically all negativity and criticism in about the game and it very much seems a case of them taking the money and running.

column8:
Note: I posted a previous review but I want to elaborate on it now.

Overall Summary
This game is having tough times. Sure the devs have took the money and, almost entirly stopped development (They release fixes, and such). But this is because at this point I can say this game is done! It has many features to explore with alot of replayability in it, the Alpha may aswell be finished. I can say if the community would lighten up and, maybe release a few mods this game would be even better!

Though I admit you can say "They took the money and, ran!" you cant blame them after what they have given to us. It is a finished game that I beleive is worth 15$. If you dont beleive me, please try the demo and, see whether it is your cup of tea. 

Gameplay review
The game is highly replayable with diffrent challanges rising, and some just repeating. Your successes may be minor at first but they get bigger and, bigger, and even bigger as you continue through the game! Once you mastered one floor, suprise there is another full of harder, and newer enemies. You can send your soldiers down, but do you want to risk a seige assualting your town when it is ungaurded? "Oh no! Robert Died!", these all arise in your game, and I assure you it is a intresting game when on hard difficulty.

Ratings
Community: 7/10
Gameplay: 9.5/10
Replayability: 9.5/10
Major Update Frequency: 2/10
Minor Update Frequency: 7/10
Features: 9/10

Style
Storyline: Generated
Characters: Randomized
Art: Blocks
Mobs: Fictional
Weapons: Varied
Armors: Varies
Crafting: Yes
RTS (Total War): No
RTS (City-Builder): Yes
Similar Game: Geomoria, Tropico (Similar in the way you build the town, and buildings but not directly control the people's choices.)

Recommended?: Yes! But please try the demo first!

column8:
Player: Alright! Let's make some bread. *Creates bread somehow.*
Town Citizen: I'm hungry! I need food.
Player: Wow! What good timing. My citizens just made some bread and put it into the food stockpile. Now you can get yourself some food, Town Citizen!
Town Citizen: I'm hungry! I still need food.
Player: Uhh... there's bread in the stockpile... If your hungry, then go to the stockpile and get some bread.
Town Citizien: I'm still hungry. You need to tell me to eat or else I will starve.
Player: What!?
Town Citizen: Oh woe! If only the player could have told me to eat instead of letting me waste away in front of this delicious bread. *Dies.*
Player: What the hell was that? I've seen sacks of bricks that were smarter than that.

column8:
It is a great alpha, but the developer stopped making it because it stopped selling. So rather than finish it, he kept the money from what are effectively pre-orders and just moved it straight from alpha to release without finishing anything.

[Nov 2017]
They sold approx 200,000 copies at an avg price of approx US$13.75 for a very approximate US$2,750,000 ... Now obviously that doesn't take into account giveaways and press copies, but that's not going to make a dent in the 'millions' part. It doesn't take over 2mil to make a game of this nature.

column8:
The game is a decent bit of fun, full of trying to make your little pissheads happy with bedrooms and food, and making more and more, and surviving more and more. You'll eventually get hero's, adventurers. You house them, and let them stay at a tavern, which in turn, they will/can explore a dungeon.

I've never gotten beyond a certain point, but I've gotten rough ideas from crappy guides and old playthroughs.
There's also not a main goal in the game. You can explore the dungeons, or not. You can make a pyramid in the desert, or a massive castle in the forest. You can make a massive walled off flat civilization, or you can shove everything into a single tower.

column8:
Es una cascara de papa de juego. El desarrollador un golfo que se hizo con el dinero y abandonó el juego. La verdad es que los de Steam deberian de hacer algo para obligar a los desarrolladores a cumplir. Si los que no compran juegos originales se les llama piratas, ¿como se deberian de llamar a los que no terminan sus juegos y los dejan abandonados despues de haber cobrado?, estafadores, ratas de cloacas, timadores, hermanos gemelos de politicos corruptos (desconozco si los hay de otro tipo), vividores, caraduras, cuentistas. El desarrollador se amparo en el tiron del Dwarf Fortress para engañar a todo el mundo. Seguro que estará embarcado en otro proyecto similar, o eso o en su lugar de residencia natural, la carcel

Edito: no entiendo como a dia de hoy siguen vendiendo este juego

Edito: El "pieza" del desarrollador se registro en PDL, un foro de gente seria y le gustan lo wargames  y buenos juegos en general para promocionar el juego. Ademas pidio el voto en Greenligth de Steam para que saliera. Cuando lo consiguio de él nada más se supo. Si mirais los primeros post promete mucho, soluciona muchas dudas. Mas adelante piden que han sido nominados a mejor juego y que lo votemos,etc.

http://www.puntadelanza.net/Foro/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=37&t=12899&hilit=towns
column9:
It's a dumb game. The developer is a crook who made off with the money and abandoned the game. The truth is, Steam should do something to force the developers to comply. If those who don't buy original games are called pirates, what should they call those who don't finish their games and abandon them after getting paid? Scammers, sewer rats, con artists, twin brothers of corrupt politicians (I don't know if there are any other types), freeloaders, shameless people, storytellers. The developer used the Dwarf Fortress hype to deceive everyone. He's surely working on another similar project, either that or his natural place of residence: prison.

Edit: I don't understand how they're still selling this game today.

Edit: The "piece" of the developer registered on PDL, a forum for serious people who like wargames and good games in general, to promote the game. They also asked for votes on Steam's Greenlight to be released. When they got their vote, nothing more was known about it. If you look at the first posts, it's very promising and answers many questions. Later, they ask that they've been nominated for best game and that we vote for it, etc.

http://www.puntadelanza.net/Foro/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=37&t=12899&hilit=towns

Remember those names and never purchase anything with their name stamped on it. column8:
I honestly can say I enjoyed playing this game.
Up until (every single time I might add) all my villagers die.
A creature (depending on the terrain) killed one of my villagers (with the guards refusing to come assist due to bad AI) and one at a time, my villagers come to pick up the remains of their deceased comrade.
Why is this bad?
They cross half the map to get to the remains, fight the exact same creature the previous villager did, and die.
Then another person comes to do the exact same thing.
Rinse and repeat until my whole village is now dead from trying to pick up a stupid bone pile.
This has ruined every single playthrough I have attempted in this game.

column8: I really loved this game when I first started playing it. Had a ton of potential and it was very fun. If you wanna see a very good lets play and funny letplay of the older game then watch the sips videos on it. That is when this game was definatly at its most fun. Then gnomoria came out and had its fully 3d block system and the devs then decided they wanted to compleatly rewrite the game to have this feature. I guess many in the comunity wanted it but in my honest opinion this was a bad move. It made the game look too much not like its previous version and dident add anything to the gameplay other then you could build a better looking buildings. The game is a town building game not a building building game they went in the wrong direction however this was not what killed it. What killed it was one of the dev's having a personal crisis that then forced them to not concentrate on the game. This in turn spiraled into more work for the other dev's and them loosing intrest. I would have highly recommended this game a few years ago durning its alpha but it seams soon as it hit steam it was pretty much abandoned. Like the other reviewers I no longer can even recommend buying this game. Maybe if it was 3 bucks but definatly not 15 like what its being asked for.

column8:
Olá! Antes de mais nada gostaria de chamar atenção a uma coisa: não existem, ainda, reviews pra Towns na Língua Portuguesa. Acredito que este é, e será, o primeiro.

 Faço isso, por conhecer a falta de conteúdo para jogos escritos em minha língua materna. Diversos são os poréns que assolam a criação destes conteúdos para essa língua. Gostaria de levantar essa temática, mas não vou discutí-la aqui.

 Então, vamos ao que interessa. Towns.

 Towns é um jogo magnífico. Mas, talvez, vc não deva comprá-lo. Sua curva de aprendizagem pode ser elevada, e descobrir como jogar o jogo pode ser complicado. Mesmo que vc procure informações aqui na Steam, ou em outras fontes de pesquisa (Youtube).

 Dito isso, se vc adora construir coisas este é um jogo que você provavelmente gostaria de jogar.

 O software é uma divertidíssima "ferramenta" que possibilita a criação de vilas - Towns - atráves do uso de blocos. Utilize sua imaginação e crie a vila dos seus sonhos. No geral, todas elas terão um aspécto medieval. Contudo, se vc seguir meu conselho, poderá criar maravilhosas estruturas modernas.

 Em suma, esteja preparado para enfrentar dificuldades e conhecer uma ferramenta que permite colocar em bits idéias produzidas por seu intelecto!

10/10.
column9:
Hello! First of all, I'd like to point out one thing: there are currently no reviews for Towns in Portuguese. I believe this is, and will be, the first.

I'm doing this because I'm aware of the lack of content for games written in my native language. There are several issues that plague the creation of such content for that language. I'd like to raise this topic, but I won't discuss it here.

So, let's get to the point: Towns.

Towns is a magnificent game. But perhaps you shouldn't buy it. Its learning curve can be steep, and figuring out how to play the game can be tricky. Even if you look for information here on Steam or other research sources (YouTube).

That said, if you love building things, this is a game you'll probably enjoy playing.

The software is a fun "tool" that allows you to create villages—Towns—through the use of blocks. Use your imagination and create the village of your dreams. In general, they will all have a medieval feel. However, if you follow my advice, you can create wonderful modern structures.

In short, be prepared to face challenges and learn about a tool that allows you to put ideas produced by your intellect into pieces!

10/10.

column8:
29% approval rating. 

I came to this game without any expectations, I actually bought it because I thought it would be fun on my Surface Pro. I wasn't wrong, with a stylus it's actually a pretty fun game.

I see a lot of people hate the game due to the promises that were made by the developer (at least, that's the impression I'm getting), but I just wasn't around for any of that, so in my opinion, this game is actually quite a bit of fun.

I'm one of the few who bought it and just enjoyed it. That's a thumbs up from me, contrary to popular opinion.
