column8:
es un buen juego con muchas posibilidades, podría acabar siendo un dwarf fortress con una interfaz entendible y en español excepto por sus desarroyadores los cuales son unos perezosos los cuales no actualizan el juego, ni ponen workshop y en general no añaden contenido jugable lo cual es una desgracia, pero si encuentras mods puedes llegar a echarle cientos de horas, si lo usas default como yo lo dudo, en mi caso fueron 73,2 horas, tengo ganas de volver a probarlo, aunque aún no hay muchos elementos aleatorios, por lo tanto no hay mucha dificultad mientras sepas lo que hay que hacer en un inicio se pueda tornar fácil, luego la parte aleatoria de este juego te afectará más y por eso siempre puedes no saber como reaccionar y perder tu pueblo

la pregunta es            ¿lo recomiendo?   en mi experiencia personal, si, pues no estas pagando 50 centimos o dolares la hora (por lo menos yo) 


PD:

yo recomiendo este juego, no recomiendo a sus desarroyadores, pues ellos lo hicieron mal , no el juego, si quieres un juego de gestión y estrategia este puede ser tu juego, pero desde más de 40 horas vas a necesitar mods para nuevo contenido, recuerda, yo recomiendo el juego, que en mi experiencia personal ha sido bueno, no a sus creadores, los cuales lo han abandonado, no creo que se merezca salir de steam pues como dije: no es culpa de el juego que sus desarroyadores los abandonen.

PDD:

yo nada más juzgo al juego, que luego me flamean más que los jugadores del league of legends
column9:
It's a good game with a lot of potential. It could end up being a dwarf fortress with an understandable interface and in Spanish, except for its developers, who are lazy, don't update the game, don't create a workshop, and generally don't add playable content, which is a shame. But if you find mods, you can spend hundreds of hours on it. If you use the default mod, like I do, I doubt it. In my case, it was 73.2 hours. I'm eager to try it again. Although there aren't many random elements yet, so it's not too difficult as long as you know what to do at the beginning, it can become easy. Later, the random part of this game will affect you more, and that's why you can always not know how to react and lose your village.

The question is, do I recommend it? In my personal experience, yes, because you're not paying 50 cents or dollars an hour (at least I am).

P.S.:

I recommend this game. I don't recommend its developers, because they did it wrong, not the game. If you want a management and strategy game, this could be your game, but after more than 40 hours, you'll need mods for new content. Remember, I recommend the game, which in my personal experience has been good, not its creators, who abandoned it. I don't think it deserves to leave Steam because, as I said, it's not the game's fault that its developers abandoned them.

P.S.:

I only judge the game; they'll then criticize me more than League of Legends players.

column8: This game is very challenging, but enjoyable. I do wish there was a way to strengthen your heroes more before you send them to the lower levels (other than raids), but at least they don't stop coming. Sure I had to look up some things on the wiki but it was the same way for everybody for games such as this, or Minecraft, or they had a friend who told them the recipes or the way redstone works and ways you can implement redstone to make something awesome. I hope Towns has more updates in the future to fix certain minor things, but other than that I very much enjoy playing the game. Another plus is how simple mods are done, unlike Minecraft I can get most of the mods I want to work (Not to dog on Minecraft because I love Minecraft too, but the mods are done poorly for it) For towns you just have to drop the mod into the mods file, while Minecraft will make you download other mods to get mods to work. Also Towns has (I think) an official mods website that you can go to, while Minecraft you have to trust your instincts on whether to download said mods. I know there's the wiki and stuff for mods, but when I download them and drop them in the mods file it always crashes my game or just doesn't work. Maybe your experience is different with minecraft and towns, but that is my experience.

column8:
Don't....just don't...

This is one of those "indie" games that was made as a huge cash grab.  The game "released" in early access, but few updates of signifigance were made.  Next thing you know, it was just called "release version".  Nothing much has ever changed, and it is boring and buggy.  Character pathing is problematic at best, and the UI is generally wothless and confusing.  You would expect that a game with graphics this bad would make up for it in other areas like gameplay.  NOPE!  Just another attempt yo grab your money with little to no concern for you as a consumer.

column8:
This is one of the games that make ALL Early Access games suspect. The Dev's took their money and ran without a full game. Why is Steam still selling it? I don't know. There are a lot of issues in the game that will now never be fixed. Spend your money on something else and be wary of anything early access.

The sad thing is, there is a lot to like about this game. If they actually had finished it this game would have been a really really good indie game. As it is, I find it embarrasing its in my game list and serves as a warning to me to be careful in the future.

This is a game I would turly like to love. It's got a great concept, and really is quite fun. That said, the developers ruined the community. There are tons of "little things" that if fixed would make this an amazing game. However the devs have abandoned the game, and don't seem to have any intention on fixing it. 

It should be one of the best games of all time, but instead it's large number of tiny, small, problems renders the game tedious to play. If they would just fix that...  But they wont. 

Save your money. Don't buy the game. It's sad, I really want to like it, but your time and money is better spent in other games of this genere.

column8:
I really loved this game and got it way back before it was on steam or even greenlight. I was excited by all the updates and look forward to them fixing the AI with the towny's (cuz they could be just dumb sometimes).  I haven't played in a long time and came back hoping for new development only to find out it was abandoned b/c of burnout in May2014. What a shame, I paid my money to support the project and  it's sad that it will not even get to beta. The main Towns website and forums are down now. I would have given this a hearty thumbs up but must vote no. 

Tired of getting taken from developers promising something great, showing the potential but never coming through aka Cubeworld and many others.

column8:
[h1] - = DO NOT BUY! = - [/h1]
[h2] Game is Abandoned [/h2]

It's such a shame, I really liked this game. It was fresh, challenging and had interesting ideas... I liked the game.

It is with a rather sad face I must say that this game is NOT worth investing in, as you can see from other reviews here, it's unfinished and the Devs have long since gone the way of the dodo.

[ed-] To clarify; If you like resource management / building strategy games then go ahead and buy this, but know that you do so only to purchase a game that will likely never ever be finished / be free of bugs / have official content added.

If this were to be finished, if the bugs were ironed out, I'd whole-heartedly recommend it to anyone that likes 'resource management' style games - as it stands right now I must say to the general public:

 [b][[ DO NOT BUY ]][/b]

column8:
It's a sad story about Towns. It was one of the first games ever to be greenlit at steam and was hyped pretty much. However the game was not announced as beeing in an alpha state at the beginning, so many people paid the money expecting a more complete game. The 2-man developer team was overwhelmed with the pressure by the community and in combination with private dramas couldn't stand the stress of further developing the game. It is unfair to accuse them of "ranning of with the money" since they are a mere victim of a false indie game advertisement by Valve, when the Greenlight-system started.

You can read the story about this games development downfall here:
http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-05-09-the-fall-of-towns

column8:
SEE BELOW FOR AWESONE ALTERNATIVES

This games has a terrible AI. Citizens will walk right into enemy territiory to pick up a random bone. They will refuse to stop working and starve to death. They are worthless at producing food weapons or anything else. Forget the grandoise buildings you see in the screenshots, just building a hut can be a monumental task.

The game is otherwise very buggy, terribly balanced and lacks a lot of features. It has been completly abandoned by the developers.

I recomend instead;
STONEHEARTH; A very similar game that is constantly updated, already has numerous features, great 3D graphics and most importantly a great AI. Has made incredible acess since it first realeased.

GNOMORIA; A game that is also very similar to towns, with a similar graphics style and a fourth of the price or less when on sale. ALso has much better AI than towns

COLCKWORK EMPIRES; A game with simialr gameplay to towns but with a steampunk vibe. It is regularly updated and the game has made great progress since its early acess release.

In other words all these games will give you very similar gameplay with better AI, and more importantly, a developement team which is on top of updating and talking about their game. Just do not buy towns!

DWARF FORTRESS- Probably the orginal game with a town building survival gameplay. It is incredibly deep, and a is practically a cult classic. It is infamous for its difficulty, but you can find it for free at bay12 games.

column8: The difficulty of this game is making your townies happy. You have to make a lot of things to make them happy, but they have to build/make it and work makes them unhappy! It's a very slow game, and if you want to, as long as you have things being made constaintly without you telling them to on your own using the auto-craft, then you can have the game run all night. Carefull about autosaves when you do this. It may not work out like you want and you'll end up with a town of ghosts! Dispite all that, I find that it's not too daunting to take on this challenge and there are now tutorials up to get you started on your way to create the best town you can. Don't forget, you can turn some townies into soldiers to protect them at the cost of them not acutally crafting things, but at least you can protect them. They can also protect themselves you outfit them  properly as well. Just try it out and have fun with it. If the game you are working on doesn't work out, you can always make another, thankfully.
column9: The difficulty of this game is making your townies happy. You have to make a lot of things to make them happy, but they have to build/make it and work makes them unhappy! It's a very slow game, and if you want to, as long as you have things being made constaintly without you telling them to on your own using the auto-craft, then you can have the game run all night. Carefull about autosaves when you do this. It may not work out like you want and you'll end up with a town of ghosts! Dispite all that, I find that it's not too daunting to take on this challenge and there are now tutorials up to get you started on your way to create the best town you can. Don't forget, you can turn some townies into soldiers to protect them at the cost of them not acutally crafting things, but at least you can protect them. They can also protect themselves you outfit them  properly as well. Just try it out and have fun with it. If the game you are working on doesn't work out, you can always make another, thankfully.

column8:
Reseñé el juego el 2015 negativamente debido al abandono que sufría.

De casualidad, hoy he entrado en la tienda de este juego y, buceando por ahí, he visto que el desarrollador se ha quejado de una campaña de descrédito y demás que seguramente todos nos creímos en su día. No creo que sirva de mucho, pero cambio la review a positiva.

Recuerdo que era un buen juego, solo que estábamos en la era de "¿y la siguiente actualización cuando? ¿Y qué añade?". Ha pasado una década desde que escribí la review original así que es difícil saber si el juego estaba o no abandonado. Lo que tengo claro es que nadie debería sufrir acoso de ningún tipo por su trabajo, menos si se trata de un trabajo creativo, como es el caso de los videojuegos.
column9:
I reviewed the game negatively in 2015 due to the neglect it suffered.

By chance, today I went to this game's store and, while browsing, I saw that the developer had complained about a smear campaign and other things that we probably all believed at the time. I don't think it's very helpful, but I'm changing the review to positive.

I remember it was a good game, but we were in the era of "when's the next update? And what does it add?" It's been a decade since I wrote the original review, so it's hard to know whether the game was abandoned or not. What I am clear about is that no one should suffer harassment of any kind for their work, especially if it's creative work, as is the case with video games.

column8:
I followed Towns before it ever came to Steam. Back then, the two guys working on it were releasing updates pretty regularly, and the basic gameplay evolved on a monthly basis. Then they broke up or had a falling out, or perhaps just got bored of working on this project, and quit rather suddenly. There wasn't any official word this was happening: the updates just sort of stopped coming out. 

This game is dead for no better reason than they didn't want to work on it anymore.

What I did not like:

- They stopped updating it:(

column9: Abandonware

column8:
>>> Проверено! Зря потраченные деньги
>>> Проверено! Разработка игры заброшена

Towns - настоящий монумент, посвященный несовершенству STEAM Greenlight и Early Access, их концепции "сначала деньги - потом функционал". В чем суть? Игру продавали, обещания давали. Потом взяли и свалили, забив на доработки. Игра до сих пор продается за 300 рублей. 

Оскорбляет ли вас как покупателей такая ситуация - решайте сами.

Но стоп. Пару слов о игре: номинально мы имеем изометрический фентезийный градостроительный "sandbox" выживастик с непрямым управлением NPС и РПГ элементами. В начале генерится карта c ресурсами и живностью (в т.ч. агрессивной), собираете полезные ресурсы избегая монстров, строите склады, организуете поставку еды своему поселению, строите здания и инструменты (функциональность комнат определяете вы), вооружаете людей и зазываете героев... ну и дальнейшее обустройство, шахты, монстры и т.д... концепт в общем интригующий. Однако, как уже было сказано игрушка заброшена. Т.е. то что есть, оно как бы и играбельно, но при этом в какой-то момент контент, заложенный в игру кончается и... и все.

Итог? Гениальный, но не реализованный концепт. То, что продается здесь - скорее расширенное DEMO. Но я *давно* деньги платил не за демо, а за полноценную игру. В итоге считаю себя обманутым... проводя аналогию с едой... это как будто вместо обещанного холодильника набитым мясом получаешь маленький бутерброд. :*(
column9:
>>> Verified! Wasted money
>>> Verified! Game development abandoned

Towns is a veritable monument to the imperfections of STEAM Greenlight and Early Access, their "money first, functionality later" philosophy. What's the point? They sold the game, made promises, then abandoned it, neglecting to improve it. The game is still selling for 300 rubles.

Whether this situation offends you as a customer is up to you to decide.

But wait. A few words about the game: It's essentially an isometric fantasy city-building "sandbox" survival game with indirect NPC control and RPG elements. At the beginning, a map with resources and creatures (including aggressive ones) is generated. You collect useful resources while avoiding monsters, build warehouses, organize food supplies for your settlement, construct buildings and tools (you determine the functionality of the rooms), arm your people and recruit heroes... and then there's further development, mines, monsters, etc. The concept is generally intriguing. However, as already mentioned, the game is abandoned. That is, what exists is playable, but at some point the content built into the game runs out and... that's it.

The bottom line? A brilliant, but unfulfilled concept. What's being sold here is more of an extended DEMO. But I paid money *long ago* not for a demo, but for the full game. Ultimately, I feel cheated... to use the food analogy... it's like getting a small sandwich instead of a promised fridge full of meat. :*(

column8:
Tbh I don't know if I should recommend this game or not...I clicked recomend because I enjoyed it (and I think my review is pretty honest so I don't want to have it masked/taken down as others seem to have been), but the thing is I cannot tell you why I liked it so much (though after 244 hours of game play I felt that I should at least try to review it). I've also experianced the errors previous reviewers have talked about so if you are worried about those I don't recommend you buy this game, though I did honestly enjoy my time (as I go onto explain).

(P.s. sorry for all the brackets I didn't really know how to start this review, but lets jump in)

MY EXPERIANCE:

At first I really hated this game, I didn't know how the layers worked or what I was doing and had to restart countless times. At one point I thought I'd quit, though because my brother had bought it and it was one of my first steam games I decided I would give one last good try.

Starting in a winter world (which is completely dominated by monsterous and powerful yeti's) my town of 20 was beaten back to just two to one-three guys (I can't remember how many probably two). Luckily they'd picked some fruits off some trees and I managed to retreat into the caves and block myself off from the Yeti outside world. Slowly I managed to turn my few fruit trees into a little cavern of food and my people were able to survive. After a while the caves became constricting and I needed to expand outside. I knew (by google) that more towns folk would only arrive if my people were happy (which they now were) and if they could actually get to my town from the corner of the map - stuck in a cave I guess this was a problem.
I managed to get my townies to avoid the Yeti's on the south-west side of the cave and I built a outdoor fenced area where I could now grow trees who needed to be on different soil and I had a gate to let new townies in.
Eventually I was able to expand my huge cave fortress across all the mountains, I had dug underground to collect armour and armour building equipment from the enemies below and I faced the yeti's in an epic battle of survival in which I won.

Skip ahead a few hours and my townies owned the map, had built a lake with a giant castle in honour of the war and a grave yard in which many brave soldiers perrished. Including my favourite townies who all had names (yes I learnt some of the names.) I continued down about 10 levels of dungeon and this is about when I started to stop playing. I guess I had quite a few goals and enemies in my game experiance and so I thoroughly enjoyed it.

THERE ARE A FEW CONS:

I'm not sure if after playing this game for so long with very little else to do I began to enjoy it, or if it was a combination of the difficulty of my original situation in the winter world and own imagination of each of my townies lives that got me to love this game. Either way I do love this game though I also understand the negative comments.

Just to clarify, I've had people die on building walls and I don't know how they got there. You have to be careful in what way things are prioritised. The AI are quite slow at building and that does rack up the hours, but you can leave it running for a while once you've got started with a bunch of tasks for them all to do. Baking is esential and so are fruits and stores and this really threw me off because people would just starve themselves out for no good reason. Sometimes when my townies had died I'd had to go back to a previous save just to figure out how and try to save them before they died again.

SUMMARY/tl;dr:

I by no means can tell you that this game is finsihed or of perfect quality, and if you're really worried about the £10 (it was cheaper when I bought it) then I wouldn't recommend it. Though what I can say, and have done a few times now, is that I really, really loved this game once I got into it. I guess the little micro managing and working out how it functions in the end made me feel a bit tallented at the game. :P

I would not recommend this game to the ones who burned my village and raped my family. 
The tale of this game tells of crimes bigger than those committed during the genocide of Rwanda. YetiChow, the moderator on the forum deletes all forms of critique against the game (For that matter he also mods the steam forum).
The devs are quiet, they have spoken more of the game on other forums during the last years. A lot of news regarding the game has come in the form of posts dropped on these other forums. 
the list goes on. 
They even tried to trick a poor dev into quitting his job and working full time on the game (which I think he actually did), but as the hut was already burning, he got in big financial problems and had to quit.
I give it a NO

I clocked up huge hours playing leaving this game run in the background and once over night after setting up a nice functional village. However, this game always felt like it was designed for a tablet or phone and was horribly unpolished and glitchy with poor AI. I can't recommend it because development has stopped. Progress through different coloured ores and baddy drops didn't appeal to me so I never bothered digging past the first few levels of dungeon.

A nice distraction and would be good if finished. Unfinished it doesn't cut the mustard. Perhaps play Rimworld instead or I hear there is a similar dwarf game.

column8:
Its an interesting game that has elements of sims, age of empires, minecraft, and harvest moon. The controls are a little confusing at first but has a different feel that makes the game take a shape of its own. There is a short tutorial you can chose when opeing the game that takes you thru the basics. It may be lacking in some information but with a little common sense it covers pretty much everything you need to know.

I bought this game when it was on sale and i was not let down.

column8:
DO NOT BUY!

It's remarkable that this game costs $15. It's even more remarkable that the game hasn't simply vanished. Every once in a while, I fire it back up to see if I can approach it from a different angle; maybe I missed something the first 30-40 times I tried playing it. It always ends the same; villagers follow no discernable path, nor can they be directed to follow a reasonable path, villagers will get stuck and eventually die of starvation, basic mobs that roam the surface will overwhelm even 3 or 4 villagers at once, villagers will not retreat if they are wounded, issuing building commands is fruitless, at best, etc.

Don't give SMP or the devs the benefit of thinking they've made a good game. They stopped supporting it over 1 year ago and have no intention of ever proceeding with its development and improvement.

column8:
researched the history of Towns after i bought it. yes i should've read what others said about this game and i see a lot of negatives.

i can see why while playing Towns as there are some missing feature as i'm tring to find out how to make stone hammer to make anvil. during the research, like what other mention on the forum the guy/s abandon Towns game and left it as it is,
The reason they gave up and left the game is because they released the game too soon and incomplete, too many complaints piling up, been recieving too many abused messangers about where the money gone, why the problems isn't resolved quick.
It an old saying 'people make mastakes' 'nothing is perfect' as far as i'm aware they did tried their best to get back into track and sort Towns out as soon as possible without anymore stress.

I know ALL the players who bought Towns (which is more then 200,000 in the research) are very demanding to get the game working again and fill in the gaps which are incomplete, i understand we players want a full working game but hey why not play other games while waiting for them to fix it rather ranting at them to push them around to get it done asap.

I hope they do get back in track and recreate Towns from scratch, since it mainly possible to try fix the first Towns to get it back up and complete or start from scratch for better version and replace the old Towns which would be easy but if it still left the Early Game Access.

i want to click as maybe instead of grenn yes button or red no button, but i would give it a thumbs up to give them hope to get Towns going.

Happy Gaming players :)

column8:
As one of a million "build a world" style games I enjoyed this one a lot based on the semi-automated NPC stuff. I found that the game made it really difficult to start actually staging in the deeper levels of the dungeon. You couldn't build much sustainable food underground, and otherwise had to manually have people go drop food for your NPCs to eat. Made the later game a little annoying.

But the building system worked really well, and I enjoyed being able to set up an entire economic supply chain for your NPCs to follow.

column8:
Disappointing.

This game is a clear example of why one should be cautious when buying into a beta, alpha, or early access title. When I bought into this, Towns was in early alpha, and looked like a promising graphic upgrade to dwarf fortress. However the game is not a completed product, missing many of the features that were promised by the devs, and full of bugs. The devs left the game in a beta state.

That being said I did get some enjoyment out of the game. The base idea for the game is a good one, and what is there is fun to play. However it gets old quick. I come back to the game every now and then, play an hour or two, and get bored again. 

All in all it was fun while it lasted. It is an unfinished game, and a good reason to be wary of early access games.

column8:
This game had a good start, but management of the town is causing serious troubles as there are no specializations for your town people. This results that the last idle villager gets to do a new task. Even if he is at the other end of the map. If you are interested in this type of game, try Gnomoria!

column8:
I understand this game has its flaws, but I was surprised to see that the ratings are "Mostly Negative".  That being said, I haven't really followed much behind the scenes with the developer changing hands and whatnot, but I have played this game a decent amount. I would play it more, but my laptop has a strange crashing issue with it. Honestly, it's not a big deal since it's possible to set the game for auto saving every couple minutes. 

Anyways, this game was enjoyable for me in the opening few minutes.  The graphics are obviously not the purpose of this game, but rather the society that one builds while playing.  I've enjoyed learning the game on my own without much research on the Towns Wiki or other websites.  The animations are primitive. but again, not the purpose for the game.  Towns is defintely a fun society simulator, so to speak, and it's definitely a relatively deep and complex game when taking all of the levels of dungeoning underground into consideration.  

I do recommend this game for the players whose interest is piqued and are a bit hesitant from the negative reviews.  I've enjoyed playing this game and it's very rewarding when I can make advancements for my settlement, such as upgraded weapons and armor from stronger materials. 

Final rating: 7.5/10  Definitely a solid game, but possible flaws with potential crashing (I hope not!)

However, it was never completed, there's no signs that it ever will be, and so it joins the growing ranks of unfinished early access games :/

If it was priced at a couple of bucks, I'd say get it and you'll get a bit of fun out of it.  But not at the current price for an unfinished game, with no sign it will ever be completed..

column8:
A Isometric town management game where instead of you playing the RPG, you are the RPG. Instead of giving quests and farming and such, you are all of these things, commanding your heros where to go. It is a completely different experience than most other town simulators. Unfortunately, the developers have abandoned the game, thus it will not be developed further. It is a shame to see this happen, especially since the game's reputation took a big hit because of it, but that doesn't stop me from recommending it.

Bottom Line: This game is great fun if you want to be the one who gives out the quests and sends potential heros on adventures, instead of the one doing all of the work as one person! This is great fun if you also like managing cities. The music while repetitive suits the style of the game, the mechanics are serviceable, and the graphics pay homage to games like the Ceasar Series, which look great! I recommend this game to those who are interested!

column8: #ERROR!

It's difficult to recommend this game at the $15 sale price (4/23/2015), while there are so many other (more finished) games on the market.

The game was created by 2 people. Steam added the game in 2012. The original creaters stopped working on the game in early 2014, and struck a deal with a single person to take over development. That person discovered there wasn't any financial incentive to continue developing the game, and let the community know that he was stopping all work.
(Reference: http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2014/05/07/towns-called-malice-development-of-city-builder-ends/  )

I like the game's concept of town management and plowed ahead with multiple game instances. However, I had to put the game down due to functionality. Sometimes my townies would starve to death instead of stopping a task to eat. They would wonder too deep even though you're supposed to be able to set the max floor depth. etc.

TLDR: I can't recommend buying it. If you're still curious, download the demo.

column8:
The idea of this game would be absolutely genius. As a fan of the dungeon crawler genre, I kinda always asked myself how cities at these brinks of hell (diablo, sacred, baldurs gate) could even exist and this game was meant to really allow me to experience it first hand - mixed with my true favorite genre which is city building and management.

Unluckily the game has been abandoned or its developed has slowed down to the point where it is basically dead, which is a very sad thing as the game is one of the most unique twists and experiences I had in a long time and I would have loved to see it getting finished or at least polished to the point where you don't get frustated with no end due to bugs ...

column8:
This was my favorite Steam game when it first came out, and at first it was getting regular updates. Sadly, there haven't been any updates for nearly 7 months now, and it doesn't look like there will be more any time soon.

This game has enormous potential, and there are still a number of really small changes that could vastly improve it. Yet, for whatever reason, it has been abandoned.

I don't regret spending money on it, but I can't recommend that other people buy it.

column8:
I had a lot of hope for this game throughout its development. Always giving the developers the benefit of the doubt. Sadly I have to agree with the rest. This game HAD massive potential but the developers flubbed it. Dont spend the kind of money they are asking for on this game. IF it was 5 dollars it'd be worth it, just to test out their idea. You'd need to accept the challenge that it'd be and work things out on your own for the most part but when you do, its fun.

I lasted 13 hours before I got tired of it and the minor bugs i had run into at that point. 

All the same, I cant recommend it, especially at the ridiculous price they are asking. I got it for like 8 bucks near the beginning of development so saying 5 bucks is worth it still applies.

column8:
Ok so let me give you my review to this game but first lets go to a few mishaps:
The developers don't exist anymore or hardly work on this game.
The game is hard to understand.
The AI are doing what they are told but doing different task because you just don't know how to set them right.

Now putting that aside let me give my review:

This game is fun! You gotta get resources make sure you have food and armor to keep them safe and healthy.
Build a hospital if they are injured. 
Build each of your villagers a home and add decoration to make them happy to allow more villagers to join in.
Build a trade market get resources you have hard time getting from the merchant and sell your resources you been gathering for money.
build a tavern with tavern room to get heroes to join the village dig below the cave to allow heroes to explore for more rare ores.
Build a animal farm so many bones drop? no problem make armor out of them and build your homes bone are useful material in this game.
Keep your villagers happy and give each of them a task so they dont over burden their works if you make them work to hard they will die so careful what action you do to give your villages and watch them prosper.

column8:
So what is with Towns? 
I would rather say it's pretty dead. This game came 2012 to steam greenlight and was a interesting project, where you create a world in which yo have to make andventurers happy and not to be the adventurer.

But what did go wrong?
It's pretty easy. The developer cashed the money in, which was brought by many people, who were exicted (like me), to try it, to play it and to support it. But unfortunately the developement stopped in 2014.

What's wrong with that?
So the problem with this is, that this game is far from being finished. This game is still in alpha and lacks many features, so many that you could rather say it is not much fun to play this game. I got very disapointed as i have heard that and my money is lost, just because someone did not manage to get their things right and just because he did not have ambitions anymore to work on this project, he stopped! 

I want to say one thing. I burned myself on this game and on some other. I would recommend for everyone not to buy early acess games or greenlights, just as they appear, but to wait and watch or to look at reviews. We gamers have to put a stop to such methods, we can not allow this to happen to us anymore!

I do not recommend this game, don't buy it and don't support someone who disappointed thousands of players, with an unfinished, not even polished, game. He earnend about 2 MILLIONS $ with it and left the game just as it is, UNFINISHED!

I would rather recommend you "DwarfFortress", it's free, developed by only 2 guys and can offer you much more. (PS.: Dwarf Fortress is very hard! and you probably need a texture pack!)

column8: Don't buy it, it's a scam...  The game is there as advertized, but it's an alpha and it's staying an alpha...  It's charging 15 dollars for a game that never gets updated.  Bugs don't get fixed even after years of development.  Features are still unfinished.  Nothing has polish to it.  This game should not cost what it does, and it should have been finished development years ago.  I wouldn't complain, but I paid 15 dollars for it, so I have a right to.  I was promised something that never came about.

But I love the game, the update to add land of any kind is really cool!

Well, that's it. =]

column8:
Held off for so long on writing this.

330 hours... Must be a great value right? Nope, nearly all of it was idle in the background while I waited huge amounts of time for the terrible AI to get anything done. 

This game is a tedious unpolished mess, filled with either insane levels of micro management or giant periods of idle time. The AI is dirt poor and starves to death doing basic tasks. Asking questions about it on the forums will get you told by the moderator how it's not a bug and is really your fault... this is only true because you bought the game.

The dev also seems to think it's cool to appoint fanboy's and white knights as moderators. The Steam moderater doesn't moderate, he takes a clear side and bans people who disagree. 

Do not buy this game, do not support this dev. There are reasons why the reviews are mostly negative.

Edit:

Be clear anyone reading this that asking about this game on the forums will result in you being lied to by the few fanboys remaining, everyone else who'd give an honest answer has been banned.

column8:
tl;dr: STAY FAR AWAY AND DO NOT BUY
___________________________________________________________
This game could have been good. But the Dev abandoned the project. The decided to pick it up again. Then abandoned it again (I think). Its pretty infamous for being one of the first games out of Early Access and the first promising Early access game that sold a ton of copies where the dev "took the money and ran". This game burned a LOT of people on Early Access, and is still burning people. I cant believe its still for sale. Its a bug ridden incomplete mess taht never got out of Early Access and is being sold as a complete game.

Go play Dwarf Fortress instead.

column8:
2024 Update: 9 years later, YETI is still there and posting lol, developer is back, posting about unfair negative treatment, both hanging out in discussions on a 28% rated game but not working on it.... its just so odd that I have to keep coming back and admiring, especially YETI's dedication on a game that was already completely dead 9 years ago.... (I would love to see the "banned" statistics for this game lol)

So if Moderators or others push you to the demo, its not the best way to understand how the game is or how well it runs. First off, the demo does not give you the greatest feel for the game, just proves that the basic mechanics are working....

I'd also like to point this out, HEAVY MODERATION in the forums, see link below. If YETI does not agree with you or finds a reason to delete "negative" posts, he will. If you post in the forums, YETI will justify and "help" you make sense of the horrible AI and how the game was built as SH***Y as it is but it was all done like this on purpose. He responds to every comment to mask the amount of players who feel the same way about the game. Discussions that become overwhelming negative he will delete because the discussion is going in "circles" Check his own delete blog on the link below. This type of moderation in the forums is one attempt to keep the game alive. He HEAVILY defends the game at every chance even with all of the people arguing with him. The only people who agree are Lvl 0 Steam Users with Blocked Profiles.... Enough said. 

http://steamcommunity.com/app/221020/discussions/0/35220315866244607/

Now for the review:

The game is time consuming which is why you may see players with a fair amount of hours, the bugs become more apparent the longer you play. Horrible AI, AI starving itself with plenty of food. Slow productivity of the AI. You have to micromanage every aspect of the game which to me and everyone else in the forums, is horrible AI construction and pathing that they will not fix. If you attempt to build a house all at once in the game, the builders constructing it will not stop working on it until it is finished, that includes dieing in the process from starvation (with plenty of food next to them).... feel free to drop me a comment on here with anything else you would like to know. *I do not respond to Lvl 0 Steam accounts with blocked profiles, your comment will get deleted. 

Dungeons get even more involved and getting to them is a pain... to say the least. Construction is not polished at all. 

To sum it up, the game runs, if you work around the poor mechanics of the game, it is playable. Its extremely time consuming which looking at this game, it should be a faster payout of fun since its a bit behind its time. 

There is no Dev support in the forums, just moderators pushing the game every now and then. Development is next to nothing, look at the update history.

column8:
Towns appears to have been inspired by the likes of Dwarf Fortress.  Like Dwarf Fortress, the graphics are rubbish and the interface is very user-unfriendly, though unlike Dwarf Fortress it's not much fun to play, particularly when you watch your villagers launch yet another kamikaze attack against a heavily-armed frogman knowing you can't do a damn thing about it.

 Oh, and the female villager death scream will probably haunt me for the rest of my life.

 One to avoid.

Abandoned.

Many others have mentioned all this before but it's worth warning anyone considering a purchase.

It was a game with a decent look and a ton of promise in terms of what could have been developed but the initial creator was... immature in his handling of the project and, by the time someone else was hired sales weren't enough to live off of and the new guy had to move on.

If it were still under development this would probably be a recommendation but it's current state, as a final product, it's nothing near what the initial goals had been, nor in a state one would expect.

column8: Pretty funny game but the dev team is sadly gone...

This game hits a couple sweet spots for me, in that you spend your time designing and issuing instructions to virtual "villagers" (or dwarves, employees, etc.) and then watching them go about their virtual lives.  I purchased it rather early on in its existance, and enjoyed running through a few plays of the basics that were in place.  It certainly never felt even remotely finished, and I decided to walk away from it and give the devs time to flesh it out.
 
They never did that.  The original developers lost interest, which is a huge risk for people who are paid in advance for the promise of a product to come, and effectively decided to cut and run.  They farmed the work to a new developer who was working solely for a percentage of future sales, and the small improvements that were being made never generated those.
 
This game is not actively being developed and is not worth a third of the asking price in its current state, which is a damned shame, becuase this genre could use more finished games, and fewer abandoned skeletal concepts.

I actually like this game, i think it needs more work to be complete. But i will recommend the game
I don't recommend paying the full price for this at the moment. 5 Euro would be a better price for what you are getting imo.

Its a fun little strategic view minecraft game. I found that most things are fairly intuitive and easy to learn. There are a few problems with the game.
mining is a bit annoying at times because marking areas works in a weird kind of way.
there are some problems with buildings when you place a roof and stuff like that.

But in general i think this is quite fun to play.

column8:
I really really tried to like this game. This is an unforgiving idiot management simulator in which villagers are needy, selfish assholes that really do whatever they want to do. simple things take forever, and it actually takes almost all of the work just to provide basic amenities and services required for survival. you have to level entire mountains just to make a handfull of houses, or delve deep into the earth with nasty monsters which kill you almost instantly.

DONT BUY THIS IF YOU WANT AN EASYGOING MANAGEMENT GAME. THIS GAME WILL MERCILESSLY BUNG YOU UNTIL YOU DELETE IT.

column8: Excitedly coaxed into buying Towns by a friend I was incredbily dissapointed. Towns is nothing but a reskin of Dwarf Fortress (A FREE game with graphics mod already available and better also for free) with no intresting mechanics, a poor tutorial that will frustrate those not familiar with Dwarf Fortress, among techinical issues I experienced (frame drops galore on Mac). Towns is also infamous for being one of the first projects taken off of Steam Early Access. That basically means the dev, knowing it was unfinished, decided to take his project off leaving the current version available with no future updates. An unfinished project that sets a terrible, unfortunate precident for furture projects in the Early Access program.

column8:
I hate to give bad reviews, but this game deserves it.  I was one of the many who jumped in early when this game was first released, mainly on the promise of what the devs said it would become.  I played the game a lot back in late 2012 and early 2013 and enjoyed it for the most part, but there were lots of things that still needed to be fixed, most notably the AI and the way it would handle performing tasks with your villagers.

Reinstalled and played the game again a few months ago.....and found that nothing had changed in almost 2 years!  Reading about how the original dev abandoned the game and "sold" the rights to someone else is almost heartbreaking.  Indie games have a bad name with a lot of casual gamers because of behavior like this, and I'm ashamed that I contributed to this jerk walking away with more than $2 million in sales.

column8:
This game had so much potential. I put a lot of hours into building several towns. While I would not necessarily call this 'abandonware' just yet as there have been updates, the feeling is that it's been put so far on the backburner that we will never see a completed product or, by the time we do, what will be the point? Something better or newer will come out to take it's place.

The developer insisted that the product is playable upon time of release, after Early Access was terminated. While the game was playable, the words were decieiving. A playable game should not be released if there are still countless bugs to be fixed and several key features that have not been added to the game.

It's such a shame, because the game had great potential and an idea for a somewhat unique mechanic. But I can't recommend this game to anyone, unless you are looking for examples of how a good concept can go bad, learn the idea, and take time to figure out how to improve upon it with your own game. Even if the developer would fix the bugs and implement all originally discussed and intended features as described, I just have no faith in the developer and this game anymore.

R.I.P. Towns.

column8:
This game has been abandoned by the devs over and over again. During the most recent sale I pointed users to a great review about the history of the game and what has happened with the devs.. It was removed as "boycott thread" I then made a post regarding how it wasn’t and it was a review... I was then banned from the forums. 

I have never seen such shadyness from developers or steam forum moderators.  Stay FAR AWAY!!!

Here is why I was supposedly banned...
[quote]
You have been banned from Towns Discussions by a forum moderator for your post in "Towns General Discussions": 
[quote]YetiChow Moderator 3 hours ago 
Deleted thread "Don't buy this game". Reason: spam, calls to boycott, and the fact that the same topic has been done to death already. Also a rather icky necroposting.

A reminder, these kind of boycott threads will NOT be tolerated. There's a reviews page for reviews; if people ask for opinions then that's another place to give them; but these unsolicited boycott threads are just unacceptable.
[/quote]

I highly disagree with this. My original post was notifying potential buyers of a great review that was written about this game. It told the back story of what happened with the devs for this game and how they abandoned it(surprise? it just happened again). How could that be a "boycott thread"? If I had somehow managed to find a positive review for towns and asked the user base to read it and get educated of the background of the game it would somehow be tolerated. This just again shows how shady you are YetiCHow for removing threads entirely and labelling them as something they are not.

Update:  YetiChow has now updated his original post to again try to make me look bad.  If you are going to police the forums in a dictatorship manner and not allow users to share reviews or their opinions unless it is in a positive way atleast own up to it.

[quote]
YetiChow Moderator
I was going to avoid naming names in the hope this was an isolated incident; but apparently that's not the case. Also deleted another topic by the same user bizkit_109, written in response to my deleting the original thread. This user has now been warned, and further behaviour in the same manner will not be tolerated.
[/quote]

Apparently they like to silence any honest negativety towards the game and if you display any of that you get the big ban hammer.  What a joke this develpoer is and the staff it lets moderate its steam forums.

UPDATE!!! MAY 28 2015 !!!!!
After a user made a post asking YetiChow to comment about my review he again went after me and spread more lies saying the following:
[quote]
YetiChow Moderator
For the record, I'm the one who issued that ban, not Supermalparit, not Burningpet, nor Moebius (the "second dev" who seems to be the person this post is addressed to?). The reason I issued that ban was because the poster was spamming (and worse, abusing other posters as well as the developers; the spam offence happened to be the straw which finally broke the camel's back).
[/quote]
I didn't want him again to be able to lie to the community and spread more misinformation so I confronted him on this as I never attacked the devs nor another forum poster.  He then banned me permanently from the forums.  Here is the screen shot of his post, my reply, and my new ban.  What a joke this guy is.  

http://i.imgur.com/Auuyizz.jpg

STAY FAR AWAY FROM THIS GAME AND ANYTHING ELSE SMP DEVELOPS!!  They obviously have extremely poor judgement putting a guy like this in charge of their steam forums.

column8:
The bottom line:  This game has an interesting premise.  Rather than casting you as the hero who goes into the dungeons in search of fame and glory, you are in charge of building and organizing the town above the dungeon where the hero rents his hotel room and buys his weapons.  That said, this game really isn't as much fun as it sounds.  It is an extensive exercise in MICRO-MANAGEMENT.  If you can get it for REALLY REALLY CHEAP, then it's worth playing if you enjoy games like the original Warcraft (the original, not WoW!!) or Sim City.  I have to say though, I am not a fan of any game where the townsfolk will starve to death if you just leave them alone for a while.

You start out with a handful of citizens and absolutely no town.  Your first 4 hours of play will be dedicated to gathering food and setting up a farm so your citizens don't starve to death (which they will do QUITE OFTEN if you are not paying attention!!).  Your next 6 hours of play will be dedicated to mining a few piles of rock and mud, chopping down a few trees, and building some basic workshops for your citizens to work in.  Then you'll spend another 3 hours setting up a kitchen and a bakery, as well as some animal farms so your people can eat something besides apples.  Only after that will you worry about building a tavern for traveling heroes to stay and eat at.  And only after THAT will you start digging down into the dungeon.  Digging into the dungeon and having a tavern with at least one open tavern bedroom are the requirements for heroes to start coming to your town.  Different types of heroes will come based on how deep into the dungeon you are, how many people live in your town, and what type of furniture you have in the tavern bedroom.  Once you do get into the dungeons, there are a ton of monsters which will probably kill everyone who finds their way down the  tunnel.  But there are more resources in the dungeon that you can't find on the surface, like iron, copper, silver, and gold... and you need a ton of those to build better weapons and armor for your city guards.  Meanwhile, you might randomly have a Werepig go berserk on your town and KILL EVERYONE, or you might have a sudden invasion by monsters from the forest and THEY ALL DIE.  But NEVER FORGET... the number one priority AT ALL TIMES has to be food production or else your entire city will starve because the citizens are as stupid as rocks.

One good thing about this game is that it is VERY EASY to create mods for it.  You can mess with the amount and placement of various resources, enemies, even mountains and plants.  If you want to get deeper into the config files, you can even change the number of citizens you start with, alter citizen and hero attributes, and even alter enemies to make them easier or harder.
column9:
The bottom line:  This game has an interesting premise.  Rather than casting you as the hero who goes into the dungeons in search of fame and glory, you are in charge of building and organizing the town above the dungeon where the hero rents his hotel room and buys his weapons.  That said, this game really isn't as much fun as it sounds.  It is an extensive exercise in MICRO-MANAGEMENT.  If you can get it for REALLY REALLY CHEAP, then it's worth playing if you enjoy games like the original Warcraft (the original, not WoW!!) or Sim City.  I have to say though, I am not a fan of any game where the townsfolk will starve to death if you just leave them alone for a while.

You start out with a handful of citizens and absolutely no town.  Your first 4 hours of play will be dedicated to gathering food and setting up a farm so your citizens don't starve to death (which they will do QUITE OFTEN if you are not paying attention!!). Only after that will you worry about building a tavern for traveling heroes to stay and eat at.  And only after THAT will you start digging down into the dungeon.  Digging into the dungeon and having a tavern with at least one open tavern bedroom are the requirements for heroes to start coming to your town.  Different types of heroes will come based on how deep into the dungeon you are, how many people live in your town, and what type of furniture you have in the tavern bedroom.  Once you do get into the dungeons, there are a ton of monsters which will probably kill everyone who finds their way down the  tunnel.  But there are more resources in the dungeon that you can't find on the surface, like iron, copper, silver, and gold... and you need a ton of those to build better weapons and armor for your city guards.  Meanwhile, you might randomly have a Werepig go berserk on your town and KILL EVERYONE, or you might have a sudden invasion by monsters from the forest and THEY ALL DIE.  But NEVER FORGET... the number one priority AT ALL TIMES has to be food production or else your entire city will starve because the citizens are as stupid as rocks.

One good thing about this game is that it is VERY EASY to create mods for it.  You can mess with the amount and placement of various resources, enemies, even mountains and plants.  If you want to get deeper into the config files, you can even change the number of citizens you start with, alter citizen and hero attributes, and even alter enemies to make them easier or harder.

column8:
Towns, un juego simple y divertido de desarrollar tu pueblecito con tus colonos mientras son devorados por criaturas que te asedian.

El juego en si esta bien, es entretenido y te permite crear un pueblecito al puro estilo minecraft, tu colocas los bloques y tus aldeanos iran creando y construyendo, y mientras tanto vas bajando por el subsuelo picando y encontrando mazmorras donde pelear y encontrar recursos.

No recomiendo el juego, simplemente por su discontinuidad, ya que se quedó un poco a medio camino de estar 100% terminado.
column9:
Towns, a simple and fun game about developing your little town with your settlers while they are devoured by creatures that besiege you.

The game itself is good, entertaining, and allows you to create a town in true Minecraft style. You place blocks and your villagers will craft and build, while you explore the underground, exploring dungeons where you can fight and find resources.

I don't recommend the game, simply because of its discontinuity, as it fell a bit short of being 100% finished.

column8: The idea behind the game has merit, but in actually play I found it very boring and repetative with few moments that felt like something had been achieved or completed. There are better games for town building and better games for dungeon adventures. While this game mixes them both, it does so it a very lack luster way. For now however, I cannot reccomend this game. 4/10

column8:
타운즈에서의 선택은 게임 내 상황에 서서히 반영된다.
때문에 내 목적(번영 또는 던젼 공략 등)을 이루기 위해서는 주민과 생산,소비 라인의 순환이 끊기지 않도록 잘 살펴봐야한다. 
주민들을 직접 조작하는게 아닌 '내가 내린 명령'을 '사정 되는 주민이' 수행하는 방식이기 때문에 게임 플레이는 조율과 조율의 연속이지만, 그 간접적인 맛이 또 제법 재미있기도 하다.
column9:
Your choices in towns are gradually reflected in the game's context.
Therefore, to achieve your goals (prosperity, dungeon raiding, etc.), you must carefully monitor the cycle of residents, production, and consumption to ensure they remain connected.
Because you don't directly control residents, but rather "the residents who are assigned to carry out your orders," gameplay is a constant process of coordination and adjustment. However, this indirect experience is also quite enjoyable.

column8:
I ended up buying this game twice, once when I first heard about it from various communities speaking favorably of what it could become, and again when the game was eventually greenlit on steam. I justified both purchases, because I was genuinely excited over the prospect of the game, and wanted to support it as much as I could. I was wrong.

The game and by extension the original community presented the concept to be a Dwarf Fortress like game with better graphics, but I would argue that it is more closely related to the old Majesty games without a mission scenario. Your objective is to build up a town that will attract adventure's. You are tasked to manage and create food for the town, gather materials for building and forging tools/weapons, and eventually mine beneath the surface and break into dungeons beneath the map. All the while you need to defend your townspeople against invaders, native enemy's and eventually the monsters living within the dungeons.

The art is very inconsistent. Between block styles, animals and items within the game, there seems to be a 'mish-mash' of different approaches to how things ought to look, and none of them are particularly good. The animation is non existent. Everything glides across the screen, the combat looks like how a child emulate a 'fight' by smashing two dolls together.  

Gameplay wise, you are allowed to create various structures, however you want. Similar to prison architect and DF-9, the game follows a system where you designate the type of room (bakery or carpenters workshop), and then supply those rooms with the necessary components allow those rooms to function (such as an oven, or bakers table). Buildings can be multiple floors up or down, though rooms are restricted to one level. The AI is what ruins the game for me. Peasants will frequently pick fights with monsters unarmed if they are near them. Like the Majesty, you cannot control the hero's that come to your town, however you also cannot curb or influence the hero's with gold or bounties. You simply have to hope the hero's will go where you need them too on their own. 

The menu's and displays aren't pretty to look at either, and navigating through the various menu's is rather unintuitive.

The sounds are pretty terrible to be honest, especially the sound for when peasants eat food or die. If you happen to have your earphones on, and at a high volume, I would imagine it would cause your ears to bleed. Overall, the sound effects are pretty generic, but maybe I'm expecting too much from an Indie game after playing Minecraft.

Now at the time, I could just explain such issues away, because the game was still in active development. However the game has since been abandoned by it's developers, and no further updates are planned. Because of that, I can't in good faith recommend this game. There's too much simply missing or unpolished for this to be considered a good purchase.

column8:
I don't like this game too too much. It is pretty grindy. If you like town/city build games and point and click for adventure style games. Then this might be your game. The game itself is very unpredictable, sometimes you think you are fine but in minutes you are dead. You have to always keep an eye on all of your resources and outposts.

EDIT:
Since the devs kinda walked away from this game I would not recommend this game if you are kinda into games that get constantly updated like minecraft or starbound or something like that.

But still if you just like the idea of managing a city/town and you want a challenge. This is your game, I highly recommend trying to mod this game or make your own mods for this game because some things are not really balanced, such as food.

Food is like a really big concern, they should've called it "Don't Starve"... but I guess that name has already been copyrighted...

column8:
6/10 

I had an earlier review of this game in which I was very positive about it despite the lack of development. I'm knocking my score down from 7/10 to 6/10 because although I still occasionally enjoy this game it feels very limited. This game had excellent potential that was never fully fufilled. The difficulty is also very biased. If you lose more than a couple people your first hour playing your town proably won't have enough people to feed itself, protect itself, AND build and expand.

I feel I got my moneys-worth from this game, but if you're considering buying it I highly suggest you wait for it to go on sale as I don't forsee it ever having another update, unless for some reason a lot of people suddenly start buying it, and then the devs may become re-interested.

I give it a 6/10 because although it's frustrating it can still be enjoyable.

column8:
I have to give this a thumbs down.  It is very buggy, a very steep learning curve, and totally random.  I got really lucky in one town, and found a merchant willing to buy dirt, and sell me gold and some magical crap.  I gave 2 townies full stets of gold stuff, and they were slaughtering everying left and right.  I had a good working farm and started to grow my town, getting heros, but building took FOREVER.  I left the game running and the next day my build orders were not done.  I left it a few more hours to find that all my townies were slaughtered by some stupid monster, exccpt the ones with gold sets.  Well, kept trying to rebuild, but could never recover the population, too slow to build, too slow to do anything.  I just don't see this game going anywhere, really cool idea with little execution.

Sadily, it has gone so long wtihout an update that I guess it will never be finished.  This game really had a lot of potential.  Buyer Beware!

column8:
I really didn't want to give this a Not Recommended, but due to how things have gone with development i just had to do it... maybe i will be able to recommend it if it can improve or gets a massive price cut

Don't get me wrong, the game is very enjoyable, maybe even to a point where I could consider it good, but it is however an unfinished product. A few very minor bugs are present, the AI is a bit dopey, the enemy scaling is absurd (due to the market system, you can get Gold, a top tier material early on and proceed to completely stomp the first 5 or 6 floors of the dungeon, then suddenly it all comes to a halt on the next floor as enemies can one or two shot your heroes regardless of armor because armor only increases evasion, it doesn't make people more capable of taking damage) the game can have massive lag at times when doing mass item hauling (most common when you want to sell several buckets of iron) and the punishment for doing something wrong can be horrible especially when you don't know why said thing is bad (ie you have to make graves for corpses or they spawn strong ghosts, but now there's an event lategame that can rarely spawn even stronger Zombies for your village to fight off if you didn't build your graveyard a mile away, even high level zombies can spawn potentially adding to the death toll unless your village is well equipped O_O 

However, despite all the bad things, I feel like they're more nitpicks that could be ironed out later (if they ever do) the game is strangely satisfying when you do the smallest of things. I felt glad when I got my first town up and running with a constant food supply and with enough production to allow the town to build walls and decor to make them happier, which brings more people in, and eventually Heroes, whom I also got a nice warm feeling from when they moved in, especially a cameo from the fantastic Sips_ :D. When a dungeon level gets cleared there's also that good feeling when you clean all the loot out and equip the village with better items to withstand the ever increasing sieges that want to ruin all your fun. Overall there's just a great feeling I get from getting things done right, it's oddly satisfying to watch all your little people mine out all the stone before converting it into a storage room for your builders so you can continue to build up the town walls to make it harder for the sieges from completely stomping all over all your work so far, and i got a really good chuckle when the nasty hoard of yeti coming in to storm the place is almost completely wiped out before they reach their victims because you built a bridge that serves as the only way in that's completely lined with traps, and watching them set them all off (sadly there's no real animation, but it's still great to watch a big bad yeti get his foot caught in a bear trap and his friend who walked on ahead set off the bamboo shooter, hitting them both as well as anyone else nearby, then the log traps finish off the already wounded, before the villagers team up to pick off any surviving monsters that are likely bleeding from every possible area of their body. Perhaps next time they'll realize that the decaying goblin heads shoved on the pikes outside are a sign that this town is defended) 

If you already own a copy go ahead and have a blast directing all your little people to their fates. Grab some mods to fix some of the problems and some of the frustrating elements and you're good to go. If it appears in a bundle with some other things you're interested in, go ahead and give it a go, you might like it. But I would not buy this game through steam now, especially at full price, when there are more options available that either offer more polished development, are cheaper or promise so much more in the future. Gnomoria, Craft the World and Banished are all around the same price but all offer their own quirks and are still being developed regularly or are even finished in the case of Banished.

The main reason I am not recommending this is because the devteam, they released a game which was basically in alpha, but not stating as such, they slowly developed said game over about a year, then dropped it. Now I can perfectly understand their situation, as one who actually browsed the forums, they got too deep into something they shouldn't have, their reputation was on the line, their own personal lives were causing them trouble. They hired another developer but their paycheck would have been so low that they too eventually dropped the project. When the game was left in this dropped state, the steam community went wild, with people buying the game just to give it a negative review, the product tags mostly consisting of "scam" and "abandoned" and the reviews said nothing about the game. The development of the game has since continued, however i would still not buy this game until they can promise to the buyers that they can bring out frequent updates (updates as of late have been very minor and slow, but a v15 is in development to help fix some issues)

So until then, if you have it already, have fun, otherwise it's probably best to stay away unless it's on sale for £3 and you're curious or have nothing better to do for a rainy weekend. Then again, if the devs do get off their butts and finish the game, this could possibly be one of the best entry level Dwarf Fortress clones ever...
column9:
I really didn't want to give this a Not Recommended, but due to how things have gone with development i just had to do it... maybe i will be able to recommend it if it can improve or gets a massive price cut

Don't get me wrong, the game is very enjoyable, maybe even to a point where I could consider it good, but it is however an unfinished product. A few very minor bugs are present, the AI is a bit dopey, the enemy scaling is absurd (due to the market system, you can get Gold, a top tier material early on and proceed to completely stomp the first 5 or 6 floors of the dungeon, then suddenly it all comes to a halt on the next floor as enemies can one or two shot your heroes regardless of armor because armor only increases evasion, it doesn't make people more capable of taking damage) the game can have massive lag at times when doing mass item hauling (most common when you want to sell several buckets of iron) and the punishment for doing something wrong can be horrible especially when you don't know why said thing is bad (ie you have to make graves for corpses or they spawn strong ghosts, but now there's an event lategame that can rarely spawn even stronger Zombies for your village to fight off if you didn't build your graveyard a mile away, even high level zombies can spawn potentially adding to the death toll unless your village is well equipped O_O 

However, despite all the bad things, I feel like they're more nitpicks that could be ironed out later (if they ever do) the game is strangely satisfying when you do the smallest of things. I felt glad when I got my first town up and running with a constant food supply and with enough production to allow the town to build walls and decor to make them happier, which brings more people in, and eventually Heroes, whom I also got a nice warm feeling from when they moved in, especially a cameo from the fantastic Sips_ :D. When a dungeon level gets cleared there's also that good feeling when you clean all the loot out and equip the village with better items to withstand the ever increasing sieges that want to ruin all your fun. Overall there's just a great feeling I get from getting things done right, it's oddly satisfying to watch all your little people mine out all the stone before converting it into a storage room for your builders so you can continue to build up the town walls to make it harder for the sieges from completely stomping all over all your work so far, and i got a really good chuckle when the nasty hoard of yeti coming in to storm the place is almost completely wiped out before they reach their victims because you built a bridge that serves as the only way in that's completely lined with traps, and watching them set them all off (sadly there's no real animation, but it's still great to watch a big bad yeti get his foot caught in a bear trap and his friend who walked on ahead set off the bamboo shooter, hitting them both as well as anyone else nearby, then the log traps finish off the already wounded, before the villagers team up to pick off any surviving monsters that are likely bleeding from every possible area of their body. Perhaps next time they'll realize that the decaying goblin heads shoved on the pikes outside are a sign that this town is defended) 

If you already own a copy go ahead and have a blast directing all your little people to their fates. Grab some mods to fix some of the problems and some of the frustrating elements and you're good to go. If it appears in a bundle with some other things you're interested in, go ahead and give it a go, you might like it. But I would not buy this game through steam now, especially at full price, when there are more options available that either offer more polished development, are cheaper or promise so much more in the future. Gnomoria, Craft the World and Banished are all around the same price but all offer their own quirks and are still being developed regularly or are even finished in the case of Banished.

The main reason I am not recommending this is because the devteam, they released a game which was basically in alpha, but not stating as such, they slowly developed said game over about a year, then dropped it. Now I can perfectly understand their situation, as one who actually browsed the forums, they got too deep into something they shouldn't have, their reputation was on the line, their own personal lives were causing them trouble. They hired another developer but their paycheck would have been so low that they too eventually dropped the project. When the game was left in this dropped state, the steam community went wild, with people buying the game just to give it a negative review, the product tags mostly consisting of "scam" and "abandoned" and the reviews said nothing about the game. The development of the game has since continued, however i would still not buy this game until they can promise to the buyers that they can bring out frequent updates (updates as of late have been very minor and slow, but a v15 is in development to help fix some issues)

So until then, if you have it already, have fun, otherwise it's probably best to stay away unless it's on sale for £3 and you're curious or have nothing better to do for a rainy weekend. Then again, if the devs do get off their butts and finish the game, this could possibly be one of the best entry level Dwarf Fortress clones ever...

column8: This is one of my favorite games. Yes, it is difficult to get into at first, how to understand where to put things and hot to make buildings look good. It is a challenge, and for that, I am grateful! This game makes you use your brain to figure out how to overcome obsticals. How to make water go where you want it, and how to prepare for sieges. I love how the people will try to do things together instead of one person trying to do it all alone. And yes, it is difficult and frustrating trying to get more people to your town at first. But don't fret! It does get easier. This game makes you constantly wnt to upgrade your town to make it like a real place, something enjoyable. Although, there are so many things they could do to make it better! When I first played this game on my boyfriends account, I was puzzled. I think I played it for about 6 hours straight just trying to figure the game out. Finally, when it started to make more sense, he was intrigued by it and also wanted to try again, even though he called it stupid because he couldn't get it before. This game has so many possibilities, so many things  you can do, oh and watch out for werepig!!

column8:
The Towns Tragedy: A Case Study in Early Access

So first off, I recommend this game... but just barely. It's pretty fun for the money, and you'll get pretty engaged managing your little town. It has a lot of complexity, but not very accessible... be prepared for a little front loading on tutorials. The features are a bit haphazardly put together, but you can still cobble together a pretty good experience out of it. 

The tragedy here is that the developer quit working on the game before it was completed. In all honesty, I wish Towns had been where it is now when it was put up for early access. Developers calling it quits or settling for "almost good enough" is getting pretty tiring in the independant market.

column8:
I was with this game from the beginning. From the moment I heard about this game in the Royal Indie Bundle, I fell in love with it. I played tens of hours of it through Desura. I desparately wanted this game to succeed because it was like a beautiful growing flower that would blossom with so much potential. I was an active contributor on the game forums along with others who shared the same passion. Then Steam Greenlight was launched and when this game was one of the first to be on passed through it, I was absolutely thrilled. And then, it all went south. The game was becoming more and more complex (which isnt necessarily a bad thing) but the way the developer did it made it more robust and annoying to get into. On top of that, each update introduced more and more bugs. The developers became less and less responsive. One of them left due to family concerns which is understandable. The gap between updates became longer and longer. Soon enough, the developers just disappeared. The game stayed in its buggy alpha state for months. Then out of nowhere a new dev was hired to fix it up. Except after only one update, he too seemingly has disappeared and the game continues in its buggy alpha state. I wanted to love this game. I wanted to see this game completed and succeed, I really wanted to. I now see that that future will never arrive.

Don't get this game. It's dead and abandoned. RIP

column8:
The description makes it sound really good, it's a pity that description bears no resemblance to the actual game.  I bought it when it was in early access, saw that it needed a lot of work but that the developer had some good ideas, things looked promising.

The original developer did one with the early access takings, theoretically leaving some new guy to finish the game, which he promptly didn't before also leaving.  

Probably the only product in my Steam library that I actually regret buying.

column8:
Original Dev took the $2mil Alpha sales and scarpered. Sold it to a second dev who said, after abandoning it:

“I hope you are not too disappointed. And if you are: I’m really sorry. I’m quite new to indie game dev and I couldn’t really see that the game sales were declining that rapidly. I guess if I had more experience I would have seen it comming …,”

Abandon ware.

It's a real shame - what exists is broken but playable. If they delivered what was initially promised it would be a cracking little indy game.

Moral of the story? Don't buy Alpha, Beta or Early Access of anything. Ever.

column8:
It's enjoyable for what it is. There's a lot you can still do and the resource system for setting up big towns is great. I haven't been able to find anything with as complex of a system. It's like Banished, where a lot of the fun can be to let the town run on another screen and check in every now and again to see how it's doing.

There are definitely some bugs with pathfinding, especially when on the higher difficulties, but I've had a lot of fun with it.

Despite not getting more updates, there's more content here than in a lot of games.
