column8:
Ok, I have a lot of hours in this game so maybe you could say that I got my money's worth - or maybe I just have a penchant for watching little pixel people go about their business(dying of starvation or eating everything in sight, dry-humping monsters to death or walking straight into a village full of hostiles) .. actually, I also go afk a lot and hang out in the kitchen.. that might be why :p


Anyway, I do not recommend buying the game in its current state:

- very buggy

- rough and unpolished(for example, last time I played the little pixel people had like 2 frames of animation when walking and looked like they were dry-humping monsters upon attacking them). 

- feels incomplete, as in missing game-play features.

- very, very slow updates(if you can even call it an update when one or two little bugs are fixed after several months).

- Dishonest developer: this is the biggest reason for me right now as to why you shouldn't waste your money on this game. Let me clarify .. some other reviewers mention Early Access but the fact of the matter is that this game was not released as Early Access, it was being offered as a finished product when I bought it back in 2012.. well no way was it finished then and still isn't now 2 years later! It could be said that Early Access hadn't started back then so we might forgive that transgression - but then this game should either be categorized as Early Access right now or removed from Steam because it isn't the complete product it is being marketed as.


*if you want a charming game where little computer people wander round and build a home, eat, sleep, dig up treasure, fight monsters, etc.. then go check out 'Craft the World', this is an Early Access title that already feels like it's polished and finished(except for missing later campaign levels); it certainly feels like a AAA title compared to Towns..

column8: My children and I play this game. We liked the look and feel of the interface. The game was interesting and fun for a bit but little things kept annoying us. Issues like folk will starve to death instead of dropping the task they are assigned and eating. I guess making that piece of armor was more important that their own survival. The town seems small compared to other games in genre. The depth is limited to about 19 or 20 levels. Some other games in genre go below 100 levels.  For over a year the developer has been releasing rare and tiny updates. The game is not polished, but playable. I gave up on game and went to other games in genre that developers are actively making their product better. I'd recommend game for a few $.

column8:
This is the game that made me lose faith in Greenlight. I have bought numerous early access games ( Prison Architect, Starbound, Space Base DF9 (ugh), Kerbal SPace Program etc.) Some have been solid games that keep building on themselves and are enjoyable even in early alpha (like KSP), some have been rocky but still enjoyable and are continuing to be made and starting to look better (Starbound), and then there are the games that don't really evolve much and kind of just.... stop.

I bought this game around the release date thinking that it was a neat fresh look at dungeon crawling with city building and some basic logistics managment. I was totally jazzed at the idea and played the game into the ground for a couple of weeks. I had a bit of trouble with the building system, but I figured that had more to do with me being a n00b at the game. (It was a mess since your villagers could get stuck on air and kinda just... sat there as they got eaten by the critters and such on the surface.),. To be fair though there wasn't a tutorial at all at the time.

I also found it impossible to attract addidtional villagers to the town or any heroes, even after fitting all of the criterea that the wiki said was required. The lack of forward movement gameplaywise is what lead me to drop the game until it hit beta.

Now many moons later I come back to check out what is up with a game that I wanted so much to love and find out that it has been pretty much dropped by the devs. I liken it to ordering a car from somewhere and stopping by for a test drive of a prototype. You drive it and think it's all cool and can't wait for the consumer model, but after hearing nothing for a while you drop by again to see how the car is coming and the one they let you drive is exactly the same except they added seatbelts. Granted that I didn't drop $20,000 on this game and that this game is not a car, you get pretty much the same feeling, like someone took your money and gave you a shoddy product.

If only I knew then what I know now.

TL;DR

Shoddy at best and the devs dropped the game.

column8:
This highlights the worst part of Steam Greenlight.  The developer posted a ton of ideas, some good-looking screenshots, and pitched a solid concept.

Before I even get to the review, I'd like to note that THE DEVELOPER HAS ABANDONED THE GAME.  He took the "Early Access" money, cranked out an Alpha-at-best version of the game and left.  He got another developer to theoretically try to finish the game, but the hopes of that actually happening are looking pretty dim.

So as for the game itself.  You build a town to attract heroes to explore and clear dungeons.  Sounds good.  The execution is NOT.  It's a buggy mess, with villagers having AI and path-finding so bad that they often get stuck and starve.   You control which heroes arrive, can't tell them what to do, and can't even sell them items.  The crafting system is tedious and the building system feels like it's constantly fighting against you.

It's a buggy, barely-playable mess with no endgame, few sounds, and almost no animations.  Avoid like the plague.

EDIT: The developers responsible for taking your money and running are Xavi Canal and Ben Palgi.  I've been asked a few times to mention them here so if you see any projects from them in the future, you can remember this cash-grab and avoid them.

column8:
I had a review up when this game was first released on early access.. I thought it was very decent for early access and bought in... HOWEVER, I must say this game is still the same POS as it was then... Hardly different.. Potential and My time WASTED!!?!?
40/100
Pros
-potential (aha there was)
-Some decent addons (this will make it just slightly more playable)
-Not buggy (not seriously buggy, however it would be more enjoyable if you could think of all the problems as just a mistake)
-:( still can't think of anything actualy enjoyable after my money was stolen for an unfinished game
Cons
-game will not be fixed (game is not gonna change now or ever GG)
-AI is fucking stupid as hell.. ( they will piss you off so bad..)
-Very boring and repetitive at times! (basic actions are way to simple and click heavy with very little aesthetic or enjoyment as a reward..)
-Not replayable (since you cant really ever do much in the first play or second or third or fourth.. you will achieve very little in this game as everything takes forever)

Don't BUY FOR THE SAKE OF YOUR PRIDE AND WALLET!!?!!

column8: This game is nice, well designed and good looking. When you play it you discover how to make tools, how to make farms, and most of all you find all the bad glitches in the game. I think the best thing about the game by far is the feature that crashes the game and shuts itself down without saving. If this doesn't throw you off buying the game look at all the comments for the game which 99.99% is mad rants. If you still have the guts to play this game good luck and I hope you find a way to enjoy it.

column8:
Basically if you're a fan of Dwarf Fortress, or think you would enjoy an easier version of DF you will definitely get your moneys worth with this game.  I sank many hours into it after buying it on sale but it's worth even the 14.99 regular price.

This game has a LOT of negative reviews simply for the fact that the Devs officially announced that they were ending development on the game.  You can see that hundreds of reviews were posted around the same date they announced they were stopping development   It seems however that they have restarted development.  This game is worth your money even in the unfinished state, but now that development is back on it's even more worth your money.  I would honestly suggest, if at all possible, that someone from the team go through and send a message to all these people that left negative reviews on that basis.  This game has massive potential and I would love to see the community in support again.  Website for the game does appear to be down however.

column8:
Слишком убого даже для раннего доступа, а вкупе с крайне редкими обновлениями - убого вдвойне. Такое впечатление, что выкладывали игру только ради получения денег, без перспективы дальнейшего сопровождения и развития.

Идея - 7
Реализация - 3
Поддержка - 1
Итого 3.3 из 10, не рекомендую тратить деньги, лучше посмотреть в сторону Gnomoria
column9:
It's too poor even for Early Access, and coupled with the extremely rare updates, it's doubly poor. It feels like they released the game purely for profit, with no prospects for further support or development.

Idea - 7
Implementation - 3
Support - 1
Overall 3.3 out of 10. I don't recommend wasting your money on it; Gnomoria is a better option.

column8:
Incomplete game, being sold as a finished product.
Dev team has fallen apart and/or walked away multiple times.
Every once in a while a meaningless patch is applied so that the founder can say "See! not abandoned!"

It had potential, they did not get there before the game stopped advancing.

It's a game where you do not directly control the units, you say what you would like done and the AI gets around to it, sorta like dwarf fortress..... but wait, that only works if the AI is functional. The AI is this game is more brainless than the original AI in Master of Orion 3.

Run away, don't read about the game, if you see what it was supposed to be you will just be sad that it never made it to that point.

column8: Ich finde Towns ist ein gelungenes Spiel es wurde zwar in der Entwicklung eingestellt doch mit dem vorhandenen lässt sich Leben . Der Hauptknackpunkt nemlich Terraforming wurde auch behoben . Was will man mehr ich habe dieses Spiel Stunde um Stunde gezockt die Entwicklung verfolgt... Ich kann nur dazu sagen die Grafik ist nicht die welt denoch passent, die KI hat ihre schwierigkeiten man spielt sich aber in die kleinen Fehler leicht ein, die Starken fehler umgeht man später mit Erfahrung ganz einfach , schade ist es das ein Ziel nicht wirklich erkennbar ist. Man Baut größer besser aber eine wirkliches Ziel wie einen Boss der zu besiegen ist gibt es nicht. Das Wachen oder wie ich sie nenne "Pfosten" sind mehr zur deku dar sie sind nur zu gebrauchen bei geringen höhen oder wenn man sie per Patrolie durch die Gegend sendet , zu gebrauchen sind sie eigentlich nur für die Siege Wellen die schlicht weg ein Witz ist einfaches Taktisches Baun und die Wellen packen ein. Das wunderschöne Job zuweisungs system ist schlicht weg ein Zeit vertreib der sich nicht lohnt ohne zuweisung arbeiten alle bewohner viel effektiever.Um bewohner in die Stadt bzw gehäufte blocke zu bekommen  reicht einfaches festlegen von räumen ohne Wände und warloses verteilen von Dekuration find ich persönlich gut dar dann mehr möglichkeiten Offen bleiben. Schade ist das es zwar händler gibt aber nicht einen für Monster Essenzen die man bereits gefunden hat was zur späteren erschöpfung der Resorcen sorgt. Doch drotz dieser Mängel bleibt der Spaß nicht unbedingt auf der Strecke. Dieses Spiel eignet sich Prima zum Zeitvertreib aber nicht als voll zeit Spiel. Ich Persönlich finde das dieses spiel auch für Kinder die Geduld aufweisen sehr gut geeignet ist , die wenigen kampf scenen sind nicht brutal bis auf en blutfleck ist nicht viel zu sehn am ende... der kampf selbst handelt sich um Figuren vor zurück Bewegen.
column9: I think Towns is a good game; it was discontinued during development, but we can live with what we have. The main problem, terraforming, has also been fixed. What more could you want? I've played this game for hours, following its development... All I can say is that the graphics aren't great, but they're still adequate. The AI ​​has its difficulties, but it's easy to get used to the small mistakes. The more serious ones are easily avoided later with experience. It's a shame that the goal isn't really identifiable. You build bigger, it's better, but there isn't a real goal like a boss to defeat. The guards, or as I call them "posts", are more for decoration; they're only useful at low altitudes or when you send them around on patrol. They're really only useful for siege waves, which is a joke; simple tactical building, and the waves pack up. The wonderful job allocation system is simply a waste of time; without allocation, all the residents work much more effectively. To get residents into the city or into clustered blocks, simply defining rooms without walls and distributing decorations without warning is enough. I personally think it's good as it leaves more options open. It's a shame that although there are traders, there isn't one for monster essences that you've already found, which leads to resources being depleted later. But despite these shortcomings, the fun isn't necessarily spoiled. This game is great for passing the time, but not as a full-time game. I personally think that this game is also very suitable for children who have patience. The few fight scenes aren't brutal; apart from a bloodstain, there isn't much to see at the end... the fight itself involves moving figures forward and backward.

column8:
Towns is one of the best games I have seen for the price its asking but...
About a year ago the devs gave up on this game and now there will be no updates or any sales untill this game gets more publicity and sales. Sadly I have to not recommend this game unless you are willing to cope with the lack of a dev team who cares.

column8:
First to say, I have spent many hours playing towns. MANY hours, and most of the 'towns' i created ended up bugged or lag-based on all accounts or glitched on load. So many faults, but i found it most likely i was building or mining something that was 'illegal' and had in previous versions faulted the game. New not good enough last ever update fixed some of the errors. My latest game or town i created, makes me rank this game AS WORTH HAVING, since no new updates are ever going to be created, possible it might be modified at some point some where on if... possibly nothing if or possible. The game recent, the only possible idea that could make this game work is more glabol control.
Point 1,
IF! if the game had an 'unlock all objects' key, which would be including those on top such as 2nd story roof and up, and scroll across the map, and a ignore all unlocked items, fading them from view so that you could rebuild as you expand, say 20 townies later on you might want to change the look of your town so that happiness is added more fluently(happiness draws in more townies, tip block all roads with fences and 1 block openings still fenced-in although the spot is used with a high happiness decoration, all townies must take the fensed roads, and always gain happiness, the fences should block line of sight too, for all other lower decorations that make your town unique looking and worth creating and blocking sight of other unhappy such stuff [corpses lol]!) so to wrap up point 1, once you build something expect to keep it, even if u realize you wasted a whole lotta space with little useless alleys that u got to block off anyways or whatever your reason. as well as each building wall block needs to be clicked to unlocked(why no auto unlock key?), It is fun to create brick by brick so to speak until you have clicked thousands and thousands of times, and you only have maybe 20 fully furnished and roofed structures(like 15% of the map if you build BIG), but where is the schematic page, where you can create and paste what you want.. I MEAN COME ON WTF stupid person could not add a schematic setup so that you do not neED to place brick by brick every damn BRICK. You might not understand the awesome happiness system, i do i love it, as is I gain 4 townies every few minutes until i reach about 100(ofcourse the townies live in unwalled unroofed houses with a single high happiness object each, only until later do i now design my town), maybe 2 hours of playing saying that at some point(in the past sometimes my game just would not load, or whateverbug at the time, since update final ive had almost no issues with bugs, sometimes lag after a while and i just have to restart towns game and its fixes) some point i dont lose my game and ok and i cap off my residents because i am tired of making the same structures to fit each part of my town, i make 80% the same with different base or roof designs. END POINT 1.

Point 2.
WTF my townies die for the most stupid reasons, and when one dies the rest follow, it takes 30 seconds for 1 high level enemy to sneak past a new hedge that grants access into your town to murder all of your townies before a single soldier townie arrives. The soldier system is laughable, the level system is worse, the townies ability to form soldier groups looks near identicle and stands on the screen right next to the 'return townies to civi status' and if you do that that once soldier loses all levels and expereienced gain. So two hours in my level 30 warrior reverts to lvl 1 cause i missclicked. Do i reload? wait i just cleared that floor and salvaged some structures (I do not want to reclick the structures brick by brick to move together to add more what/ever is needed floor layout). Its a bummer, the soldiers four options are useful, well 1 is useful the 'patrol script', say you have 3 soldiers and a single patrol point, at least one soldier will be there if that single spot needs defending. So you can bundle your town opening with your dungeon opening and that one soldier can last until heros or townies or your actual soldiers get off thier fat behinds and leave the dining room to fight or patrol is what it is. What could be added, is a auto level for all characters based on time they have been in your town, or gain experience for all townies, but soldiers gain double. As is the soldier usage can be annoying, i try to make 1/8 to 1/4 townies into soldiers since i play on the hardest difficulty and i do survive most instances of invasion.

Point Final

As was townies die, or the game glitches because some townie is trying to fly off a roof, or climb three spaces high for that first piece of stone or ore and cannot reach, that does now with the last update usually cancel all actions for a townie that cannot reach or interact with a ai-script(farming,mining,building) and does not cause too much of an issue. Unless that townie is behind that 3 story wall just too far to reach the ground, and dies of starvation, scaffolding!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! WTF WHY is there no auto build SCAFFOLDING when something is just out of reach, or why start up the map with stupid stone bricks i need to mine on the surface of the map stacked up like some tower. REcent update added scaffolds decay after time, so no need to delete them unless that immediate space is needed, wait a while and the scaffolding will fade away from the game, its kind of cool getting a 3 story structure up and watching it unfold as teh scaffolding decays away and reveals the time you spent clicking each brick into place, each window painstackingly placed. It makes it worth it too, if like I do often I show off my towns online or to friends i say hey look what i spent four hours making.( I got one friend to buy the game, and after about ten hours of playing he had about 15 townies, i wanted to cry) The game has no introduction, as well as no explanation, examples being bone torch=1 happiness, harp=2 happiness, decorated wall= go ---- yourself(i think to myself) it does not add any worth while happiness as it does override all better happiness objects. 

EXTRA POINT------------------------------- MAKE ALL WALLS,optional decorated(same look but with makes happiness) and costs say 1 extra material of a single needed of a single variety.
Back TO last POINT of interest------------- Play this game only if you understand ai scripts and basic map editor knowledge as once you get the hang of it, its totally easy to play even on the hardest of difficulties, my favorite too because you do not get stupid molerats stealing your food, instead just some ogres to fight. 

Yes i recommend this game to anyone who has a brain and enjoyings a challenge, it is unfinished, good chance what there is is all there will ever be in this game. 
So far, I have yet to find a single piece of useful information on the forums and online searches, you need to learn from the game, find the flaws and single them out.

My personal example of play


Either map type,
FIRST ACTION-------------- CREATE 16 resident tiles 3x3 each, wait 30 seconds, you get more townies to start the game with!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
SECOND ACTION----------- Make into soldiers all townies and hunt down all of the monsters on the surface of the map, no not leave a single monster alive. Change all but the best soldier(based on stats, only hp and offense matter) back into 
townies(equip the townies who are your lumber workers with the dropped weapons from the monsters. ENJOY a fruitful start to a great town.

column8:
I've come back to this game a number of times and sadly I'm unable to recommend it.

While the graphics are generally ok, the font used is rather difficult to read - its simply a very poor and quite small bitmap - I've seen much better bitmapped fonts, from java even a pure opengl application its not too dificult to implement true type fonts...

If only the text were the only issue, I could get past that and get on with the game

The real issue comes when you attemt to create a building, it is almost impossible to be sure (even with their "2.5d" cursor) if you are building on top of a lower level blocks, and don't even start on a roof I hear its possible but a blavk art indeed.  A simple ghost block above lower blocks might help, but its just really confusing trying to work out whats going on.

column8:
Remember the last time you were on the toilet and thought to yourself, "I'm hurting so much, I feel like I'm going to die on this toilet"

okay take that and imagine instead of being on the toilet your in a crowd of people with friends you know and you have exploding poops of fire sliding down the sides of your legs and you just cant hold it in anymore and you poop yourself infront of everyone and your friends never hang out with you again and people stay away from you cause you pooped yourself like an old man person.

Now take that emotion and multiply it by 3 the result = THIS DAMN GAME!

Seriously this game is like 2 in a half years old and this is the best they can do? I'm sorry but this is rediculious. Steam why are you letting games like this sell. This game you start it up and you die... You literally get killed. It spawns your towns people in an area with either to few resources-to many enemies-traps everywhere and not to mention the building system is easily compaired to a man shoving a stick up his but to try and do a magic trick.

Let me make this as clear as possible for anyone looking to play this game.
It suuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuucks like you poopdid yourself.

0/10 <not even a single score its that unentertaining

column8:
El juego es una chufa. Está sin terminar y los desarrolladores no son nada competentes en el desarrollo del mismo.

El concepto es bueno, pero todo esta sin acabar, las mecánicas, las IAs, la interfaz... Cada X sacan un parche que corrige algo o añade una nueva función, pero el ritmo es de lento, sofocante y seguro que jamás estará terminado. De hecho desde que está en Steam se han arreglado un pequeño puñado de cosas (dos años ya). Si siguen a este ritmo yo creo que en cosa de 7 años o así les quedará un producto mediocre.

En conclusión, no es un buen juego, bajo ninguna razon lo compreís.
column9:
The game is rubbish. It's unfinished, and the developers aren't at all competent at developing it.

The concept is good, but everything is unfinished: the mechanics, the AI, the interface... Every few minutes they release a patch that fixes something or adds a new feature, but the pace is slow, suffocating, and it's sure to never be finished. In fact, since it's been on Steam, a small handful of things have been fixed (two years already). If they continue at this pace, I think they'll be left with a mediocre product in about seven years or so.

In conclusion, it's not a good game; under no circumstances should you buy it.

column8:
Towns est le jeu dont le développement est abandonné possédant le plus de mises à jour à ma connaissance, bien plus que d'autres jeux "en développement" qui sont au final abandonnés !

Que dire du jeu ? Il est jouable, a de très bons, et très mauvais côtés.
Les mauvais côtés :
- Les longues parties entrainent une consommation de puissance notable, allant jusqu'à rendre injouables les sous-sols profonds au bout d'une poignée d'heures sur un netbook
- La musique est agréable au premier abord, puis [b]assez vite[/b] répétitive
- Les chemins empruntés par les Townies ne sont pas toujours pertinents (Mais pourquoi il a été chercher l'aggro ? Pourquoi ??), et parfois fatals pour des raisons stupides (ils vont chercher à terminer leur action en cours coûte que coûte indépendamment de leurs besoins vitaux, quitte à mourrir de faim avant d'arriver à l'objectif...)
- Il n'est pas encore possible (en version 1_14e) de gérer les coffres par "groupes", rendant la localisation des ressources au mieux fastidieuse, au pire complètement aléatoire
- Les invasions aléatoires (heureusement désactivables) sont une plaie en début de jeu (même en niveau facile) en l'absence de héros pour défendre le village, puis deviennent d'une simplicité déconcertante quand ils arrivent
- Le jeu est limité dans le nombre d'ennemis qui ont le droit de se déplacer, une accumulation d'invasions (ils sont une une nuée en difficulté très élevée !) fournit un résultat assez indésirablement drôle à observer, puisque les monstres se font découper sans broncher, le temps que leurs trop nombreux copains bougent sur le reste de la carte
- La vue est énorme, il aurait été souhaitable de pouvoir "dézoomer" pour avoir un meilleur aperçu d'ensemble du terrain
- Les objets ayant une image qui s'affiche sur plusieurs cases de haut "traversent" visuellement les couches supérieures, rendant fouillies les constructions d'étages au-dessus des arbres par exemple

Les bons côtés :
- Jeu très addictif quand il est maîtrisé
- Les chaînes de production sont intéressantes
- Le mode de gestion des ressources semi-automatique est très appréciable
- L'exploration du monde est gratifiante (les sous-sols regorgent de monstres sanguinaires et de ressources uniques !)
- Le monde (malgré une surface assez faible) contient un nombre de couches suffisamment important pour y entasser tous les Townies de vos rêves
- De nombreuses bonnes idées sont mises en oeuvre (marchands qui viennent apporter des ressources pour compléter un risque de pénurie, héros à nourrir sinon ils quittent tout simplement le village, bonheur moyen des villageois à assurer pour en attirer d'autres)
- La communauté fournit des mods très imposants (notamment l'indispensable Towns++ (ayant fait l'objet d'une traduction Fr/multilingue il y a quelques versions, non tenue à jour)), et dont les bonnes idées sont intégrées nativement au jeu

Il est à regretter que le développement soit arrêté : les problèmes de consommation de mémoire ne seront donc pas résolus avant une refonte du coeur, qui n'aura vraisemblablement jamais lieu.
Les autres mauvais côtés peuvent néanmoins être corrigés dans les prochains patchs (groupes de coffres, arrêt d'action d'un Townie en cas de besoin vital), voire de nouvelles surprises arriver (traduction native multilingue), et les bons côtés sont déjà solides.
Pour 12€, il y en a pour plusieurs heures de découverte et de GamePlay valables pour joueurs occasionnels et amateurs du genre, mais dont la maîtrise totale ne doit pas être vue comme un challenge pour les joueurs invétérés.


Je recommande globalement ce jeu.
column9:
Towns is the abandoned game with the most updates to my knowledge, far more than other "in development" games that are ultimately abandoned!

What can I say about the game? It's playable, has some very good and some very bad points. The downsides:
- Long games consume a significant amount of power, even making deep basements unplayable after a few hours on a netbook.
- The music is pleasant at first, then [b]quickly[/b] becomes repetitive.
- The paths taken by the Townies aren't always relevant (But why did he go looking for aggro? Why?), and sometimes fatal for stupid reasons (they'll try to complete their current action at all costs regardless of their vital needs, even if it means starving to death before reaching the objective...).
- It's not yet possible (in version 1_14e) to manage chests by "groups," making locating resources tedious at best, and completely random at worst.
- Random invasions (fortunately, they can be disabled) are a pain at the beginning of the game (even on easy difficulty) in the absence of heroes to defend the village, then become disconcertingly simple when they arrive
- The game is limited in the number of enemies allowed to move, and a buildup of invasions (they're a swarm on very high difficulty!) creates a rather undesirably funny effect, as monsters are cut down without flinching, while their numerous friends move across the rest of the map.
- The view is enormous; it would have been nice to be able to "zoom out" to get a better overview of the terrain.
- Objects with an image that is displayed several squares high visually "cross" the upper layers, making building floors above trees seem cluttered, for example.

The good points:
- Very addictive game when mastered.
- The production chains are interesting.
- The semi-automatic resource management mode is very enjoyable.
- Exploring the world is rewarding (the basements are full of bloodthirsty monsters and unique resources!)
- The world (despite its relatively small surface area) contains a A large enough number of layers to cram all the Townies of your dreams in.
- Many good ideas are implemented (merchants who bring resources to compensate for a risk of shortages, heroes who must be fed or they simply leave the village, average villager happiness to be ensured to attract others).
- The community provides very impressive mods (notably the essential Towns++ (which underwent a French/multilingual translation a few versions ago, not updated)), and whose good ideas are natively integrated into the game.

It's unfortunate that development has stopped: memory consumption issues will therefore not be resolved before a core overhaul, which will likely never happen.
The other downsides may, however, be fixed in future patches (chest groups, stopping a Townie's action in case of vital need), or even new surprises may arrive (native multilingual translation), and the upsides are already solid.
For €12, there are several hours of discovery and gameplay, suitable for casual players and fans of the genre, but mastering it completely shouldn't be a challenge for hardcore gamers.

I generally recommend this game.

column8:
The devs have returned and picked up the game, so I gave it a try!

I don't normally play town building games such as this but it seems the perfect blend of a town builder, RPG, and Minecrafting. I was told there is a steep learning curve to play the game and they were not kidding! Although the tutorial is informative, it takes a while to sort out your priorities and get your townies on their feet in order to take full advantage of what the game has to offer! I definitely recommend watching some tutorial videos online before you tackle this game, if only to learn your way around the nav bars. Be prepared to lose a few townies and maybe even start over. And be prepared to spend a lot of time at your PC because this game is highly addicting. If you like RPGs and Minecraft, you'll like this game!

column8:
The first and most infamous game to come out of Steam's "Greenlight" program, Towns is an incomplete and buggy mess, released in a beta state (yet conusmers such as myself were not initially informed of the fact it was still in beta) that never was completed, but rather ABANDONED by its programmer in a miserable state.  That's right, the sole developer/programmer took the money and ran.  The game is as complete as it will ever be, and that's very depressing.

Towns was billed as a "Dwarf Fortress"-type game, wherein you build a town atop a "dungeon" filled with various baddies.  Your goal is to build a nice enough town to support guards to protect your citizens, and adventurers who will come to your city (given your city has the necessary buildings) and venture into the depths to assault the creatures therein.  The problem is the programming is dreadfully incompetent.  The AI is beyond dumb.  People will stand around and starve to death rather than harvest and eat food.  Citizens will wander off alone and get themselves killed by groups of enemies.  The "tutorial," if you can call it that, teaches you next to nothing about the game.  The still images of the towns initially shown on the game's Steam page were actually impossible to create in the game.  Building (especially roofs) is an exercise in frustration as pieces don't seem to want to fit together like they should.  The programmer's ambitions far exceeded his capabilities and after as few beta updates (which didn't really fix anything), he simply bailed.  What a great guy.

Don't buy Towns.  Get something better.  And practically ANYTHING is better than this pile of excrement.

column8:
I've owned Towns for quite a while now and although some poor decisions of the developer have thrown a lot of flak it’s way recently, I’d like to say that the game itself is still very enjoyable.

Throughout its development, Towns has been all over the place in the performance department but it has never been unplayable. There is ample content for many many hours of creation and enjoyment and even since the last time I played there has been some significant addition to the game. The UI is very functional, the art style is charming, and compared to the titles which inspired it, Towns is extremely accessible for newcomers to the isometric, town building, minion ordering.. micro managing... I’ll try that again- Towns is extremely accessible for newcomers to the Dwarf Fortress genre of game.

column8:
Towns is now the poster child for Early-Access-Gone-Bad. The devs took the money and ran. All I can say about Towns, is that it was the first (as far as I am aware of) game that mixed a usuable interface with Dwarf Fortress. The graphics were fine, and the music is meh. The game was really fun.

I really want to give this a positive review because I got well over 20 hours out of this. I think I paid 15$ so I feel like I got my moneys worth out of this title. Would I tell you to buy it now? No. Go for Gnomoria. Trust me on this one.

column8: Towns was a fantastic concept, something that I had been looking for for a long time. As the game was "improved," however, I quickly lost interest. The game is dead. It has been for years. The only good thing I can say today about Towns is that it tought me a valuable lesson about impulse buying. Do not learn that lesson the hard way. Do not support "cash grabs" like Towns. Do not support SMP. This game could have been great. Instead, it ended up half-finished and abandoned like so many other early access titles. Avoid this game like the plague.

column8:
I bought this game about a year ago thinking I was getting a casual city builder similar to dwarf fortress. I was wrong. What i infact got was a buggy, unfinished mess that needed some serious patching. Yet it was advertised as a finished game. After playing for a few hours i decided to leave it and come back when it's in a better state.

And now this happens: http://kotaku.com/unfinished-steam-game-abandoned-after-thousands-bought-1572931721. 

Thats right. The developers just gave up! Got bored. Couldn't be asked. So they took their money and left. 

The game did have some potential but the fact that you cant even build a roof on your house without watching extensive youtube videos so that you don't screw it up and break the game is ridiculous.

I got scammed and I feel sad about it. So now I'm venting my fustration through a review.

Please don't buy this game. Although thinking about it you probably never would of done anway.  

(Now I wait for the inevitable abandonment of the other unfinished game I bought Starbound)

column8:
It's odd. All these games that are so clearly very much like Dwarf Fortress just lack almost all of the appeal of Dwarf Fortress. Towns is one of the worst in that regard. The complex, text-based menu system of DF is here replaced by a seemingly MORE complex icon-based menu system.

The gameplay is very similar to DF's Fortress Mode, having you build a Town from scratch by harvesting resources from the land and using them to build tools, then using those tools to harvest resources more efficiently, then using THOSE resources to build structures.

I can't really put my finger on why DF has such an appeal to me while Towns (which, as stated, is VERY similar in most regards) just doesn't. If you like town-building sims and managing a population, this is a good game. If you don't like complicated menus and long-ass tutorials to teach you how to use them, try something else.

column8:
Towns es un juego en etapa beta, de administrar pueblos fantásticos, con sus respectivas catacumbas, héroes y criaturas fabulosas, la fórmula opuesta a Dungeon Keeper, y fuertemente inspirado en Dwarf Fortress. Como en el caso de Gnomoria, Goblin Camp, Dwarves! o A Game of Dwarves, intenta implementar aspectos faltantes en su modelo a seguir, así como le resta capas de complejidad y esoterismo al juego de culto de los hermanos Adams, resultando en un producto accesible y entretenido durante unas cuantas horas.

Para ser un proyecto muy independiente y siguiendo los pasos de un juego tan restrictivo y obscuro como lo es Dwarf Fortress, Towns es un proyecto decente. Sin embargo, no está exento de problemas.

El tutorial para aprender a controlar a los Townies, una inclusión bienvenida (y necesaria) en este tipo de simuladores, está narrado por una especie de asesor. Los problemas empiezan cuando se advierte que la lengua nativa de los desarrolladores es el español, y los textos en inglés son pobres y a menudo confusos. A alturas de la versión V14, la más reciente hasta la fecha, el tutorial no reconoce algunos comandos e instrucciones, y en mi caso particular no tengo audio en lo absoluto (el audio en sí no es muy bueno ni atractivo, hasta donde lo recuerdo de la V9)

Lon gráficos isométricos con sprites bidimensionales no son agradables a la vista, reminiscentes al vilipendiado Farmville de Zynga. Los Townies carecen de carisma, y en ocasiones los items y el equipamiento se cuelgan de forma poco elegante. Intentando crear una interfaz limpia y accesible para el mouse, Towns peca de no ofrecer suficientes hotkeys en el teclado, y algunos de los menús de construcción se pueden perder si uno no hace click en en lugar correspondiente, obligando a recorrer toda la serie de menús nuevamente.

En cuanto a ciertos elementos de la mecánica de juego, como la decoración, son innecesariamente complicados (incluso más que en Dwarf Fortress) y limitan el estilo de juego que uno quiera adoptar.

Las actualizaciones a este tipo de bugs, typos y balances se tardan mucho por cada entrega, y a veces las adiciones no son las más satisfactorias. Si Towns adquiere un mejor ritmo en sus mejoras, o permite el involucramiento de terceras personas para su desarrollo, tal vez haya futuro, pero por ahora se ve amauterístico, inacabado y muy atrás de sus ambiciones.
column9:
Towns is a game in beta about managing fantasy towns, complete with their respective catacombs, heroes, and fabulous creatures. It's the opposite of Dungeon Keeper and is heavily inspired by Dwarf Fortress. Like Gnomoria, Goblin Camp, Dwarves!, and A Game of Dwarves, it attempts to implement aspects missing from its model, while also subtracting layers of complexity and esotericism from the Adams brothers' cult game, resulting in a product that's accessible and entertaining for a few hours.

For a very independent project, following in the footsteps of a game as restrictive and obscure as Dwarf Fortress, Towns is a decent project. However, it's not without its problems.

The tutorial for learning how to control the Townies, a welcome (and necessary) inclusion in this type of simulator, is narrated by a sort of advisor. The problems begin when you notice that the developers' native language is Spanish, and the English text is poor and often confusing. As of version 14, the most recent to date, the tutorial doesn't recognize some commands and instructions, and in my case, I have no audio at all (the audio itself isn't very good or engaging, as far as I remember from version 9).

The isometric graphics with two-dimensional sprites aren't pleasing to the eye, reminiscent of Zynga's much-maligned Farmville. Townies lack charm, and items and equipment sometimes hang in an inelegant manner. Attempting to create a clean and mouse-friendly interface, Towns fails by not offering enough keyboard hotkeys, and some of the building menus can be missed if you don't click in the correct place, forcing you to go through the entire menu system again.

As for certain gameplay elements, such as decoration, they are unnecessarily complicated (even more so than in Dwarf Fortress) and limit the style of play you want to adopt.

Updates to these types of bugs, typos, and balances take a long time per release, and sometimes the additions aren't the most satisfactory. If Towns improves at a faster pace, or allows third-party involvement in its development, perhaps there's a future, but for now it feels amateurish, unfinished, and far behind its ambitions.

column8:
デモ版から始め買った勢です。時間を忘れてできるゲームで、シムシティなどが好きな方は楽しめると思います。
ですが開発中止になったみたいで、これから内容が増えないとなるとなると、後半に飽きが来ると思います。
序盤は敵MOBを避けひたすら食糧を安定させるのが第一で、中盤になると地下を探索したり交易や勇者達を集めて
パーティを組ませたり、家や町を作ったりとすることが多いと思います。ですが後半になると地下探索の作業ゲーになったりします。
楽しいですがデモ版で安定してるのでそちらをお勧めします。
column9:
I bought the demo version first. It's a game you can play and lose track of time, so I think people who like games like SimCity will enjoy it.
However, it seems development has been discontinued, so if there won't be any more content added, I think it will get boring towards the end.
In the early stages, your main focus is avoiding enemy mobs and ensuring a stable food supply, but in the middle stages you'll spend a lot of time exploring underground, trading, gathering heroes,
forming parties, and building houses and towns. However, in the later stages it becomes a game of underground exploration and work.
It's fun, but the demo is more stable, so I recommend that.

column8:
Good City Builder/ Dungeon Crawler with a twist (you want your heroes to die so you can steal their equipment and give it to your townspeople), No direct control over units which is a nice throwback to older pc games like Majesty. 

Good buy if its on sale.

It has bugs, After playing for awhile you know how to not cause them.
It's not perfect, It's clunky, and I've had a lot of fun with it.

All These Negative Reviews Are Just Salty People That Don't Understand That If You Can Get 100's Of Hours Of Playtime From Something, It's Well Worth The Money.

column8:
Jeux tout bonnement annulé car (après avoir engrangé soit dit en passant plus du million d'euro de bénéfice) les dev ont jugé que le jeu ne leur rapporterait pas assez pour vivre.
quel jeu ? Il s'agissait d'un accès anticipé, d'une alpha voire d'une beta donc, qui a tout bonnement été transformée en jeu terminé et il est honteux de le trouver encore en vente à ce stade alors qu'il n'est clairement pas terminé et officiellement annulé.

Les developpeurs ont déjà annoncé qu'il allait sortir une suite, ou plutôt un opus identique totalement recodé.
Il faudra bien entendu de nouveau payer pour se le procurer... pour que probablement il connaisse la meme fin que celui ci. Un abandon en cour de développement une fois qu'un nombre suffisant de joueurs aura investi dedans.

Je déconseille et ce jeu, et tous ce qui pourra être produit par ces apprentis developpeurs.
column9:
A game that was simply canceled because (after having made over a million euros in profit, by the way), the developers decided the game wouldn't bring in enough revenue to survive.
What game? It was an early access game, an alpha or even a beta, which was simply transformed into a finished game, and it's shameful to find it still on sale at this stage when it's clearly not finished and officially canceled.

The developers have already announced that a sequel will be released, or rather, a completely recoded identical opus.
You'll, of course, have to pay again to get it... so that it probably ends the same way as this one. Abandonment during development once a sufficient number of players have invested in it.

I advise against this game, and anything else produced by these budding developers.

column8:
The game has an interesting concept and was the first Greenlight title.  Take a typical RPG setting and control the town instead of the heroes.  Your job is to build up sufficient infrastructure to attract and keep heroes happy for...some reason.  Who knows.

Most of the 36 hours I spent playing were staring at the game in frustration trying to get it to work.  It has some similarities to Dwarf Fortress but it felt like I didn't have as much control.

As others have said, get Gnomoria instead.  Cannot recommend this game to anyone.

However I must give Towns at least a 1/10.  Due to its incredibly broken and frustrating nature, I had to look up help on YouTube and that led me to discovering Sips for the first time.  So thank you Towns for helping me find one of my favorite YouTubers.

I have played alot of towns, my steam hours dont even cover it because I was playing towns before I had steam!
I really liked the game however I stopped playin when it just never seemed to improve. 

I got sick of people starving in the mines which I loved to explore, heroes being absolutely crap against the high end monsters down the bottom of the mines my soliders having to go down in big groups only to starve on their way back

game is fun if you just want to build a city on the top level but if you want to explore as welll it will drive you insane!

unless it is on special and going cheap I would recommend you look at other town builder games before this one

column8:
[b]Towns is sadly full of wasted potential. [/b] On paper, it had everything going for it: resource gathering, micro management, needs of villagers, crafting, construction and combat. Instead, everything is implemented in a basic way that for some reason just doesn't work, and ends up being a clusterfuck, to put bluntly. The screenshots showcasing busy townfolk running around a bustling city look amazing, but don't be fooled: whilst it's true a picture says a thousand words, gameplay says a thousand words + 1.

[b] The graphics, well, it looks like it was made in the early 90s, [/b]   there were a few games using similar painted-art style, but I can't remember their names. The interface is ugly and obstructive, thankfully though the buttons can be minimised. The entire game looks like a free game you play on those Flash sites. Not necessarily bad I must add, but surely if they took a backseat towards the visual department, then they could have pumped more beans into the gameplay side of things? Apparently not.

[b] Main game problem: Artificial Intelligence. The villagers lack any kind of soul and brain, that makes the NPCs in Doom and Quake more likeable. [/b]  They'll randomly dart across the landscape for no apparent reason, and the way they slide across the place looks freaky. They have no goals and just stand there doing nothing, permanently frozen in an upright stance for eternity (except when they die they rotate 90 degrees). Order them to chop down a forest, and they'll just fly towards the area en mass, stand completely motionless in front of the tree and it magically dissapears, through use of sound effects. Couldn't they at least have the sprite of an axe in their hand?
	[b] About their intelligence, they just come across as mindless drones. [/b]  Granted, they actually do a very good job of following orders: ask them to hack down some trees, mine some rock and what not, and they'll literally drop everything, rush towards the area like a bunch of gophers and gleefully carry out said task until it's done. If only public service workers in real life were as committed as these folk are. 
	[b] On the other hand, the villagers lack any sense of self preservation. [/b]  They'll often, for no reason at all, decide to wonder to the complete opposite end of the map and get killed (or raped rather, due to the bad animations) by some high level monsters. Then again for some unknown reason, another villager will decide it's their turn to dash to the other end of the map and repeat this morbid process. It's extremely frustrating as there is no explanation nor solution to this phenomenon, I've actually lost an entire village due to this sick process. If it's not a bug and actually some invisible monster using mind control on my villagers to turn them into suicidal lemmings, than I do apologise.

[b] Remember when I said before about game features being basic, yet for some reason not actually working? [/b]  Well here's an example. I tell a villager to go bake some bread, he does so without delay. Next to the bakery is a designated area for storing bread. Said villager then bakes the bread, and takes the finish products to the store room. Simple right? What actually happens is SOME bread gets put in the store room, whilst the rest is just littering the floor of the bakery, for no explained reason. And now the villagers are eating the bread off the dirty floor INSTEAD of the stockpile, despite the stockpile being closer to them. And again for some unknown reason, some of the villagers decide to find food in the dangerous jungles be yonder, rather than pluck it from the safety of their own town. Maybe they suffer from wheat and gluten allergy?

[b] OK, good things. City building is decent enough, as the villagers will happily carry out construction, even when they are dying of starvation: [/b]  a problem with other city building games is that sometimes buildings weren't been built because the villagers were too busy with other trivial tasks or "idleing", so props to Towns for fixing this common issue (even if it's due to bad AI). You can custom build your houses block by block, choosing a variety of different colours, furniture, etc, and decorate the surrounding area with plants and other decorations. So in essence, Towns does actually deliver what the name implies, assuming you can get past the bugs and terrible AI, and the fact is you need the AI to get the most out of Towns.


[b] Finally, there is only one, ONE single 2 or so minute long music loop that plays throughout the entire game. [/b]  Do yourself a favour, switch that damn thing off and play something in the background of Youtube, as this single endless loop will drive you absolutely insane.


[b] Towns is a massive disappointment, considering the hype and broken promises the developers blew around. [/b]  It actually got abandoned after it was pushed out of beta and into its final, albeit broken release state. I guess they jumped onto the city building craze every other indie game was doing, but didn't have the know-how on how to actually make a game properly. It's a colossus shame as Towns could have very well become a massive hit and a new standard for village building games. If the original developers were to release the game engine/source code for open modification, that could potentially completely turn this game into a success as I bet there's many talented people out there just hoping to get their hands on this and fix all the problems.
There's tons of other similar games that does everything way better. And for the record, to end the Towns vs Gnomoria debate, Gnomoria wins tenfold. At the time of writing, I've only spent 3 hours in Towns, as opposed to 65 hours in Gnomoria. Don't need to say more.

column8: Not worth any value to play. The game has no depth in story or play since. It is really just a low graphic, insanely frustrating sandbox. Yes you can have fun for the first 30 minutes of game play, while you try to learn the ropes of the game and see how far down in the dungeons you can go. After a while you just either get frustrated at all your towns people not doing what you wnat them to, or everyone gets slaughtered by some random monster. The game doesn't have any potential at this point.

column8:
This is the infamous game that has gave a bad name to steam's early release program.

This was one of the first games to be available to purchase from a new (at the time) steam division which was intended to give funding to games which were partially developed and showed a lot of promise.  Back in 2011ish, this game was seen as having amazing potential. Lots of people bought the game, and we thought the money we gave would be used so that the programmer would work full time on the game.  (There is a big write up on exactly how much money was generated from game sales, I can't remember if it was in the hundreds of thousands of dollars or more). 

What happenned instead, was that the developer took the money and stopped working on this game.  Disbelief, outrage, and anger from the community ensued.  No refunds were issued. Steam didn't withhold any of the cash.  

So many people feel they were burned by this affair, that they swore off purchasing pre-release games ever again. And that's the real loss here.

So many people feel they were burned by this affair, that they swore off purchasing pre-release games ever again. And that's the real loss here.

column8:
TRY THE DEMO! It's free, and believe me - it's the best test of whether the game is worth your money. TRY THE DEMO!

So, Towns. Oh boy, where to begin...

This game is not a game for casual play. It's not a traditional game (although I will always believe it helped pave the way for an emerging genre) like most people will expect, and it's not most peoples' defenition of "easy".

It's a game where you get out what you put in, and then some. But the catch is, the "and then some" is an exponential value. After a while, you realise that you've gone from mildly interested, to challenged, to excited, to inspired, to totally hooked. 

Now, in all fairness, the initial challenge is steep. Like I said, it's not an easy game, it's not pick-up-and-play-and-eventually-win.  In fact, Towns is designed to encourage experimentation and multiple approaches. There are no unlocks, it's quite possible to take your first town through the whole game and reach the "end"... but to get there, you'll need to unlock your own creativity and disaster management skills. That takes practice, plain and simple. But like any hobby, after that initial investment the first wave of reward convinces you to keep going, and after that it just gets better and better.

Towns gets a lot of flak. Partly that's because it is genuinely lacking in content - at least, compared to what the content was obviously intended to be. However, I'm convinced that the flak is only spat so vigorously because Towns forces players to take a look at themselves and their own play style. In my view, a lot of the complaints are based off of the horrible realisation that some people just can't get their heads around the new strategies required to do well at this game. Because Towns is a game of strategy. It takes a keen perception and a lot of understanding to see the strategy in all its layers, but there is an underlying logic that is oh so satisfying to crack.

That's not to say this is a game only for super-nerds. Rather, it requires a bit of patience and a bit of humour, plus a healthy curiosity. The patterns are simple enough once you spot them, and infinitely scaleable - that's the beauty of this game. Once you crack one challenge, you can expand and expand that solution and take the same basic logic into other challenges. That's not attractive to some players, but for others it's an absolute joy.

Fortunately, there's a free demo - so you can see for yourself whether you enjoy that challenge or not. 

I wholeheartedly reccomend this game to anyone who is prepared to invest the time and open themselves to the experience. It's not what everyone will enjoy, but those who enjoy it will enjoy it a lot. If you're sick of the instant-gratification games, the ones with no substance or originality; if you just want to deeply engage with a challenge and figure it out; if you're the kind of person who thinks "gah, this is so complex... I love it, how do I solve this?", then Towns may well be one of the games you never entirely forget.

column8:
This game is not complete, even though they it's not listed as Early Access. Basically they just took the cash and ran. I'd like to say some really nasty things about that, but that would be pointless.

Lots of playtime pre-Steam. Game still has most the bugs it did when it was alpha. IMO the biggest bug is that your people work themselves to death, literally, they forget to eat and starve. Got one town up to 70 population, only to see them starve to death in the next 2 hours to to 5. After that I deleted it, being that was the upteenth town that did that.

One of the patches made all the townies rock climbers, so you only need the first set of stairs. And then you get to watch them all race down into to the depths, to fight and die. Heroes are the ones that are supposed to go fight the monsters, not your townies. Once you've collected all that loot and minerals, you're left thinking, what do I do with it. Since there really isn't much to make, I think there's only 1 item made out of gold. So you have that hero running around with that wooden sword you made because he's too stupid to pick up that magical sword that was found. So usually one of your townies will equip it. You can tell them what to equip, but it's a click fest just to get it done. Your townies are kinda stupid too, they just drop everything on the ground rather then put it into containers that are right next to them (that was also int he alpha).

Want to have more fun? Turn on sieges and get wiped out before you even make that the second crafting table your need. Last time I played with siege's on (that's where the monsters can attack you town up top, not counting what the heroes pull to your town), I had just made my first workstation, and here came the spiders, they killed off most of my townies and then the rest of them were wiped out by the next 2 sieges that were 5 minutes apart. 

Games are supposed to be fun and keep the player active and interested. This game doesn't do that. This is also the only game I know of where the player is penalized for being active. So if you're constanly giving them orders, none will show up. I used to go watch tv so they could have 'idle time. 

I heard that there was a patch that came out for this. From what I understood of it, it did minor fixes and made it playable on some other OS so they could suck more money from unsuspecting buyers.

How strange my original review of this poor game disappeared. Might have been deleted by the devs due to me stating that they have a new game they want you to buy. I forget the name of that one. However I intend to avoid anything these guys work on it the future if I possibly can. They abandoned this  BETA because they got bored and started playing the blame game. Who's to say they won't do it again. One dev even bragged in the Steam forums that he took a months vacation in South America from the profits.  How about finishing the game?

So if you want a game that penalizes you, gets boring, frustrating and is incomplete, go ahead and buy this.

column8:
In the current state, I would not recommend this game to anybody.
When I got the game in the end of December 2012, the devs were updating it relatively frequently. It wasn't like they were releasing weekly or monthly updates. The game worked well for what it was. Then the updates dropped off.
I realize this was a greenlight game. I view that similar to a kickstarter game that fails to deliver what was promised. This stuff happens. I got the $4.99 i paid for out of it. I don't know how much it costed to buy it when it was originally greenlit, but it was fair for what I paid. I've bought worse games for more money.

Instead, check out Gnomoria.

Unfinished, buggy, tedious. There's a kernel of fun to be had in the game, even in this pathetic state, but it will be obtained through a terrible UI, broken game mechanics, tedious micromanagement of the most simple of tasks, and poor game design.
The developers abanonded the game after they cashed in on early access, and then have the audacity to suggest a sequel to this unfinished game. Remember their names (Xavi Canal, Ben Palgi) and ensure that their reputation follows them on any future games. To the authors: EA Games could use more people like you.

column8:
DO NOT BUY.  THIS GAME HAS BEEN ABANDONED.

This initially had promise as one of the first Greenlight titles in 2012, and I enjoyed the potential within.  However, the developer did not complete the game as promised, and I'm actualy quite stunned it's even for sale still.  Personally, I would not recommend anyone purchasing an incomplete product and rewarding someone for essentially being incompetent.  This game sold well, and generated more money than what this result is worth.  There are a myriad of better, and cheaper, alternatives.

THIS IS AN INCOMPLETE GAME THAT WILL LIKELY NEVER BE FINISHED.  DO NOT PURCHASE.

column8:
Summary: Towns is a good game, in a beta-like state. The devs have not continued the game, if you purchase this game (at a price far too high for what it should be), then you are supporting developers who have inethically abandoned a game. Do not buy this. If you have a friend who has this game, it's better to just download it from them and play it from that. The best thing about this game is that it's DRM free.

Full Review:

Towns is a game that is well known for being abandoned by the developers. It was created and sold many copies, and then later abandoned.

So the game is given all these bad reviews for being abandoned, however the content itself isn't bad. It has a few glitches, none of which I've experienced being game breaking, mostly just visual. The game is small in size, and runs well. It's graphically not the best, but it's not terrible either. The music is basic, and there isn't much of it. The actual town building aspect has a good amount of stuff to it. It has good management tabs, but ordering your townies is slightly strange. There is a fair amount of content and as a town builder you can do quite a lot with it. The content of the game is actually pretty good.

So should you buy this game? No. If the game sold for less than $3, then it would be better. However for $15 you could much better games that are much more worth it. If this game got continued, then perhaps it could be better too. However, right now, it has been abandoned and is not worth it for the price of the game.

column9: Even though development has unfortunately been discontinued, Towns is still a relaxed city-building game that can be played in a variety of ways. You can either build a highly efficient food supply, search the various dungeons at all costs, or build a beautiful town whose inhabitants enjoy life's daily rodent battles.

column8:
Game was disappointing and unfinished when I bought it, but there was a promise of "will be further updated later". Apparently the developer has now abandoned the game, leaving it half finished. Complete rip-off; there is no way this should be on sale without an "Early Access" tag, and seeing as it will now likely never be finished it is difficult to see how even that would be fair advertising. Buggy, unbalanced, and with many obvious missing features; it compares badly with many games currently available in the same genre, many cheaper and some free.

Current price is £9.99, which is insane- almost twice the current price of Gnomoria. Might be worth 10% of that as a brief diversion, but frankly anything more than "free" is probably a waste.

column8:
I played this game back when it was in alpha, back when there was still active development and a very active community. A friend of mine did a Let's Play of it and I enjoyed what I saw and played. Sadly, the last developer has finally called it quits, and I personally doubt this game will ever leave its alpha/beta state. It is fun micromanaging your town, trying to get immigrants to come to it and attract heroes to it as well, but the food system seriously needs to be reworked. My villagers can go all the way down to the bottom of my mine before needing to come back up again to eat, and since your town can experience hunger lock (Where you don't have any food at all and all villagers can't do anything due to starvation), expect a massive kill off if your food supply ever dwindles to an incredibly low number.

There was a lot of potential behind this game, enough potential that I threw my money behind it back in 2011. Sadly, that potential will never be truly realized since its own developers and the last man working on this game gave up on it. If there ever is a Towns 2, I will not buy it due to the lack of interest the developers had in the first game.

column8: 说点好的吧，这个游戏还是不错的，只是需要花时间掌握。建造的时候，脚手架很有用。材料或者人力不够时，会受到很重的惩罚，建造速度会很慢，或者整个系统发生混乱。新人上手不容易，但上手以后，会觉得还是有些乐趣的，至少它的自由度比较高。虽然没有MC那样的红石电路，但造个楼房，把水引上去，在二楼钓钓鱼什么的，还是比较轻松的。
column9: On a positive note, this game is pretty good, but it takes time to master. Scaffolding is incredibly useful when building. Running low on materials or manpower can lead to significant penalties, slowing construction, or even system chaos. It's a bit tricky for new players to get started, but once you get the hang of it, you'll find it quite enjoyable, especially given its high degree of freedom. While it lacks the redstone circuitry of MC, it's still relatively easy to build a building, divert water up to it, and fish from the second floor.

column8:
Steam Greenlight is a great idea but like all great ideas, people have habit of taking advantage of the situation and Towns is made by some of these people. 

The "About the Game" part of the store page lists features that either barely work or will never make it to a final build as the developers have moved on and left the game in a terrible condition. 

I didn't pay full price so I'm not upset by the matter but hopefully people will read these reviews and stay away. I'd rather throw my money away on Steam Backgrounds rather than games that are never going to be finished.

column8:
As a patron of Minecraft, I very much enjoyed musing the idea of having multiple people placing the blocks, especially in the form of a functioning town rather than a purely aesthetic one. Towns has the potential to be that awesome crossover, but it is not. 

Although listed as a finished game it feels very much as an Alpha. The control over the "Townies" is extremely limtied, and each map begins the same way : a horrible struggle.

The question is why is it a horrible struggle? Right off the bat there are a number of monsters covering the surface of the map, many are able to kill a townie 1 versus 1. The townies will engage anything they encoutner and unlike the "Heroes" do not ever disengage until one of them is dead. So very early on your main task is gathering resources but in very controlled ways to avoid your townies by chance encounter a monster.

So you lost some townies, how does one get them back? Well you will need to have rooms built individually for each town plus any extras you want, they must be well furnished and food must flow in abundance, this together allows them to maintain their happiness which will entice others to join. Here is the kicker: work quickly saps happiness, so when you lose a townie or two the others must work twice as hard to provide happiness. I am sure you can see the paradox happenning.

Ofcourse many other small time problems persist throughout the game which make building anything close to the promos provided to be a long, long way away. Sure this sounds like the right approach, you cannot build a city over night, but the truth is you will spend many weeks before seeing anything resembling a couple huts.

In conclusion this game was greenlit with the hopes of it being grown, expanded and ultiamtely polished. Here is how it looks. 
Greenlit - September 11th, 2012
Last Monthly Update - September 21th, 2013
Date of Review - June 24th, 2014

It has been nearly a year to the date of this review since anything signficant was changed and it will be a surprise to see another.

column8:
If Gabe were as awesome as we'd like to believe, he'd give us a $15 voucher for another game. The best analogy I can come up with:

Gaben is a wealthy pharmacist. He knows his job is to acquire new prescriptions for his large community. Now, there are so many new drugs coming out every day, that Gaben has to ask his community, "What new drugs should we offer at the pharmacy?"

The community heard some neat things about this Townsicol, a do-everything drug. Gaben can only assume that his community knows what they want, even though they don't often know how to get the information about the pharmaceutical companies that made the drug, at least not as profieciently as Gaben. The people assure Gaben that yes, we want Townsicol in the pharmacy!

So Gaben orders Townsicol, even though it hasn't gone through proper FDA qualifications.

The people buy up their prescriptions of their new drug and GOSH! IT TASTES AWFUL! OH GOD! IT'S GIVEN ME DYSENTERY! WHY GA-BGLALARBGB-BEN WHY-ARHGBLARBL?!

But Gaben, watching his customers launch projectile vomit at one another, is distressed. He feels bad for his customers, but THEY ASKED FOR THIS. He brought it in as a special order and the man that sold it to him has completely disappeared like some peddler pushing snake oil! 

Worse, there are those, like yours truly, that watched everyone throw up, walked through that lake of vomit, waded to the counter in all the puke they had expelled, and bought a bottle of Townsicol for themselves.

TL;DR game's bad; developers ran with the money; don't buy it, bitch.

column8:
Despite the bugs, it had been pretty damned fun to play for quite a while. After hearing that the devs had abandoned ship with this game and there will most likely not be any future updates, I wouldn't recommend any of my friends buy this game.

For what it was worth, I did put in some good time managing a city of my own in this game for a while. It was fun while it lasted. Play the demo. Then, if you don't care about any current bugs or future updates, you might consider purchasing this game. It probably wouldn't be worth the full price tag since it lacks any development, but it might be worth it if it went on sale.

Edit: Just saw an update for this game in my download queue. Hopefully this game isn't as dead as it was announced to be. Although the update is an extremely minor update, it's still an update.

column8:
By far the worst thing that could have happened to the opening days of Valve's (now beloved) Greenlight system. It was a game with so much promise--but which fizzled under poor care and lousy management from devs who (seemingly) simply had no interest in their community beyond the potential for money making. Despite valiant efforts by some few out there, this game is a dud, a broken piece of potential doomed to forever drift the landscape of Steam on the backs of the dollars many hopeful fans (myself included) spent toward its grand debut.

This is no Terraria, no Gnomoria, no Dwarf Fortress or Minecraft. Any of those games would be a fine alternative, and I would recommend you turn their way instead.

column8:
This game is abandoned by the developers so no more updates to fix this buggy pile of arse. I played this game before it came out on steam (so my hours played is wrong), i was in an area with no internet and had a new computer so i only had towns installed because it looked like a promising game; with awesome stuff to build, nice customization (many blocks and armours) and a cool endgame with adventurers helping your town, but after some hours of playing i'd rather just look at a plain wall for three days. 

The stuff you see in the screenshots are quite "end game", even the most simple structures, your "townies" will most often sleep eat and work outside because you won't be bothered building houses because the building system is VERRY frustrating because:
1. Your townies do not indicate whether or not they can build something unlike Dwarf-Fortress and Gnomoria and your townies can't reach shit.
2. Most building-blocks require some weird-arse items like slime "stuff" (can't remember name and this game is to horible to back and look) to make some stone bricks. Why? I don't know but it hampers creativity.
3. You can't build floors unlike DF or Gnomoria so every story you add you need an extra layer just for floors (this may have canged, it was a long time since i played)

There is a solution for the reatching problem and that is "scafolding" a block that can be stood upon, walked troug and climbed up. it's completley free so it feels like cheating using it. In other games that adds a scafolding sort of thing they usually cost resorces because scafolding tends to be realy good for moving around. The scafolding tool has been dubed a "god tool" by the comunity because it is realy OP. Other god tools are things like the ability to drop lava anywhere on the map.

At least you can get a lot of hours out of this game, but i would definetly NOT recomend it. Go play Gnomoria (that is 2 euros cheaper), DF (that is free) or any other city builder but definatly DO NOT play Towns.

column8: Legitimately one of the biggest disappointments on Steam early access. Let's not kid ourselves- Greenlit games are often half-built engines that never see the light of further development. But this takes the cake. Left sitting here alone since 2013, this game had promise, but was only ever a simple town simulator- and not even a good one. I'm personally so tired of paying for games to be developed in hopes my money will be put to use creating something amazing, and while this had some direction and potential, in the end it was abandoned and we were all quite honestly fucked for supporting it. Don't buy this piece of shit.

column8:
Проведя в этой игре 100 часов, Я могу сказать, что это один из лучших градостроительных симуляторов. Да, она не идеальна. Да, у неё слабый графон (хотя это далеко не признак). Да, она без цели и смысла. Но это и позволяет нам придумывать свой собственный смысл. Разве не для этого делают подобные игры песочницы? Тот же Minecraft - смысла нет, а игра популярнейшая. 

Косвенная система управления поселенцами вносит долю хардкора в эту игру, а кубическая система, как лично по мне, лучше всего подходит для подобных игр. Без деления на эти квадратики ни одна игра подобного жанра хорошо не зайдёт. Мне нравится, как тут сделали систему подземелий. И нравятся, естественно, герои - всегда хочется иметь парня под рукой, который будет делать всё за тебя (пусть даже и воровать).

Ясно-понятно, что этой игре не хватает многих вещей. Да, можно сделать сюжет. Да, можно сделать воду более обитаемой. Да, можно сделать большее количество блоков. Можно сделать систему прокачки не только героям, но и обычным жителям: кто-то будет печь хорошие булочки, а кто-то будет ковать прочные доспехи. Карты, конечно же, нужно сделать больше, в десятки раз больше, ибо эти чистятся за пару дней игры.

В целом эта игра - шедевръ. Только надо её немного отшлифовать и будет сверкать на Солнце, затмевая другие игры. Разработчикам, конечно же, удачи!
column9:
Having spent 100 hours in this game, I can say it's one of the best city-building simulators out there. Yes, it's not perfect. Yes, its graphics are weak (though that's far from a negative). Yes, it's purposeless and meaningless. But that's precisely what allows us to create our own meaning. Isn't that what sandbox games are all about? Take Minecraft—it's meaningless, yet incredibly popular.

The indirect settler management system adds a touch of hardcore to this game, and the cube system, in my opinion, is the best fit for this kind of game. Without these cubes, no game in this genre would work well. I like the dungeon system here. And, naturally, I like the heroes—you always want a guy at your side who'll do everything for you (even if they steal).

It's clear this game lacks a lot. Yes, it could have a story. Yes, it could have made the water more habitable. Yes, it could have had more blocks. We could implement a leveling system not only for heroes but also for ordinary citizens: some would bake good buns, while others would forge durable armor. The maps, of course, need to be bigger, dozens of times bigger, as these ones can be cleaned up in a couple of days of play.

Overall, this game is a masterpiece. It just needs a little polishing, and it will shine in the sun, outshining other games. Good luck to the developers, of course!

column8:
This game was one of the first games picked by the Greelight community, and it seemed to have a lot of potential. But 2 years later, every hope i had for this game is now dead and buried, since the developer first abandoned it, then sold it to a third-party-dev, who abandoned it again. Playing it feels like playing an Early-Access game, and a lot of important fetures are either incomplete or missing. 
If you really have 12€ to spare and want to weep over the games former bright future, don't buy it. Support some other developer who will use the money to finish their game, instead of trying to sell the unfinished first part to develop a second part (which you will be charged for a second time).
