column8:
Au début, j'ai trouvé ce jeu absolument fantastique. Je veux dire, je l'avais payé une somme ridicule, et il avait l'air sympa (et on pouvait même jouer en cours vues les perfs qu'il demandait). Mais... mais en fait non. Si vous voulez au début, vous avez votre village, vous le développez, et vous avez un peu de mal à avoir tout ce qu'il faut pour construire ce que vous voulez, mais vous vous dites que c'est parce que vous êtes débutant et que ça viendra avec le temps. Le problème, c'est qu'avec le temps ça ne vient pas non plus. A chaque fois que vous voulez construire quelque chose de nouveau, vous avez besoin de deux, trois, voire quatre étapes intermédiaires à construire puis à utiliser pour construire votre objet final. Etapes intermédiaires que vous n'utiliserez sans doute plus jamais par la suite.
Et il y un autre problème considérable : les gens meurent. Oui c'est un fait les gens meurent, mais dans ce jeu votre population sera décimée en moins de deux. Vous vous développez tranquilement lorsque tout à coup, le premier meurt, laissant un tas de cendre. Puis un deuxième, puis un troisième. Vous apprenez qu'ils n'ont pas à manger, mais ils ne mangent pas quand vous leur donnez de la nourriture ! Et ils sont finalement achevé par un fantôme du passé qui les déciment tous sans exception en leur passant dessus. Et à ce moment votre sauvegarde ne vaut plus rien puisque plus personne n'est là pour faire fonctionner votre ville.
Selon la description du jeu, le but de celui-ci est de développer une ville pour que des héros viennent passer un peu de temps avant d'aller affronter d'horribles choses pas trop loin de chez vous. Je n'ai jamais vu un seul héros de tout le temps que j'y ai joué.

Cependant, je trouve qu'il est cruel de mettre un pouce rouge à ce jeu, et je demanderais à tous ceux qui se plaignent de lire ce qui suit : 
[url]http://www.townsgame.com/forums/viewtopic.php?f=8&t=10615[/url]
Comme l'expliquent les développeurs, le jeu était parti sur de mauvaises bases, et tout était à refaire, et c'était impossible. Je regrette d'avoir acheté ce jeu, parce qu'il faut le dire, il n'est pas fini et surtout que ce n'est peut être pas mon genre de jeux. Mais j'aurais préféré voir ses développeurs le continuer, d'autant plus qu'ils ont réussi à en vendre 200 00 exemples, réunissant ainsi des bénéfices de plus de deux millions d'euros...
column9:
At first, I thought this game was absolutely fantastic. I mean, I paid a ridiculous amount of money for it, and it looked fun (and you could even play it in class given the performance it demanded). But... but actually, no. If you want to, at the beginning, you have your village, you develop it, and you have a little trouble getting everything you need to build what you want, but you tell yourself that it's because you're a beginner and that it will come with time. The problem is that it doesn't come with time either. Every time you want to build something new, you need two, three, or even four intermediate stages to build and then use to build your final object. Intermediate stages that you will probably never use again.
And there's another considerable problem: people die. Yes, it's a fact, people die, but in this game your population will be decimated in less than two. You're quietly developing when suddenly, the first one dies, leaving a pile of ash. Then a second, then a third. You learn they don't have anything to eat, but they don't eat when you give them food! And they are finally finished off by a ghost from the past who decimates them all without exception by running over them. And at that point, your save is worthless since no one is there to run your city.
According to the game's description, the goal is to develop a city so that heroes can spend a little time before going to face horrible things not too far from home. I never saw a single hero in the entire time I played it.

However, I find it cruel to give this game a thumbs-down, and I would ask anyone complaining to read the following:
[url]http://www.townsgame.com/forums/viewtopic.php?f=8&t=10615[/url]
As the developers explain, the game was off to a bad start, and everything had to be redone, which was impossible. I regret buying this game, because it must be said, it's not finished, and especially because it might not be my kind of game. But I would have preferred to see its developers continue it, especially since they managed to sell 200,000 copies, thus generating profits of over two million euros...

column8:
The idea of this game was something i couldn't ignore. Sadly, i should have. Bugs, and lack of any sort of walk through, or starting help. Just to start off with. AI that is more likely to kill itself off at first chance than not, can be very frustrating to say the very least. Beyond that, lets look at a very important aspect of the game.

The Dev team. They have dropped the game, and decided to come back, more often than i can believe. The very fact that they decided to drop it even once says a lot. The fact that the hired help, decided to jump ship, because he found out.. there wasn't going to be much of a pay check, says a lot. This is very much a "buyer beware". The game isn't finished. The game according to some news feeds is never going to be finished, and yet the games forums (not steam) says they've decided to work on it... "again"

Just save your money, and look towards a different game. I know, i will personally be avoiding any game made by this group in the future.

For what it is, it is a great little game with a fantastic concept. Controlling the development of a village sitting on top of a dungeon and suiting the town to the needs of the heroes (instead of the other way around).
Yes its unfinished, and yes its unpolished. But this game was introduced before the Early Access category was available. Technically this is an early access game that has not been finished yet, and it is likely that it never will be, as the developers has decided to drop the game.

column8: I really wanted to be able to recommend this game.  I really did.  Unfortunately, a game that many customers paid money for has been abandoned, leaving only the bare-bones alpha build for review or recommendation.  As things stand, this game had a lot of potential, but it was abandoned by the original designers.  The game's future is uncertain, but as things stand, the product is as good as abandoned.   This is a huge letdown to anyone who put up the money to support this project.  I don't know what I expected from the finished product, but I did expect a finished product.

column8:
[b]BUYER BEWARE[/b]

This game is not a finished product, although all patching and further development has been completely abandoned. DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME AND MONEY HERE. There are far better titles out there (See: Gnomoria and/or Banished) That are still being improved.

The Tutorial explains next to nothing aside from the VERY basics, the UI feels odd at best and at times needlessly tedious. Many players have expressed practically being FORCED to go through online guide after online guide just to understand how this or that works. 

There is also currently a petition on the forums for this game demanding a refund.

column8:
The game is broken.  Bottem line.

Its hard to describe because the game WAS (the devs gave up once they got the $) getting patched so broken things were removed... and then new broken things were added in but here is a list of what I found the most broken.

1. Building is not fun.  There is no easy copy and paste for buildings.  And if there is, then it is hidden under the games terrible interface.  It can take a lot of effort of placing certain building blocks in certain orders to build a house with the clunky building controls.  But then if you have to do it at least 20 more times if you want to get townies.  It can take a while.

2.  The interface is horrible.  The labels are off.  It just felt clunky.  First you have to click one menu button, then you have to click a sub menu button and find what you want.  Then if its something like wheat and you want it to be bread you have to go into more menus and submenus to find what you want.  The bread making tools and blocks should all be on the same page not scattered around.

3.  Your villagers are idiots.  They have no clue how to do anything without dieing.  Horrible monsters attacking?  Don't worry, your villagers will just stand there and die instead of running.  Sometimes they run indoors but most of the time go around doing what they normally do.  Their are even some maps with randomly wandering enemys, I dont have a problem with that but they do it so poorly in Towns.  In the snow maps one stray yeti can just wander on over and kill EVERYONE.  Also they will run though hell and back...to get stone.  I have seen them go on some brave runs just to get a basic resource.  You got to give them credit.  They will stop are nothing to drag that junk back to the stockpile... even if they all die in the process.

4.  The monsters that attack your village come out of THIN AIR.  You would think they would come from any dungeon entrances you have but they seem to pop out of midair at times.  

5.  Monsters are either really OP or really easy.  I watched a guard kill five slimes once.  Then I watched three guards with iron gear just get massacred by ONE wearpig. (Which is actually a common enemy.  Any normal pig could be a wearpig.)  

6.  Hero's are broken.  I must have done EVERYTHING I could think of to attract a hero.  They never come.  They are broken.  That or the system is terrible.  Either way the game dosen't explain things and after browsering the web for a while I still can't get damn Heros.  Worst part is.  You need heros to clear dungeons, but you can never get them it seems.

7  The way you make your townies happy is stupid.  They mainly get happy from eating.  Problem is, if you have food that fills them up a lot and dosen't make them eat as often.  YOU GET PUNISHED.  I actally tested this at one point by making bread fill 1500%.  Sure enouth happyness dropped to zero because they were not eating.   You can do a few other things like have badger fights (which seem broken) and put decorations but it seems food is what they want the most.  So remember, just spam cakes.  Anything that actually fills their stomachs is bad.  They don't want to be full.  THey want to be hungry.  Makes zero sense.    

8.  Last thing I am going to mention is the dungeons...THEY ARE EVERYWHERE.  It seems I can't dig down at all without hititng a dungeon on most map.s  I just wan't some stone but the game shoves the dungeons everywhere.  They cover the whole map when they should be deep underground and have SMALL entrances.    

Now things may have changed since I wrote this but this is what I encountered when I played the game.  And maybe some of the issues I mentioned have easy fixes but there is a problem...THE GAME SHOULD EXPLAIN IT THEN.  There is no tutorial.  Well there claims to be one but it just starts you off on fixed map without telling you much.  You have to find the message log and it tells you to do basic stuff.  Nice they have one at all but it never explains the fine details of the game.  Just the basic crude that I could probably figure out just by expermenting.

column8:
DO NOT BUY - GAME IS VAPORWARE

The original developer stopped working on this game because, despite a couple million in sales, he didn't feel like it anymore. To top it off, he sold the game to a third party developer for a pittance (15% of revenue after taxes and Steam fees are taken off, which is likely less than 10%). The icing on the cake is that they are talking about a Towns 2.

This game is a scam.

column8: Im going to get hate for this but, I cant say Towns is a bad game. The time i had with this game was great. Sure the textures are not the best and the AI can be dumb at some times, but i was still having fun with it. Would i suggest buying towns? no, not at all. BUT if its on sale and its cheap enough i would suggest picking it up and playing it for a hour or two. People are getting pissed off that the devs are complete shit and in some way that is true, but they had to stop developing the game becuase they ran out of money and a lot of people complain that the devs are sellouts cause they think they walked away from this with 2 miilion dollars blah blah blah what ever your reason is to hop on the hate train is your reason. I personally dont think that the game is that bad to be honest. I have played this game for 35 hours and my brother has played it too for about 40+ and after we stop playing towns me and him both felt it was a fun good game with some bugs of course. In ending thought, if you have a chance to pick up Towns, then i suggest doing so. I would give this game a 6.8/10 rating which isnt bad but could be better.

column8: A game with great promise that has been abandoned by it's develops - who are now talking about making towns2.  They won't be seeing any money from me.  An involved, fiddely and engaging game marred by a clumsy UI and a grinding build process.  The sort of game you need a wiki open on your second moniter to work out.  Towns is a tragic game, it could have been legendary - now it's edged out of the market by clones. 3/5

column8:
I poured many hours into this game. I will admit that a great deal of them were while I was afk, letting the world run itself, especially if I was in a bit of a recession. 

Towns as a game is a great idea, and had the potential for greatness in it. It had some fun elements, digging deep into the earth looking for ore, while building a utopia above.

It has it's fair share of bugs, and the AI leaves a bit to be desired. Can't tell you how often I've lost an entire village while afk because the guards don't know how to protect the villagers and then go heal themselves properly. Can be a real spirit breaker. 

As it is, it is playable, and a certain level of fun can certainly be had for this game, but I give you fair warning here:

THIS GAME HAS BEEN ABANDONED BY THE DEVELOPERS. That means this product will come to you AS IS, with no thought of change to make note of. It's not terribly expensive, and I've certainly poured enough time into this game to have made it worth the 15 bucks I paid for it, but all in all, you may just end up avoiding this game and try something with a similar touch to it, but is more polished.

column8:
As a player of Towns with 72 hours, I'd say it's pretty much finished. It's a decent game with (last I played) not many bugs and had many solid features. Easily worth a measly 15 dollars - I honestly thought the devs were finished with Towns as there were no longer any updates, I didn't think they abandoned it.

2 cents from a person who's actually played towns.

also note it's not perfect - what indie game is?

A better game in my opinion is Gnomoria. It's a fun game that takes a while to learn but it's being actively updated every 2-3 weeks (aside from last two months cause the creator had a child and was focusing on being a father; the updates started back up). Easily worth the cost.

A lot of people are coming here and posting because they read it was 'abandoned' and wanted to write a review, yet they've never played. This game is also a niche game, make sure you'd be interested before buying. I would also suggest watching a lets play or tutorial of it because it's easier to learn from watching than the in game tutorials. (for either game)

column8:
Buyers Beware - This game has long been on life support (I'd consider it to be effectively abandoned.) The creators seem unwilling to invest what it takes to actually make this game succeed long term, and the developer that was hired to continue the project has just quit:

http://www.townsgame.com/forums/viewtopic.php?f=8&t=11480
http://www.townsgame.com/forums/viewtopic.php?f=8&t=11485

As someone who liked the game and very much wanted to see it continue to expand, I am very, very disappointed with how this has turned out.  I've been watching things go sour for quite a while now, and in light of these events I think I have reserved judgement for long enough.  Perhaps even too long.

The developers released a good product, and sold hundreds of thousands of copies.  They actually grabbed the golden ring of indie game development.  Then they took that golden ring and chucked it in the swamp.

It was rather obvious months ago that they were not serious about continuing to support the product that was released, especially as they repeatedly failed to deliver on expectations and sales declined.

I hope they enjoy their money, it's obvious now that it is not going back into Towns development as was implied when I bought the game on Steam Early Access. I also hope they didn't spend it all, because I will never buy another game from these jokers after watching them get handed bags of cash during Steam Early Access only to have them fail to reinvest those funds to improve the product.

I'm usually not this harsh, but watching developers squander success like this really pushes my buttons.

I think it is time for me to abandon Towns, too.

column8:
先に言います、面白いし、長く遊んだけれど、お勧めはしません。

Wineを通していないSteamで遊べるのは良い。実際Ubuntuで遊べています。Linuxで遊べて要求スペックが低めなのはいいところです。実際、Linux対応のゲームでも、Linuxで遊ぶ場合はWindowsよりも必要なスペックが上がりますからね。


このゲームは、最初の11人に指示を出し、町を作るなどして人口を増やしたりするゲーム。
MAPによっては、開始地点が悪いとあっさり全滅してしまいます。始めは運も必要です。

AIが良くないのでしょうか、近くに置く場所を設置しても、遠くに設置した置き場に持って行こうとすることも良くあるため、街が大きくなるとより効率の悪い状態になります。位置よりも設置した時期を優先しているのでしょうか？


タイトルがタイトルなだけに、攻略方法やらMODやらの情報を集めたりするのが困難です。いや、そんなに種類もないかもしれないけれど。ワークショップ対応してから終了してほしかった。
（今となっては似たようなゲームも増えて、MODを作ろうとするユーザーが出てくるかどうかは怪しいが）


開発が終了しなければ、おすすめにしていました。AIの改善等をして欲しかったのですが、残念です。Townsが面白くないというわけではありませんが、似ているゲームはあります。

買うならセール待ちでも良いでしょう。
column9:
I'll say it first: it's fun and I played it for a long time, but I wouldn't recommend it.

It's good that you can play it on Steam without using Wine. I can actually play it on Ubuntu. The low spec requirements on Linux are a good thing. In fact, even games that are compatible with Linux have higher specs when played on Linux than on Windows.

This game involves giving instructions to 11 characters and increasing the population by building towns and other means.
Depending on the map, a bad starting location can easily wipe you out. You also need luck at the start.

Perhaps the AI ​​isn't very good, but even if you set up a nearby storage location, it often tries to take the item to a storage location farther away, making it even more inefficient as the town gets bigger. Does it prioritize the time of installation over location?

Given the title, it's difficult to gather information on strategies and mods. Well, maybe there aren't that many options, though. I wish they had added workshop support before discontinuing the game.
(Nowadays, there are a lot of similar games, so it's doubtful that there will be any users willing to create mods.)

If development hadn't ended, I would have recommended it. I wish they had improved the AI, but unfortunately, they haven't. It's not that Towns isn't fun, but there are other similar games out there.

If you're going to buy it, it might be a good idea to wait for a sale.

column8: I'm extremely livid that they chose to walk away from this project. The idea was really cool, and I hadn't heard of anything like it, so I decided to buy it. The menus were pretty bad, and it was annoying to build anything. The tutorials were terrible as well. I stopped playing it because I was hoping that it would eventually become finished with a nice and polished menu to build your town. I hadn't seen an update in so long that I forgot I even had the game. I do not wish to ever do business with the developers after this, and I will be very careful with which games I choose to buy and greenlight from now on. Hopefully Valve will help their customers avoid situations like this in the future.

column8:
I'm really just more disappointed than anything. The game has so much potential, but the developer is either too lazy or corrupt to provide a finished product.

It's painfully unfinished. Early-access buyers paid to support Towns through development, but the game was never further developed. The developer, Xavi, vaccilates between claiming the game's in a complete state (lol, not at all) and that he's "new to indie gaming" and "burnt out."

I really want to like the game, but I can't go more than a few hours before getting tired of hitting bugs, clunky UI and mechanics, and content holes. I wouldn't think of buying this for a friend, and I hope others don't make the same mistake of buying it that I did.

column8:
While Towns clearly had potential as a city builder/simulator with hints of Dwarf Fortress and Dungeon Keeper, the development of this early access title has officially been abandoned. This means that no further updates will be made, plus it will very likely never reach "full game status".

While there might be opportunities for talented modders to salvage what is left, paying customers will inevitably feel cheated. Buying the game at this point is a waste of money and time, unfortunately.

column8:
It had a lot of potential and the dev provided screen shots make it look a lot more amazing than it really is. While it was fun, anyone who plays this game for any length of time will realize that it's unfinished both in terms of balance and requested/necessary features.

There are other games out there that, while they might not be as user friendly, greatly surpass this in terms of quality.

Also I discovered recently that the devs decided to halt all production on the game, citing it as 'stable' after a year with no updates, leaving disgruntled fans all over the place and at the same time touting they plan to make a sequel. 

If they seriously think Towns 2 is going to make it on steam, they're kidding themselves with an almost religious fervor.

It had a lot of potential and the dev provided screen shots make it look a lot more amazing than it really is. While it was fun, anyone who plays this game for any length of time will realize that it's unfinished both in terms of balance and requested/necessary features.

There are other games out there that, while they might not be as user friendly, greatly surpass this in terms of quality.

Also I discovered recently that the devs decided to halt all production on the game, citing it as 'stable' after a year with no updates, leaving disgruntled fans all over the place and at the same time touting they plan to make a sequel. 

If they seriously think Towns 2 is going to make it on steam, they're kidding themselves with an almost religious fervor.

column8:
This game has been OFFICIALLY ABANDONED, as of 7 May 2014. This is not opinion or trolling, but straight from the developers. Development of this game has been cancelled, and no refunds are being given. The game went through Steam Greenlight prior to Early Access existing, which is the only reason it doesn't have an EA tag on the store page. The game is very much unfinished, and will NOT be completed.

There is still fun to be had, but you will have more with Gnomoria. Play that game instead.

column8:
If you like buying a game where the developer announces they are abandoning it before it's finished and in the same post announces the sequal. This is the game! I don't get how you can announce a sequal in the exact same post of you deciding you'll never finish this game. I hope you realize how stupid that was, I'm sure marketing Towns 2 is going to be great. "Hey remember Towns, the game we never finished, buy Towns 2!"

This game needs to be removed as soon as possible. The gameplay is nowhere near polished to be sold on it's own. At first, it's kinda easy to maintain all the citizens and stop them from going deep underground to get useless items. But, the more citizens you have the harder it is to stop them from going on suicide missions and you'll have citizens dying constantly. It's more fustrating then fun trying to build a decent town.

column8:
PENDING FUTURE UPDATES: As of now I can't recommend. This is a game that has a lot of promise but ultimately fails to deliver. The tutorials do not explain a whole lot, and are often buggy. (Random shutdowns.) There hasn't been much
work done on the game. If you're going to sell a product, make it a playable product. One that delivers. The dungeon mentioned that is below the town? Not there. Character AI? Random, buggy to where it doesn't always respond to your
commands. Everything else plays like someone put it together with a poor copy of RPG maker. I held off reviewing this for a while, because I liked the initial promise...but it has been months and months with nothing of merit added to the game. I can see why the others felt ripped off.

Steer clear until the devs get their act together.

column8:
A great game to kill time with! It takes town managment to a new level of fun, along with creating a vibrant and alive city~

Don't expect the whole pie here, folks..expect a good portion of it, as updates are massivly slow and the game buggy...but dont let that fool you out of a great game! Its aspects are much alike with Dwarf fortress, only simpler and a less massive UI. The UI itself is a masterpiece, and learning how to play the game is cake-walk...though youll need plenty of trial and error. 

A great buy...though, as much as i love it, you might want to wait on a summer/winter sale on it..if you have the money, buy it now!!

column8:
Interesting. Where did all the reviews go? Wow. Starting on a blank slate here, maybe?

Let's be honest: The premise of Towns is as quirky as it is unique: You build a fantasy town OVER a monster-filled dungeon, so that heroes will come and explore said dungeon- and with your town being endared by the monsters but at the same time able to provide important services to the heroes the game clearly has a tongue-in-cheek approach to both town-building and fantasy tropes in general.

Let's be honest: This is an early access game. So you can expect it isn't done yet. It allows you to build a diverse range of buildings and services, and heroes do occasionally pop up and do their thing, and yes, there are monsters.
And that is the catch, the premise is really interesting but at this stage, the features that are in don't make for a very interesting game.
column9:

column8:
"Towns is an amazing experience to have. It may seem tough and unforgiving when you first play it, but the more you play it and the more you learn, the more you will enjoy it! This game doesn't hold your hand the whole way through which isn't a bad thing. One bad thing about this game though is that the tutorials make absolutely no sense and doesn't really help at all. This game will make you manage a colony of people, while dealing with things like starvation and monsters. It is by no means an easy game, but if your up for a challange, then I really must recommend this game because, even though it is not perfect, it is still entertaining. I give it a 6/10." -Snubbo 2014

Well, I see that my oppinions have greatly changed. This was the period when I was engrossed in this game. Let's just say that I no longer find any enjoyment out of this. This is a game with tutorials that are about as easy to understand and Astro Physics, the difficulty curve makes it really hard for newcomers and really annoying for anyone else. In this game you build a town, get people to move in, manage the food, water, ect. Eventually you may even get a warrior to move in. The problem is keeping your people alive, with the management system not quite working, which is a big problem in a game that is all about managing. Here is an example...
You set some of you villagers to start picking apples, drop them off, and then cook them into pies. You then get the rest of your crew to go mining, with the help of some warriors. After about 20 seconds the warriors decide to wander off, 2 of the 5 you had get themselves killed, on the way to the apple and pear trees your villagers manage to drown themselves, the rest come up from mining to find no food and then die from starvation on the way to pick apples.
The result is a game that doesn't want you to enjoy it too much. Final score? 
Get a better game/10

This is a game with tutorials that are about as easy to understand and Astro Physics, the difficulty curve makes it really hard for newcomers and really annoying for anyone else. In this game you build a town, get people to move in, manage the food, water, ect. Eventually you may even get a warrior to move in. The problem is keeping your people alive, with the management system not quite working, which is a big problem in a game that is all about managing. Here is an example...
You set some of you villagers to start picking apples, drop them off, and then cook them into pies. You then get the rest of your crew to go mining, with the help of some warriors. After about 20 seconds the warriors decide to wander off, 2 of the 5 you had get themselves killed, on the way to the apple and pear trees your villagers manage to drown themselves, the rest come up from mining to find no food and then die from starvation on the way to pick apples.
The result is a game that doesn't want you to enjoy it too much. Final score? 
Get a better game/10

column8: When you get this game, just know that it will likely never be finished. No update has come out in months (years?) and even though a new dev supposedly took over I don't have high hopes. That said, this is still an amazing game if you can get it for sale. It's sort of a baby Dwarf Fortress, with neither the frustration nor the depth. I liked it quite a bit. But I also only paid $2 for it.

column8:
Bought this over a year ago, and I loved it then (83 hrs). I've read about the new updates, and I can't wait to play it again.

Towns can be difficult to learn at the beginning of the game. It has a deep level of complexity due to how flexible it is for player building. You do not get complete control over your villagers. Rather, you place a series of instruction for your villagers to follow. As is typical for town building games, your villagers can be pretty dumb sometimes, but that is all part of the fun. You think that you are safe to leave your people to work on the things that you assign them, and sometimes, things go horribly wrong. 

I've had several cities that have failed horribly, but I have no problems restarting. It just gives me more delivery and more fun.

column8:
[EDIT] Holy crap they released a patch Apr 2014 and are taking suggestions for v15. It's alive!

Objectively, the reviews below saying "not recommended" are correct. The game is really not finished, and given it has an development for many years, and has not seen an update in a while, and the developer statement that he is "burned out", I would not expect any more updates.

With that said, I still spent an enjoyable month or so playing this game. Coming from Dwarf Fortress and wanting something a little prettier, this game provides a nice twist on the genre, rather than mining you "dig too deep" by hiring heroes who explore dungeons.

It provides an interesting and detailed tech tree, one of the best workshop designs I have seen in any such game (you place zones for workshops and then crafting stations within zones).

That said, I am obsessed with this genre and desperate for other games in it. If you want to try something like this but with active development and far more polished, I highly recommend Gnomoria (and keeping an eye on Stonehearth and Clockwork Empires).

I would still recommend this game, although given it is unlikely to see any updates I would personally want to see the price knocked down a little given its incomplete state.

I really hope the new developer breathes new life into this game, but I feel like once the game gets into a negative feedback cycle developers have little incentive to do so -- when everyone is panning your game on Steam and no updates have been released for a year and a half, what is your incentive to continue working on it?

Even if you decide not to buy, I would keep an eye on this game just in case things change.This game has a tremendous amount of potential, and is farther long than many games in the genre.

column8:
Great game, kept me busy playing for hours and hours. 
Took some time to figure out how everything works in detail. It's great to manage and come up with new systems to take care of town.

However... the game has many bugs. Some can be easily ignored, others may get annoying. for the current €12,- steam is offering this game, i'd say its too expensive. But, when you are able to buy it in a sale for a couple of euro's it's definately worth it. 
If you only like polished games, don't buy it. If you think you can handle some bugs like me, you could have a good time playing this game.

column8:
ONLY GET THIS GAME IF YOU LIKE DYING AND A CHALLENGE.

It is not that bad of a game. If you give it enough time. If you are wanting to build an elaborate fortess with 5 stories and everything perfectly place in it, you will get mad and quite the game. Instead look at it as a survival game mod with ever increasing sieges that force you to explore the depths of dungeons so you can equip your villagers with good enough weapons to survive the 200 spiders that spone inside your base. 

It does have many bugs to it: having to set flags at every square to explore a dungeon, a villager ignoring your minimum level setting and going into the 5 floor just to pickup a set of bones, the over bulky food production (only efficient way is to eat T1 food that only fills 20%), the "heroes" that drag dungeon monsters into your city, the glitchy animal farming, the complete lack of certain resources on maps (excluding that random unreachable piece of coal placed floating ontop of the lake). 

But these are all part of the random events and part of the challenge. Every time you get killed off, you learn a new aspect of the game. The reason they don't explain much of the tutorial is becuase they want to you figure it out in the game.

It has a lot more depth into the game: dealing with traders, forming an army to defend sieges, creating a badger areana, wood working, smithing, fishing, glass blowing, vanities (cosmetics), inlisting heroes, killing monsters (orcs, goblins, ogers, giant, trolls, ect), a death cycle for villagers (disease, disposal of corpses/ wraiths), farming, pastry making, complex item system, and a lot more that you have to discover. 

But you do not see these with just playing for the first 5-10 hours and calling it crap.

column8:
Pending an Edit, I might change this in the future.

This game has great potential, but it all fades after about 20hrs of gameplay.

The early learning curve of the game is very steep. Infact, since there is no ingame help of any kind, you will be going to the internet to figure out some mechanics of this game.

Villager path finding is always shortest route, regardless of danger. Hostile NPC's do have random and specific spawns, but more often then not I feel they are hunting me down.

Building is somewhat confusing till you get the hang of it. The only drawback is, if you don't build in small sections the game seems to hang on larger designs. The same goes for most the resource managment. Even after giving out specific jobs, and setting priority's all my villagers do is eat and sleep.

Fact is, this game has loads of pontential. But fails to deliver. At best this feels like an Alpha Version of a game.

I do not recommend this game.

column8: yeni birşey sunmuyor kesinlikle almayın

I'll keep this short, This game has a learning curve thats quite steep, and it will be about 3 games before you figure out the basics. By the time you have a thriving town that can sustain itself you'll feel very acomplished. Soon though, things stop being so rewarding. Your townies are irritating at best, they can die from starvation because they straded themself 2 blocks high wile building, or drown because their path took them into water. Your buildings will very quickly trade estetics for fuctionality, possibaly a gribe for someone only as perfectionist as myself. There is nothing really to do after you figured everything out, because besides for a stray orge or something random like that the challenge is gone.
I'm not saying not to buy this game, if its on sale by all means buy it, the learning curve wile give you enough entirtainment at least. But, this game is buggy and unpolished, and updates are nearly non existant, so it is a risk.

column8:
Most RPGs take from the "you are the hero" vantage point, but I never thought to be the one who controlled the town/village that housed the adverturers, and I didn't expect to like it so much.

I'm not sure why but this game was a lot of fun when I was playing it. There is something about the difficulty in discovering how to do things that made it all worth while. If you can catch this game on sale and/or have your mind open I think you'll be happily surprised at this gem. 

It's light hearted, simple, yet difficult to master and really rewarding when you get everything working smoothly. A lot of reviews talk about how buggy it is, but when more than a year ago when I was playing it most I didn't experience those problems.

column8:
Ursprüngliches Review März 2014: NICHT KAUFEN! Die Entwicklung des Spiels wurde eingestellt, wobei das vorhandene schon nur halb bis gar nicht funktioniert. Nette Idee und grundsätzlich spielbar, aber eigentlich sollte das Spiel aus dem Store genommen werden.

Ergänzung September 2014: nach fast einem Jahr ohne Updates kam tatsächlich mal wieder eines heraus. In der Zwischenzeit gab es einige höchst widersprüchliche Aussagen der Entwickler und ohne jeglichen Programmfortschritt in so langer Zeit ist euer Geld in andere Spiele immer noch besser investiert. Sollte Towns jemals fertig werden vielleicht nochmal nen Blick drauf werfen, bis dahin: lieber andere Dinge spielen und kaufen.
column9:
Original review March 2014: DO NOT BUY! Development of the game has been discontinued, and the existing version is already only partially functional or even non-functional. A nice idea and basically playable, but the game should really be removed from the store.

Update September 2014: After almost a year without updates, one finally came out. In the meantime, there have been some highly contradictory statements from the developers, and without any program progress in such a long time, your money is still better spent on other games. If Towns ever gets finished, maybe you'll take another look. Until then, play and buy other things instead.

column8: This game. THIS FUCKING GAME. I had fun. I had a lot of fun. But this game is like a FUCKING CRASH TO DESKTOP SIMULATOR. Once every hour, this game will CRASH WITH NO INDICATION AS TO WHY. Plus, I have heard that the developers have STOPPED. Early access they said. Now what? $15, and they don't even finish their game. What made me write this review was what happened a little while ago. My citizens dug out some stone, which I told them to. The stone was holding up a shit ton of water from the river above. Water is infinite in certain situations, and my miner ended up dying. Tried to remove the water by doing the "Remove Liquid" option, ONE DAMN BLOCK AT A TIME. GUESS WHAT? HALF THE TOP OF THE RIVER IS GONE, WHICH IS LIKE A THIRD OF THE FUCKING RIVER, AND THEN THE GAME CRASHES! FUCKING BULLSHIT. YOU GET A NOT RECOMMENDED FROM ME, TOWNS. MADE ME FLIP OUT SO HARD, I CRASHED MY FIST DOWN ON MY TABLE AND ENDED UP DESTROYING MY SOUVENIR RING FROM WASHINGTON DC.

Overall looking forward to see whats to come of this game.

column8: Well, it's been months since any word on this game.  It's sad, but safe, to say it's discontinued.  What started as a promising but crude 'dwarf fortress with graphics', a functional prototype was quickly hashed out.  Obviously far from finished, an 'early alpha' at best, the game was near-unplayable due to constant crashes, game-crippling bugs, the most cumbersome resource management system in history, and an exponentially growing supply chain that cripples and ends every game on a sour note.  The lack of content and clearly thrown-together mechanics left everything to be desired.  And those sorely hoping for more were disappointed, as little to nothing changed over the many months since it saw the light of day.  By this point, it's a lost cause-  it can no longer hope to add anything new or compete with the myriad competition.  It will forever be known as a half-hearted attempt to alpha-scam the sandbox genre during it's boom.

column8:
If you want a Dwarf Fortress Clone with graphics, please play Gnomoria. 
This game is a very low quality and not fit for release.

While the game was promising while it was being developed, the developers have stated that they have seized all development and support. The game more or less feels like a scam now, and Xavi Canal and Ben Palgi made millions of euros from it. This was probably the last unfinished game I ever purchased because of that.

A sad fortune, because the game really did have promise.

Edit: It seems someone has been appointed to further develop this game. If this is the case, the outlook should be more positive.

column8:
very time consuming, very complex and challenging if your willing to put your mind to it.  Simple interface makes the gameplay much more soothing to the not so strategic minds.  

The game can be very easy if your looking for the short game.  Food Shelter etc.  But if you want to "dig deep" into the game you will need to apply a little more thought.   The Sieges can be extremely hazardous to your citizens.  If not properly equiped with weapons and armor your town will soon become a ghost town. ( no pun intended)

Overall this game is a must have for simulation strategists.

column8:
Towns had the potential to become a good Dwarf fortress clone, however development halted and an official statement on the forums made clear that the current version (with a lot of bugs, and debugging/admin tools availble to users) will be the final version.

That being said: i enjoyed the game dispite all the bugs and frustrations, Do i recommend it? [b]NO[/b]
unless you want to buy an unfinished game and are willing to bite your fingernails off of frustration, dont buy the game
Gnomorria is a better DwarfFortress clone, and more complete

-update-
apparently a new developer has been hired, but at the moment of this review, its still far from being recommended

column8:
2014-03-04 기준 ( 7 점 / 10 점)

분명히 답답한 부분... 시민들이 다들 정신이 해까닥 했는지 피떨어지면 영웅도 도망가는데

지들은 죽을때까지 끝까지 싸운다. 게다가 아군이 지원하러 왔으면 뒤로 빠질만도 한데 절대 물러서는 법이 없다 ㄷㄷ

그리고 집 짓는 방법이라든지 부족한 설명 덕분에 몇번이고 헤매는 자신을 볼 수 있다...

적의 수준은 약간 하드하게 되어 있다. 초반에는 굉장히 신경써야할  부분.  앞에서 말했다 시피 도망가는

뇌기능이 없어서 세심한 컨트롤이 필요하다...

그래도 영웅 키우는 재미나 지붕쌓는(!?) 재미가 있으니까 하는중.. ㅋㅋㅋ

영웅도 밸런스붕괴가 있고 인공지능은 모든것을 덮을 정도로 심각하다.. ㅜ

단순히 싸우다가 죽을 성 싶으면 도망가는 것인데, 뻔히 길 두고 죽는 모습이 여러번 보인다...

다행인 것은 몬스터보다는 발이 빨라서 순식간에 도망간다는 것. 하아,,,,

답답한 게 한두가지가 아니지만 그나마 계속 개발중이라는게 마음에 위안이 된다!!

일해라 모비어스!
column9:
As of 2014-03-04 (7/10)

It's definitely frustrating... The civilians are all out of their minds, and even heroes run away when they're out of blood.

They fight to the death. Plus, if allies come to support, they might retreat, but they never back down. ㄷㄷ

And because of the lack of explanations, like how to build houses, you'll find yourself getting lost several times...

The enemies are a bit tough. You'll need to be extremely careful in the early stages. As I mentioned before, running away

requires careful control because the brain isn't working properly...

Still, I'm still playing because it's fun to raise heroes and build roofs (!?). LOL

The heroes also have balance issues, and the AI ​​is so severe that it overwhelms everything. ㅜ

They should simply run away when they're about to die, but I've seen them die many times, clearly leaving the path open...

The good news is that they're faster than monsters, so they can run away in an instant. Sigh,,,,

It's frustrating in so many ways, but the fact that development is still ongoing is a comfort to me!!

Get to work, Mobius!

column8:
This deserves deeper analysis that I'm about to give it, but this is one of my favorite "small game" experiences as of late.  When describing Towns to people, I decided it was like telling 10 people how to play minecraft… but without the patterned crafting.  So much of minecraft is lived in telling someone where to put something in a 3x3 grid, but in towns you just say "Go make a wooden sword" and they must goto the wiki on their own and look it up.

Towns places you in the traditional omniscient 3rd person viewing angle that Christ himself enjoys.   You get a randomly generated world with 11 citizens of your "Town".  You drop orders for what to do, and the citizens go do it.  Chop down all these trees I've moused over.  Harvest this apple tree.  Build this wall.  Dig this tunnel.  Oh crap, there's spiders in that tunnel.  No, no don't die… run away… crap.

And then you start a new game and realize there's much more you need to do before you plumb the depths of your little block world.

Towns is an impressively deep game where it does not appear to be on the surface.  I mean that literally as well as figuratively as while at the surface of the game it's about Townsperson happiness management (oh yea, they need to be happy, not over worked and if you can manage that, you'll get more people showing up in town… that's an important mechanic that I didn't think of until now… see… deep) and setting up replenishable resources so everyone doesn't starve and you've got plenty of wood for that epic barbarian castle you just dreamt up.  Dig down only a couple layers and there's combat to be had.  Not super impressive combat, just your people wiggling at the beast until one of them makes this strange death noise.  You can't control the combat at all.  Soldiers can be designated, even set on patrol routes, but they intervene somewhat rarely which makes taking them off labor to just stand around with the best sword you've made so far a little useless.

Again, this game goes so much deeper than I'm giving it credit for in this review… suffice to say, it's quite enjoyable. If you like economy heavy RTS, dwarf-likes or civilization games give it a whirl.  I recommend buy-in at $10, but that's only because it's a little bit of a gamble as to wether you'll like it.  I'd be willing to give this game $25, but that's knowing how much I enjoy it after playing it for hours.

4 Visuals
8 Gameplay
8 Slant

Overall : 67

column8: This game is addictive and has so much potential to be great, but right when you start asking yourself where this game has been all your life, something bugs, or glitches, or you can't do something in the game that seems obvious.  I bought this game in beta and was excited to see how it would come out.  I guess I bought it on the last update, because there have been no more and now I hear that this game has been dropped from production.  I am dissapointed in the devs for throwing out what could be a potential classic, and I'm mad at steam for selling me a game that is still being made, then allowing the game to stop.  I had fun with it and if anything I think the modding community will pick up where the devs left off and give this game the polish it deserves.  I had fun with it and I tend to play it for days straight then don't play it for months then give it a few days again.  I would only reccomend this game if you are into modding, otherwise save your money because it is far from perfect, yet close, but at some times it's not even good, if that makes any sense.

In the state this game is currently in I cannot and will not recommend it to anyone. Check the Official Forums, keep an eye out for developments or any news pertaining to this and if you see nothing new in the coming months (development with the new programmer starts in March, and this guy seems to really want to take the game forward), then I'd turn away and never look back.

Then again, there is a good possibility that should things not go according to plan with this new programmer, that this game will go Open Source anyway, at which point you'll be paying £10 for some DRM and an older version of the game :P

column8:
In a nut shell, Towns didn't make any sense. The game was extremely boring and quite dull. There are many better town builder games out there which are very similar, but better, then Towns. At first glance the game seemed interesting and new, but it turned out to be buggy and unpleasant. It being the one of the first few games to get Greenlighted, Town had a lot of potential. Some of the blame for the flop of Towns goes to the developers. I feel like these Devs almost completely ignore there game and get out around 2 patches per year. For a game that is still this buggy the devs should be working harder. The upside to Towns was it gave me a hour of mediocre fun. Overall, don't buy Towns.

3.9/10 Sloanster Score

This game has more or less been discontinued post v14b. The AI is weak, the game is buggy, and the mechnics are generally lacking. It's unfortunate, because the game had some serious potential. With a better dev behind it, this game could have been absolutely amazing. 

Minecraft, Dwarf Fortress, or the Sim City series would be better choices if you want to play a city building game.

column8:
This game managed to slip through right before the WarZ controversy and the implementation of Early Access.

The original game description from the end of 2012 pointed out that the game had planned features not yet implemented, listing the features available and those that would be available in the future. The current description has no indication that this is an incomplete (and now, defunct) product. I wish I had a screenshot of the original 'About the Game', as the difference in length alone is staggering. 

The game had definite promise, and I was able to spend >25 hours playing around with an older version, but it is absolutely unfinished.

There is no point in purchasing this and even the developers have abandoned the official forums.

Caveat emptor, and such.

column8:
Unfortunately, the developer has apparently "burned out", and is not delivering updates in a timely fashion. It is a small developer, so it's understandable in a sense, but I was hoping for more from this game. At the time of writing, it has been almost 5 months since the last update. 

I have the sense that I threw my money away, but thats a risk with Early Access. But, please, don't waste your money. There are other, better options available, until such a time when this game is actively worked on again.

TLDR - great concept, no updates/support; save your money until it's fully developed.

column8:
I don't have much to say about the gameplay of this game since I gave up on it a couple of months earlier, for it's buggy, controls are tedious, often gives you literally instant death starts, and the graphics are just outright horrendous, reminiscent of cheap point-and-click adventure games. And most importantly - the developers gave up too. It has been at least five full months since the latest update. 

When you flood the market with thousands of greenlit indie, early access games, there're bound to be duds. I understand that this game was still early in development when I got it and things indeed might turn sour since life is so unpredictable, but it's still so frustrating that what you bought at a real game's price suddenly went silent with updates without giving any real explanation beforehand.

For all intents and purposes we could say that this game is effectively dead now. Consider getting Gnomoria if you liked this game's concept, it's currently in active development and even though the dev "team" seems to be just one man, he (or she?) at least gives consistent weekly updates with real content and interacts with players regularly.

column8:
Beware: Developer has ceased all work on the game and will be releasing no more updates. [b]Towns v14b "will be the last build"[/b]
(See [url=http://www.townsgame.com/forums/viewtopic.php?f=8&t=11402] http://www.townsgame.com/forums/viewtopic.php?f=8&t=11402:
[i]
Hello everybody,

I login to the forums to make you all know the current game situation. Have to say that this news won't like the most of you.

Towns v14b will be the last build we will release as SMP. I have no words or response of why I didn't post this months before. The only thing I can say, and I understand you don't care about it, is that I'm burned, really burned about the game and all it involves. I don't have the strenght to continue with it.

At some point we tried to hire someone to continue with the development, we also did some interviews to some nice coders. But at the end I messed that, because I'm so burned to show the code to other guy and explain him how all works. So we cancelled the hiring thing.

Not sure you will agree with me that v14b is a pretty good build, it solves some issues and add some new features. Adding more features won't change the game to a "finished" status, this is a never-ending story. So, I had to stop at some point and consider it finished, and I did that.


So, about the future.... we are still considering what can we do to make you happy, one of the possibilities means to make the code open source, but not sure that is a good option and we are debating what can we do.


I make this post "replyable" so you can post anything you want to, I will read and reply it.

Thanks and sorry.
Xavi[/i]

column8:
To my great disappointment, this "early access alpha"- looks, sounds and plays just about the same as it did over a year ago. 

Sounds - None of the 4-5 sounds adds any value to the experience, what so ever.
Graphics - The graphics are all placeholder at best.
Gameplay - Has potential, but the AI will destroy any play beyond the first hour of play.

Steam should have pulled this title a long time ago as it feels like the developer made it available only to go on a permanent vaccation right after. If you want a town-building-management experience, pick up Dwarf Fortress and make a donation to Bay12Games instead.

column8:
EDIT: Now that there is a new lead developer, Moebius, I believe this review needs some change
EDIT2: Changing to finalize true opinion in light of many shattered agreements


IF (and I mean IF) you like population sim games, and do not mind very long development times and some annoying bugs, than try the demo. Take all reviews with a grain, and test the game yourself. I personally like the game and feel that I have (almost) recieved what I have payed. Opinions will vary, and there are a rising amount of Dwarf Fortress based games out there that are being actively patched and expanded upon, such as Gnomeria and Timber & Stone, that may better suit your needs.

column8:
Don't buy this.  Don't even consider it.

I made the mistake of thinking this was a near-finished product that would be a bit easier to play than Gnome Fortress.  Not as complex but you know- a town simulator of SOME degree.  So I bought it more than a year ago.  The "tutorial" was garbage, as was the interface, the gameplay- basically everything was atrocious to one degree or another.  I promised to never touch it again until it was released in a finished state.

News: IT WILL NEVER BE FINISHED.  Seriously.  Look at http://www.townsgame.com/forums/viewtopic.php?f=8&t=11402.  They're done "updating it."

Basically, this was a Greenlight product that was released before it should have been.  This is the one game that made me completely cautious of ever supporting any Early Access title whatsoever- AND THIS WASN'T EVEN EARLY ACCESS.  IT WAS RELEASED AS A FINISHED PRODUCT.  FOR 15 DOLLARS.

This is a perfect example of what developers have the potential to do with your money.  Promise to make finished products and then back off and reap the rewards without any reprimand.  Sure, it sucks that the developer got burned out but he should have realized what he was doing before he was able to put this on Steam as a completed game.  And shame on Steam for allowing it.

Don't buy it.  Don't touch it.  Just don't.

column8:
Seems fun, was kinda fun for the first 10 hours then you hit a point where you see all that is wrong with this game. It's unfinished, not supported anymore, hardly fixed with mods, redundant and to top it all you can lose all your progress if you arent careful and something goes wrong with AI (which WILL happen at one point or another). To try and make it possible to have a lasting town, you better read the wiki and follow every single tidbit of info. so basically you read a flowchart, apply it and you can see what it has to offer, which by the way once you read the wiki loses most of it's appeal. 

Another one of those could have, should have, would have games that had a lot of hype that failed to deliver. get gnomara instead if you absolutely want a game of this kind on steam (or even better, just stick to dwarf fortress)

Do not buy this game. 

They have promised updates and don't deliver. It is just a really buggy and poorly made game. I have had it for over a year and I couldn't tell you in all that time what improvements they have made if any. The dev's got this ALPHA grade game greenlit as a complete game, made their money, and haven't bothered doing anything since.

I seriously regret giving them any money so save yourself a headache and buy pretty much anything else.

column9:
It's hard to honestly recommend this game. It's not for everyone.
There's a lot to remember, and it can get frustrating when residents don't behave the way you want them to.
But it's fun.
It's a game where you build a town (fortress) in the style of Smicity, assign jobs to your residents, and explore underground dungeons.
That's the kind of game it is.

column8:
Who ever wrote the AI for this game should be arrested for inventing a new kind of torture.

While playing this game, I had the impression that is was "rushed out the door", as numerious bugs, AI problems and design issues were easy to spot.

 When first playing the game, AI problems are not an issue, however after 2 hours or so you will be banging your head off the wall.

Here is a short list of issues I have with this game after 2+ hours of game play:

1: Hunger cycle is too short. This is a game breaking flaw.
2: If you have harvesting set as a higher priority than cooking, your peope will eat the raw food instead of cooking it.
3: If you have item crafting set as a higher priority than chopping, your people will often times not bother to chop trees in tree farm to make stiff with.
4: After a couple hours of game play, your people will only do the top 2 or 3 proprity chores, and ignore everything else.
5: Never cook anything that requires 2 or more different ingrediants. People will often times stoop what they are doing, and the ingrediants they are "holding" dissapears.
6: People often times drop what they are carrying and go do somethign else.
7: People will almost neve use a stock pile or container, reguardless of how close by it is.
8: Some times people stop doing a chore, and what ever they have in their "hands" dissapears.
9: There are no sprite animations for sleeping, sitting down, fighting, chopping, harvesting, or doing chores.
10: The AI is too stupid to eat when hungry most of the time. If cooking and gathering are not your 2 top prioritys, your entire population will eventually starve to death.
11: An infinate loop of "gathering - cooking - eating" happens WAY too often, mostly caused by the short hunger cycle. This happens reguardless how filling the food is.
12: Raw and prepared food containers do not work.

I just bought this game yesterday, and have been spending many hours tryng to figure out how to play the game around all the issues.
 I want my wasted time back.

Upfront, Do not buy!

Development is super slow, the game is in general more annoying then fun, and the dev team is more often MIA from the view point of the customers point of view then actually there.

I am sorry I spent money on this just to have it stall like this in an as of yet incomplete state.

column8:
By general standard this is not a "complete game"

Graphic of this game is....let's say retro.

AI in this game is poor.

Last update v14 was released in September, 2013. V13 was released in May, 2013. The changes that was implemeneted in these patches contains very few contents and minimun bug fixes. It seems like the developers just don't care or hoping that modders can fix everything for them.

LIke every other games in the same genre that's on greenlight, AI in this game is poor.

and there's a breakdown of their "about the game" info page on steam

"The game brings a fresh new take on the city building/management genre by introducing many RPG features. "

Nope, there are many others just like it, the game is heavily inspired by many other game and it offers nothing "fresh" and "new".

"n Towns you manage a settlement on top of an active dungeon. Instead of playing the hero who delves deep into the dungeon, how about playing the town that houses and caters to the hero's needs?"

Heroes don't need jack. All it takes to attract heroes is to boost your population and have an area set up as "tavern". The "tavern" area doesn't have to be enclosed. Meaning that heores will be perfectly fine sleeping on the ground looking at stars just because you painted a 3x3 block purple and called it "inn".

There is no intereaction between your townsfolk and heroes at all. They have very poor AI and die very easily if you are new to the game. Gearing up these heroes is not an easy process and sometimes random. You need to put the items on their path or "hangout" area and hope that they pick up the gear you want them to wear. 

"Both the RPG and strategic aspects will be fleshed out over a series of sprawling dungeons."

The only RPG elements involved in the dungeons is "there are mobs, they drop loot". The only strategic aspect of the game is "pray to the gods that when you dig down, you don't dig directly into a group of mobs because your townsfolk are dumb and they will not flee" and "dig open dungeon walls bit by bit and hope your townsfolk don't try to engage the mobs"

There is minimun strategy and minimun RPG elements in this game. Townsfolk has a hunger bar, a sleep bar and a happiness bar and that's it. There is no "leveling" for your townsfolk and leveling for heores is meaningless.

"Attract travelling heroes that will independently explore the dungeons below, fight off monsters, gain levels, special skills and collect the best loot they can find in order to clear the land of all evil!"

Like stated above, there is no interactions between you and the heroes. 

About the loots, here's the funny part. Once you clear a dungeon, it's best not to collect loot from the dungeon because there's a billion of trash loot lying on the ground. Heroes will pick up gears when they feel like it. It's best to leave those in the dungeon.

The best loot is often not dropped in the dungeon. Once you have a market set up, travelling merchants will come and they will randomly sell you the best gear in the game. So in order to get the best loot in game, you priorites a market over anything else. Regardless your progression in the game, you will be able to buy best gears purely based on luck.

"Craft unique weapons, trade with exotic items, obtain randomized loot, set up devious death traps and build a settlement capable of holding back the forces that come up from the depths!"

Mobs in the dungeon will come to your town only when a hero engages them with low health and decides to run away. Those mobs will not stop chasing the fleeing hero until one of them is dead. This normally leads to a few townies dying because of the poorly designed AI. 

There is nothing unique about the weapon and item designs. They are very generic items. I wouldn't describe loots to be "randomized". 90% of them are trash loots and 99% of them are just junk on the ground waiting to be sold when a merchant arrives (if that merchant has enough money and willing to buy these crap. normally they just don't want them at all).

In summary, this game is not worth its asking price. Yes, it's about the price of a very fancy subway sandwitch in Canada but I assure you that you will get more satisfaction out of that sandwitch than this game. If you are desprately looking for a game like this, wait for it to go on sale and do not expect any updates because it's not very likely. 

There is a modding scene for this game. It's small and I suggest you to go to their forum and check out more information there. Simply google "towns" and you'll be able to access their website and forum. 

Thank you.

Thank you.

column8:
The concept of this game is neat, but it is lacking a lot. I've played it a while ago, and I dare say it was a bit better back then than it is now. Development seems to be quite stagnant here. At the end of this review you'll read what I really recommend instead.

The tutorials are, to say the least, quite braindead. They could've made it more interactive, but as it is now it's quite dull. Some details seems to be badly written as I didn't always get the desired results.

The military in the game is kind of a joke. If I see a spider or any other enemy, why oh why can't I just go rightclick it and tell the military to go attack it? Or at least something that enables me to make more use of the military than 'patrol there' and hope that they actually will engage the enemy on their patrol routes.

The actual mining is quite non-intuitive. Somehow I wasn't able to mine certain areas until I moved up/down. It's rather hard to see what level you are at currently, and there are no size indicators in the area you're about to mark to be mined. And you can build a roof but somehow I have not managed to build a roof on top of my shacks. I might give that a try again another time, but the game seems so pointless that it isn't really motivating to.

You have absolutely no connection with those little guys you're ordering around. You can see some basic stats, but all those little peoples aren't really special. It's lacking a certain something there, and I can't quite place my finger on it. Let's just say that you don't really care who they are, as long as they get the jobs done already. There's no feel of a story attached to it.

Assigning jobs and assigning productions/stockpiles is quite a chore. So much a chore that you just leave everything up to the defaults. A quick overview is rather impossible. Sure, they do have a list of civilians, and a stockpile list. But instead of having it present a clear overview, it's rather a messy job. I think they focused way too much on iconized displays with tiny numbers inside. In cases like this, a table-format would probably make more sense. We want to know some nice numbers and some other stats, not how pretty they look in a circle with one tiny number in there.

Speaking about iconized displays.. the GUI is very clunky. It is definitely not polished and is just bare bones style. Nothing fancy about it and there are options lacking. The build icons are non-intuitive. If you want to go back a level in the menu, the 'go back' arrow is in a different location every level. So you can't just 'click click click' fast to get to the root level. No, you have to check every time you went back one level in the menu where the back button is at now. Nothing has been streamlined in this game.

If you are charmed by this kind of game, I can recommend a different one instead which is still in active development and is rather more promising. Take it from me, you want to try [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/224500]Gnomoria[/url]. It might be in Early Access, but I've been playing it for a while (on Desura and now also on Steam), and it is way more finished than this Towns ever will be.

column8:
Not quite as riddled with bugs as some of the reviews would have you believe. Nevertheless, later on in the game as your population really grows and you start wanting to build real structures it gets... frustrating. I'm a really patient guy, but this game nearly had me swearing at the screen a few times.

And as a previous reviewer stated, the game doesn't really explain anything... at all. I had to do some mad googling just to figure out some of the less obvious key mechanics.

column8: I love this game.  I love what this game could be.  I think the developer has unfortunately shipped an early release product, taken some money, and bounced.  The update cycle is beyond what's expected, and there are existing crash bugs that make the game nearly unplayable.  I would recommend it, but I can't.  I do play it a lot, but be warned.  It seems very shady.  One of the shadiest early access titles i've played.

column8:
Unfinished game that somehow jumped from "alpha" to a finished game in the span of a week. At launch day, the game had such devastating bugs that made it mostly unplayable, and only some of those fatal bugs have been fixed in the year after the launch. 

There isn't really much actual gameplay involved, that portion of the game is out of balance and broken. Most of the things in-game don't actually do anything, they're just decoration and "make believe". Once you get food production running (and half of that is broken due to new patches implementing flawed animal feeding system etc), there's no longer anything interesting to see. Unless you like wasting your time building pointless things. I suppose some people do like that, but I don't. I would've actually liked to see some of that "city management" in the game instead.

column8:
Despite all the flaws you can find on game like that, I've spent more than enough time to say that it worhs the little money you can spend on it.
Of course it's infuriating to see the peons running right in the middle of a pack of monsters without weapons with no self-preservation whatsoever, of course it's stupid to see a peon starving because he has started a long task when he was already hungry. Not mentionning the heroes who flee faster than the light and bring home monsters that will decimate your population. And I forgot some...
But still, how fun this game is, you have a sim game, where you can grow a whole village with many aspects (food, buildings, construction, armors & weapons, trading...) and you have a dungeon that reveals itself and brings a lot to your experience.

column8: While the concept is interesting, the execution is shoddy at best. On top of that, its clear the team making it is in way over their head and, probably, completely sick of it. This meas little real fixes or updates. Even the fixes they do release are bandaids which don't really solve the underlying design flaws. It could've been grand, really, but it just falls flat on its face instead.

column8:
I've got to say I'm glad I got it when it was on sale. It's definitely more of a $5 game, not a $15 one. If you find this game at $5 or less, then think about it, but any more than that and you might want to find something that got finished. This review is based off of my experience and the regular price though, so overall I don't recommend it. There's no way there isn't better games out there than this.

Let me start with what I found to be good about the game though, since I did technically like it. I never played this Gnomoria that everyone else is mentioning, and with little function in Minecraft for watching a village come to life even with mods, I found it to be a great idea. Even though it was immediately obvious from opening the game that it was far from finished I found myself enjoying finding different combinations and ways of getting my limited villagers to survive.

Secondly, the zoning. By assigning a zone type to an area the area gains a particular function, while losing other functions. This makes building a city kind of cool because the buildings one makes will actually function the way that they've zoned it to. Added to the fact that, if one could figure out the menus easily, one could get the villagers to use and upkeep these zones automatically, without any help from the player. 

Then there's just the world in general. Although the maps are small, they generate well, and they're fun and easy to shape. If a player shows enough patience, it actually is possible to build the kinds of places they show in the promotional material and screenshots.

The last thing I thought was really cool was being able to put writing on tombstones and books and things. I can go through my village and remind myself of the events that passed. Who died, who did the best, or helped the most – it felt like making a civilization, even though it was really just a town at best. Epic legacies in a tiny town.

Now, the wonderful negatives that ruined it. Unfortunately there are a lot of these, so I'll put a chunk of them in point form;
*Odd menu style. That took a while to get used too, and I feel like things could be implemented better.
*Moving items is a hassle, or just plain confusing.
*Can't place enough text in books, graves, signs, etc, and can't use characters like “/”, making labels and text look flat and odd, like they were written by some 10 year old that was too lazy to use any punctuation. Breaks immersion. 
*The use of scaffold isn't clearly stated to be useful, and so it can be difficult to find out about it and how to use it properly to build better buildings. There isn't a lot of direct help on the internet either, so simply building can be a hassle. Also, making second floors is too tricky.
*Extremely limited character sprites. Everyone will have too many clones for you to care about them. They also all have weird french-sounding names, even if playing the English version, and though unimportant, feels like it takes away from immersion into the game.
*The armour doesn't fit on the sprites properly. Sometimes this is funny, but it just isn't proper for a game that costs $15.
*The first floor dungeons, though easy to pass, are too expansive and too full of monsters. There's no easing into it at all, making the game feel less thought-out and more slapped together. Also an immersion breaker.
*Next to no updates. These people probably don't care anymore, and it's showing. They don't update anywhere near as much as they should, and some of the bugs in the game could really use some fixes.
*The bugs. Seriously, the game is definitely not a finished product. Amusing, but certainly not finished.

And lastly, though kind of silly, what I found to be the game-breaker; 
The weapons you make, buy, and find are cool and all, but it isn't hard for some "hero" to waltz by and take all your good stuff, leaving your citizens and soldiers pretty close to defenceless. Some heroes. I worked hard on that stuff. “That hat was for the blacksmith!” and “she needed that spear to save her life!” might become alarmingly common frustrations.

So yeah. Ends up under $5? It'll amuse you long enough. $15? It's cute, but it ain't that cute, just go back to your Minecraft mods and this "Gnomoria" everyone else is talking about.

column8:
I was initially hopeful for this game. It looked super interesting and I thought why not. So a few dollars later I had a shiney top-down minecraft. Similarly powered by java (woo hoo).

Sadly the game really does fall quite short of expectation.
The menus are hard to navigate. There is no tutorial to speak of. You can instruct your citizens to build things, but if you do not have the supplies to make it, instead of telling you why you can't, it will sit, forever until you produce the needed materials or manually cancel the order. You cannot change the camera angle (which gets really aggravating). The perspective makes it really difficult build a lot of the structures shown on the store page. There is exactly one music track that will drive you absolutly crazy after a few hours of playing. Your citizens are difficult to direct. For example if you task them with digging a hole. if they find water, and proceed to drown in that water. ALL your assigned citizens will continue to drown themselves until you cancel the order, which is really hard to do, when it takes 5 seconds a person to drown and about 2 minutes for you to navigate to the cancel order screen, get to the right layer, and cancel the order. 

There is some good however. Once you look up on the wiki how to pretty much play the game, it becomes more of a meditative visual rather than an actual game. I stopped at about 40 citizens and just let them do their thing. They were feeding and growing and happy. They did not require any input from me. I watched them tear through dungeons and make food, build things. It was nice 
You can also build some pretty neat structures if you have the patience for it. But it will drive you crazy at first due to the limited visual angles .

I will recommend this game IF you buy it on sale. However I would most assuredly not pay full price for it.

column8: Game is a great survivial game, it puts all the surviving factors together, starvation, wild life, etc, aswell with traits that took place back then and even today, including Rivalry, Citizenship, and currency. Although it has good factors, it has some bad ones too.  The game seems to bore you a bit too easily, and the randomly generated spawns can quite frequently put you right on top of a biom with hostile natural life. I have 25 hours on it, and i've had it for nearly a year. In my 25 hours of gameplay, i've never figured out how to get Iron, and make needed tools. I try to build a town, but every time I try to, my citizens starve to death, or Ghosts kill them. To fix this, I focused a TON more on food, but that didn't stop the Ghost of Heroes past's from attacking and slaughtering all my people. This game does have alot of Pros compared to Cons though, and i highly reccomend it    to any survival type people out there who love to play a survivial, and always ask "Can i build a city on it?" type questions. I would rate it a 8/10 if it was up to me. Graphics might be a bit dissapointing, but if you don't only look at games for their graphics, and just want the fun, this is a good game. I never noticed many bugs, maybe a few, and I seen the comments.

While a good concept for a game, Towns is too incomplete to be worth the price.
