column8:
**** August 2015 Update ****

Almost a year after being told the game development was suspended for "home renovations", there has been no word from the developers and the forums continue to stay without complaint (due to moderator Yetichow not allowing posts that factually state the game's status or factually state why the game is unfinished/needs improvement/general feedback).

So, on that note, please make sure you avoid the game (unless you want to waste your money).  Read the REVIEWS of the game and disregard the forums (since Yetichow had decided to scrub them clean and ban any who disagree).   

Congratulations, Towns.  You made it into the Steam group, "ScamReport".  You should be proud...

(/sarcasm)

****March 2015 Update****

I wouldn't bother checking the forums for any kind of clarity.  The current moderator bans anyone who criticizes the game, despite there being valid reasons to criticize.  Only the positive forum posts don't get edited or deleted.  Anyone trying to warn potential buyers on the actual status of the game, gets banned.

We were told that development had picked up again (for the fourth time of it being active and then subsequently stopped) but after only a month-ish, the current moderator stated the developer was having house renovations done and did not have regular internet access.  That was in September of 2014. 

Make your own judgement call from that...

---------------------------------
**** Initial Review ****

Voted to Greenlight the game WAY back and upon it's release on Steam, I was excited to buy it.  

Imagine my shock when the game I loaded up was nothing more than a poorly coded alpha with a crap tutorial and a laundry list of game-breaking bugs.

According to the Devs, the game was fulling finished and wasn't in alpha/beta/whatever.  Fully finished. Fully playable.  With continued updates scheduled!  

Please note:  There was no demo released at the time.  NOWHERE on the page did it state that the game was feature incomplete (which is STILL is).  And then customers started voicing their concerns.  They (myself included) were met with insults from the PR/Devs directly (anyone remember TommyKent's abrasion?).  We were called stupid for not "understanding" how these type of games are to played.   That "if we just gave it time" we'd figure it all out.

Screw that.

Even over a year later, the game has only had a handful of crappy updates - most not even addressing major issues.  We've been told the entire run of excuses from health problems, to vacations, to quitting programmers (who left to work on other projects! AWESOME!)

Avoid this like the plague.  It was a cash grab.  They're millionaires now (not exaggerating) and they're never coming back to save this wreck of a game.  

Matter of fact, avoid anything SMP does.  I will be.

column8: I honestly can't say I'd recommend this game at any price point.  There are quite a few other games out there that fill the same niche and many more currently in development, e.g. Banished and Stonehearth, and sadly actually have active development staff.  Yes that is currently a problem for this game.  If like me you picked up this game back when it was first greenlit only to assume that it would actually get patched and improved over time I feel your pain.  If you're looking at reviews to decide whether it's worth your money you can get a lot more enjoyment out of other games at any price point and a lot less frustration.  You can mod the heck out of the game manually to make it somewhat passible to get past some of the more glaring development omissions but it only gets you so far.  I can't say I've finished a single session with this game feeling happy about spending the time there.  You want fun, look elsewhere.

column8:
Od czasu do czasu, nie za często, ale trafiają się gry wyjątkowe. Niekoniecznie muszą to być hity albo produkcje dobre, gdyż swoją wyjątkowość potrafią okazywać na wiele różnych sposób, nawet w byciu zupełnie beznadziejnymi. Towns jest grą nietypową, jednak tak jak w przypadku innych – nie mogę się zdecydować, czy jej specyfika to coś dobrego, czy nie.

 

Jedenastu nas było

Gra jest trudna, skomplikowana i zagmatwana tak bardzo, że po długich godzinach nie odkryłem nawet połowy możliwości, jakie produkcja ta przedstawia. Na samouczek nie ma co liczyć – pokaże nam główne założenia, jednak wytłumaczy może z pięć opcji występujących w Towns na setki, które rzeczywiście powinny zostać wyjaśnione. 
Zaczynamy na kwadratowej mapie, obfitującej w rośliny, surowce i zwierzęta. Wszystko obserwujemy z rzutu izometrycznego, co przywodzi oczywiście na myśl wszelkie gry RTS. Po mapce kręci się jedenastu obywateli, którzy mają swoje imiona, potrzeby określone w współczynniku „szczęścia” i „głodu” oraz wyświetlone aktualne zadanie. Naszym celem jest zbudować wszystko, aby zapewnić im przetrwanie i satysfakcję z życia, nie wiedząc do czego służy połowa przycisków i jak działa większość stref. To właśnie na nich – na strefach – opiera się większa część systemu rządzącego grą. Znajdziemy wśród nich stolarza, kamieniarza, kuźnię, jadalnię, piekarnię, kwatery osobiste, szpital i wiele innych. Do niektórych z nich dostawić trzeba stoły z miejscem pracy, aby obywatele mogli produkować coraz to lepsze meble, narzędzia, jedzenie, itd. Oczywiście, na wszystko trzeba wytrzasnąć surowce, do których dostęp jest w miarę prosty. Drzewa rosną dosyć gęsto, kamienia również jest pod dostatkiem – a są to dwa najważniejsze i podstawowe surowce, których zabraknąć nigdy nie powinno. Drzewa oczywiście można zasadzić, co ułatwia znacząco dostęp do drewna, jest szansa też obsiać pola pszenicą, czy zrobić sobie sad z jabłoniami i gruszami. 

 

Nieskończone możliwości

Budować możemy, co dusza zapragnie. Jeśli tylko odkryjemy sposób, w jaki Towns działa, stworzyć możemy przepiękne miasta, zamki, jaskinie czy wioski, zgodnie z naszą wyobraźnią. Dzięki strefom, mieszkańcy będą spać tam, gdzie chcemy. Jeść, gdzie im pozwolimy i tak dalej. Widziałem zapierające dech w piersi budowle, choć sam nie mam pojęcia, jak osiągnąć choćby połowę z tego, gdyż moje podejścia zazwyczaj kończyły się wymarciem społeczności, zanim zdążyła osiągać cokolwiek. Działo się tak, gdyż nie miałem nieograniczonej kontroli nad moimi obywatelami – gdy kazałem im sadzić drzewa, szukali sadzonek nawet po drugiej stronie mapy, gdzie grasowały wrogo nastawione żaby z włóczniami. Nie było ocalałych…
Choć można powołać wojsko do życia, wyznaczyć im patrole lub kazać bronić wioski, to moi obrońcy zazwyczaj dochodzili do jaskini pełnej pająków, gdy zwłoki moich górników zaścielały już podłoże. Nie zostało wyjaśnione jak stworzyć można bohatera, których lista wyświetlana jest obok wojska. Nie wiadomo do końca jak działa szpital (choć miałem wszystkie możliwe w nim przedmioty, potrzebne w szpitalu i łóżko, to nikt z rannych nie udał się tam), w związku z czym szybko traciłem ludność. Jak się pewnie domyślacie, wskazówki, czy można ich rozmnożyć w jakiś sposób – również nie było. A gdy zostaje nam pięciu mieszkańców, cała praca idzie w ślimaczym tempie i grać się po prostu dalej nie chce.
Pikseloza 

Oprawa graficzna, która w charakterystyczny sposób zapisała się w dziale gier Indie, jest brzydka. Pikseloza, przywodząca na myśl jedne z pierwszych gier strategicznych. Nie ma co liczyć na skomplikowane animacje, czy na oszałamiające widoki – wszystko, czego uświadczymy, to uproszczone kwadraciki, zaścielające cały świat Towns. Ma to oczywiście swój urok, wiele ludzi uwielbia takie podejście do grafiki i nie ona jest tutaj najważniejsza. Dźwięki również są starodawne, więc i tutaj nie ma co liczyć na jakieś wyjątkowe i zachwycające nutki. W kółko leci ta sama muzyka, jest jeden dźwięk do ścinania drzewa, jeden do kopania i tak dalej. Choć grafika nie przeszkadza w grze, to jednostajna muzyka potrafi doprowadzić człowieka do szału, więc często albo wyłączałem głośniki (nic nie traciłem w ten sposób, gdyż reszta odgłosów również potrafi po czasie zirytować) albo zwyczajnie odpalałem własną ścieżkę dźwiękową w tle.

 

Gra wyjątkowa

Staję w taki oto sposób przed oceną całej gry i dalej nie wiem, co o niej myśleć i jak podsumować. Choć Townszachwyciło mnie swoją złożonością i mnogością możliwości, które pozwalają na zbudowanie społeczności swoich marzeń, na wzniesienie zamczysk, które będą tętnić życiem i pracą, to zarazem ta złożoność przytłoczyła mnie i sprawiła, że nie wiedziałem od czego zacząć i jak do tematu tak naprawdę podejść. 
Wszystkiemu winny jest samouczek, który potraktowany został po macoszemu. Może było to specjalne zamierzenie twórców, aby użytkownicy doszli do tego, jak się gra na metodzie prób i błędów, jednak jakiekolwiek nie były ich plany – takie rozwiązanie po prostu jest złe i psuje przyjemność z rozgrywki. Zdaję sobie sprawę, że Minecraft również nie miał najmniejszego wprowadzenia, jednak tam wszystko jest jakieś sensowne i oczywiste, pierwsze kroki postawić można bez zaglądania na wiki. Towns niestety jest bardziej skomplikowane i nie narzuca się w sposób oczywisty, co z tym wszystkim zrobić. 

 

Prawdziwy fan oczywiście znajdzie setki samouczków i wciągnie się dużo, dużo głębiej i będzie w stanie wyeksploatować maksimum z gry, ja jednak oceniam samą produkcję, nie fanowskie poradniki.
Dobrze więc, nie przeciągając już dłużej – jaki jest mój werdykt? Połączenie Minecrafta z The Settlers (również nie możemy bezpośrednio kontrolować swoich jednostek, tylko wydawać polecenia, które wykonają, jak będzie im się chciało – może to bardziej podobne akurat do Majesty?) jest zaiste grą wyjątkową, która zasługuje na uznanie za możliwości, jakie daje w ręce graczom. Jednak, póki nie wyjdzie do niej kilka większych patchy, usprawniających choćby wprowadzenie – dostaje silne siedem! Twórcy natomiast zapowiadają ciągłą pracę nad swoim dziełem, więc spodziewać się możemy wielu łatek, które zapewne wzniosłyby ocenę – może nawet o dwa oczka w górę.
Plusy
•	Bardzo rozbudowana
•	Niemal nieskończone możliwości budowy
Minusy
•	Beznadziejny samouczek
•	Irytująca muzyka
column9:
Every now and then, not very often, exceptional games come along. These don't necessarily have to be hits or good productions, as they can express their uniqueness in many different ways, even down to being completely hopeless. Towns is an unusual game, but like many others, I can't decide whether its specificity is a good thing or not.

Eleven of Us

The game is difficult, complex, and confusing, so much so that after hours of playing, I haven't explored even half of the possibilities it offers. Don't count on a tutorial – it will only show you the main concepts, but it will explain maybe five of the hundreds of options in Towns that really need to be explained.

We start on a square map, abundant with plants, resources, and animals. Everything is observed from an isometric perspective, reminiscent of all RTS games. Eleven citizens roam the map, each with their own names, needs defined by their "happiness" and "hunger" stats, and a displayed task. Our goal is to build everything we can to ensure their survival and a fulfilling life, without even knowing what half the buttons are for or how most zones work. It is these zones – the zones – that form the basis of the game's system. Among them, we'll find a carpenter, a stonemason, a forge, a dining room, a bakery, personal quarters, a hospital, and many others. Some of these zones require workbenches so that the citizens can produce increasingly better furniture, tools, food, and so on. Of course, all of these require resources, which are relatively easy to access. Trees grow quite densely, and stone is also plentiful – these are the two most important and basic resources that should never be in short supply. Trees can, of course, be planted, significantly improving access to wood. There's also the opportunity to sow fields with wheat or create an orchard with apple and pear trees.

Endless Possibilities

We can build whatever our hearts desire. Once we figure out how Towns works, we can create beautiful cities, castles, caves, and villages, just as we imagine. Thanks to zones, citizens can sleep where we want, eat where we let them, and so on. I've seen breathtaking structures, though I have no idea how to achieve even half of them, as my attempts usually ended with the community dying out before it could achieve anything. This happened because I didn't have unlimited control over my citizens – when I told them to plant trees, they searched for seedlings even on the other side of the map, where hostile frogs with spears prowled. There were no survivors…
Although you can raise an army, assign them patrols, or order them to defend the village, my defenders usually reached a cave full of spiders just as the corpses of my miners littered the ground. There was no explanation for how to create a hero, whose list is displayed next to the army. It's unclear exactly how the hospital works (even though I had all the necessary items and a bed, none of the injured went there), so I was rapidly losing population. As you can probably guess, there was also no hint of how to reproduce them. And when you're down to five residents, work moves at a snail's pace, and you simply don't want to continue playing.

Pixelosis

The graphics, which have become a hallmark of indie games, are ugly. Pixelation, reminiscent of some of the first strategy games. Don't expect complex animations or stunning vistas – all you'll see are simplified squares dotting the entire world of Towns. This, of course, has its charm; many people love this approach to graphics, and it's not the most important thing here. The sounds are also old-fashioned, so don't expect any unique or captivating musical notes here either. The same music plays over and over again: there's one sound for chopping down a tree, another for digging, and so on. While the graphics don't detract from the game, the monotonous music can drive you crazy, so I often either turned off the speakers (I didn't miss anything by doing so, as the other sounds can also become irritating after a while) or simply played my own soundtrack in the background.

Exceptional Game

I'm now faced with this assessment of the entire game, and I still don't know what to think or how to summarize it. While Townszach captivated me with its complexity and the multitude of possibilities that allow you to build the community of your dreams, to build castles that will be bustling with life and activity, this complexity also overwhelmed me, leaving me unsure where to begin or how to truly approach the topic.

The tutorial, which was treated so poorly, is to blame for everything. Perhaps this was the developers' intention, allowing users to figure out how to play through trial and error, but whatever their plans, such a solution is simply wrong and spoils the fun of the game. I realize that Minecraft didn't have the slightest introduction either, but everything there is sensible and obvious; you can take the first steps without consulting the wiki. Unfortunately, Towns is more complex and doesn't offer a clear explanation of what to do with it all.

A true fan will, of course, find hundreds of tutorials and delve much deeper, being able to maximize the game's potential. However, I'm judging the game itself, not the fan-made guides.
Okay, so without further ado, what's my verdict? The combination of Minecraft and The Settlers (you can't directly control your units, only issue commands, and they'll execute them as they please—maybe it's more like Majesty?) is truly a unique game that deserves recognition for the possibilities it offers players. However, until a few major patches are released, improving even the introduction, it gets a strong seven! The developers have announced continued work on their work, so we can expect many patches, which would likely improve the rating – perhaps even by two points.

Pros
• Very extensive
• Nearly endless building options
Cons
• Awful tutorial
• Annoying music

column8:
This game is an early alpha, and has been since release.  There are rarely updates.  Basically, this game's creators were greenlit, made a boatload of money through promising to update their game regularly and telling everyone that it is an early alpha, then walked away with their cash and never looked back.

Do not purchase this game.  There are much better games out there, trust me.

Towns does have its errors and faults.
However, in my opinion there is no doubt that the game is still very fun and still gives you near limmitless creative possibilities mixed with a challenging RPG element that still takes a while to explore.
Overall, buy this game if:
A) You are open minded and don't mind how a game works if it's fun or
B) You have £10 to burn (preferably use option A)
Otherwise, you'll just end up like those dissapointed purchasers bellow me :'(

column8:
Despite the numerous negative reviews, Towns is a cheap game that I've gotten hours and hours of fun out of. The graphics are adorable, and I loved the customizability with community mods to give it new heroes, weapon types, etc. If you enjoy micromanaging, you'll love the crud out of this title, where you can suit up every one of your villagers, give them names, assign them tasks. The building is quite fun too.

Many thumbs up for Towns!

column9: In Towns, you command a group of settlers in a sandbox world. Despite the RPG elements, which are plentiful and fit perfectly into the building/sandbox setting, the game is rather calm and relaxed. The ability to create and use mods makes it adaptable to all players.

column8:
I tried to give this game a fair shake, but I've found it too daunting to really get in too far. The menus are incomprehensible, I can rarely figure out what the heck I'm looking at. The tutorial confused me more than it helped, and I honestly have trouble even building a few starter buildings due to the horrific interface and my villagers running around not doing what I expected them to be doing. 

Maybe there's a great game here if you can figure out what to do and play it for more than an hour or so, but I wasn't able to find it.

column8:
Towns is an addictive little game. Sure, it's not finished yet, but if you're one of those who enjoy building stuff and watching your world grow, it can be fun. I find it amusing that of all the games I have, this indie title is the one that has clocked the most hours for me.

I hope that the developers pick up the development pace and finish it, and if there is a feature I would like see implemented, it would be the possibility of manually equipping visiting heroes with gear. They tend to arrive with primitive equipment and forcing them to replace it is so much work that I have not even bothered. The result is a dungeon cluttered by the remains of heroes who blithely bumbled past that Armor of Immortality or Longsword of Instant Death you lovingly crafted for them. Serves them right, I suppose.

column8:
RTSライクのサンドボックスゲーム　プレイヤーは村人を直接操作することはできない。
様々な「命令」を与えて、自給自足生活をさせるゲーム。ポピュラス的な感じで住民を導いて色々創るのが主なコンテンツ。

ある目的に沿ってRPしたり、お気に入りのヒーローを育てたり、巨大建築したり遊び方はマイクラやTerrariaみたいな砂場ゲーより多彩
実はMODもそこそこ上がってる　でも日本語フォーラム&wikiが死んでるから、ある程度は自力で翻訳していかないとキツイかも？

エンドコンテンツが現状無いので 飽きたらゲームクリア
column9:
This RTS-like sandbox game doesn't allow players to directly control villagers.
It's a game where you give various "commands" and lead a self-sufficient life. The main content involves guiding your villagers and creating various things, similar to Populous.

Players can roleplay according to a certain objective, develop their favorite heroes, and build large structures, offering more gameplay than sandbox games like Minecraft or Terraria.
There are actually quite a few mods available, but the Japanese forum and wiki are dead, so you might need to translate them yourself.

There's currently no endgame, so you can just finish the game when you get bored.

column8:
Seemly unfinished feel to this game. It is very difficult to start off and even in 30 hours, I still cannot build a perfect town without food problems every so often. 

The difficulty of this game is what makes me keep playing it. It isn't difficult enough to make me want to stop playing it forever, and the challenege is rewarded by creating a productive civilization. 

The soundtrack could use more than 1 track that loops continously, but it doesn't get annoying that fast to warrant muting it. 

I've played Gnomeria for about 8-10 hours and can say that I prefer this over that game. The soundtrack may not be even close to Gnomeria, but the gameplay isn't as annoying and the townspeople of Gnomeria never seem to listen as the responsibilities menu glitches out every 30 minutes.

6.5/10 Would reccommend buying at a sale.

column8:
I really loved this game to start. I wanted it to be great, but between bugs, long periods with no updates or news from the developers, and a dying community (for good reason) I have to give up hope.

This game was a great idea that was poorly done and evenly more poorly managed. At this point the game is unplayable for me and many others I talked to. The last update was months ago, and it was more broken than anything to date.

Remember, this is still an alpha game, it can be fixed and I would love to change my review, however I don't want others on the steam community buying into a game that seems so hopeless.

column8:
This game was Super fun, Addicting, and Great for a graphical version of Dwarven Fortress Lite. 

However I can NOT reccomend this game no matter how many hours I've put into it. In fact I will be requesting a refund from steam after this review. This is a green lit alpha game. Most of us bought it before even then. It had LOADS of potential. 
Sadly here is why I say don't buy it. 

THE DEV'S HAVE ABANDONED THIS GAME! After making loads of money off the prospect of a finished title. The programer has gone off to "Work on another title they are making." Well thanks for telling me not to buy that one either. Finish what you start. That is the mantra that should be followed. There are Many other games that are better. However this game had soul... until it was abandoned. They aren't going to release it a freeware either. "Because he may come back to it." Sorry I don't think people would have supported NOTCH if he stopped in the  middle of minecraft.  

Currently they are looking for another "Java Programmer" but they've been looking for 3 months now. No telling how long before they told us. No I WILL NOT support a game that is abandoned half way through production.

When I first bought Towns from their website I thought I was getting into an early production of a great game. Even though promised updates kept me optimistic I have since fallen from that high for this game. Now it is full of bugs, new stuff that causes more bugs, and absolutely no community updates on how or where the game is going next. If developers are going to give up on a game because it isnt worth it anymore, then drop it and stop "earning" profit from broken software.

*shorter review*

This game is a great example of lazy developers

This game offers hours of gameplay (aslong as you dont speed throught it). I've been playing it for a while and im not even half way through the doungeons. column8: I wanted to like this game. I really, really did. I played this for days, almost obsessively. It almost seemed like it was starting to get better, after many hours of having it constantly crash on me, I got into the habit of saving compulsively. After losing progress, hours upon hours of progress I'd start anew, stronger, faster, better prepared. But I don't think it was ever as fun as it seemed at the time. It was horribly tedious. I often had another game going on another system at the same time, as I waited for things to happen in the background. That's not a game. That's a simulation. And if I wanted to play a simulation, I'd run one with more polish and more things that were interesting to watch. This has neither. I'm certain there's something similar, better, out there. Find it. Play that instead. Don't waste your time like I did.

column8:
Hello,

First of all, I would like to point out that this game is not anywhere near a finished, polished product. It has bugs. It has some issues. It lacks some fundamentals of the genre. This should have been released as an early access game, and it is my firm believe that Steam should take matters into their own hands to put it there. This game may or may not ever be finished; updates are quite slow comming.

If you can look past this, you will find an entertaining game. The modding community helps to make it even more so. If you are a fan of this genre of games, I would whole heartedly recommend it to someone after this disclaimer, but only after they've bought and played "Gnomoria".

column8: This game is kind of hard to get into. The tutorials are really vague and almost useless, and most of the stuff you just need to figure out. column8:
[b]FREEZE![/b] Before you even think about buying this game, let me ask you a few questions. 

Do you like unfinished games that try to pass themselves off as "finished"? Hopefully not.
Do you like extremely buggy and unplayable games that make vanilla Bethesda games pale in comparison? You really shouldn't!
And finally, do you like wasting money on a game that promised continual updates? Of course not!

"Towns" is the epitome of unrealized potential. Lazy developers took what would have been a decent time-wasting game and somehow managed to turn it into a mess. This pile of slop caused a backlash worthy of a Penny Arcade article.

http://www.penny-arcade.com/report/article/the-perils-of-greenlight-how-towns-enraged-a-community-by-selling-a-game-th

 It was published in 2012 and still rings true over a year later.

In short, please [b]DO NOT[/b] buy this game ever. Ever. Under any circumstances. Thank you for your time.

column8:
I caught it on sale for real cheap.  At first I thought I wasted money on this game and It took awhile, but I am really into it now.  The paths to success are not obvious and it can appear extremely simplistic at first but there is a much deeper game to be found.  Even in the current state of the game you can build a fully functioning economy.  Its kind of like playing with legos, except you have to keep your people alive and obvious oversights can lead to starvation or running into momsters that will happily eat them for dinner.

It is not for everyone, the basic functions are all there.  There are some features half implemented but the modding community seems to have taken care fo the holes (I am not currently using any mods).  I have no doubt the finish product would keep me playing even longer than i already have... but it will require some patience for this game to get there... if it ever does...  If all the the above issues dont turn you off and you want to Alpha test the foundations of what could be an amazing game I'd buy it.  Like I said before you can build a functioning town. However,  DO NOT EXPECT A FINISH PRODUCT YOU WILL BE DISSAPOINTED.

column8:
If you want a game that will take days, not hours out of your time, go for this.  Its one of the better games to come out of the dwarf fortress inspired games.  

Its draw backs are that you either find a game that works for you straight away or one that instantly crumbles away.  And once your town starts going under... It really clings by a thread of hope... Ouch.  >_<

Edit:
So I'm going to change my review to negative.  s the game stands its okay, but due to the development behind it, I do not recommend supporting the devs.

Its draw backs are that you either find a game that works for you straight away or one that instantly crumbles away.  And once your town starts going under... It really clings by a thread of hope... Ouch.  >_<

Edit:
So I'm going to change my review to negative.  s the game stands its okay, but due to the development behind it, I do not recommend supporting the devs.

column8:
From initial release the dev team of this game has mislead customers on Steam.  Initally it was released as a complete and playable version.  However, it hadn't hit it's full version number in beta yet.  The UI was terribly implemented, the pathing, AI, inclusion of god hand mechanics to work around lazy coding problems, and a plethora of truly unproffessional issues plagued the game.  To top it all off, there wasn't a patch for almost 4 months after release.  Last December the Dev threatened to quit the game and then quickly changed his mind during the holiday sale.  Since that initial release there has only been 5 patches of minimal consequence to ongoing issues of the game - in fact trying to add features to an already broken game has caused even more problems than before.

Even though now that the Store Page has been updated to read, "Towns is continually being developed and updated to bring you the best experience possible," it simply isn't.  You can go months with zero dev updates on their work.  Patches are released up to 5 months period in between patches.  None of the prior mechanics implementations have been fixed.  And now the dev is saying he is trying to hire another coder.....

The owner of this game is a self admitted full time employee of another company.  He has said on more than one occasion that they can't keep up with updates cause they have to work their jobs.  Don't support a game where the devs are not committed to it.  Let it die, and perhaps some of the more fanatic fans can take the code and do something legitimate with it.

column8:
Pass this on up. It *had* promise, but it failed in the end. Lack of updates, buggy AI, and the fact mobs don't respawn make this game pretty pathetic. If anything, it might as well be a ant farm for your desktop, and is moderatly less fun than SimCity.

Only plus is that it works on Linux. There are FAR better Linux games for on steam these days, some are even free (TF2, Minecraft which this game borrows a lot from). 

This game snuck in during the early days of the "green light" program, and before games were clearly marked as being under devleopment.  

In the future, I'll avoid any games with a Java requirement. .Net also burns me a little.

If you want a fun Linux game that supports Indie developers, go with Kerbal Space Program, or a number of the other games availble on steam.

column8: I feel strongly that this game has it right in a lot of old school ways. Yes, its graphically lacking, however whats happening is pure gold. All of the content we have grown to love as gamers exists in this piece of software. City building, creation, leveling, crafting, exploration and dungeon crawling all in a randomly generated package? Delicious. This is one that I do not care for a second lacks some pretty new age graphics. When im in the mood for some good old fashioned gaming fun, Im playing Towns.

column8:
I have lost all hope for this game.  I won’t argue anything about the initial release.  This game, overall, feels like a never ending chore of keeping villagers alive without the meaningful ability to micromanage functions of the game.  If it were not for modding, I would declare this game as being unworthy of disk space.  If you are unsure about purchasing this game simply look at some objective reviews on this game, and its forums.

In short, "Would not recommend".

column8:
I can say for sure what i think about towns after about 200h of gameplay.

Yes, i did everything there is up to this point in towns. My city is huge as you can see on screenshots and i had all kinds of heroes and did all kinds of building and stuff.

Lets point some good things : Dungeon system is simple but cool. its always amazing to open up a new floor. Heroes system is amazing as well since in towns you play as the "town" that supplies the hero, and not the hero itself.

So thinking on these points towns fullfil his promise and is a overall 8 of 10 game. I enjoyed.

its pretty much like Gnomoria, but less complex. Workshops and else are very simple and crafting dull. Town building is hard due game mechanics but overall its all good.

Towns is by itself a 8 of 10 game as said before (unique idea of being the town providing to heroes)
Compared to other games like gnomoria is just a simple 6 of 10.

The important thing to notice is that no matter how you look. its a good game for someone who likes to build and lose everything out of the blue due a huge siege =)

column8:
"Towns is continually being developed and updated to bring you the best experience possible!"
Beware, this is a lie, and the developers have abandoned the game long ago.

Do not get tricked into buying this as it was left unfinished and I doubt it will ever get more development.
It's a ripoff by scammers that took our money and ran off, and it's almost criminal to keep selling this. 
Absolutely ridiculous.

Forget this vaporware scam and get Gnomoria instead. 
It's similar in concept but those developers are actually doing their job.

column8:
This game is unintuitive, poorly done, very buggy, bland, and disappointing. I got the game when it first came out (before you could purchase beta access to games). The game was difficult to figure out and very clearly incomplete. At the time it hadn't claimed to be anything other than complete so I was surprised by the alpha phase feel of the game. The tutorial wasn't clear or useful and I had to take to the internet to learn how to play.

The UI is awful and looks largely like it is meant as a placeholder until the game is further along and finished. The game is still not finished. The last update released for the game as of this writing (12/6/2013) was 9/30. That update made some things better, but didn't really affect the problems, such as the weirdness with townies auto-equipping things, the awful UI, the terrible tutorial, the stupid pathing and ai, the cruddy combat system etc.

I was really looking forward to this game because it is similar in spirit to games like Dwarf Fortress and Dungeon Keeper, but it fails miserably and doesn't seem to be trying all that much. If you are a fan of DF or DK, I suggest just playing either of them, or try Gnomoria. Gnomoria is regularly updated and communicative with the player base. Don't get this game unless you are the kind of person who gets a kick out of bad games.

Update 8/19/2015:
Just wanted to add that as far as anyone can tell, the developers have abandoned this project and Steam continues to leave it up where it can still be sold. If you made the easy mistake of purchasing this game thinking it is complete or being worked on, please keep in mind you can refund games now and refund as soon as possible. I know I wish I had that option when I bought this game.

column8:
I bought Towns on sale just over a year ago...in that time it has received a few updates and undergone some changes.  However, this does not change the fact that this game left an utterly appalling impression upon me not only with the game but with the people working on it.  The tutorials were shamefully unhelpful, the gameplay was unintuitive, and the art style was unique but lead to an overall crude feel due to the games clunky play.

As time has passed I'd expected this game to get refined some and updated to assauge some of the issues I had...but to this date the progress has been glacially slow and it remains the same lump of an overcomplicated mess that it always was.  Perhaps I'm being overly spiteful given my own impressions, but I can't for the life of me find any redeeming features about this game after it has remained the same awful product for so long.

It's possible that you might enjoy this game, but I would heartily advise in-depth research about it, if not choosing a different product outright.

column8:
The first time i started this game i thought OMG what have i done and just uninstalled it within a few minutes. The UI is bad...really, REALLY bad. So is the tutorial.

I came back to it after a few months and just loved it to death. Don't get me wrong it has bugs and UI choices which will drive you up the wall, over the bridge and into the orc lair...and the minions are dumb as fuck. As are the adventurers haha

I really enjoyed this game, even with all the minor problems and it was absolutely worth the £10 i paid for it.

column8:
Terrible game.  Development is slow to the point of almost being non-existant (6+ months between major patches).  The AI is bad, especially the player's Townies (they border on suicidal at times).  Heroes are nothing more than dungeon-clearing mooches that sometimes bring total death to your Townies by bringing a train of mobs when they run away.  Only one music track that continually plays.  Townies cannot tear down already placed structures and items.

It's truly an alpha-stage game that is passed off as a release-ready game.  Look elsewhere for a city-building game.  Dwarf Fortress or Gnomoria are truly better options.

EDIT:  Also, do not listen to a word that YetiChow, the mod of the Towns forums on Steam, as he is a self-professed Troll that has no actual interest in the Steam community except to get rid of people who are critical of Towns and Town's developers.  http://www.townsgame.com/forums/viewtopic.php?f=88t=8032&start=40&p=47838&view=show#p47838

column9:
Terrible game.  Development is slow to the point of almost being non-existant (6+ months between major patches).  The AI is bad, especially the player's Townies (they border on suicidal at times).  Heroes are nothing more than dungeon-clearing mooches that sometimes bring total death to your Townies by bringing a train of mobs when they run away.  Only one music track that continually plays.  Townies cannot tear down already placed structures and items.

It's truly an alpha-stage game that is passed off as a release-ready game.  Look elsewhere for a city-building game.  Dwarf Fortress or Gnomoria are truly better options.

EDIT:  Also, do not listen to a word that YetiChow, the mod of the Towns forums on Steam, as he is a self-professed Troll that has no actual interest in the Steam community except to get rid of people who are critical of Towns and Town's developers.  http://www.townsgame.com/forums/viewtopic.php?f=88t=8032&start=40&p=47838&view=show#p47838

column8:
The concept of the game is that you are the town that supports the heroes that explore the caves beneath it. A bit of a twist on the adventure game. I personally turn it into Sparta. All the men and women of my town are in armor and have weapons. I enjoy sending 50+ soldiers into the dungeon to clear it myself at times. 

Overall this game can on some level play without you and does at later levels when you are stable, micromanaging chores out to the towns folk. Just make sure to have some tasks prepared for emergencies. (like graves) Other wise you will end up with your town folk dying off to ghosts some where. 

If you like building, fighting and don't mind the graphics. You may enjoy this game. 

If you purchased this game, check out these 2 tutorials that may help. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bRMiyptqk2g
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KtBJ4w6SP14

column8: This is a great game for someone willing to dedicate time to understanding it. The tutorials are rather poor and most of the learning is done by understanding what little the tutorials teach and applying it elsewhere. The game is a lot of fun and offers some replayability. It's a great challenge that I enjoy. I know there's a lot of bad reviews, but I honestly don't think these people gave their best effort in trying it out, and the game improves greatly with each update; most of the reviews were done before the game's main components were complete. I think it's a great game to play, but it takes a certain kind of player to enjoy it. I'd recommend trying the demo out first to make sure you like the game.

column8:
Towns ist eine nette kleine Abwechslung zum DungeonCrawling, das man sonst ja eher selber macht: Hier wird ähnlich wie bei anderen Spielen Dein Job verdreht, doch nicht dass man nun einen Dungeon "keepen" muss (Gruß an Bullfrog an dieser Stelle), sondern dass man die Stadt an der Oberfläche betreibt - bzw. erst mal aufbaut.
Startend auf der grünen Wiese mit nur ein paar Leuten heisst es pioniermäßig in die Hände zu spucken und eine Stadt inkl. der Verpflegungskette, Warenflüsse, Gebäude etc. pp. aufzubauen. Gerade die Verpflegung ist eine ständiges Problem und schon kleine Änderungen in der Versorgungskette kann katastrophale Folgen haben.
Anfangs wird man kleine Häuser, einfache Waffen und rüstungen herstellen, doch mit größerer Tiefe die die angelockten Helden erreichen kann man höherwertige Materialien finden und verarbeiten.
Aber Vorsicht: ab und an wird so ein Städtchen von Monster überfallen, ach und ebenso oft flüchten Helden in die Stadt, nur um eine Monstergruppe im Genick zu haben, die dann ja irgendwer killen muss ... Stadtwache?! STADTWACHE!!

Update nach einem Jahr:
Hunderte Stunden später muss ich wohl einsehen, dass ich Towns einfach mag: die Steuerung ist gewöhnungsbedürftig und Überleben mit allen Bewohnern ist anfangs eine Qual, später immernoch nicht sicher. Die kleinen Leute sind halt recht stumpf und erfüllen, was man ihnen aufträgt. Und wenn einer es nicht packt, macht sich der nächste auf den Weg. Oder jemand setzt ein Stück Dach und sperrt sich damit auf dem Dach weg ... dann merkt man erst an der sindenden Einwohnerzahl, das was falsch lief. Leider gibt es kein echtes Tutorial, was einem alles auf die Nase bindet. Trial and Error läßt einen Spieler anfangs gerne ein - zwei dutzende Male neu anfangen. Aber weiss man erstmal wie man die Mäuler mit Nahrung versorgt bekommt, kann man mehr und mehr auf Design der Gebäude/Stadt setzen. In meinem aktuellen Spiel habe ich die ersten 30 Stunden nur Stadt bauen lassen - keine Helden angelockt oder gar in den Boden gebudelt. Nur Unterkünfte und stabile Grundversorgung für 20 Leute. Und als die Vorräte immer größer wurden und die Leute gerne mal am Markt abhingen, da fing ich an eine Taverne zu bauen und hinab zu steigen, in den Dungeon.

Das Spiel ist unerbittlich bei Fehlern, wenig erklärend und bietet viele Möglichkeiten alles zu verlieren. Und der Verlauf ist LANGSAM. Ich denke, viele haben weder die Geduld, noch die Nerven für das Spiel, so wie es ist. Aber zu behaupten, es sei unfertig oder buggy, finde ich einfach falsch. Mit der richtigen Technik kann man alle Level im Untergrund erreichen, also entweder man lernt wie es geht oder sollte es sein lassen. Kein Spiel, wo einem ein Berater/Wizard alles vorkaut. Eher wie eines dieser kruden alten Spiele, wo man nie eine Anleitung für hatte, aber spürt, dass es großartig sein kann.
column9:
Towns is a nice little change from dungeon crawling, which you're usually more likely to do yourself: Here, similar to other games, your job is reversed, but instead of having to "keep" a dungeon (shoutout to Bullfrog here), you run the town on the surface – or rather, build it up first.
Starting on a greenfield site with just a few people, you have to get your hands dirty like a pioneer and build a town, including the supply chain, goods flows, buildings, etc. Supply, in particular, is a constant problem, and even small changes in the supply chain can have catastrophic consequences.
At first, you'll build small houses and simple weapons and armor, but as the heroes you attract go deeper, you'll be able to find and process higher-quality materials.
But be careful: every now and then, a small town like this gets attacked by monsters. Oh, and just as often, heroes flee into the city, only to have a group of monsters on their tail, which someone then has to kill... City Guard?! CITY GUARD!!

Update after a year:
Hundreds of hours later, I think I've come to the conclusion that I simply like Towns: the controls take some getting used to, and surviving with all the inhabitants is a pain at first, and later on, it's still not safe. The little people are pretty dull and do what you tell them. And if one doesn't manage it, the next one takes off. Or someone puts a piece of roof and locks themselves away on the roof... only then do you realize something went wrong when the population count drops. Unfortunately, there's no real tutorial to explain everything in your face. Trial and error often forces a player to start over a dozen or two dozen times. But once you know how to keep the mouths fed, you can focus more and more on building/city design. In my current game, I spent the first 30 hours building a town – not attracting heroes or even digging them into the ground. Just housing and a stable basic supply for 20 people. And as supplies grew and people started hanging out at the market, I started building a tavern and descending into the dungeon.

The game is relentless with errors, offers little explanation, and offers many opportunities to lose everything. And the progression is SLOW. I think many people have neither the patience nor the nerve for the game as it is. But to claim it's unfinished or buggy is simply wrong in my opinion. With the right technique, you can reach all the levels underground, so you either learn how to do it or you should leave it alone. It's not a game where an advisor/wizard tells you everything. More like one of those crude old games where you never had a manual, but you sense that it could be great.

column8:
(Game has been abandoned by the developers at what feels like late alpha / early beta)

I haven't really read any of the other reviews, except a quick glance at some of the positives, as I don't want mine to be influenced by them in any way. I will note that many of the positive reviews seem to be accidental recommendations, and Steam needs to remove that as the default option :P

So.. Towns. Well it's a decent base for a game, and I generally enjoyed the parts of it which worked properly, but that's really where it ends. If you try, you can perhaps push 20 hours or so out of the game, but ultimately the bugs and complete lack of content and polish will leave you despairing at the developers, who have abandoned this game.

The screenshots paint a pretty picture of flourishing towns and wonderful defenses, but it doesn't really apply to a real game, and you'll find yourself becoming frustrated at how fiddly everything is and how face-palmingly unintelligent the AI is, being almost unable to self regulate their most basic requirements. They almost seem suicidal.. but given the state of the game, I won't hold it against them.

Ultimately what you see in the screenshots is pretty much everything, and at it's unlikely best (visually). I strongly resent paying full price for games being brought to market which are late alpha/early beta, especially when the developers dump them and run off with the money because they don't really feel like doing it anymore. That's theft where I come from. I don't think the game was officially an 'Early Access' game? Just Greenlight perhaps, but either way I won't be buying a game until it's fully released from now on, and I wish Steam would pull this game off the store and stop putting it on sale. It's a skeleton of a game and will never be more than that.

Previous review.

I've bought the game last year and it never changed since then (I played about 20 h in offline mode)
Unplayable as usual. They tried to modify some elements like the most wierd one... wheat crops.

To build your town you need to produce bread from wheat. At the release of the game on Steam dev simply forgot that when worlds are randomly generated you may be unable to find enough wheat crops...

They resolved it by being able to plant harvested wheat. Could they do that before ?!

Add to this the fact that feeding your population is a real burden and you got something real painfull ,uggly and controls are terrible.

TOWNS is not a good game and even not an average game !

column8:
Do I recommend this game? Let's see: I got access to an early Alpha build of this game in early 2012. The game still seems to be in the same state today. The UI is not user-friendly and looks like it was designed by a time travelling programmer from 1992. The 'tutorial' does not really teach you things you need to know. Your townsfolk get killed at random by some monsters roaming around the map. The AI goes wonky and does not do what you ask.

So, do I recommend this game?

No.

column8:
Wow, my last review was huge.

Before you buy, (who is looking to buy this game anymore??) be sure to check out various reviews and decide for yourself what you expect.  Yeah, there are bugs, the game is unfinished.  At launch, it was one of very few city building sims on Steam that had that element of RTS/Hero management.  

Banished for the same money is a near-AAA experience, so don't go buying this game unless you own that or Cities: Skylines.  If you are into resource and development sims then Factorio is infinitely a better choice.  There are others, but I'm only naming ones I have a lot of experience with.

Towns can be considered an early Java template game, it doesn't stray far from what you usually see in typical browser games, but I love it and that's that.  This game has a much better experience than Towncraft, an abandonware game that is way worse of a consumer-trust relationship.

Make sure you educate yourself if you're actually consider spending full price on this game.  There are hundreds of games on Steam that would probably be better suited for that amount.  If you want a unique glimpse into what was one of the "founders" of how Steam became the conglomerate of early access/scam gaming, you won't be disappointed.  And hey, once you get past the bugs and logic-defying mechanics, you might even enjoy playing it a little bit.  I sure as hell did, and that was back when this game was front and center in the Steam Drama world.

Wow, my last review was huge.

Before you buy, (who is looking to buy this game anymore??) be sure to check out various reviews and decide for yourself what you expect.  Yeah, there are bugs, the game is unfinished.  At launch, it was one of very few city building sims on Steam that had that element of RTS/Hero management.  

Banished for the same money is a near-AAA experience, so don't go buying this game unless you own that or Cities: Skylines.  If you are into resource and development sims then Factorio is infinitely a better choice.  There are others, but I'm only naming ones I have a lot of experience with.

Towns can be considered an early Java template game, it doesn't stray far from what you usually see in typical browser games, but I love it and that's that.  This game has a much better experience than Towncraft, an abandonware game that is way worse of a consumer-trust relationship.

Make sure you educate yourself if you're actually consider spending full price on this game.  There are hundreds of games on Steam that would probably be better suited for that amount.  If you want a unique glimpse into what was one of the "founders" of how Steam became the conglomerate of early access/scam gaming, you won't be disappointed.  And hey, once you get past the bugs and logic-defying mechanics, you might even enjoy playing it a little bit.  I sure as hell did, and that was back when this game was front and center in the Steam Drama world.

column8: Buy Gnomoria instead.
column9: Buy Gnomoria instead.

column8:
このゲームはマジ面白い！
村人を使って自分の村を作っていくゲームですが、作ってる途中にモンスターの群れなどが襲って来たり
村に食料が無ければ村人全員が餓死してしまったり、山や鉱山に木材や鉱石を取りに行こうものなら
モンスターに村人を殺されて数を減らされたり・・・

初めてプレイすると操作方法とかちょっとよく分からないかもですが
何度も何度も村を全滅させてるうちに・・・きっと村を全滅させない方法をご自身で見つけると思います
(私は序盤でかなり村人を全滅させてました100回ぐらい・・・=.=;)

今時珍しいゲームだと思います、最近のゲームに飽きてきた方！
このゲームをプレイしてみてはいかがでしょうか！
column9:
This game is seriously fun!
You build your own village using villagers, but as you build, hordes of monsters attack.
If there's no food in the village, all the villagers will starve to death. If you try to get wood or ore from the mountains or mines,
monsters will kill villagers and reduce their numbers...

The controls might be a little confusing the first time you play, but
as you wipe out villages over and over again...I'm sure you'll find a way to avoid wiping them out.
(I wiped out so many villagers early on, about 100 times... =.=;)

This is a rare game these days, so if you're tired of modern games, why not give this one a try?

column8:
I´ve voted "No, i do not recommend this game" but i really would like to say: "Yes!"
Why? This game really gave me some good time, cause i like the freedom in which you're able to build up a town, the retroish graphics and the possibility to alter the game due editing some xml files. Unfortunately the problems start right there: Since the engine limits the world to a 64*64 cube, you have to choose between dungeon roaming and building high up in the air, when altering the world generation (only a change in values). Last one is my favorite playstyle... or: would be, if the engine would not getting annoyingly laggy with more than 12 surface leves. There seem to be too many transparent blocks which affects the game as soon as you are giving more than two orders to your Townies. So, i am just not able to build high buildings without having a second lag, a second none, a second lag, a sec.. you get it. And that "really grinds my gears".

Also, the menu is crap and the tutorial basically only explains how to move your mouse from left to right and bottom to top. Furthermore, there are some serious bugs, which are a total pain in the a**. Check out the Community Hub's discussion to get an idea of them, it is a long list.
And yes, the devs spoofed those who bought this game, cause updates came in irregularily, were minor and the communication to us customers is worth mentioning.

At the moment rumors say the devs are looking for someone new to heritage this project. We´ll see.

After all Towns is a perfect example for everything which could go wrong with Steam's Greenlight/Early Access policy (or which mechanism else failed).

I recommend to keep this game in mind, check for updates and buy it when the shitstorm moves on.

column8:
I really wanted to like this game, but I just can't.
The concepts were sound, but the graphics/interface/interaction just aren't there. 
I played for a while, but felt unfulfilled by progress.   I know it's a sandbox game, but maybe a bit of a story would have been nice, or perhaps some rewards for reaching certain achievements, or...?

Going to put this on the proverbial shelf, perhaps it'll get better in time.

column9: There's not much to do in the game. Even the underground levels are not as long as you might think. The important thing is that, despite the promise of continuous updates, there's only been one update since the summer.

column8:
These unethical developers took their alpha game and released it as a full game without any notice to potential customers.  After the backlash that ensued, they added the line about continually developing the game.  This is a lie as the game has not been continually developed.  It has been patched a few times since release, but really isn't much better than the released alpha it started out as. 

I REALLY wanted to like this game, I thought the concept was great.  I tried so hard to learn to workaround all the missing and broken features looking for the fun inside, but never found it.  I regret giving my money to unethical people and regret every minute wasted in Towns that could have been spent in a real game.  It is a very sad story as this game had tons of potential.  Ultimately, all it is right now is wasted potential.  Even for the sale price, there are TONS of better choices out there for the same amount or less.  Don't give these unethical people any more of your money, they've already made millions off the rest of us suckers.

column8:
Towns war für mich eine große Überraschung! Eigentlich hatte ich mir nicht allzuviel erhofft, aber für den billigen Preis von nicht einmal 5 Euro hat es mich doch sehr begeistert! Die Grafik ist zwar ein bisschen gewöhnungsbedürftig, aber sehr liebevoll gestaltet.
Ehrlich gesagt hat es mich süchtig gemacht!

Meine Bewertung: Towns schrammt bei mir auch nur knapp an der maximalen Punktzahl vorbei, und bekommt von mir 4 von 5 Dschungel-Schwammerl, b.z.w. vier von fünf Punkten.

P.S.: Würde es nicht ständig abstürzen (ich muss mir beim Spielen den Handy-Wecker stellen, den ich alle 10 Minuten wegdrücke, damit ich das Speichern nicht vergesse), bekäme es von mir 4.5 von 5 Punkte.
Aber dass es so instabil läuft ist wirklich äusserst nervig!
column9:
Towns was a big surprise for me! I actually wasn't expecting much, but for the low price of less than €5, I was really impressed! The graphics take a bit of getting used to, but they're very lovingly designed.
Honestly, it's addictive!

My rating: Towns just barely misses the maximum score for me, and gets 4 out of 5 jungle mushrooms, or four out of five points.

P.S.: If it didn't crash constantly (I have to set my phone alarm every 10 minutes while playing, which I dismiss every 10 minutes so I don't forget to save), I'd give it 4.5 out of 5.
But the fact that it's so unstable is really extremely annoying!

column8:
Ok, having reviewed the game again, it still seems to me like this is a very hit or miss game.  On the one hand, it's a game with the interesting premise that you're creating a town to attract heroes to fight in the dungeons that are invariably discovered beneath the town.  On the other hand, it's bogged down by horrible micromanagement through clunky menus.  

Before you find yourself running a town worthy of adventurers coming to visit, you have to BUILD the town.  You start with a handful of people standing around with their thumbs up their asses waiting for you to tell them what to do.  You tell them to grab some fruit and put it over there in a patch of ground we'll call a stockpile.  You tell them to chop down trees and put the wood over there in a different stockpile.  You designate certain areas of ground as a room for various purposes and then have to figure out what order you're required to build the furniture for these rooms.

So you want beds for your people to sleep in?  You're gonna need a carpentry bench in a carpentry zone.  What about food more filling than apples and pears?  I guess you're gonna need a baking table and a baking oven in a baking zone.  But wait; there's something about this baking oven being made out of stone.  Now you're going to need a masonry room and an appropriate table in an appropriate zone.

This kind of crap takes place all the time in this game. Oh and it's also set to some mind numbing repetitive music barely above "bad midi song" level. The characters themselves aren't very well animated and most might as well be colored stick figures.  I mean, you tell your guys to chop down a tree...do you see them pull out an axe and swing it at the trunk?  No, you see them stand next to a tree for a few minutes while a chopping sound effect is played and then you're treated to your character hauling a log across the map to a stockpile (if you bothered to make one).

This game has a lot of promise and I've actually had this game since it was "officially released" waiting for it to live up to that promise.  It hasn't done it yet.  Oh and about that official release:  It basically went from alpha to final release overnight.  Had steam's "Early Access" been a thing at the time it would have been a perfect candidate for it.  Instead they released it as if it were done when just a day before it was "alpha" quality...but again, that wasn't really an option for them and they were desperate to make sales.  

Now, in the time since the game went "live" on steam to the writing of this review, they've put up a few updates and it does look like they've fixed a few things here and there, but it hasn't changed to the point where I could wholeheartedly say "yes, buy this game!"  It's still got a rough and unfinished feel to it, and if they'd take some time to polish up the UI, add some more variety to the music, and redo most of the graphics, it would at least look like they've made some progress.  Instead it's all "under the hood" stuff with very little outward change from the earliest version on Steam.

If despite all of this you're still willing to buy the game, yes, you can easily sink 10-20 hours into it (I've almost sunk 20 into it when it was in its most broken state) because you get that feeling that somehow you're slowly making progress in the game and building something.  It's not entirely unsatisfying...it's just not entirely satisfying either.  If you buy it, lower your expectations and I'm sure this game will meet those lowered expecations and maybe even surpass them.  If instead you go into it expecting a great and polished game from the start, you'll be let down hard.

column8:
Broken, buggy, unfinished mess. This game was released on Greenlight, with the devs claiming that they would continue development. I understood this to mean that I was buying into an alpha that was in development still. The game feels about 40% complete. It's playable, but..

1. The AI is terrible. Both townie and mob. 
2. The way you construct things is really hard to use, reminescent of RCT2 in that the isometric way the roofs tile makes it difficult for you to see if you placed a roof properly or not, but with the added annoyance that you need to have it so that your townies can reach it, so you need to place scaffolds everywhere. It's not fun, it feels like a chore.
3. The GUI seriously leaves a lot to be desired. Things with no tooltip, weird buttons that do unclear things, annoying flashing notification buttons every single time you pause/unpause..
4. Complete(or near complete) lack of satisfactory tutorials. It's not extremely hard to grasp like DF is, but there are strange things that I still don't understand, like why the entire underground of the map appears to be a giant dungeon and there is no underground stone. 
5. Bugs.
6. No where near as much customization is possible as DF has, the environment is basically the same generic map each time.

All of these things are totally fixable. The problem? The devs have halted development. There hasn't been a patch in several months, no offical posts on the (horrible, echo chamber of a) forum, total silence. They kept complaining about being bogged down by all the work, and being burnt out. Plenty of devs are, but you don't just stop development completely. You take breaks, not quit. Ask people for ideas, don't quit. Open up your code so that others can work on it with you, don't quit. 

Really disappointed I supported this project and got a broken, unfinished product. It's made me more cynical about buying into alphas, which isn't a good thing to be, either, I guess. 

Don't buy this broken, unfinished mess. Truly a disappointment.

column8:
If you want a Dwarf Fortress Clone with graphics, please play Gnomoria. 
This game is a very low quality and not fit for release. 

It is a bummer that this was one of the first game to be ever Greenlit. Contrary to the public belief, this game is not and never was Early Access, yet we got an Alpha Version of the game sold. The store page also says that it will be continuously updated, but this does not happen. We get a patch all few months, which tends to break even more things. 

The visuals are okay, but the menus are just downright amateurish, the tutorials useless and the game absolutely explains nothing. Hello Developers, it is 2013, wake up. You don't need to hold my hand, but if you don't explain how your game works, then there is not fun to be had. Crawling through half the internet to understand how the game works is not something you want. 

Gnomoria is way more intuitive and has a clear progress line, even if you never played this genre. 

Don't touch it with a 10 ft pole held by someone else on the other side of the street.

Update May 7th, 2014:
The devs have now officially abandoned the game. There will be no more updates.
http://www.townsgame.com/forums/viewtopic.php?f=8&t=11480

column8:
I originally bought this with the thought of "Woah cool, a town simulator!" in my mind.  After all, the screenshots showed some very epic looking towns, and the game wasn't in the Early Access category. (meaning it wasn't an alpha/beta, but rather a full release)
Boy was I in for a surprise.. and not the good kind.

I can sum up this game in one single word - Awful.  

There was barely a tutorial involved, so I had no idea what I was doing.  I started up a game and within minutes my villagers with their fantastic AI decided to disregard all common sense and took it in turns to throw themselves at a monster, resulting in most of my population dying right away.  Those who survived died of starvation a few in-game days later because I had no idea how I was meant to feed them, despite throwing food down right infront of them.
The game is filled with bugs, and there's been very little care and attention given to the game from the devs.  They've tried to pass off this game as being a full release, yet it's clearly still in alpha stage.  There's been many players complaining and demanding answers from the devs, but their cries seem to fall upon deaf ears.  Now that the devs have made a cool $2mil from this game, they couldn't care less, and it clearly shows.

Don't buy this game, not even for a laugh/joke.  These developers don't deserve any of your money.

Update: Abandoned now. It is what it is. Not exactly broken but neither finished as such. There are other games instead. Sorry.

A rather cute sandbox game set in medieval time. 
The graphics is really nice retro. It is in a 45 degree turned isomettric view. This is also the low-point of it, it can't be turned that I know of. The menues are in the tiniest format, it's as easy to delete a game as it it to load it. That said, the menues inside the game are much better. Which is where the main production value seems to have been spent.
The sound is very nice, slightly reminiscent of Settlers, the very first game, in the mood at least. I wouldn't say it's intrusive but you won't remember it either, which to me is a good point for game music.
The actual game is fairly straight up management with the added fun of actual being able to lose quickly. The learning curve is steep, not overly but it will take a few games to get it like you want it. The management increases over time as you gain more people living in your town.
You are very much victim of circumstances with this game. Sometimes you find iron at the surface, sometimes there is none to save your life. The caravans are an offset but dreaming of gold statues after a few hours, you've really struck gold. This makes every game a new challenge which is nice. Pretty much as Civilization was.

The main thing to say about this game is that it's a time thief. You constantly look for the next thing you'll 'just do before quitting'. It sort of reminds you of minecraft in that aspect.

column8:
It's nice after you get into it. No proper tutorial makes a bit hard in the beginning, but no deal-breaker. This isn't the short 2-hour game, you can really spend time there, it's a crude version of Sims combined with Minecraft in strategy mode where you command a lot of "minecraft players", your citizens. The commands are leaned towards automation so you dont have so much direct control, but enough for sure.

Note: this game was supposedly made by one programmer and one artist and the programmer has allegedly quit this project (and there's rumors this project was never a high priority thing for him) so dont expect the bugs to be fixed. I did enjoy the game, but that's because I like to discover new things, even find out the game mechanics instead of having them explained to me. Anyone who feels differently, you shouldn't buy this game because there's a lot finding-out to do with game mechanics, and that's most likely not gonna change.

The game mechanics work though, it's just a long try & fail process often. But you can also make up for your failures, like build new if buildings get destroyed (they shouldn't), get new villagers if old ones die (how compassionate) and even buy new animals from the visiting vendors.

I feel this game has a lot of potential, but is poorly polished. I dont know how much the developers make with this, but they could make 10 times more bucks if they polished it, hired the crew and decided to listen to people.

column8:
Do NOT, under any circumstances, buy this game. It is STILL unfinished, nowhere near completion, and will most likely never be done. The developers haven't been active for months and sent the alpha out to die. 

Early Access was introduced partially due to the bloody mess of this game's "launch", and yet it never actually received the Early Access tag, and instead is being sold disguised as a finished product.

Not much has happened since then, and it is unlikely that this is going to change in the near future. Yes, it has its charme, yes it had potential, but this potential has not yet been touched by the developers - and this game launched on Steam A YEAR AGO!

If you are a fan of this type of game, I wholeheartedly recommend Gnomoria, which is not only cheaper, but also well underway to being a finished game. It wears its Early Access tag with pride, and releases patches very frequently. Just this week they released version 0.9.2, which tweaks, rebalances and fixes a LOT of combat mechanics, and the game itself works and looks charming. While not done yet, it is very much playable without the level of frustration Towns will give you.

Stay away from Towns.

column8:
Great simulation game. You manage harvesting, planting, storing, building, mining and exploring, etc. Very steep learning curve, which is nice. Took me around five hours and as many restarts just to achieve a self-sustainable colony. Great music and lovely graphics.

Edit: addictive as HELL. Multiple times I've played for just one more cycle of harvest/replant, well into the night, well past my bedtime.

Somethings I'd like to see added/improved:
 - bigger maps
 - more fluid animations (on your Townies)
 - more in-game tools to fix things, change things (create Animal in case you wipe out a population, etc)
Those are just suggestions, not criticisms.

column8:
You'll hate yourself for playing this game. You really will. You see, this entire game revolves around using an annoying UI to control villagers with an intensely annoying AI to handle logistics poorly and theoretically command them to eventually get around to doing the things you'd like to do. Sort of like Majesty, if you had to build your buildings from scratch, the only part of them that was technically necessary outside of aesthetics was the floor and your kingdom had a rule of law that all new citizens born in the nation must be dropped on their head.

You start out with about 11 morons to shepherd around, gradually kit them out in safety harnesses and protective helmets so that they'll be safe when you shove them out the door and hope that you'll lose as few as possible. Eventually you start getting heroes and such that you can use to explore the dungeons that extend deeper and deeper into the map and who protect your village from the increasingly difficult sieges laid by enemies, which can feel satisfying as hell to watch them fight after getting used to your moron brigade's perpetual failure.

This is also one of those games where you open a wiki while you play, just so you know. Otherwise your village will completely and totally fail because the only way to get new villagers depends on the happiness of the village, which is designed in a way that either you intentionally build your village with them in mind, or else you die and start over.

I dumped about thirty hours into it over the course of a week, then didn't touch it again afterward. That's pretty much the type of game this is.

[b]EDIT[/b]: About a year later, coming back to this review I'm changing my review to negative and adjusting the sarcastic-praise slightly. The game is still fun (and from playing it a bit more, the AI is less moronic than I recalled), and the UI is tolerable now that I remember how it works (though it's still not good). That said, you shouldn't buy this game. Buying it supports the developer, and he abandoned it without shame. If you want to play it, by all means do so, just don't give the developer money in order to do that. I'll leave figuring out how to obtain the game without paying the absent dev up to you, but that's my suggestion.

column8:
If you like builder/survival games, this one is fantastic. In the vein of Minecraft and Terraria, Towns puts you in control of multiple villagers who have... nothing. You start with the proverbial Tabula Rasa and you have to build a thriving village. The catch is that your people chose a REALLY bad place to build... on top of a forgotten dungeon!

Survival, Building and Real-Time City Simulator all in one.

column8:
Офигенная игруха! 
Хотя графа не ужаснет только тех, кто начинал играть еще под DOS'ом :)))

Минут 15 тратишь на изучение менюх.
Минут 60 тратишь чтобы понять как же блин это все работает.
Потом еще минут... часа 3-10 :) на то чтобы, после 20 перезапусков игры по новой, наконец построить хотя бы одно здание и при этом жители не попередохли от окружающей флоры и фауны :)
А дальше можно "расслабиться" и отбивая осады, организуя питание, добычу полезных ископаемых, складирование всего добытого хлама, развивая инфраструктуру, начать потихоньку углубляться вглубь недр :)
Отгребая в процессе погружения от монстряков, хороня героев пачками, собирая трупы своих геройских жителей решивших забрать что-то в другом конце подземелья и умерших с голоду по дороге назад :)
Веселуха та еще :)
Рекомендую всем задротам! :)
column9:
Awesome game!
Although the graphics won't be terrifying only to those who started playing under DOS :)))

You spend about 15 minutes learning the menus.
You spend about 60 minutes figuring out how the hell it all works. Then another 3-10 minutes... an hour or so :) until, after 20 restarts, you finally build at least one building without your residents dying from the surrounding flora and fauna. :)
And then you can "relax" and, fending off sieges, organizing food supplies, mining, storing all the scrap you've collected, developing infrastructure, slowly begin to delve deeper into the depths. :)
Defending monsters as you dive, burying heroes in droves, collecting the corpses of your heroic residents who decided to take something from the other end of the dungeon and died of starvation on the way back. :)
It's a lot of fun. :)
Recommended for all nerds! :)

column8: A very fun, very challenging game that just keeps on making you want to play more and more. If you like minecraft, you'll LOVE this game. The graphics are blocky, but just like in minecraft, you can build what your imagination gives you. The occasional siege might set you back, but it only makes you want to make your army better and explore the dangerous depths of your world. Create a Tavern and soon enough you'll have powerful heroes to help you explore your dungeons, and who knows, maybe you'll get some famous heroes in your village, such as Sips, Vechs or even Sir Punchwood! Set up your farms, get buildings going and make your own kingdom!

column8:
Bit of a rocky start to this one. The developers should have had someone to handle public relations, 'cause they really pissed people off for no reason. The AI's severly buggy, which can be a problem in this type of game, but it seems to be improving over time. Overall, I'd say it's fun and worth the indie price tag to play with digital legos every so often.

Update:
So, nothing seems to be happening with this game. I kind of expected it to go... anywhere at all. But I was mistaken. Don't bother - there are plenty of other games out there that care enough to put out updates once in a while.

column8:
Great game, fun to play and its nice to have the ability to design buildings and your entire town and how it runs is intuitive. Would Recommend this to everyone who likes Town building down to laying the bricks of each building yourself.

Note: Due to halted devolopment by Xavi (reason of course is he's to bored of working on it to continue making updates and improvements. Also that he decided to work on another project while he was working on Towns). At the moment of this update a new programer was hired to take over for Xavi's obvious lack of updating of this game. So it's really a risk to buy the game, till there's real progress put in by the new programming lead. SMP atm has lost all respect from me, considering and I qoute Xavi said, this game was pretty much a learning experience for him nothing more. So everyone who bought it was really just paying for Xavi to learn to program so he can work more on other projects he started while working on Towns. Awesome.

column8:
Towns could be a great game. It has a lot going for it. From the unique perspective to pleasing graphics it has the base to be a enjoyable time sink. Unfortunately the execution leaves a bit to be offered.

The game itself is quite good. You control a group of townspeople who have started a town that happens to be on top of an active dungeon system. You go through the usual gathering and building phases, but are also tasked with dealing with monsters. As you begin to dig into the earth looking for resources you find caverns and tunnels populated by the genres classic baddies. Everything from spiders to ogres await you hapless townsfolk as they dig deeper. You have to build up a guard force to keep you town safe from these creatures, and at a certain point you can even attract "adventurers" that are much more powerful and able to really beat down some baddies. It's a fun mix of dungeon discovery and building and offers quite a bit of content as is.


The bad part of it is that you can only pretty much count on it "as is" the "early access" part of this game is seriously slow. There have been exceptionally long gaps between developments, at some points even rumors development had stopped. Issues between developer and publisher have not helped things. So if you're willing to shell out for the game as it is now you will get quite a bit of content, just don't rest any solid hopes on it advancing. The chances of it ever actually being finished and brough inline with the initial goal of  the game is even less. 

Because of the issues I simply cannot recommend this game to someone. If there were regular updates and some progress towards completion I would completely back this game, but as I can't recommend a game I don't think is ever going to be completed for someone to buy.

column8:
This has been one of my favorite games on steam. It has its problems but the slowly get fixed.

You start out with 11 villagers in the wild and your goal is to build a thriving town that attracts heros who will go into the dungeons the town is built upon. With a bit of hardwork you can make your villagers clear out the dungeons as well, but they are better suited to keeping the heros happy. I believe this game is still under construction but it has the potential to be a great game and as far as im concerned it already is. Id give it a 4/5 simply because it needs a little polishing.
