column8:
Dwarf Fortressに似た、ちょっとアップデートが遅い未完成なゲームです。
バージョンアップごとに食べ物の作り方が変わったり、セーブデータに互換性が無かったりがあるっぽいです。
ゲーム自体が発展していく中で発見もあれば戸惑いもあるという。そういったのを楽しめる人にはお勧めだと思います。
Java Runtime Environment(JRE)のインストールが必要です。
column9:
Similar to Dwarf Fortress, this is an unfinished game that is updated a little slowly.
It seems that the way food is made changes with each version update, and save data may not be compatible.
As the game itself develops, there are discoveries and confusions along the way. I recommend this game to people who enjoy that kind of thing.
Requires the installation of Java Runtime Environment (JRE).

column8:
Fun sandbox game that is easy to pick up and easy to maintain with minimal time (but easy to micromanage and spend a lot of time in, if you want). Fun game for a good price.

Edited @ 1:57 PM, Friday June 20th 2014.

Just over a year after I wrote that first review, I have to change my stance. When I first bought this game, I was under the impression that work would continue to happen with it and that it would see improvements. But this game is Not finished. Not even close.

The number of glitches encountered with some of the most basic game mechanics are just inexcusable for a game that is neither in Alpha, nor Beta.

I have a lot of time in this game, and it's gaming time that I've enjoyed. But I would never have bought this product had I known it would never see development again. After wanting to hope that there'd be some chance for change, it's time to delete it from my computer and give it up. If you want a finished game, do not buy this one.

column8:
The idea of this game is kind of cool.  Unfortunatly that is all this game really is, an idea.  There are a lot of unfinished game-play mechancis. you know, interesting ideas, that just do not go anywhere.

For the most part, you start a town, get your food production going and then you need to attract heros to clear out the gaint dungeon undernearth your town.  So what do you end up doing with most of your time once you get past the startup phase?

You just watch the heroes bumble around and try and clear out one level of the dungeon.  And when they are done with that?  You just get to watch them do the same thing on the next level.  Thats all you do. 

Oh sure, you can build stuff for the sake of building stuff, like a garden or place decortave statues, but something really useful?  No.

My reccomendation is to NOT buy this game.  Maybe in a few years the game-play will be fleshed out more, but right now, there isn't much, if any, of a game here.

column8: В игре довольно мало возможностей по сравнению с DF, хоть в последних обновах разрабы стараются внести что-то новое, вот в 12-ом апдейте добавили "археологию". Недавно добавили героев (Rpg-элемент), торговлю; значительно упростили менеджмент поселения, ушли от полностью непрямого контроля. Строительство тут ппц какое кривое, типов минералов мизер, глобальная цель игры довольно банальна - зачистить все 10 (вроде) нижних этажей. Из плюсов - простота освоения, приличный бестиарий, много видов деятельности (пока сильный уклон в заготовку еды), теперь еще добавилась преемственность городов и уникальной экипировки, добытой другими игроками на просторах сети. Брал я ее год назад (версия .42б), думал, что разрабы ее забросят, да и аналоги приличные вышли Gnomoria и Timber and Stone, как оказалось - зря. Но , честно говоря, ей бы еще годика два до финала в бетках походить.
column9: The game lacks quite a bit of functionality compared to DF, although the developers have been trying to introduce something new in recent updates, such as "archeology" in Update 12. They recently added heroes (an RPG element) and trade; settlement management has been significantly simplified, moving away from completely indirect control. Construction is incredibly poor, mineral types are minimal, and the overall goal is rather simple: clear all 10 (I think) lower floors. On the plus side, it's easy to learn, has a decent bestiary, and offers a wide variety of activities (with a strong focus on food preparation for now). Now, there's also the added feature of city continuity and unique equipment obtained by other players online. I picked it up a year ago (version .42b), thinking the developers would abandon it, especially since Gnomoria and Timber and Stone have already released decent alternatives. As it turns out, that was a mistake. But, to be honest, she needs another two years of betting time before reaching the finals.

column8:
The developer has stopped work on this game and it is currently buggy and unstable.  DO NOT BUY!

Below is my original review when things were still being worked on and the game was mostly stable.


In this game, you create and build a town that caters to dungeon-delving heroes.  That dungeon just happens to be BELOW your town and goes very deep into the ground.    Think: SimCity meets Minecraft for a basic idea of the game.  I have mixed feelings about this game.  It has plenty of micromanagement, resource acquisition and goods production but you can't directly control your civilians, soldiers or any of the heroes.  It can be very frustrating when your civilians are starving to death about 12 levels below ground while they were trying to collect raw materials, such as copper or silver, that another civilian mined.  It can also be frustrating when your town of 10 people becomes a town of 0 people when monsters from the depths over-run your populace because you inadvertantly mined a pathway for the monsters to come to the surface.  The game has a good concept and is fun to play but it is missing a big part of the equation which could make this a great game.  The potential I discovered by playing the free demo was what prompted me to buy the game.  It's worth trying the demo if you are into stragety/management games, you get 20 in-game days of playtime, just be sure to put the game on the slowest speed so you aren't overwhelmed in minutes.

column8:
1 part fixed camera version of Minecraft (which is as difficult to navigate as it sounds)
1 part ProgressQuest (http://progressquest.com)

Laying down the initial settlement was fun, but now that it's established I am no longer needed. My little automations are clearing the 3rd dungeon level as I write this.

UPDATE: I've got a 60 hour playtime because, back in March at least, you could leave it running in the background at no risk to the well being of your Town. All dungeons were cleared with about 4 hours of play and 56 hours of idle.

column8: I got this game with the impression that it was going to be like Minecraft. When I started playing it, I realized just how wrong I really was. Towns really gives the impression that you are playing a minecraft clone from a bird's eye view, but what you soon learn is that amidst all of the building and gathering you would expect to have to do, there lies even more. Managing your citizens happiness, raising livestock, and creating automated systems to gather and plant crops, all of this just to skim the surface. As a game still being constructed, Towns has a very promising future. Highly recommend this series to anyone who likes the Sims franchise or any castle building games.

column8: A game with a lot of potential that really falls quite short at the time.  The concept is cool; build a town and let adventurers clear out the dungeon for you.  On paper it all seems great but in practice not so much.  While the devs admit the game is still being updated (and they have been updating it) there is still a lot of work to be done.  One redeeming fact is you can edit game files to modify things in the game to make it more enjoyable.  I recommend this game because it is a really neat concept, but i'd wait for more patching and maybe a price drop to make sure you are getting a complete product to get your money's worth.

column8:
Once I recommended the game, and it looked like the developers were making a good game... then it was abandoned.

Original Review: It reminds me of minecraft plus sim-city, which, in all honesty, is fairly fun. To be fair, the game feels like it still needs a fair bit of spit-and-polish (several menus aren't labeled, you'll need to make multiple references to the wiki to figure out what you're doing) But the game's still early in its life and they're promising they're still working on it, so I have high hopes for it, and I see a fair amount of potential. And its fun regardless. (Although can be tricky to actually get your town growing instead of dying at start.)

column8:
Pros: Building your town one block at a time is good fun, and exploring the random environments is enjoyable,

Cons: It contains a "happiness" mechanic that rewards you for not playing and -- annoyingly -- forces you to leave the game running on its own for long periods in order to advance well.

Certainly worth a look, but lacks the long-term appeal of Terraria.

The interface and controls feel clunky, and the tutorial is terrible at explaining stuff. I lost the will to continue playing after 10 minutes. Despite the amount of content this game feels like a beta or perhaps even an alpha. I wish I had played the demo first, could've saved the money.

EDIT: Steam turned down my refund request because it had been more than 2 weeks since I bought the game, even though back when I got this game the refund policy wasn't in place yet. What good is even letting you request refunds on games that you bought more than 2 weeks ago if they won't refund you for abandonware?

3.Возможность строительства и крафтинга в целях развития человечества.
Задание - выжить :D

Также данная игра из списка игр, в которые стоит играть длительное время, иначе не почувтсвуешь всю суть игры. :D
column9:
A rather engaging game that combines Minecraft-style graphics with Simcity gameplay.
The game's objective is straightforward.
You're given:
1. A clean, untouched world.
2. A group of several people.
3. The ability to build and craft for the advancement of humanity.
The goal is to survive :D

This game is also one that requires long-term play, otherwise you won't fully appreciate the game's essence. :D

column8:
In a word, Unfinished.

In many -- Towns is a promising, but rough experience. Nothing seems to work quite as intended, the UI is a little finicky, mouse clicks don't always register in the right place (if at all), and digging is a nightmare. The further down you dig, the more erratic the mouse behavior becomes.

At 15$, I'd say the price is steep -- comparing to Minecraft, which released at a similar price, the level of functionality is far less. Though then again, the requisite functionality is far greater in the case of Towns. However, this game is flawed for a far simpler reason, it was released onto steam with no notice that it was an unfinished, alpha game -- I'm an alpha-player, I love to play and watch as a game evolves, and I am _more likely_ to purchase an alpha game than many non-alpha games. I know many of my friends feel the same way, but  this game released to steam (via Greenlight) purporting to be a fully-ready 1.0 release, and that's just not what it is.

I say wait. Maybe get it if the price drops to the 2-5$ range. It has potential to be quite good, if the development continues, but everything about the more general practice smells of a smash and grab on my wallet, and I don't much care for it.


Weak accept on potential, Strong Reject on Honesty.

column8:
*Edit* 

This game was a promise of good content with challenging updates and what we got was basically a crappy, two-bit, clone of Gnomoria and other games of the title. 

While not all bad, the villiagers are idots, get killed often and require bogus needs of happiness to repopulate. Good luck with that as you gather the resources to make the houses as poor old John and Jane Doe die to starvation, disease, monsters or even natural events. 

Also second note, while interesting, the final floor of the dungeon lairs was a let down.

2/10 for it's current unfinished state.

Dwarf Fortress.  This is Dwarf Fortress with a texture pack, mouse feature, and less options.  Imagine if Dwarf Fortress came out for Facebook.  Kinda like that but a bit notch above Facebook/Mobile Tier. 

I'm finding a lot of problems with it though.  I hear there are many many AI bugs.  Will it be patched, or are the developers just looking from quick cash from a broken game?  We shall see!

They didn't fix anything.  Game is abandoned.  Do yourself a favor and go learn Dwarf Fortress.

column8:
Deep, somewhat confusing but very engaging.  Think of a non-ASCII dwarf fortress.  The UI is terrible and there are some features missing that would really help round it out, but it has a lot of potential.  However, it appears to be updated once or twice a month, adding new features and fixing bugs.  

Definitely keep an eye out for when it's "finished" and put it on your wishlist to see if it's on sale again.

잠재력 따위는 헛소리다. 비디오 게임은 완성된 물건으로 평가해야 하며, 완성되었다고 자신있게 말할 수 있을 때 판매해야 옳다. (미완성된 그림을 앞으로 대작이 될거라며 파는 예술가를 본적 있나?) 분명 앞으로 좋은 게임이 될 가능성을 가진 [드와프 포트리스]의 클론 게임이지만, 유저 편의를 위해 여러가지를 희생한것 치고는 그다지 발전한 모습을 보여주지 않는다.

그리고 개발자가 공식 개발 중단 발언을 했다. 망할.
column9:
Potential is nonsense. Video games should be evaluated as finished products, and only sold when they can confidently claim to be finished. (Have you ever seen an artist selling an unfinished painting claiming it will become a masterpiece?) It's a Dwarf Fortress clone with the potential to be a great game, but despite the sacrifices made for user convenience, it doesn't show much progress.

And the developer officially announced the end of development. Damn it.

Coge el concepto de Majesty y súmale las opciones de construcción de Minecraft y tendrás una idea de lo que es Towns. Aunque ahora es disfrutable perfectamente, aún tiene que salir una gran cantidad de contenido para que pueda ser explotado al 100%. Recomendado.

Edit. Le han dado mucha caña con lo de estar abandonado. Realmente no lo está, los parches salen pero cada muuucho tiempo. Aun así el juego es perfectamente jugable tal como es.

Lo sigo recomendando si te gusta el concepto y lo ves a buen precio.
column9:
Take the concept of Majesty and add the building options of Minecraft, and you'll have an idea of ​​what Towns is all about. While it's perfectly enjoyable now, there's still a lot of content to be released before it can be fully exploited. Recommended.

Edit: They've been giving it a lot of heat about being abandoned. It's not really abandoned; patches come out, but they're very infrequent. Still, the game is perfectly playable as is.

I still recommend it if you like the concept and find it at a good price.

這應該是BETA丟出來的吧....
雖說有MC般的世界...但是說到底也是模擬市民類型的東西

遊戲BUG不少...雖說推薦買這款GAME...
可是還是特價5元在買好了

超過5元去他們官網玩試玩版就好了
-------------------
經過改版
這次的狀態好很多了
AI不再這麼蠢，畫面也提升許多
儘管音效還是一樣差.但是遊戲性一下子提高了許多
如果說之前的推薦是5元的話.那這次改版的價值直接超過5美金，直接提升到10-15美金

如果對模擬城市、對矮人要塞有興趣，這款初階版本的矮人要塞
絕對會適合你的胃口，不會太硬派
column9:
This must have been released in the beta...

Although it has a MC-like world...it's still a Sims-style game.

The game has quite a few bugs...While I recommend buying it...it's still on sale for 5 yuan.

If you spend more than 5 yuan, go to their official website to play the trial version.
-------------------
After the revision, it's much better. The AI ​​is no longer so stupid, and the graphics are much improved. Although the sound effects are still as bad, the gameplay has been greatly improved. If the previous recommendation was 5 yuan, then this revision has increased its value by more than 5 yuan, directly to 10-15 US dollars.

If you're interested in SimCity and Dwarf Fortress, this entry-level version of Dwarf Fortress will definitely suit your taste. It's not too hardcore.

column8:
I like this game, but I don't enjoy it as much as I should. It feels incomplete. The tutorials can be done in 5 seconds where it seems pointless to do them and the tutorials don't cover enough. Some pre made towns would be awesome. A news ticker would be great. A lot of this game is tranquil waiting. You send your townies to do something and it starts off being quick, but as the town gets bigger it can take them hours to build a set of small homes. Its a game you can watch TV and come back to while it plays.

Oh and to top it off.... I've played one single game around 60 hours and NEVER EVER had any town that looks like the screenshots. NEVER EVER. I might not ever in fact. That's just how the game is. I often have the game playing in the background on another computer virtually unattended.

column8:
{{{{this is a review guied bit you can say}}}}

well towns is a beta alpha (when i wrote this)  it is very muchly buggy and glitchy and annoying at times but so was minecraft back in its baby years (least as i heard and not alot to do i figure this be like minecraft buggy glitchy and get fixed as it goes and may raise in price!)

now its not a bad game imo worth the 10-20 dollars (us) 

it alsohas alot of mods to make it more interesting kinda like minecraft only you dont controll the players and there kinda stupid at times do not get this game if your looking for an alternative minecraft get terraria its closest i found! but  this game is a  fun build type game my advice try demo first to see if this be what you want do tutorial and a map its 20 in game day demo!!

its fun but very challenging and i mean very cause the ai doesnt always make the propper link to make food so you will end up having your peoples starve to death ALOT (grain->flour->bread they dont do this less there hungery! and no fruits)

now my advice is take all the tutorials then! start the normal map (easiest to do imo)
then look for 1 thing on the map away from the jungle
iron (it b a orange colouring on the map)
find iron! so you can make a anvile and a smelter and a stove (also butcher and kitchen table but iron not needed for these and a cow and pig farm advice best meat in game)
with those items you can cook all the meat you want and spare a 2x2 iron least one more be better for a mine shaft (2x2= 2 by 2 dont know what thsi means its simple 2 above and 2 below 2 by 2)
then once you got your stove(s) {i have 4 of almost all utilitys} going adventure out find coal for your mining shafts to automatically get free iron with out destroying it wonderful! 
then find a 2x2 coal and put a shaft on it! prob best to do it first then a iron then a coal then the other irons
then after this point when you get ALOT of extra food so much you ready 2 toss alot out... make your tavern for heros to come by and oh make sure if  you make a ladder down to the dungeon to wall the entrance off in some way to prevent monsters

duly note this you WILL restart alot of times even if you dont hunt for irons i find it very diffcult at first but when you get used to the game its easy and to regain villagers let them idle around makes them happy! and ahve spare personal zones beds and stuff
(ive not gotten that far in my game)

with those items you can cook all the meat you want and spare a 2x2 iron least one more be better for a mine shaft (2x2= 2 by 2 dont know what thsi means its simple 2 above and 2 below 2 by 2)
then once you got your stove(s) {i have 4 of almost all utilitys} going adventure out find coal for your mining shafts to automatically get free iron with out destroying it wonderful! 
then find a 2x2 coal and put a shaft on it! prob best to do it first then a iron then a coal then the other irons
then after this point when you get ALOT of extra food so much you ready 2 toss alot out... make your tavern for heros to come by and oh make sure if  you make a ladder down to the dungeon to wall the entrance off in some way to prevent monsters

duly note this you WILL restart alot of times even if you dont hunt for irons i find it very diffcult at first but when you get used to the game its easy and to regain villagers let them idle around makes them happy! and ahve spare personal zones beds and stuff
(ive not gotten that far in my game)

column8:
This game is great if you are a fan of progession and long-term building strategy. However it does have afew things that will constnatly piss you off. For example, the AI will try to automatically collect stuff even if it will get them killed, so you can get through 6 hours of play, then lose all of your people 1 by 1 as they spend 10 minutes each trying to run through a labyrinth of badguys to reach a piece of stone at the bottom of some dungeon. 

Still, generally good fun.

column8:
The first and only game that I've ever removed from my Steam library.

It was a promising city builder with many layers to managing your city to prosperity, but issues arose in the news regarding updates very frequently. Despite being voted for in Steam Greenlight as well as the support it received in general, the updates posted by the developers nearing the end of this game's development were more-or-less telling us that they got tired of working on the game.

Eventually the news reached the point where the developers were basically arguing on who was going to continue the development before announcing that they were stopping as a whole. After that, someone else said that they would work on the game and no news has been heard of since. This game is nearly 6 years old now and nothing has changed.

column8:
You can use anything you get in the game!  Similar to Minecraft BUT has its own original values.

Key Features:
*Grow crops, tend to animals, the list goes on the task to survive.
*Similar to Stonrghold (the Castle Sim that started it all) EXCEPT no preset buildings meaning you get to decide how you want everything to look acordingly to your pigment of imagination!
*SIEGES!  But you can control the difficulty level if you are only looking to create.
*RPG elements!  Heroes comes to your village/castle/whatever you want (after meeting requirements) which they can level upby fighting the monsters lingering the deeper you go underground.
*No multiplayer but that being said increases your will to push harder in able to let your villagers survive with no help from anyone.
*CONSTANTLY GROWING!  A whole active community is always around the corner regarding Mods, ideas, discussions, and much more.
*Nostalgic graphics and easy to understand and play.
*AND MUCH MORE!

More info on www.townsgame.com

column8:
Kind of like a poor mans Dwarf Fortress... Even though Dwarf Fortress is free... this game feels like a less indepth version of Dwarf Fortress. That said.... DW is hard! Almost game breaking hard and difficult to understand most of the time. 

Towns is more current gen... eaiser and has some differnt mechanics. It's hard to say which of the two is better. And it's even hard to compare them. Towns is worth the pickup if you like this style of game play. I have not played enough of it yet to fall in love. But that might happen in the near future. One thing for sure it needs upgrades or updates badly. It's not like it feels incomplete but it certainly is not at the point were I think it needs no extra work. They say they plan on updatng it as an ongoing thing. And it sure needs it.  I like the game for what I have played. 

If it keeps getting updated I am sure it will reach the point were I can suggest it to everyone! For now I suggest it to those who look at the pictures, watch videos of the game play and think themselfs.... looks fun!  Those people should get this game. Also if you like DW this is worth checking out.

column8:
Towns（城鎮）是個模擬經營遊戲，在荒蕪的一方土地上，領導著移民（鎮民）們建立家園、農耕畜牧、挖礦鑄造、組備軍隊保護鎮民、招募英雄探索地下城。喜歡工人物語（The Settlers）或是矮人要塞（Dwarf Fortress）的玩家應該會喜歡這款，Towns是基於矮人要塞的概念上所研發（類似DF的遊戲還有Gnomoria，該遊戲也是基於DF來開發的圖形遊戲，與Towns相比更接近DF），但Towns更圖形化以及簡單（相對於DF），同時此遊戲也與偏重軍事戰略的工人物語有所不同，著重於城鎮經營維持與地下城探索（某方面算是另外一種概念類型的RPG）。我個人當初是迷上了工人物語在城鎮經營的部份，但工人物語越來越走向戰略遊戲，對此我感到小小的不滿與失望...幸好還有DF這類遊戲～

其餘介紹與攻略請見個人BLOG：http://loni6912.blogspot.com
column9:
Towns is a business simulation game. In a desolate landscape, you lead settlers (townspeople) to build homes, farm and raise livestock, mine, forge, raise armies to protect them, and recruit heroes to explore dungeons. Fans of The Settlers or Dwarf Fortress will likely enjoy this game. Towns is based on the concept of Dwarf Fortress (a similar game to Dwarf Fortress is Gnomoria, a graphical game based on Dwarf Fortress that's closer to Dwarf Fortress than Towns). However, Towns is more graphically simplistic (compared to Dwarf Fortress). Unlike The Settlers, which focuses on military strategy, Towns emphasizes town management and dungeon exploration (in a sense, it's a different kind of RPG). I was initially drawn to the town management aspect of The Settlers, but I've become a little dissatisfied and disappointed with its shift towards strategy. Fortunately, games like Dwarf Fortress still exist.

For more information and strategy guides, please visit my blog: http://loni6912.blogspot.com

column8: Despite almost nothing but horrible reviews, I found myself quite liking this game. Never played Dwarf Fortress, so I'm one of the few who can't really compare this to that. To me, it's like a mashup of Minecraft and Majesty. There's definitely room for improvement, but the developers are saying this is still technically only an alpha build of the game, so if they don't drag their feet and actually listen to feedback from their community, this game could one day go from being a fun little time waster to a truly great game in it's own right. For what it's worth, this is what had it's hooks in my almost nonstop until XCOM Enemy Unknown entered my stable. And then THAT one blasted everything else, including Guild Wars 2, right outta the water. lol

column8:
Najpierw spodobało mnie się założenie "Nie biegaj bohaterem po podziemiach, zamiast tego zadbaj o ich potrzeby budując miasto u wejścia do lochów!" - CZAD !! Coś prawie jak odwrotność Dungeon Keeper ? Kupuję przecenione, instaluję, odpalam - CO ZA SHIT !! Toporny interfejs, grafika z gatunku Indie, ale przez bardzo małe "i". Klikam, klikam tutoriale. Troszke coś nie tego, można by popracować nad opisem co, gdzie, jak zrobić. Odpalam pierwszą samodzielną grę. Gram, biją mnie, ludzie padają z głodu, warstwy przeskakują. No nic nie da się grać ! 
Nazajutrz - Dam jeszcze jedną szansę. Odpalam, gram, rozumiem, przyzwyczajam się. Wyłączam po paru godzinach nieprzerwanej rozgrywki - Zakochany w tej grze. Połączenie pierwszych SimCity i MInecraft , mam nadzieję że twórcy będą ciągle ją rozbudowywać bo gra ma wielki potencjał. Dobra kończe pisać moją mała recenzję, bo muszę rozbudować szpital...
column9:
At first, I liked the premise: "Don't run your hero through dungeons, instead, take care of their needs by building a city at the dungeon entrance!" - AWESOME!! Almost like the reverse of Dungeon Keeper? I buy it on sale, install it, and launch it - WHAT A SHIT!! Clunky interface, indie graphics, but with a very small "i." I click and click through tutorials. A bit off, the descriptions of what, where, and how to do things could be improved. I launch my first standalone game. I play, I get beaten, people starve, layers skip. Nothing is playable!
The next day - I'll give it another try. I launch it, I play, I understand, I get used to it. I turn it off after a few hours of uninterrupted gameplay - I'm in love with this game. A mix of the first SimCity and Minecraft. I hope the developers will keep expanding it because the game has great potential. Okay, I'm finishing writing my little review because I have to expand the hospital...

column8:
It's Dwarf Fortress with visuals.  If you're into DF, including the arcane rules and experimentation required to learn how to do things, then Towns is awesome.  I lost my first game because the forlorn spirits of slain townsfolk rose from their dismembered corpses and slaughtered all that remained.  It was epic.  

If you're willing to put in the time to learn how to play, it's really fun.  Also the bone seller being an actual skeleton on a bone tricycle was hi-larious.

I'll tell you what I think when this game is a game. Right now it seems to be pre-alpha; the tutorial isn't done with step 1 yet. I literally can't complete tutorial step 1. I have unwittingly paid money for a pre-alpha, and cannot tell you what I think (and not just because I'm unspeakably angry for being tricked into buying a not-product). So ask again in early 2013, because in late 2012, this is not a video game. This is a video game like Romney is president. Could happen someday. Not today. Tomorrow's not looking good.

0.2/10  Fantastic concept.  Would like to see more.  "We never said it was a finished product" = absolute copout and ripoff.  They knew Steam users expect the games they purchase to be . . . um . . . finished games and not concept art?

column8:
街づくりゲーを思わせて最序盤のサバイバルゲームっぷりが半端なくて素晴らしい。最初の数時間は糞ゲーだ。まず間違いないだろう。そのためプレイ時間5時間未満の不評価は当てにしてはいけない。このゲームで一番の敵はクソわかりにくくやる気が削がれるチュートリアルだ。しかし最低限こなさないとゲームがわからないとくる。しかも全てを教えてくれるわけではない。あくまで最低限である。まずは何回もやり直すことになるだろう。住民が餓死し、モンスターにやられ、時には最初に切ろうとした木がモンスターでいきなり数人死んでリセットということはよくある話しだ。しかも何もわからないと一向に住民が増えない。住民の増やし方はチュートリアルで教えてくれないからな。なんてファッキンで理不尽でクソッタレなゲームだろうか。しかしそれをありあまる謎の魅力がある。ある、確かにあるのだ。もしあなたが購入を迷ってるとしたら、合わなかったとしても「なんだこの糞ゲーは！」と笑いながら後悔するつもりで楽しんで欲しい。そしたら楽しくなってくるから。本当だ。
　まあしかし真面目に遊ぶならwikiとか動画を探して見るんだ。それが最も手っ取り早いだろう。
column9: The survival game-like opening is incredibly amazing, reminiscent of a city-building game. The first few hours are crap. That's almost certainly true. So don't count on negative reviews from players with less than five hours of playtime. This game's biggest enemy is the tutorial, which is incredibly confusing and demotivating. But you won't understand the game unless you complete the bare minimum. And it doesn't teach you everything. It's the bare minimum. You'll probably have to restart countless times. Villagers starve to death, get killed by monsters, and sometimes the first tree you try to cut down is attacked by a monster, killing several people and forcing you to reset. And if you don't know anything, your population never increases. The tutorial doesn't teach you how to increase the population. What a fucking, unreasonable, shitty game. But it has a mysterious charm that overflows with it. It's there, absolutely. If you're hesitating to buy it, even if it doesn't suit you, I want you to enjoy it, knowing that you'll regret it and laugh, saying, "What a crappy game!" Then it gets fun. Seriously. But if you're serious about playing, look up a wiki or watch videos. That would be the quickest way.

column8:
UI/design isn't as sexy as other design disciplines but it can really set (or unset) the tone for how a user perceives the game. Towns reminded me how much of an impact UI/menu makes and it screams this game is NOT READY in its current state as of 11-14-2012.

The game Towns has LOTS of potential and I look forward to seeing it get polished in future iterations. :)

column8: This game is a mixed bag. On the one hand, you get a deep sims style simulation with a dungeoun. On the other doo-doo hand, you have an overcomplex simulation with no instructions on how to do things. I am smart enough that I grasped the dynamic, but once I had my town running I had to deal with spiders spawning inside my town. This made me unhappy. This is well done for someone slamming some java code together. Well done, but developer, try instructions and possibly a narrative. This would help your game significantly. C+

column8:
Really fun town building and sim city/dwarf fortress type game. It's pretty complicated to learn how to play at first though and it may be confusing with the different height levels and stuff but once you learn how to do everything it's really fun.

Once you have a little village built you have to train some soldiers to preotect your villages and craft armor for them as well as keeping a food supply for your village, you can do things like surround your village with a water stream, set traps, get raided by random events, mine underground and find dungeons with mobs to kill and pretty much make your town as decorative as possible making your villages happy which makes new immigrants join your town.

Really fun game after I learnt how to play but as the game is still in development there is a few bugs such as stairs do not know which way they should be rotated if there is two walls next to it as well as it currently not being possible to rotate things such as furnature, but I expect these to be added soon! I rate it 9/10 really fun game which I have been addicted to playing.

column8:
The game is still VERY alpha. Calling it a finished product is incredibly dishonest. Nowhere on the game's store page does it inform you that development is not finished. I paid the same amount for Minecraft when it was still in beta and it was more complete than this. Terraria equally I bought for $5 and it was a better finished product than this.

Avoid this game until they finish it, if they get around to it. Download the free demo from their website if you really want to see if you like it, but I can't honestly say this is worth even the initial sale price of $12 in its buggy, incomplete and VERY alpha state.

Check back in a few months and see if the devs are still releasing updates or if they just take the cash and run. Also, the game forums are full of major league douches. Caveat emptor.

column8: An awesome mixture of Minecraft, SimCity and roleplaying scheme! Start from pretty much nothing, command your people to harvest wood, gather apples, grow wheat and afterwards bake a bread out of it. Crafting is as necessary part of this game as it is in Minecraft. In addition to this, you should really take it as a serious matter to equip swords and armor to some of your townsfolk, because if you face a vicious tree, a ghost, a spider or anything between them, you're pretty much dead. By setting your military men to patrol around your village when building it towards to the greatest empire on earth, you should feel pretty safe! An awesome title with a little learning curve, but when you get a hang of it, you wont stop advancing further and further!

column8:
Not the most original of concepts, but definitely a fantastic implementation. Imagine Kairosoft's Dungeon Village had an affair with Terraria, which resulted in the spawn of this isometric wonderland of hardcore strategy and micromanaged world-building. If Towns ever goes multiplayer, it will change how we view multiplayer world-builders like Minecraft.

The only downside to this game is that it's java and thus runs in JRE. Here I thought Minecraft was an example of why you SHOULDN'T make your 3D game entirely in Java, but this lesson was clearly not taken to heart by Canal and Palgi. 7/10.

Towns is still in development (currently v80a) and has minor performance issues, but it's still worth the money.

column8: Not bad - not worth 12 bucks yet though.  Needs a lot of work. UI is painful to use.  AI is nearly non-existent.  It seems to work fine at first, but the more complex the town becomes the stupider the AI gets.  This is kind of "The Sims" meets "Minecraft".  Hopefully the devs. keep working on it and make this into a GOOD game, not just a mediocre one.  I have my doubts that it'll ever be great, but here's hoping.
